fields.headline: Hussain wary of stage fright
fields.trailText: When Nasser Hussain, the England captain, asked his players to "show some bottle" against Pakistan in the first one-day international here today he was clearly being irresponsible.
fields.body:
When Nasser Hussain, the England captain, asked his players to "show some bottle" against Pakistan in the first one-day international here today he was clearly being irresponsible.

Such bravado could have one flung in chokey for a decent stretch in these parts. If you are prepared to sign a form, owning up to alcoholism, you are allowed to drink beer while sitting miserably on your bed; the brass-tipped pump and the barmaid's pinny are but a memory.

If you are braver, and you know a local bootlegger, some suggest you take your ill- gotten hooch to one or two restaurants where they will exchange a knowing smile and serve it up in a teapot. But it is a risky business. Showing bottle is absolutely out of the question.

Despite a tendency to drop an unfortunate metaphor, Hussain speaks better than any England captain this side of Tony Greig. He is better than Greig too and, as he looked forward to today's match under lights at the National stadium, there was a whiff of Henry V about Hussain's battle cry.

"There will be one hell of a noise," he said. "It does make you feel uncomfortable, there is no other way of putting it. You can feel lovely in your air-conditioned room but out there in the middle, or fielding on the boundary, it is a completely different atmosphere.

"Our boys will have to have some bottle about them. It can lift individuals but it all depends on the individual. I can't see Darren Gough worrying about it too much; he will rise to the occasion.

"I can mention the noise to the boys and tell them to keep looking at me for things, but this is where they have to look within themselves and ask where would they rather be: in front of 20 people at Derby or here?

"This is what we play for. There is nothing better than this. This is the highest level, the highest crowd, the highest pressure, the highest heat, against one of the best sides in the world . . . this is where I want to test myself.

"You can either go this way or the other way and say, 'I would rather be back in my hotel room'. That is what we will find out in the course of these three matches."

Ten of the England players - six batsmen and four seam bowlers - picked themselves. The remaining place is likely to go to Ashley Giles, replacing Paul Grayson in the side heavily beaten by South Africa in the recent ICC Knockout Trophy in Kenya.

Strangely for one so shrewd, Hussain retains his Nelsonian eye about his own best position; he will continue to bat at No3. "Trescothick has come in and taken his chance," he said.

"I don't think anyone has taken to international cricket for England like he has for a long time, and Nick Knight and I have to say good luck to the lad. The way he has played has been quite exceptional."

Hussain is right about Trescothick and the Somerset left-hander should clearly be left alone. But Hussain, who admits he does not have the power or range of strokes of his team-mates, gets in the way. The obvious solution would be for him to open with Trescothick and for Alec Stewart to move down to the middle order. But for now, at least, Hussain cannot see it.

More sensibly, he has not allowed his head to be turned by familiar stories of Pakistan disunity. "I think we've been hearing such stories for about 70 years. But they will rock up on the day - they have been waiting for this for 13 years. So when it comes to my team talk I'm not going to bother to mention trouble in their camp.

"For raw talent they are very impressive, and they are a multi-dimensional side. But they are unpredictable and under pressure at home. We must stay in the game. If we release the pressure on them, they will show all their skills. We must take it to the wire and the crowd might get on their backs."

If Hussain does not make it work at three, he will be doing a few piggy-backs of his own.

England (probable): Trescothick, Stewart, Hussain, Hick, Thorpe, Flintoff, White, Ealham, Giles, Caddick, Gough.

Pakistan (from): Saeed Anwar, Salim Elahi, Inzamam-ul-Haq, Yousuf Youhana, Shahid Afridi, Moin Khan (capt & wkt), Abdur Razzaq, Azhar Mahmood, Wasim Akram, Saqlain Mushtaq, Mushtaq Ahmed, Waqar Younis.

Umpires: Riazuddin and Saleem Badar.

TV: Live today on Sky Sports 2 from 10.15am; highlights tonight on Channel 4 from 12.10am

webTitle: World music review: Lama Gyurme/ Rykiel

fields.headline: Lama Gyurme/ Rykiel
fields.standfirst:
Adelaide, Glasgow
****
fields.trailText:
Adelaide, Glasgow
****
fields.body:
Glasgow's Friday night pubbers and clubbers probably had little clue that, inside an old church on Bath Street, they were missing the first UK concert by the latest, and unlikeliest, European club sensation. Implausible though it may seem, the musical duo that has topped various European charts and represents the ultimate chill-out music for thousands of frazzled dancers at raves across France, are an exiled Bhutanese Buddhist monk, Lama Gyurme, and a blind, French classical pianist, Jean-Philippe Rykiel.

In Glasgow as part of Billy Kelly's fifth far-reaching Big Big World festival, Lama Gyurme (officially a Tibetan master of music in Bhutan) sits in the lotus position, resplendent in saffron robes, near the altar of the spartan church that now forms part of a multi-purpose venue/cafe/ guesthouse. Eyes closed, he expels unfeasibly extended notes of Tibetan prayer song, with Rykiel adding the ambient synth wash and keyboard chimes that have propelled European post-ravers into a relaxed Nirvana and the duo's album, Rain of Blessings: Vajra Chants, into the charts.

Gyurme's voice produces a kind of sonic hypnosis: his low-level growl, akin to the amazing Tuvan throatsingers, ricochets off the church walls in a continuous undulating wave. Only an off-microphone cough between 10-minute incantations indicates that Gyurme has had to breathe at all. Rykiel, who met Gyurme in his French monastery-in-exile after composing and arranging for Youssou N'Dour and Papa Wemba, injects sometimes superfluous aural garlands of birdsong and bell samples along with pattering keyboard trills. The overall sound veers dangerously close to Enya's elevator-ambient territory, until Rykiel unexpectedly breaks into sprightly semi-jazz breaks reminiscent of Herbie Hancock in electronic mode.

But this was a quintessential Big Big World event, introducing genuinely inspirational artists to a surprisingly packed Glaswegian venue. Gyurme's low, resonant song chants were a wonder of control, waves of earthy yet spiritual sound, and one of the last songs, or mantras, sounded curiously like an ancient Scottish lament coming from somewhere we have never encountered yet recognisable as a universal music from the soul. Like the motionless Gyurme himself, as majestic and calming as a still loch.

fields.headline: Ixion Ensemble
fields.standfirst:
Warehouse, London
****
fields.trailText:
Warehouse, London
****
fields.body:
Extraordinary things happen to the perception of time during performances of Morton Feldman's music. His slow, quiet, long compositions suggest a listening experience of epic endurance and stamina. Crippled Symmetry, written four years before his death in 1983, clocks in at around 90 minutes; his String Quartet II can take more than five hours.

Crippled Symmetry was performed as part of the Cutting Edge series by a trio drawn from the Ixion Ensemble - Michael Finnissy on piano and celeste, flautist Roland Sutherland and percussionist David Price. Instead of inducing exhaustion, their performance created a state of preternatural calm, and passed much more quickly than its gigantic clock time implies.

Feldman's music fills time in a unique way. The reductiveness of dynamics and tempo in Crippled Symmetry suggests an aesthetic related to that of minimalists such as Steve Reich and Philip Glass. However, Feldman's harmonic language and rhythmic sense are much more chromatic and elaborate than that of those composers. There is repetition in Crippled Symmetry, such as a fractured loop made from the flute player's opening fragments of melody, but the texture as a whole is ceaselessly changing and the music is impossible to predict. The only option as a listener is to cast oneself adrift in the music's sea of warped patterns - like being trapped in the benign machinations of an endlessly proliferating fractal equation.

Later in the evening, Ixion presented three world premieres. Pianist Stephen Gutman's pyrotechnical virtuosity gave Geoff Hannan's Joyrider the best possible first performance. But the music's monomaniacal focus on grand, pianistic cliches palled before the end of the piece. Joe Cutler's Five Mobiles after Alexander Calder, for a trio of piano, clarinet and violin, were by turns strident and delicate. But Bryn Harrison's Ground for ensemble was the most notable debut: a tapestry of swoops and slides that owed a passing debt to Feldman.

The music of Michael Finnissy, who conducted Ixion throughout, was represented by Traum des Sängers, a polyglot creation of superimposed tonalities. Where Morgan Hayes's piano works, Flaking Yellow Stucco and Le Lardon, were elegantly explosive in Gutman's performances, Gerald Barry's Triorchic Blues for solo violin was a barrage of rhythmic invention, expertly projected by Charles Mutter.

fields.headline: Harry Hill and his fiery ants
fields.standfirst:
Palace, London
***
fields.trailText:
Palace, London
***
fields.body:
It is always interesting to watch a performer when you know they're at a crucial moment in their careers, when everything may be about to go pear-shaped. Harry Hill, after what must have been a lifetime high-point appearance as Morrissey on Matthew Kelly's Celebrity Stars in their Eyes, now faces such a moment. A question mark hangs over his television show, and his advertisements for a range of mobile phones are jaw-droppingly unfunny. If you're a comedian, not being funny is a bad thing.

Through some of the websites set up to trumpet his genius, Harry has told the fans that he doesn't care if the TV show stops because television doesn't pay very well, and he prefers doing stand-up. And as he springs on to the Palace stage, dressed as Morrissey once again, and shoots us "leddies and gennelmen" straight into a liddel musical medley, he doesn't seem to be sweating it at all.

Hill specialises in a fairly gentle, very English type of entertainment. There's no plan to overthrow the evil political dictatorship (aka Tony Blair), no plan to advance the frontiers of comedy (see The League of Gentlemen), and no bid for domination of the entertainment universe (Ben Elton, perhaps?). Instead, there are mild ribbings of the audience: from the safety of his own hairless head, he greets a baldie in the audience: "You just noticed it was taking longer and longer to wash your face, right?"

There are odd verbal and physical tics that longtime fans will recognise, but which can be slightly bewildering to the Hill-novice - why does he want to stroke a pony? Why are badgers excluded from the theatre? And there are straight jokes, told with a drumroll - ba-dum - to accompany the punchline. We could be down the end of the pier.

But Harry has achieved such fame because sometimes, after five minutes of jokes that have made you smile but not much else, he will shoot out a jewel of humour that gets that wonderful reflex laugh from the entire audience. "Have you ever noticed, when looking at ants through a magnifying glass on a hot sunny day, how often they spontaneously burst into flame?" Ba-dum (thanks to his back up band, the Caterers) - we all rock backwards in our seats. One man along the row is crying into his hands (there is something about Harry Hill that particularly seems to make men laugh). And as long as he keeps coming up with them, he'll probably be all right. When a comedian is funny, that is, obviously, a good thing.

At the Congress, Eastbourne (01323 412000), tomorrow, then touring.

fields.headline: Scottish Dance Theatre
fields.standfirst:
Riley Theatre, Leeds
****
fields.trailText:
Riley Theatre, Leeds
****
fields.body:
She stands on one leg, perched on a brick like a contorted heron. Two bricks balance on her back and there's another rammed between her legs. Dancer Davina Givan stoically bears the burdens of abused womanhood in She Is as He Eats, a surreal but strong look at relationships from Belgian choreographer Jan De Schynkel. No Highland Flings here. Instead this sharp young company offer a selection of inventive, beautifully danced works with a European feel.

De Schynkel used to be with Nederlands Dans Theater 2 and it shows. His work has that visually compelling NDT feel and here he puts couples under the microscope with strange images and bizarre actions that trigger strong messages. The dancers appear on white cloth, stretched across the stage as if bungee-jumping horizontally. Givan dangles at the end of her tether while another couple entwine in bliss, hands hovering all over their bodies. The six are bound by the constraints of modern togetherness, but some eventually break free.

An imposing figure with elegant control, Errol White places bricks in neat lines. Are they the building blocks or stumbling blocks of life? Givan, browbeaten by her partner, seemingly gives birth to a brood of bricks. She builds up her family, only to see the foundations destroyed. In a poignant display she protects them like vulnerable infants.

Very different, Yael Flexer's new piece, Undone, is a quirky, engaging mix of martial arts and playground games. The five dancers stand in the corners of the stage with fixed grins as if embarrassed to step out, eventually breaking into uneasy action. Half the cast trained at the Northern School of Contemporary Dance in Leeds and graduate Givan makes a good advert, dancing with great expression. She ventures into the square archly, eyes wide with amazement, and ends her off-kilter solo thrusting her pelvis out over the edge of the stage.

The piece teems with action and duels burst out as the performers try to outdo each other with slicing legs mirroring bouts of Tae Kwon Do. Danced in silence, until Nye Parry's score gradually kicks in, the choreography is full of whiplash moves. With their cropped heads and baggy grey garb the men look like Buddhist monks. They lift each other in spectacular fashion and suddenly the game's over. What's been done is undone.

webTitle: Business: Housing market starts to stabilise

fields.headline: Housing market starts to stabilise
fields.trailText: Britain's housing market is showing signs of stabilising after several months of slowdown, say new figures today.
fields.body:
Britain's housing market is showing signs of stabilising after several months of slowdown, say new figures today.

Property values are still falling in the south-east, however, resulting in a narrowing of the north-south price divide, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors in its latest survey for the three months to September 30.

Nationally, during September, 6% more estate agents reported falling prices than rising prices, the same figure as in August. This is the first time since January that the pace of price inflation has not deteriorated from the previous month, said the RICS.

"This month's survey confirms the continued stabilisation of the market. This is expected to continue into the new year," said its housing market spokesman Ian Perry.

In the south-east, the number of estate agents reporting falling prices rose sharply last month - to 54% from 44% in August.

This compares with 5% in April this year. The predictions for the south-east in the coming months are bleak, according to the report: "The outlook for prices is still negative and surveyors forecast price drops over the next three months." But London is bucking the trend - there, 14% of agents reported rising prices, up from 9% in August.

London aside, the north-south divide in prices remains but the gap has narrowed, with more estate agents in the north of England, Yorkshire and Humberside, the north-west and Wales reporting price rises than falls, whereas in the south-west, east and west Midlands, and East Anglia, the trend for prices was predominantly downwards.

"Demand is, however, still lacklustre with the number of new enquiries by potential buyers still falling, reflecting the fact that first-time buyers are reluctant to pay high prices," states the report.

fields.headline: BBC Symphony Orchestra's birthday bash
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText:
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
The BBC Symphony Orchestra gave its first concert on October 22, 1930 in London's Queen's Hall; Adrian Boult conducted, and the programme included Ravel's Daphnis and Chloe. The Queen's Hall, at the northern end of Regent Street, is long gone - it was destroyed by German bombs in May 1941 - but the BBCSO is still very much with us. On Sunday it celebrated its 70th birthday in typical fashion, with two new works commissioned specially for the occasion, by Simon Bainbridge and Mark-Anthony Turnage; it also brought its Chorus to the party for Prokofiev's cantata Alexander Nevsky, in which Michelle DeYoung was the mezzo soloist. The concert was also Leonard Slatkin's first as the orchestra's chief conductor.

It was the BBCSO that premiered Bainbridge's best known work, Ad Ora Incerta (1993), the settings of Primo Levi for which he won the Grawemeyer Award four years later. His new birthday tribute is very different from that grave and searching cycle. The five minutes of Scherzi seem very consciously designed as a teasing concert-opener, an overture that has little time to build up a real head of steam before it is all over. fields.headline: The shambolically serious Coldplay
fields.standfirst:
Shepherds Bush Empire, London
****
fields.trailText:
Shepherds Bush Empire, London
****
fields.body:
The way things are going, Coldplay aren't going to be appearing at venues as small as this for much longer. Still, it is a measure of the startling speed of their rise that there's still an endearingly shambolic quality about them. For half an hour, the crowd were thrilled by the sight of roadies wandering listlessly around the empty stage; finally someone managed to play the introductory tape of Ennio Morricone's music from Once Upon a Time in the West. The band strolled onstage, plugged in and negotiated their way safely through Spies. But when frontman Chris Martin then sauntered over to his electronic piano to sing Trouble, the evening screeched to a halt. The instrument refused to emit any sound, even when Martin banged his head on the keys. They hastily rejigged the set-list, an apologetic Martin returning to his acoustic guitar while technicians crawled around in the wiring.

Despite it all, Coldplay possess an elusive but unmistakable allure, and not only to the sizeable female contingent in the audience. While their album, Parachutes, radiates inward-looking aloofness, their live performance introduces some much-needed personal warmth, almost exclusively from Martin. Geezerish and remarkably chirpy for a man who sings such lugubrious songs, Martin banters matily with people in the front rows like a rockin' Jamie Oliver, and hams up his frontman role by making melodramatic dashes into the crowd to let people grab at his clothes and adore him.

But when the music starts, the going gets serious. Sometimes lampooned as a baby Radiohead or as "Jeff Buckley-lite" (presumably on the strength of the vaguely Buckleyish tune, Shiver), Coldplay's moochy, autumnal songs hover perilously close to the student/bedsit bracket, but the band consistently lift their material with cunning arrangements and purposeful musicianship. Their best songs have a distinctive colour that sticks in the mind, whether it's the keening, trebly guitar that Jon Buckland sends gliding above Don't Panic, Martin's stately piano figure in Trouble, or Guy Berryman's bassline in Sparks. Almost everywhere, Will Champion's restless, hustling drum patterns give the music an urgency that its slow tempos and melancholy melodies might otherwise lack.

Although they lobbed a couple of new songs into the mix, including the string-synth-powered In My Place, the Coldplay repertoire is still fairly narrow, and the big question is which way they will jump next. Yellow, needless to say, was the crowd-pleasing highlight of the evening. A couple more like that could find the foursome leaping up the US pop chart.

fields.headline: The Three Birds
fields.standfirst:
Gate, London
****
fields.trailText:
Gate, London
****
fields.body:
This is 95 minutes that will leave you speechless. Not quite in the same way as poor Philomela, her voice silenced by the brother-in-law who rapes her and rips out her tongue so that she cannot tell of his crimes. No: what renders you silent in Joanna Laurens's impressive debut is the audacity of the language, the way she says the unsayable about men and women, love and lust, the pain of being an outsider; the way she tells the tale to its wretched, vengeful, beautiful end without flinching. Afterwards, words have been quite choked out of you.

Laurens's play makes Ted Hughes's Tales From Ovid look whimsical and the Royal Shakespeare Company's recent attempt to stage the story seem hopelessly prissy. She takes her cue from Sophocles's lost play, and makes some adjustments to more familiar versions of the story. Tereus's rape and mutilation of Philomela springs not just from tyranny and lust but from the incoherence of love. He has been made, by the clumsy machinations of Philomela and Procne's father exerting his own warped power, to marry the wrong sister.

"What's in a name?" asks Juliet in Shakespeare's play about love. Tereus - older, wiser - knows that there is much. "Procne. A clumsyknock name to my Philomela. Procne. Your name limps," he says on learning that he must wed and bed her. Laurens offers no excuses here, but in every distorting word she charts the psychological malformations of Tereus's mind. There are other wonderful touches: the intimacy of the sisters is depicted by a shared language that is delicate, joyous, and so private it is almost autistic. When Procne finds herself alone and unloved in Thrace she sounds foreign. Her young son Itys never gets the chance to speak. The weakest is always sacrificed.

Laurens writes with such murderous beauty that you are put in mind of the work of the late Sarah Kane. Here she matches story and language so that the mutations and mutilations of one are always reflected in the other.

There is a stark beauty in Rebecca Gatward's delicately judged production, which transforms the Gate into a tiny amphitheatre. The chorus perch on shelves like an inquisitive flock of birds, beadily watching the story as it rushes towards catastrophe. This is a quiet, emotionally branding piece of theatre, made all the more devastating by amazing performances from Alex McSweeny as Tereus, whose life and line is gutted, and Sharlene Whyte and Syan Blake as the sisters, whose story takes wing and soars.

Until November 4. Box office: 020-7229 0706.

webTitle: Cheaper loans could follow Halifax's re-mortgage lead

fields.headline: Cheaper loans could follow Halifax's re-mortgage lead
fields.trailText: Cheaper mortgages could be around the corner if lenders decide to follow Halifax's lead and let existing customers change mortgages within the company in a bid to stop them re-mortgaging with rival lenders.
fields.body:
Cheaper mortgages could be around the corner if lenders decide to follow Halifax's lead and let existing customers change mortgages within the company in a bid to stop them re-mortgaging with rival lenders.

Concerned about the number of customers it loses every year, the country's biggest mortgage lender hopes that by inviting them to move mortgage within the Halifax group without incurring any penalties, it can stem the losses.

Halifax's 100,000 standard variable rate (SVR) customers will be allowed to transfer to its flexible tracker mortgage without paying any early redemption fees or changing the life of the loan. Such a transfer would save £400 a year on a £60,000 repayment loan.

In a related move, the bank is also writing to a further 200,000 customers a month, outlining Halifax products which could save them money. And of the 1m customers contacted to date, it says around 10% have switched product.

The move comes just days after the council of mortgage lenders announced a significant rise in the level of re-mortgage activity in September. Re-mortgaging was up by almost 7% from £2.9bn in August to an estimated £3.1bn in September. Compared with September last year, the level of re-mortgaging was 35% higher.

A spokesperson for the council said the increase reflects intense competition in the mortgage market which could lead to cheaper mortgages from the outset: "The Halifax decision does suggest cheaper loans might be a sign of things to come, but it's still early days. Everything will depend on how the other lenders react. If they copy Halifax, then mortgages as a whole could become cheaper but, that being said, the market is already very competitive and profit margins are already squeezed to the limit".

The country's other top five lenders, however, were sceptical about Halifax's move, saying it only applied to a fraction of its 2.5m mortgage customers and would have a limited impact on the market as a whole.

Most said they have no intention of offering similar deals because whilst the lower rates may be attractive to Halifax customers, they are higher than some of their and other lender's existing rates.

The latest offer will see customers with SVR mortgages being offered rates of 7.10% for loans under £60,000 and 6.99% for loans above £60,000. But loans with rates of between 5% and 6% are readily available, if customers are willing to pay typical early redemption penalties of between 1% and 5% of the loan's value and arrange for new surveys and valuations on their property.

Halifax is hoping the hassle of moving loan will act as a deterrent, convincing customers to stay with them, but the CML findings suggest home owners don't mind the time and effort or the penalties if, in the long-run, they save money.

Nationwide said that as a building society it is always able to offer cheaper loans with lower charges and penalties and therefore, has no intention of following Halifax. Similarly, Woolwich said it was confident its deals were competitive and saw no reason to change.

But all lenders admitted the market was very competitive, with profit margins being squeezed to the limit. If the level of competition and re-mortgaging continues, they say, and starts causing their customers to defect, rates may well have to start coming down across the market.

webTitle: For one game only: England unveil their dream team

fields.headline: For one game only: England unveil their dream team
fields.standfirst:
 Taylor and McClaren in charge for Italy
 Wenger, Eriksson and Hodgson on the FA shortlist for permanent manager
 Venables left out in the cold
fields.trailText: Nineteen months after losing control of a successful Under-21 team Peter Taylor will pick the England side to play Italy in a friendly in Turin three weeks from now. The 47-year-old Leicester City manager agreed to take on the task last night in the chaos left by Kevin Keegan's sudden resignation following the World Cup defeat by Germany at Wembley a fortnight ago.
fields.body:
Nineteen months after losing control of a successful Under-21 team Peter Taylor will pick the England side to play Italy in a friendly in Turin three weeks from now. The 47-year-old Leicester City manager agreed to take on the task last night in the chaos left by Kevin Keegan's sudden resignation following the World Cup defeat by Germany at Wembley a fortnight ago.

Originally the Football Association's plan was to have Taylor and Steve McClaren, Sir Alex Ferguson's assistant at Manchester United, working under Bobby Robson for as long as it took to find Keegan's full-time successor, but that idea was scuppered on Saturday evening when Newcastle United refused to allow Robson to be approached.

Instead Taylor and the 39-year-old McClaren will take a break from their clubs to look after the Italian job with Brian Kidd, now in charge of youth development at Leeds, running the Under-21s. "Leicester are very happy for me to take charge of England for this one match," Taylor explained, "and it will not affect my work at Filbert Street."

More significantly, in terms of rebuilding England over the next five to 10 years, the FA has already reduced the list of candidates for the job to three and will begin to sound out the choices this week.

Arsenal's Arsène Wenger remains the prime target with Lazio's Swedish coach, Sven Goran Eriksson, not far behind him. The third man could be Roy Hodgson, the Londoner who took Switzerland to the 1994 World Cup, or even Ferguson. The 67-year-old Robson is not being considered.

Adam Crozier, the FA's chief executive, yesterday made it clear that Taylor's caretakership would provide the time necessary to find the right man and it is still the intention to have a new coach signed up by Christmas. Certainly the FA will be disappointed if England find themselves approaching the next game after Italy, a friendly against Spain at Villa Park on February 27, still with nobody in charge on a long-term basis.

"We don't want to have to leave things until the last moment," Crozier stressed. He refused to rule the popular choice, Terry Venables, in or out at this stage but did point out that media hype would play no part in the FA's thinking. "I always go on personal conversations and what people say to you in private," Crozier said. "That is the proper way to do this, not through opinion polls.'

For the moment, then, the task of halting an England decline which began with the failure of Keegan's side in this summer's European Championship and continued with the 1-0 defeat by Germany and soulless, scoreless draw with Finland under the FA's technical director Howard Wilkinson has fallen to two likeable and able coaches whose experience of handling teams at full international level is nil.

To be sure Taylor's three years with the Under-21s, where he learned much from Glenn Hoddle, and McClaren's time with Ferguson at Old Trafford, where he has worked with a number of leading England players, will stand the pair in good stead. Yet the latest appointment is still a matter of make do and mend.

Technical turbulence

To avoid embarrassing speculation both Crozier and Taylor went out of their way to explain that the position of Wilkinson would not be affected by the appointment of the man from whom he took over the Under-21 squad.

"My relationship with Howard is very good," Taylor insisted. "When Glenn left it was natural that the technical director would want to be running the most senior team for which he was responsible, which was the Under-21s. Had I been technical director I would have done the same."

"The position of Howard Wilkinson is unchanged," said Crozier. "He has been fully involved in these appointments and has always believed that the best future for England lies in long-term planning."

Nobody could argue with that but, if the FA cannot get a coach in place before the end of the year, the problem of who is to pick the team not only for the Spain game but the World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania in late March will loom large. Last night Taylor and McClaren made the right noises about their future availability but at that time of the season United and Leicester might be less ready to let them go.

If Taylor appeared a little bemused by his sudden promotion it was understandable. Originally a Southend United player, he won four England caps as a Crystal Palace winger, later moving to Tottenham and Leyton Orient.

As a manager he began at Dover and enjoyed a humdrum period at Southend before Hoddle called him up to take over the England Under-21 squad. It was his success with the juniors which brought him national recognition as an accomplished coach and on returning to management with Gillingham and now Leicester he has continued to thrive.

One effect of having Taylor in charge could see England reverting to a 5-3-2/3-5-2 formation in Turin. "I like 5-3-2, but I also like a back four," Taylor said last night.

But first he will have to see who turns up. At least with a United man as his assistant Taylor will receive first-hand information about aches and strains at Old Trafford.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: The rise and rise of United's No2

fields.headline: The rise and rise of United's No2
fields.trailText: For all the unseemly chaos at Lancaster Gate over the past couple of weeks, at least the Football Association managed to get its lines right yesterday. And for that at least, Steve McClaren should be grateful.
fields.body:
For all the unseemly chaos at Lancaster Gate over the past couple of weeks, at least the Football Association managed to get its lines right yesterday. And for that at least, Steve McClaren should be grateful.

In February last year, when he was being unveiled as Sir Alex Ferguson's No2 at Manchester United, his rise from next to nowhere seemed too much for the chairman Martin Edwards. "Ladies and gentlemen," he said. "It gives me great pleasure to introduce our new assistant manager . . . Steve McClaridge."

Sixty-two Premiership games later, 45 wins and only four defeats, McClaren has managed to chisel his identity into England's premier club while maintaining a low profile.

webTitle: England upbeat as Giles turns the corner

fields.headline: England upbeat as Giles turns the corner
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan A 169-7
England 170-0
England won by 10 wickets
fields.trailText: A breeze is always welcome in the humid heat of the National stadium's concrete amphitheatre and England's cricketers certainly enjoyed one here yesterday.
fields.body:
A breeze is always welcome in the humid heat of the National stadium's concrete amphitheatre and England's cricketers certainly enjoyed one here yesterday.

They beat Pakistan A - which in reality was more like the country's Under-23 side - by 10 wickets with more than 20 overs to spare. The tour gets serious tomorrow when they play Pakistan in the first one-day international but it is difficult to fault the smoothness of their preparation.

In truth Pakistan A were not up to much. But England dismissed them with a pleasing insouciance, as one might flick away a picnic bluebottle.

Even so, they made life as hard for themselves as they could. Nasser Hussain did not toss up but negotiated to field first, giving his bowlers the chance to run in when the sun was out and his batsmen the opportunity to play under the new lights.

Then, as they swaggered towards victory, they opted to retire their batsmen, Marcus Trescothick and Alec Stewart making way to give some batting practice to the others.

It was almost patronising, like playing cricket with one's little sister in the back garden and batting left-handed with one eye shut to make it more interesting. But in the circumstances it made much sense.

Those circumstances make it difficult to trade in superlatives over individual performances but that of Ashley Giles will have pleased him enormously because, rather like Darren Anderton at Spurs, he was becoming the object of alehouse sniggers, more famous for not playing than playing.

Famously Giles has played only five one-day internationals - the last occasion being almost two years ago - despite being picked for 36 squads. He failed to play a single game in South Africa and Zimbabwe last winter and injured his left leg almost as soon as he took the field in Kenya.

His latest setback was diagnosed as a calf injury but it set alarm bells clanging because he has a recent history of achilles problems.

Back in the team yesterday, however, he performed with some distinction, wheeling down nine overs of slow left-arm for figures of three for 34. With the England management beginning to demand that he prove his fitness for the coming Test series, his timing could hardly have been better.

Giles will be up against it here, because Pakistani batsmen - with their dancing feet and wristy aggression - think finger spinners cannot bowl unless, like their own Saqlain Mushtaq, they have something unorthodox to offer,

But Giles said last night: "It just felt great to be back. I know I'm no Saqlain or Muralitharan but I was selected on merit and do feel I have something to offer.

"I was so focused on my own bowling today that I didn't feel the heat or hear the noise. And there has been no reaction from my calf."

Giles is adept at bowling at the "death" - or the end of the innings - in the shorter game although, at this level, the role is more likely to be filled by Darren Gough and Craig White.

The only batsmen yesterday to trouble the England bowlers, of whom Andrew Caddick was the best with three for 15, was Naumanullah, whose 64 came from 88 balls. But Trescothick, who hit three sixes and five fours, played better. England have won the phoney war.

fields.headline: Third Division  Round-up
fields.trailText: A weekend which saw the top four teams play each other panned out much as expected with both Chesterfield and Rochdale winning.
fields.body:
A weekend which saw the top four teams play each other panned out much as expected with both Chesterfield and Rochdale winning.

Chesterfield, now five points clear at the top of the table, took their time over their win however - a Jamie Ingledow goal in stoppage time granting them a narrow victory over third-placed Brighton.

Rochdale found matters slightly easier at Cheltenham. Mark Monington scored twice either side of the break in a match dominated by the away side.

Meanwhile last year's strugglers Leyton Orient suffered a slight setback, held 1-1 by the injury-hit York City. Tommy Taylor's rejuvenated side went into the match on the back of three successive wins but, although Richard Garcia put them ahead after 37 minutes, Neil Tarrant, signed on loan from Aston Villa this week, scored on his debut to even the score.

Thing were considerably more gloomy for Halifax who lost 1-0 at Barnet, their fourth successive defeat to keep them marooned at the bottom of the table, two points adrift of their fellow strugglers Carlisle, who lost 4-2 to Torquay.

fields.headline: Second Division  Round-up
fields.trailText: Wigan made up ground on the top two thanks to a 1-0 win against Port Vale , Andy Liddell scoring the second-half goal which kept them two points ahead of fourth-placed Wycombe, who beat the leaders Walsall 3-1.
fields.body:
Wigan made up ground on the top two thanks to a 1-0 win against Port Vale , Andy Liddell scoring the second-half goal which kept them two points ahead of fourth-placed Wycombe, who beat the leaders Walsall 3-1.

Wycombe's Andy Rammell scored twice in the second half after Michael Simpson had opened the scoring. Darren Wrack replied.

Reading , whose four wins in their previous five games had taken them to second place, crashed 4-0 at Bristol City. Lee Peacock scored two while Scott Murray and Mickey Bell got the others in what was their first home win of the season.

Bury went down 5-2 at home to Bournemouth, for whom James Hayter, with only five previous goals in his career, hit the target four times after Claus Jorgensen had opened the scoring.

Millwall's Neil Harris put his team in front after 20 seconds at Stoke but Peter Thorne soon hit back with two goals in six minutes before Chris Iwelumo, on the bench only as Stefan Thordarson was injured in the warm-up, killed the game as a contest in the last minute. "I was in my suit getting ready to watch the game from the players' lounge," he said. "The goal was a dream."

Cambridge lost 2-0 at Colchester where Steve McGavin got both goals, the second from the spot. The visitors also had Tom Cowan sent off for violent conduct.

Rotherham moved up after their 3-1 win over bottom-of-the-table Oxford, two goals from Paul Warne and one from Kevin Watson rendering Derek Lilley's late goal academic. Luton won for the first time in 11 attempts, two goals from Stuart Douglas and a Matthew Spring penalty putting them out of sight after 36 minutes against Brentford.

Wrexham's Chris Killen, on loan from Manchester City, gave his new team a 1-0 win against Swansea, who had Michael Howard sent off for a second bookable offence.

fields.headline: First Division  Round-up
fields.trailText: Stockport County produced Saturday's shock of the section at Edgeley Park when they ended a run of 14 games without a win by beating Bolton, previously undefeated on their travels, 4-3.
fields.body:
Stockport County produced Saturday's shock of the section at Edgeley Park when they ended a run of 14 games without a win by beating Bolton, previously undefeated on their travels, 4-3.

County went three up through Andy Tod, Jarkko Wiss and Ian Moore before fourth-placed Bolton drew level with Ian Marshall scoring twice either side of Michael Ricketts' goal. But Aaron Wilbraham hit the winner in the last minute to give Andy Kilner's side only their fourth win in 36 games.

Sheffield United went two up through David Kelly and Michael Brown but were beaten 4-2 with Norwich striking through Phil Mulryne, Iwan Roberts, Tony Cottee and Chris Llewellyn for their first home win. To make things worse for the Blades, Marcus Bent was sent off in the 74th minute for a second bookable offence.

Crystal Palace suffered a fifth straight defeat after leading Portsmouth 2-0, with Steve Claridge maintaining his 100% record since taking charge with the aid of another goal. The player-manager pulled one back just before half-time before Thomas Thogersen and Mike Panopoulos seized a third successive victory for Pompey.

Crewe lost for the fourth time on the trot, beaten 4-0 at home by Wimbledon as Chelsea's on-loan Jon Harley scored twice on his debut.

QPR lost their home record when John Mullin's goal was enough to give sixth-placed Burnley a 1-0 win, the Clarets' fourth successive victory.

Blackburn overcame Grimsby 2-0 with second-half goals from Gary Flitcroft and Matt Jansen while Tranmere have now gone six games without a win after the 2-2 draw with West Bromwich, where the substitute Stuart Barlow rescued Rovers in the last minute.

Gillingham drew for the fourth match running in the goalless stalemate with Barnsley .

fields.headline: Wenger switches to cruise control
fields.trailText: For the time being Arsenal will be content to stalk Manchester United with the dedication of gumshoes. What remains to be seen, when the pace hots up after Christmas, is whether Arséne Wenger's latest pursuit of the Premiership title is maintained in the spirit of Maigret or Clouseau.
fields.body:
For the time being Arsenal will be content to stalk Manchester United with the dedication of gumshoes. What remains to be seen, when the pace hots up after Christmas, is whether Arséne Wenger's latest pursuit of the Premiership title is maintained in the spirit of Maigret or Clouseau.

Already Arsenal are demonstrating that when it comes to winning matches with an economy of labour they are not far behind United. On Saturday morning, Sir Alex Ferguson saw off Leeds without using Ryan Giggs or Andy Cole. In the afternoon, Wenger won at Upton Park with Thierry Henry and Nwankwo Kanu employed only as late substitutes and even Ray Parlour, an important piston in the machine, left on the bench at the start.

Wenger had less reason than Ferguson to save his players' legs since, unlike Manchester United, Arsenal are already through to the next phase of the Champions League and can use their remaining two first-round matches as practice games. Dennis Bergkamp's fear of flying, moreover, will ensure that the Dutchman, free of wearisome midweek trips, remains fresh for the weekend.

Arsenal will be fortunate, however, if they continue to find opponents quite so obliging as West Ham were on Saturday. For most of the first half West Ham's defence, missing the injured Igor Stimac, did not exist as a recognisable entity. A slipshod error by Trevor Sinclair allowed Robert Pires to score after 12 minutes and an own goal by Rio Ferdinand increased Arsenal's lead after 21.

The rest was a familiar story of West Ham recovering their faculties sufficiently to get back into the contest after half-time and perform with enough vigour to convince themselves, their supporters and their manager that they deserved a point, even though the opposition had enough chances on the break to double their score.

After the game Harry Redknapp made his usual speech, the one which starts with condemnation of the defence - "You cannot give goals away like that at this level" - but ends with a ringing assertion that things will get better - "I'm still convinced that we'll finish in the top half of the table, nothing has changed my mind."

Admirable though the West Ham manager's faith in his team may be, Redknapp is starting to sound like the three-wheeled waggoner who believes that around the next bend is a hidden cave where he can watch those Cherokees go galloping by. In fact his defenders rather pre-empted him on Saturday as they stood and watched while Silvinho, Pires, Sylvain Wiltord and Fredrik Ljungberg galloped by, spurred on by Bergkamp's arrows.

When Frank Lampard and John Moncur eventually man aged to establish a base in midfield to back the skills of Joe Cole, whose qualities shone through West Ham's football like a search-light, some sort of parity was restored. Yet the omnipotence of Patrick Vieira - "a giant from the first to last minute," according to Wenger - was not seriously challenged, while alongside him Gilles Grimandi again showed that he is more effective for Arsenal in midfield than ever he was at centre-back.

Until a low free-kick from Stuart Pearce, struck left-footed from just beyond the right-hand corner of the penalty area, beat David Seaman through a crowd of players early in the second half, Upton Park had been resigned to blowing raspberries rather than bubbles. West Ham, after all, have still to win a league fixture at home this season and the natives are getting restless.

Pearce's goal, however, roused West Ham to something approaching fervour and had Davor Suker, recently recovered from injury, been at his sharpest he might have brought the scores level 12 minutes from the end when a nod-down from Sinclair put the ball on to his favourite left foot. Instead he sliced his shot.

It had been a sliced clearance by Sinclair as he attempted to cut out a cross from Bergkamp that led to Pires putting Arsenal in front. Then Ferdinand, lunging back to prevent a centre from Silvinho reaching Bergkamp, diverted the ball past Shaka Hislop.

In between times saves by Hislop had twice thwarted Wiltord and later on, with West Ham pressing forward, Henry and Parlour both missed chances to increase Arsenal's lead. Pires, meanwhile, had a goal disallowed because Bergkamp was offside.

At the final whistle Martin Keown indulged in a maniacal one-man celebration for the Arsenal fans which might have been better saved for the winning of the Premiership or the Champions League. At present, beating West Ham is worth about half a whoopee.

fields.headline: Taylor ready for instant return
fields.trailText: Graham Taylor, despite his team's many defeats, could not lose last season. Having achieved successive promotions to land in the Premiership, Watford's manager expected little else than to go there, get the T-shirt and come straight back down.
fields.byline: Adam Sills at the City Ground
fields.body:
Graham Taylor, despite his team's many defeats, could not lose last season. Having achieved successive promotions to land in the Premiership, Watford's manager expected little else than to go there, get the T-shirt and come straight back down.

He now believes the experience has left the club fully prepared for an instant and successful return and the players are certainly doing their bit. They remain unbeaten after Micah Hyde's two goals secured victory over Nottingham Forest on Saturday and they are just two points behind the leaders Fulham. The master plan is bang on track.

"When we got promoted to the Premiership last time it was like 'where's all this money coming from?'," Taylor said. "But, even though we found it too hot to handle, on and off the pitch, it gave the club an opportunity to sort itself out financially, put some money into the academy side and make sure we have some decent facilities."

Forest's manager, David Platt, could have been lining up for Watford on Saturday but the summer before last, having left Sampdoria after an unsuccessful spell as coach, he turned down Taylor's offer to join in pre-season training.

"When he sought my advice after Sampdoria I told him, 'I can't believe what you're doing. What you need to do, pal, is come and play in the Premiership with us.' He might have scored the goals that kept us up," said Taylor.

Platt made life less easy for himself by saying no. After a difficult first season Forest have not won at home since the opening day of this one and their yo-yo course of the 90s, when they spent as much time in the Premiership as out of it, seems to have lost its momentum.

webTitle: Spurs see off dismal Derby but mediocrity remains a fond memory

fields.headline: Spurs see off dismal Derby but mediocrity remains a fond memory
fields.trailText: It reveals much about the diminished expectations of Spurs' fans under George Graham that their nostalgia is no longer moored in the glorious distant past but in the mediocrity of recent yesterdays.
fields.byline: Roy Collins at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
It reveals much about the diminished expectations of Spurs' fans under George Graham that their nostalgia is no longer moored in the glorious distant past but in the mediocrity of recent yesterdays.

Thus the pictures on sale at the little memorabilia stalls along Tottenham High Road are not of the 1961 Double heroes, Mackay, Blanchflower, White, et al, but of David Ginola in all his L'Oréal glory.

Inside the ground, even more sadly, the supporters no longer arrive in the hope of being seduced by some dazzling forward play but of experiencing a swashbuckling moment from the full-back Stephen Carr, last year's player of the season and, in the absence of Sol Campbell, the most popular man on the park.

Carr did not disappoint on this occasion, scoring the second goal with a tremendous swerving shot with the outside of his right foot which killed off Derby. Not that Derby need much killing off, so versed are their defence in the myriad methods of footballing suicide.

The Derby back four could hold seminars on the art of hara-kiri, though their plain-speaking manager Jim Smith had a more down-to-earth phrase to describe their errors. "Schoolboy stuff," he rightly said of their complicity in Spurs' third goal, which is likely to have fourth-form footballers up and down the country consulting their lawyers.

In a bid to at least spread the blame, Smith has continually rearranged his back four but has found the exercise a bit like one of those old Rubik's cube games; when he succeeds in getting one bit in place, he discovers that it has only put some other piece out of kilter at the opposite corner.

Now he may be forced into the equivalent of throwing the damn thing into the dustbin by buying a defender who can sort the mess out for him. It will probably, however, be a case of selling Peter to buy Paul, or more likely, in Smith's case, Paolo, since bottom of the table Derby do not have money to burn.

Neither do they, nor Totten ham, have talent to burn, despite the claims of Graham that Spurs' football in the opening 25 minutes was "top, top drawer." Impressive as it was, one has to take into account that Derby's football was from the bottom of an ageing sideboard with three wonky legs and woodworm.

Oyvind Leonhardsen scored with a sweet strike into the corner of the net just as Derby's defenders were about to congratulate each other on keep ing a clean sheet for the opening four minutes. And after Carr's effort in first-half injury time, Leonhardsen wrapped things up with another in the 47th minute as two Derby defenders mimed a clearance.

The final goals ensured Tottenham's first Premiership wins in almost six weeks and stifled chants against Graham in protesters' throats. Yet Spurs supporters still went home to polish the frames on their David Ginola prints.

webTitle: Saints and Sylla show style to rout Rangers

fields.headline: Saints and Sylla show style to rout Rangers
fields.trailText: In a ragged classic, St Johnstone produced a result that almost suspends the laws of Scottish football's universe. Rangers now lie fourth in the Premier League and are 12 points behind the leaders, Celtic. Martin O'Neill, though he would never admit it, must have the scent of the title in his nostrils.
fields.body:
In a ragged classic, St Johnstone produced a result that almost suspends the laws of Scottish football's universe. Rangers now lie fourth in the Premier League and are 12 points behind the leaders, Celtic. Martin O'Neill, though he would never admit it, must have the scent of the title in his nostrils.

The game teemed with incident at either end and was graced with the presence of the remarkable Mohammed Sylla. The Guinea international, plucked from the French club Le Mans by the Saints' manager Sandy Clark in the summer, waltzed through the match conferring both guile and mayhem.

A law unto himself, he fittingly scored St Johnstone's momentous winner - a hammered shot from 20 yards into Mark Brown's top corner, after he had sprinted the length of the field.

Unsurprisingly, the Rangers manager Dick Advocaat was livid. His side's behaviour is increasingly erratic and they must now visit Sturm Graz in the Champions League on Wednesday stalked by their domestic struggles. Still, whatever the Dutch instinct is for not mincing one's words, Advocaat possesses it.

"My team are big heads," he spat afterwards. "They always think they are better than they are. I have Scottish internationals and Dutch internationals but they have no idea about football.

"It was a hopeless performance and I am sick of it. With no disrespect to St Johnstone, we should be better than them. But they were up for this game while my players were not."

Early on in the match Advocaat fell into a strop, as only Advocaat can, over the decision that provided St Johnstone's opening goal - yet it would be hard to find a more glaring penalty.

Keigan Parker, at 18 years old a lithe and slippery striker, took on the creaking Italian Sergio Porrini inside the Rangers box and turned him outside in. When the defender finally resorted to tugging and wrestling with the youngster, the referee, Alan Freeland, quite rightly blew for a penalty.

Advocaat was out of his dugout as if one of the world's great injustices had just been witnessed. Parker dusted himself down and slammed home the spot-kick. "He's growing in stature," Clark said calmly of his prodigy later.

Amid the general subjugation of Scottish football by the Old Firm, you occasionally glimpse these traces of rebellion. St Johnstone should have gone two up when Sean Evers' beautifully-paced pass released Paddy Connolly, whose finish proved weak. Such a lead would not have flattered the home side. Their technique was inferior but their old-fashioned exploitation of the flanks was enticing.

Miller's equaliser after 55 minutes arrived with startling suddenness. The young striker has hardly been seen since his £2m arrival from Hibernian but in an instant here he leapt back into the spotlight. From 22 yards Miller rifled a low drive with venomous pace past Alan Main.

This looked like being the goal of the game. It was for 11 minutes before Sylla's advance from defence brought the house down, producing sounds rarely heard in a ground dubbed Sleepy Hollow.

fields.headline: Robson's £8m gamble falls flat
fields.trailText: Bryan Robson said that Middlesbrough had taken "a calculated risk" in spending £8m on Ugo Ehiogu at this time of acute transfer uncertainty. Given the rapid abortion of the record signing's debut here on Saturday, it already looks an unwise decision. The manager and his club surely cannot afford many more.
fields.body:
Bryan Robson said that Middlesbrough had taken "a calculated risk" in spending £8m on Ugo Ehiogu at this time of acute transfer uncertainty. Given the rapid abortion of the record signing's debut here on Saturday, it already looks an unwise decision. The manager and his club surely cannot afford many more.

Robson knows it, reportedly saying he will quit at the end of the season if his expensively assembled multinational team do not improve - "I will look at where we are around April and consider my position then."

Boldness was certainly not Boro's friend here and neither was the referee. "Mr Riley seems never to give us any decisions," Robson sniped. The manager was pinpointing the official's rejection of a penalty when Andy Campbell was clearly brought down by Mark Kinsella in Charlton's area shortly before half-time.

The fates had already risen up against Boro. Ehiogu, pursued for so long by Robson, limped off after only five minutes - and only one touch of the ball - with a calf injury. Robson's immediate diagnosis is that his new defender will be out "for three to four weeks" and denied that he had taken an undue risk in fielding someone who had played only one full senior game this season.

Robson has now lost four players to injury in a week which started with the huge blow to parochial pride of being outplayed by Newcastle at the Riverside and ended with the unlucky termination of their unbeaten away record. With just one of that quartet, Alen Boksic, Boro surely would have extended their happy travels. But as Boro slide - they are now two points off the drop zone - tolerance on Teesside is running low.

For all the "discussions within football" Boro had before agreeing £8m for Ehiogu, they may find as early as next week - while the £40,000-a-week recruit is resting up - that they have paid heavily over the top if the European Union radically alters the transfer system.

In any case, many close Boro watchers have been questioning his signing because Ehiogu was earmarked to replace Gianluca Festa, one of the team's most consistent performers. Sure enough the Italian was relegated to the bench yesterday, if only for five minutes.

Charlton, outplayed for virtually all the match, and lucky to escape as Paul Ince (three times) and Brian Deane went close, could scarcely believe their good fortune, even if their Swedish substitute, Mathias Svensson, certainly could.

The confident striker boasted before the game that "the Premiership does not look difficult from the touchline". His assessment seemed marvellously accurate when, just two minutes after coming on for his first taste of top-flight football, he punished Boro's slack marking at the far post to head in Claus Jensen's free-kick.

It was Charlton's only effort on target. Alan Curbishley could not disguise his delight at the gift of three points, or his surprise at being so high in the Premiership. But, mindful of Charlton's slump near this time two years ago, he cautioned: "Let's get to 16 games and see where we are."

For Robson, it threatens to be an even more nervous November.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Harkness stops the Wednesday rot
fields.standfirst: Francis misses his cue and a faint glimmer of hope reappears
fields.trailText: Trevor Francis was briefly idolised at Hillsborough for a managerial reign which brought Sheffield Wednesday promotion and two cup finals in 1993. But never has he done them a greater service than yesterday, when his drab and predictable Birmingham side presented Wednesday with a victory that brings fresh hope to an anguished season.
fields.body:
Trevor Francis was briefly idolised at Hillsborough for a managerial reign which brought Sheffield Wednesday promotion and two cup finals in 1993. But never has he done them a greater service than yesterday, when his drab and predictable Birmingham side presented Wednesday with a victory that brings fresh hope to an anguished season.

Wednesday's decline was already setting in when Francis was sacked on FA Cup final day five years ago but few imagined the extent of their subsequent descent: relegation last season, when they were assaulted by bickering MPs and crippling debts, the swift dismantling of a lackadaisical, overpaid side and a subsequent run of eight successive league defeats to slide to the foot of the First Division.

The assertion of their manager Paul Jewell, a man of elementary sweat-and-toil principles, that "this job was never going to be a quick fix" could hardly have been a clearer example of stating the obvious had it come from the management of Railtrack.

Jewell can take heart today; at least Wednesday have overtaken Huddersfield. Before their lowest league crowd for 11 years victory was secured by a dipping shot from Steve Harkness, the former Blackburn defender, just before the hour.

It would be unfair to chide Wednesday's supporters for being absent yesterday because of Sky TV; after all, Birmingham fans have heard that excuse for years. That Francis finds time to indulge in his extra-curricular television duties remains bewildering as long as Birmingham lack the quality to treat their annual promotion challenge with any seriousness. They remain third, six points off the pace, and on this evidence it will not get any better.

Wednesday had summoned Efan Ekoku, once of Wimbledon, to reinforce their forward line amid concern that his spell at Grasshopper might have left him a yard off the pace. Only eight seconds had elapsed when it was discovered that he was actually six inches off the pace, the distance by which his flailing left foot failed to connect with Alan Quinn's left-wing cross, with the goal gaping.

Birmingham should have led by half-time. Ian Hendon was given a roasting on his home debut by Stan Lazaridis. Fortunately for Wednesday, Dele Adebola's speed of thought never matched the Australian's speed of foot.

Throughout Wednesday's turmoil Des Walker, signed from Sampdoria by Francis, has sur vived. He needed nine stitches in a head wound suffered in a collision on the half-hour with Adebola, and Birmingham came closest to scoring while the needle was still going in, Geoff Horsfield swivelling to strike the foot of the left post after Adebola had headed on Ian Bennett's hoofed clearance. Walker returned to make a vital block from Horsfield and even left Lazaridis reeling after another aerial collision.

Gerard Sibon came on to jeers as Wednesday addressed their midfield deficiencies by switching Harkness to left-back. From hardly getting a kick, he produced the one that won the match, beating Bennett with a dipping shot from 22 yards.

Jewell was so jumpy in injury-time that he kicked the ball away from a Birmingham player to waste a few seconds. Martin Grainger shaped as if it might get nasty, no blows were thrown and the referee smiled. Wednesday could breathe easy.

webTitle: Hammam and Cork turn back the crazy clock

fields.headline: Hammam and Cork turn back the crazy clock
fields.trailText: After all Sam Hammam's talk of changing the club's name, logo, nickname and colours, not to mention a suggestion of trading in the mascot Bartley Bluebird for a real live orangutan, this was always going to be a big game for Cardiff's owner.
fields.body:
After all Sam Hammam's talk of changing the club's name, logo, nickname and colours, not to mention a suggestion of trading in the mascot Bartley Bluebird for a real live orangutan, this was always going to be a big game for Cardiff's owner.

The relegated club he bought for £3.1m in the summer need promotion quickly but they went into this match under the head coach Alan Cork, their third manager this season after his former Wimbledon manager Bobby Gould, shunted upstairs last week, and the now departed Billy Ayre.

Five minutes before the break Hammam left his seat and wandered down to the dug-out to offer moral support to Cork, still without an assistant after a rebuff from Robbie Earle last week and possibly wondering how they were going to score in a game they were totally dominating.

"Sam comes down making his comments; I tell him to shut up and he tells me to shut up," Cork said later. "I've had a funny week with him, laughing and laughing. You never know what will happen next."

He is not alone and the 4,625 fans who made up their lowest league gate of the season seemed bemused by events of the past week. "They have been let down so many times," Cork added. "They want to see 100% effort; I've told the players if they give it, the crowd will love you. They wouldn't care if I had managed Swansea for 25 years as long as Cardiff are winning."

They won this one after Mansfield turned up for a point but lacked the savvy to take it despite the excellent Bobby Mimms. But Robert Earnshaw got goal-side of the defence after the break to beat Mimms with a lob from 20 yards and Paul Brayson finished them off from the edge of the box.

Thereafter Hammam, who had been continually checking his watch, indulged in a spot of high-fives with a handful of young fans before lobbing them headers with the spare match-ball. The Crazy Gang's crazy guy is still enjoying his football.

webTitle: Gregory's gall as Villa lose ground in race for Europe

fields.headline: Gregory's gall as Villa lose ground in race for Europe
fields.trailText: Aston Villa continue to resemble the table dancing club that offers plenty of tease but precious little strip. Not for the first time, and doubtless not the last until John Gregory is given the wherewithal to sign the accomplished striker his side so desperately needs, Villa failed to capitalise on the midfield probings of Paul Merson.
fields.body:
Aston Villa continue to resemble the table dancing club that offers plenty of tease but precious little strip. Not for the first time, and doubtless not the last until John Gregory is given the wherewithal to sign the accomplished striker his side so desperately needs, Villa failed to capitalise on the midfield probings of Paul Merson.

It all adds up to an overdose of frustration for Gregory who, after unexpectedly landing his dream job when appointed Villa manager almost three years ago, now harbours ambitions of taking them into the Champions League. After just nine games, profligacy in front of goal means they are already losing ground on the Premiership's top three.

"It was the same old story," Gregory said after watching his side fire yet another round of blanks. "We had enough of the play but were unable to make it count. The same happened against Liverpool, Middlesbrough, Chelsea and Arsenal and the simple fact is we need a quality striker."

Gregory expects to be given £5m from the sale of Ugo Ehiogu to make a signing, but he is not sure that will be enough to recruit the player of quality he needs. "I'm not going to buy for the sake of it," he said. "I need to sign someone who will make a difference to our play and win us matches rather than fill a vacancy.

"I think my chairman, Doug Ellis, understands that, although I appreciate with the uncertainty over the transfer market we could pay £10m tomorrow for a player who might be worth nothing in a couple of months' time."

It must be galling for Gregory that Villa have invested £12m plus to replace the old Trinity Road stand and increase the ground's capacity to 50,000. With just 27,000 present yesterday the construction, opposite the Doug Ellis stand, is in danger of being known as Deadly's Folly.

Gregory spent most of the match perched on an unfinished part of it monitoring his team's progress, or lack of it. Alongside him stood his Sunderland counterpart Peter Reid, who was left similarly frustrated by his strikers' failure to make the most of their opportunities.

Unlike Villa's strikers, however, the waywardness of Kevin Phillips and Niall Quinn was, as Gregory will testify, uncharacteristic. Beforehand the Villa manager had said the presence of both Phillips and Quinn in his squad would guarantee that coveted Champions League berth. Afterwards he was grateful for a collective off-day by the pair.

Sound defensive work from Gareth Southgate and Co restricted Sunderland's chances, but when they did appear there were no takers. Phillips cracked a second-half shot against David James' crossbar and Quinn, set up after Michael Gray's left-wing cross had skidded off Southgate's head, toe-poked the ball wide.

At least Kevin Kilbane did force James to make a save seconds after the interval when, put through by his fellow Irishman Quinn, he hit a right-foot shot that the Villa keeper kept out by diving to his right.

Kilbane was a constant menace down the right flank and his display was consistent with his improved form this season. "He's a lot fitter than when he first came here last March and he's causing teams a lot of problems," said Reid.

"Unfortunately our strikers did not - we were comfortable throughout and had the best chances but wasted them. I'm disappointed with our display in the last third of the pitch, although to come here and get a result is not a bad achievement."

In contrast to James, Sunderland's Thomas Sorensen had just one save of note to make, a one-handed tip-over to an effort from distance on the stroke of half-time by Lee Hendrie. It all added up to the first goalless draw in this fixture for 110 years.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Fulham falter at the round dozen

fields.headline: Fulham falter at the round dozen
fields.trailText: That this meeting of two of the First Division's richest clubs should finish goalless suggests a case of cheque-mate rather than stalemate but far from it.
fields.body:
That this meeting of two of the First Division's richest clubs should finish goalless suggests a case of cheque-mate rather than stalemate but far from it.

After investing upwards of £40m in an effort to get the club he has supported man and boy into the Premiership, Wolves' benefactor Sir Jack Hayward is as far away as ever from earning a return. And with the team 13 points adrift of a play-off place and seemingly destined to remain in the First Division for a 12th season, Sir Jack - or his succession of managers - seems more big spendthrift than big spender.

Now the penny has dropped with Sir Jack and spending, unless the cash has been generated by the sale of players, has stopped. Instead an increase in the less expensive attributes of bloodymindedness and determination are being demanded by the manager Colin Lee to compensate, especially against teams such as Fulham.

"We had to play in a disciplined way and match them man for man," Lee said. "Everyone knew what they had to do and they did their job well."

All of which ensured Wolves continued their habit of raining on Fulham's parade. Last winter Lee's team ended Fulham's year-long plus unbeaten home record; in April they were the last team to defeat the London side in the league; and their reversal of the form book on Saturday meant the end for Fulham's chances of recording the best ever start to a season.

With 11 successive victories behind them Fulham needed another two to emulate Reading's achievement of 13 on the bounce in 1985. Curiously Wolves ended that run, too, but their intervention this time is seen by Fulham in much the same way as they play the game, positively.

"The pressure has been lifted a bit because our 100% record has gone," explained the defender Steve Finnan. "It was getting to the point when games against us were treated as cup finals by other teams. Now we should be able to relax a bit and there's no reason why we should not put another run together."

If the winning run had become something of an albatross, then, in the teenage defender Joleon Lescott, Wolves had just the boy for the burning-deck routine required to keep the visitors at bay.

Consequently, serious threats to the Wolves goal were few and far between. Finnan himself came closest to scoring late in the game with a speculative chip that bounced to safety via the underside of Michael Oakes's crossbar.

It could all have been very different, however, had Fulham been awarded a penalty when Barry Hayles was tripped by Kevin Muscat in the 19th minute. Hayles, clearly aggrieved by the rejection, continued chirruping his displeasure until silenced by a yellow card. In the long term, though, the signs are that money talks and Fulham are Premiership bound.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Fluent Chelsea begin to speak Ranieri's language

fields.headline: Fluent Chelsea begin to speak Ranieri's language
fields.trailText: Concerns may have been aired during the week about Claudio Ranieri needing an interpreter to get his message across in the Stamford Bridge dressing room. But nothing was lost in the translation on Saturday.
fields.body:
Concerns may have been aired during the week about Claudio Ranieri needing an interpreter to get his message across in the Stamford Bridge dressing room. But nothing was lost in the translation on Saturday.

Chelsea's football was as fluent as their coach's English is not, a clear indication that the Italian's demands and tactical message are quickly getting through to the cosmopolitan minds that make up the first-team squad.

So relentless were Chelsea's attacking options that they were overwhelming Coventry long before the visitors were reduced to 10 men when their young goalkeeper Chris Kirkland was wrongly sent off after a challenge with Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink.

Having said that, Ranieri is astute enough not to get carried away by a one-sided win. Teams often play better with 10 men, but Coventry were so hapless it was if they were trying to offer physical proof of why they have been leading the campaign for a more equitable share of Premiership television money.

They gave the ball away at will, were regularly caught in possession and defended with all the nous of a sand castle at high tide.

"This was a horrible experience that we must all learn from," said their manager Gordon Strachan, although the only clear realisation he can surely come to is that his side is simply not good enough to achieve much more than avoid relegation.

Every time Chelsea attacked - and, it has to be stressed, every time - they looked as if they would score. The only relief to Coventry was that somehow they managed to avoid double figures.

If the villain of the piece was the referee Steve Lodge for reducing Kirkland to tears in only his second first-team start, the hero was Hasselbaink who ended up with four goals to double his season's tally.

Not that there was any sign of such ruthlessness in the opening 20 minutes when the Dutchman somehow missed two sitters from all of six yards and watched a diving Kirkland push aside his 19-yard drive.

But then he got a lucky break. As he fastened on to a lovely through ball from the returning Gustavo Poyet and took the ball round Kirkland, the 19-year-old - only playing because of a goalkeeper injury crisis at Highfield Road - got a touch on the ball before Hasselbaink fell over his shoulder.

Bizarrely, Lodge pointed to the spot and sent off Kirkland - awful decisions both. Hasselbaink converted the penalty and Chelsea were away.

Ranieri had spent the previous week working with his players on a new 3-4-2-1 formation, and the hard work paid off as Chelsea found so much space behind the Coventry backline it was embarrassing.

An end-to-end move started by Dennis Wise's dummy concluded with Hasselbaink taking on the clueless Gary Breen, before bending a shot low past the substitute goalkeeper Alan Miller for No2 on 42 minutes.

The third goal arrived two minutes into the new half. A great ball from Sam Dalla Bona played in Gianfranco Zola behind the Coventry defence and the little Italian found the net via the post.

Five minutes later Tore Andre Flo and Poyet linked up down the right, Zola's shot was saved by Miller's legs and Hasselbaink mopped up the rebound to complete his hat-trick.

Zola then fluffed two chances before, on 58 minutes, a poor Coventry pass was intercepted by Mario Melchiot and fed to Flo, who found Hasselbaink. A little drag-back produced space for the shot and goal No5.

Miller then saved from Dalla Bona and Hasselbaink before goal No6 arrived. Celestine Babyaro's cross found Flo's head so easily that the Norwegian looked embarrassed to claim any credit.

A miskick by the under-employed Ed de Goey allowed Cedric Roussel to snatch a late consolation goal for Coventry. But despite the excuse of having only 10 men, there was no escaping the fact that Strachan's team had been comprehensively outclassed.
