webTitle: Tonic for Toon as Robson remains

fields.headline: Tonic for Toon as Robson remains
fields.trailText: After a fortnight of intense speculation and to a collective sigh of relief on Tyneside, Newcastle, not the Football Association, have finally got their man.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at St James' Park
fields.body:
After a fortnight of intense speculation and to a collective sigh of relief on Tyneside, Newcastle, not the Football Association, have finally got their man.

Bobby Robson will arrive at United's training ground in Chester-le-Street this morning aiming to raise spirits after Saturday's surprise defeat to Everton. His players should not need much lifting - the knowledge that Robson is staying put will be fillip enough.

The FA's attempt to hire the Newcastle manager on a part-time basis was given short shrift by the United board and, while Robson was disappointed not to be returning to the international stage, the Toon army breathes again.

"I was very flattered and honoured that the FA wanted me, but I understand the board's decision and their difficulty," said Robson. "I was willing to do the job on a part-time basis, but there's nothing I can do but accept the decision. I was disappointed but I understand the chairman's feelings."

"We had wanted his experience and enthusiasm for a short period to be made available to the England team," said the FA's executive director David Davies, putting a brave face on an embarrassing snub. Newcastle's chairman Freddy Shepherd yesterday ruled out Robson taking even a consultancy role with the national side.

"You cannot second guess the FA but I think it is dead and buried," he said. "It is impossible to do both jobs. Newcastle is a full-time job and Bobby has 100% accepted the position. The meeting after the match was between two friends and I asked him if he would now choose between England and the club - there is no way he will choose."

Newcastle may now complain to the Premier League about the FA's approach and, in particular, the presence of two club rivals on the selection panel - Arsenal's David Dein and Leeds's Peter Ridsdale.

"I'm as patriotic as the next man, but I don't see others being patriotic when their manager's being mentioned," said Shepherd. "It's not my problem. I have to worry about Newcastle and its supporters and that's big enough for me."

While Robson's commitment to all things England had him champing at the bit to return to the post he held between 1982 and 1990, quite how he would have fitted the job around his life as Newcastle manager is unclear. Indeed, the Geordies' revival under his stewardship owes much to the 67-year-old's meticulous approach.

"Last week he didn't spend one evening relaxing at home," said his assistant Mick Wadsworth, who recently failed to persuade Robson to miss United's game at Southampton while he recovered from a throat infection.

"He was at it from 8am until 11pm every day last week and, although that was an exception, he would do that two or three times a week normally."

"Bobby is a workaholic," added Shepherd. "He is the best manager the club has ever had - he works seven days a week and 16-hour days. If it had been someone without his work rate you might get away with it, but he would give everything to everyone. He's such a kind, honourable guy and determined man - he was willing to try it."

Possibly grudgingly, Robson agreed. "If you take on another job, you have to take time out, and there is no way the England job is part-time as the responsibility is huge," he said. "Newcastle is a big club and not a part-time job."

As if to prove the point, Everton plundered Tyneside on Saturday, although their manager Walter Smith must wonder what he has to do to generate his own headlines. A thoroughly deserved win, sealed with Kevin Campbell's first Premiership strike for seven months, ended an alarming five-match winless streak and was inspired, inevitably, by the returning clown prince Paul Gascoigne.

Smith's tactic of flooding the midfield with blue shirts stifled Newcastle's attacking options and gave Gazza licence to roam. The former darling of the Gallowgate duly tore around St James' Park as he had in his youth, his clever flicks and canny passes baffling the home side and prompting both Alex Nyarko and Thomas Gravesen to test Shay Given from distance.

But when Campbell, under pressure from Nolberto Solano, speared wide of an open goal it seemed the visitors' chance had gone. Cue Gascoigne's backheel and Nyarko's pass to the debutant Gary Naysmith, whose perfect cross was converted by Campbell at the far post.

"Gazza's still stuck to the roof and he won't be down for a while," said Everton's former Newcastle defender Steve Watson. "He gets so hyped up before every game, but his attitude's fantastic and people buzz off him."

Without a goal in three league games but with Robson staying in Toon, the home fans were just as satisfied.

fields.headline: Taylor stays street-smart in defeat
fields.trailText: As those who have delighted in dragging down successive England managers may shortly come to appreciate, Peter Taylor is not a man easily ruffled.
fields.body:
As those who have delighted in dragging down successive England managers may shortly come to appreciate, Peter Taylor is not a man easily ruffled.

The smart, authoritative football that Taylor has drawn from his Leicester City charges since stepping snugly into Martin O'Neill's shoes may have been noticeably absent here but the man who might just be king was ready for any would-be detractors. As Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan et al will tell you, when you are sitting at the big boys' table, forewarned is forearmed.

Before being asked whether he was ready to do the decent thing and gallop, white knight-like, to his country's rescue, the theory was put to Taylor that, after such a spirited start to the season, Leicester's bubble had burst.

"We have lost two games in a row to Manchester United and Liverpool," he replied. "That's the sort of thing that would test Real Madrid, never mind Leicester City." Touché.

Midway through the second half of a game that always drifted enticingly between the sublime and the breathless, Leicester's defender Callum Davidson hoisted the ball skywards with the speed of a bullet.

It fell into Anfield's main stand, straight into the lap of Michael Owen to be precise. Inactive because of a head wound sustained the previous weekend at Derby, the young striker collected, controlled and dispatched with customary efficiency, bowling the ball down towards the touchline.

Although not exactly well-placed, given that the profligacy of those called upon to fill the void created by his absence had been so pronounced, Owen must have been tempted to shoot.

The Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier's assertion that his team had created a shed-load of chances brooked no argument. Neither did his claim that Leicester only really threatened to steal something late in the afternoon when, perplexingly, Liverpool's refreshing sense of adventure had been eroded by the Chinese whisper-style transference of the belief that if something can go wrong, then it will. They call it Roy Evans' law on Merseyside.

This was a hard-won if deserved win, for as Liverpool began to fall back and protect their slender advantage, Taylor's boys sensed their lack of ambition would, after all, have tangible reward. Indeed, but for Markus Babbel's marvellous tackle on Paul Gilchrist just minutes before the final whistle, logic would have been turned squarely on its head.

Much of Liverpool's football, particularly in the first half, was mesmerising and Houllier would have required an abacus to tot up the number of chances his players missed.

Indeed Emile Heskey, the man whose goal finally divided two teams of quite differing merit, should have claimed a second consecutive hat-trick. He did not because, as his manager pointed out, he still lacks composure in front of goal.

Twice after scoring, Heskey scampered clear of his old team-mates only to fire tamely into the legs of the outstanding Tim Flowers, who combined impeccable timing and beguiling athleticism.

But it would be churlish to criticise Heskey; he was a delight on Saturday, striking the decisive blow on 69 minutes after Matt Elliott hopelessly misjudged both the flight and strength of Babbel's cross from the right flank.

webTitle: Ipswich have a script for all struggling managers

fields.headline: Ipswich have a script for all struggling managers
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Richmond asked last week that Bradford be judged after the Ipswich game. He sounded like a chairman who fancied his chances. Sadly his team made few and took none. Even Benito Carbone, clear 15 yards out, snatched wide when he would naturally have hit the target. It reflected the whole team's loss of confidence.
fields.body:
Geoffrey Richmond asked last week that Bradford be judged after the Ipswich game. He sounded like a chairman who fancied his chances. Sadly his team made few and took none. Even Benito Carbone, clear 15 yards out, snatched wide when he would naturally have hit the target. It reflected the whole team's loss of confidence.

Much, such as magic goals out of nothing, was expected of the Italian. He is, indeed, joint top scorer. But his only goal came nine matches ago, against Chelsea, when team morale soared with a 2-0 win. They have scored only two since and Carbone, suspecting his locks and Alice band were making him too easy to spot and mark, has shaved his head in the hope of getting lost among the broad beans.

Saturday was more mangelwurzels. Dean Saunders, who came on for his first 16 minutes of the season, believes some of the newcoming old-stagers, astutely picked up by Chris Hutchings in the summer, think "we're going to play teams off the pitch, which is not realistic. We must go back to making it hard for teams to play."

This will come hard to Hutchings. If the team has delusions of grandeur, he has commendable delusions of style. He has blind optimism too. "The situation is nothing a couple of wins can't put right." But wins mean goals. Last week he abandoned extra shooting at training, saying "you can practise things too much".

Certainly over-concentration can breed anxiety and banish instinct. These players need to regroup first in shape and spirit. Otherwise Bradford will find they are building a stadium fit for the Premiership that sees first service in the Nationwide - delusion indeed.

Typically on Saturday fortune favoured the fortunate. Everything is going enviably right for Ipswich since their promotion. This was their fifth successive game unbeaten, their third successive away win and thoroughly deserved. But they went ahead through a grotesque lunge of luck as Dan Petrescu put through his own goal. And the second was rough justice for Matt Clarke who had just made a stunning save from David Johnson, tipping a point-blank header on to a post. Two minutes later Jamie Clapham scored with a free-kick which, being generous to the wall, went over it.

George Burley was generous to Bradford, though it may not have encouraged them to hear that "our passing was poor by our standards". It was, too. Instead of their recent copperplate script, it was as if they were writing on blotting paper. It was fuzzy at the edges. There was less bright movement but the confidence was undimmed.

The force is with them, many of them unremarkable players playing above themselves with faith in the system and the club. Two who are special, Matt Holland and Titus Bramble (again rested), signed extended contracts last week; John McGreal and Mark Venus were outstanding in defence; Marcus Stewart's angled runs were constantly deceptive. "We set our standards, thinking we would have to improve by 10% this season to survive," said Burley. "Now we have no fears about playing the best."

Finding himself in sixth place Burley added: "I was brought up with Ipswich in the 70s and 80s in Europe. That's where I want to take the club back." His manager was Bobby Robson. If Bradford's manager can see how simply it is done, the cry could one day be heard, "Hutchings for England."

fields.headline: Warner's Charone launches entertainment agency
fields.trailText: 12.15pm Madonna and REM are among artists set to join a PR agency being set up by Barbara Charone of Warner Europe UK. by Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Madonna and REM are among the artists set to join a new PR agency being set up by Barbara Charone, director of publicity at Warner Europe UK.

Ms Charone is leaving Warner after 20 years with the record company to launch MBC Media, a PR agency that will specialise in the entertainment business.

As well as Madonna and REM, her client list will include Mick Hucknall, UB40, William Orbit and Eliza Carthy. She has also been hired to promote the Pet Shop Boys' new musical, Closer to Heaven, and will handle the PR for Teatro, the West End club and restaurant owned by the actress Lesley Ash and former Leeds United star Lee Chapman.

Ms Charone said of her move: "The time was just right. Our company is going through changes and I have always thought about setting up on my own. I'm sure the new team here will be fantastic."

MBC Media will be based in St John's Wood and will form part of MBC Management limited, the talent consultancy set up by the former Warner Europe managing director, Moira Bell.

Ms Charone will be joined by one other as-yet-unnamed PR executive and an assistant.

Warner press officer Ginny Luckhurst is expected to take over at the head of Warner's publicity department.

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.standfirst: Leeds and Manchester United fans should be ashamed, but Terry Venables did nothing wrong. Not in Australia, anyway.
fields.trailText: Who's that starting the sick chants?
fields.body:
Who's that starting the sick chants?

Our mailbag today is dominated by the somewhat disconcerting topic of who started the sickening chants at Old Trafford on Saturday. "Daniel Taylor implies that Leeds began the ritual with the Munich references, whereas in truth Manchester got the response they wanted AFTER they began glorifying in the murder of the two Leeds fans," reckons Dave Sowden. "Still, we can't be seen to blacken the name of the world's favourite brand name now, can we?" he adds.

However Maxine Dunham takes the opposing view. "Thanks for mentioning Manchester United's chants of "Always look out for Turks wielding knives" on Saturday morning. In the interests of unbiased reporting, it would have been nice if you had mentioned that this was in response to Leeds's famous Munich song - 'Who's that lying on the runway, who's that dying in the snow' with which they have taunted us for many years, particularly when Sir Matt Busby was present," she says.

But Paul Hylton's reaction is probably the most considered. "As a lifelong Man Utd fan who has criticised other fans in the past for singing songs about Munich, I am appalled that our fans sang about the tragic incidents in Turkey," he says. "I would call it mindless, but that would be paying too much of a compliment."

Can anyone help?

Can anyone help Football Unlimited reader Neil Cuniffe? "Your excellent article highlights my five minutes of fame (sad man that I am!). For it is I, a humble Leicester fan, who after seeing Mr Flowers struggle without a cap lent him my England cap (oh! what irony!).

"Did you by any chance take a photograph of Tim wearing the aforementioned by any chance? I would love to get a copy and get Tim to sign it for me. I've already contacted the Leicester Mercury and Liverpool Post and Echo to no avail. Your help would make a sad middle-aged man very happy (and his 10-year-old son)."

If anyone can help email us at the usual address and we will pass the details on to Tim.

Don't forget about Tel

The FA have - according to reports - made a shortlist of three candidates (Arsene Wenger, Sven Goran Eriksson and Roy Hodgson) for the vacant England manager's job. And yet still some of you pine for Terry Venables to return and lead England out of the international football wilderness.

"Why will they not give Venables the job?" asks a bemused Louise Harvey. "He has plenty of international footballing experience and he is tactically minded - and does anyone really care about his slightly dodgy past?"

Well the FA might have something to say about it, not that Louise is deterred. "The England team has many world-class players (trust me, Northern Ireland could benefit from a few of them) but no sense of team spirit, unity, or tactics. This is what Venables could bring to the squad."

And Mark Elliot agrees. "El Tel was the best manager I have ever seen," he claims. "As Aussie coach he bought soccer on to the front page by playing exciting and winning football. I don't think we ever lost a match. We just threw it away to Iran. But that was the only hiccup and it was not Venables's fault - the players fell apart in the last 15 minutes. The whole country was - for the first time ever - united as one, swept along by a whirlwind that was called El Tel."

Elsewhere, there's a word of warning from Switzerland about Roy Hodgson. "Living out here in Zurich one sometimes feels a little detached from the cut and thrust of English football," says Neville X, "but if Roy Hodgson cracked under the pressure of managing his unsuccessful Grasshoppers team last season (with their massive 10,000 gates, the challenge of local derbies against the mighty FC Zurich and the media onslaught from Blick newspaper) then how on earth can he even begin to be considered for the national job? And by the way, what league are Blackburn in now?"

Marvellous Maradona

Many of you have written in to praise Simon Kuper's piece on Diego Maradona. "Your portrait of 'El Diego' is very human," says Jorge Argento. "It's one of the few times that a journalist has seen the human side of Maradona and his circumstances, and not just the consequences of his behaviour." Luke Garry agrees, calling it "a very moving article," while Tim Read, who has lived in Argentina for over ten years, says "the piece captures Maradona's contradictions superbly."

webTitle: Dewar's successor to seek more power for parliament

fields.headline: Dewar's successor to seek more power for parliament
fields.trailText: The man who will succeed Donald Dewar as first minister of Scotland signalled yesterday that he will seek greater powers for the Scottish parliament.
fields.body:
The man who will succeed Donald Dewar as first minister of Scotland signalled yesterday that he will seek greater powers for the Scottish parliament.

Henry McLeish also promised to address the deep disaffection among Labour backbenchers exposed by his snap election at the weekend.

Mr McLeish, who had been expected to win convincingly, only narrowly defeated the finance minister, Jack McConnell, by 44 votes to 36 to be elected interim leader of the Scottish Labour party. He is due to be formally sworn in as first minister on Thursday.

In a series of broadcast interviews yesterday, Mr McLeish, 53, said Scotland had not taken full advantage of the devolution settlement, but he would not be drawn on how he planned to increase autonomy.

"We are only scratching the surface of devolution at the present time and I would hope with my colleagues over the next few days and next few weeks to show people that this is not an annex of anywhere in the United Kingdom, this is a very proud, very purposeful, parliament in which I will take a very Scottish role indeed."

His first priority, however, will be to improve relations between the Scottish cabinet and backbench MSPs. A majority of MSPs voted for Mr McConnell in Saturday's election and analysts say the party is now badly split north of the border.

"There is a lot of disaffection of the backbenchers," said Mr McLeish.

"That goes back a long time. One of my first tasks is to get them involved more in the Holyrood project and, more importantly, the mission of carrying forward some of our policies.

"It was quite clear to me that a lot of them felt... that they were not as involved as they should be."

Mr McLeish has confirmed that Mr McConnell will be given a senior cabinet position in any reshuffle, and he has denied that his election was the result of influence from Westminster. Mr McLeish, the former enterprise and lifelong learning minister, was known to be the favoured choice of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to replace Mr Dewar.

Asked yesterday if he was "Gordon Brown's man," Mr McLeish replied, "certainly not". He added: "I dismiss that this is London-led or London interfering. Jack McConnell, myself, all the cabinet, we have very good set of relations with the prime minister and the chancellor, because that's the nature of devolution."

But Mr McLeish has already been attacked by opposition parties who say he is a Westminster placeman and has no democratic mandate.

Saturday's vote was taken by a "selectorate" of 80 Labour MSPs and members of the party's Scottish executive, because a full electoral college could not be organised in the 28-day deadline set by the Scotland Act for choosing a new first minister. That official process will now take place and will be concluded in December. It had been expected that Mr McLeish would stand unopposed, but the party's left wing has indicated that it intends to field a candidate.

"Labour have emerged from their bogus leadership 'election' in a significantly weaker position," said the SNP leader, John Swinney, yesterday.

"Henry McLeish has no democratic mandate from his own party - never mind from the country."

Analysts, meanwhile, say Mr McLeish will struggle to unite the party in Scotland and prove himself a worthy successor to Mr Dewar.

John Curtice, professor of politics at Strathclyde University, said: "This is not someone who is going to have the kind of authority that Donald had."

webTitle: First politics, now German sport tainted by scandal

fields.headline: First politics, now German sport tainted by scandal
fields.standfirst: National football team's coach designate tests positive for drugs as some begin to fear for country's moral values
fields.trailText: The ostensibly squeaky clean world of German football was last night in shock as fans, players, coaches and administrators absorbed the biggest scandal in its history - a steamy affair involving allegations of drug abuse, embezzlement and prostitution at the highest levels of the game.
fields.body:
The ostensibly squeaky clean world of German football was last night in shock as fans, players, coaches and administrators absorbed the biggest scandal in its history - a steamy affair involving allegations of drug abuse, embezzlement and prostitution at the highest levels of the game.

On Saturday, Christoph Daum was fired as the German national side's coach-designate, and he left his job as manager of the club Bayer Leverkusen after testing positive for drugs.

His downfall is to German sport what the scandal over the illegal funding of the Christian Democratic party under the former chancellor Helmut Kohl has been to German politics. And, like the Kohl scandal, the Daum affair has prompted commentators to question whether some of the basic values of post-war Germany have been eroded.

Daum was the man chosen to lead the once-mighty German national side out of the crisis it entered earlier this year when it was knocked out in the first round of the finals of the Euro 2000 competition.

His abrupt departure is all the more embarrassing because the soccer authorities in Germany are at the forefront of a campaign against drug abuse among young people.

The coach, who is renowned for his aggressive stare and forthright manner, had sought to disprove claims he was a cocaine addict by offering a strand of hair for examination by Cologne University's institute of forensic medicine. A spokeswoman for the city's public prosecutor said yesterday a decision would be taken this week on whether to bring charges against Daum in view of the outcome of the test.

With resounding understatement, Gerhard Mayer-Vorfelder, the vice-president of the German Football Association (DFB), described the weekend's events as "not good for the image of German football".

They will also come as a blow to the giant German utility company RWE, which had signed up Daum as a corporate ambassador and had been planning to use him in a campaign to promote electricity sales.

The results of the forensic tests on the hair sample were made public by Reiner Calmund, the manager of Bayer Leverkusen, the side Daum has coached for the past four years. He said Daum was being relieved of his duties at his own request.

The coach continued to protest his innocence. In a statement read out by Mr Calmund, he said : "I do not believe this test. I want to have a second test, but because of this test I am not able to do the job any longer."

Daum had been scheduled to take over the national side from its caretaker trainer, Rudi Völler, at the end of the current season. Shortly after the announcement by Leverkusen, the DFB decided it was time to show Daum the red card. It said it had "dissolved" its agreement with him.

"I am personally stunned," said Mr Mayer-Vorfelder, who had backed Daum since the scandal first erupted at the beginning of this month. "It is a personal tragedy. I have trusted Christoph Daum for years and believed his emphatic assurances that there was no truth in the rumours."

Earlier this month, however, a Munich newspaper reported that he took drugs and had links with prostitution rackets and the criminal underworld, despite Daum never having faced police charges. It subsequently quoted his arch rival, the Bayern Munich manager, Uli Hoeness, as saying that Daum should not become national trainer if the accusations were true.

Franz Beckenbauer, the president of Bayern Munich and the most influential voice in German football, denied that his manager had intended to harm Daum. But, he added: "These rumours didn't start with Uli Hoeness, they have been there for 10 years."

Shortly afterwards, it was reported that Daum was under investigation over an alleged fraud. But the source was a jailed property developer who accused Daum of failing to pay for a property which the coach recently acquired in Mallorca.

On the day it was revealed that the Bayer Leverkusen coach's financial affairs were under scrutiny, Völler steered Germany to an unexpected 1-0 victory over England.

webTitle: Comment: Peter Preston on the Arab/Israeli conflict

fields.headline: Palestinian children are cannon and media fodder
fields.standfirst:
We watch as they die because adults on both sides won't protect them

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Someone, day after day, is killing the children. We see them die, amid blood and grief. Yet in part, as we watch, we are killing them, too. That is the damnable thing about Ramallah and Nablus and Gaza.
fields.body:
Someone, day after day, is killing the children. We see them die, amid blood and grief. Yet in part, as we watch, we are killing them, too. That is the damnable thing about Ramallah and Nablus and Gaza.

Consider our children, the children of Britain. They come wrapped, by public consent, in special status: they are minors, kids who aren't responsible and thus the ultimate responsibility of society itself. When their parents abuse or neglect them, they are taken away to a place of protection. The law adopts exceptional measures to hide their identities if they are involved - directly or indirectly - in crime. Schoolteachers can't raise a hand to them on pain of dismissal. Children come first.

Press and television, in their own codes of conduct, echo that concern. No identification under the age of 18; no photographs or interviews without parental approval; no invasions of privacy. And not just for Euan Blair or Prince Harry Windsor. If children perish, as they perished at Dunblane, we do not want to see the bodies in the playground nor the parents, engulfed in emotion, talking unwillingly to a prying camera. These children are our children; and their tragedy is our tragedy. Children, in the purest sense, are innocents. Children come first.

But on the West Bank or Gaza, children come first in a different way. They are the first to die - from the 12-year-old who died in his father's arms almost three weeks ago to 13-year-old Mohammed al-Najjar, shot in the head this weekend. Try to compute the victims of this latest uprising, this supposed war, and most of the 130 or so dead already are Palestinians - and, overwhelmingly, most of them are kids, teenage lads well short of their legal majority.

Thus mothers sob and fathers choke before our eyes. Schoolteachers talk sadly about empty desks. Women pallbearers at the endless funerals chant that "Israeli peace means killing the children". Mourning crowds take up the refrain to these teenage "martyrs". "Oh Arabs, pay attention - the Palestinians are getting killed."

And here is the damnable thing. None of this is an accident, a happenstance, a contrivance of fate. The children are first in the firing line by design. They have become cannon and media fodder.

Dr Stephen Males, a former assistant chief constable with a commission from Amnesty International, reported directly the other day on the course of the carnage. "The key point is that Israel is using military tactics and not establishing policing practices." This means that the army - and, yes, thousands of young conscripts - is bent on winning a conflict of retribution and domination the way armies do. "They are simply trying to wipe out or dominate the enemy" - while police officers, who know all about crowd control, stand idly by.

An appalling verdict, compendiously documented. Israel indicted. And the charge is not just sickening brutality, but imbecile strategy as well. For this, if it is war at all, has turned into a war for hearts and minds. "One side waits for violence; the other side obligingly shoots them."

The Palestinians, in turn, actively invite casualties. There's a "ritual pattern" to their demonstrations. Their police are not on hand to protect life or defuse tension. "They make no attempt to stop children and youngsters let out of school for the day from running alongside," Males told Michael Binyon of the Times. "There is a cynical allowance of the enormous risk to their lives."

Why, you ask, such callous cynicism? Oh Arabs, pay attention. The Palestinians can't "defeat" the Israelis (if such a concept has any meaning) by throwing sticks or stones. They have no army worth the name. They cannot wage conventional warfare. What they can do, and are doing, is foment world repugnance. Sit down, in your comfortable western homes: turn on CNN or ITN or the BBC or any of the swelling range of cable channels - and be sickened.

More specifically, fill the cable and satellite TV channels of the Middle East - like MBC or ANN - with this everlasting horror, and the leaders of Damascus or Cairo or Riyadh will feel the heat. The boys on their streets see the pictures; they know which side they are on. Can they exert pressure for actual war on their fragile regimes? Will they, in turn, become the radicalised standard bearers of upheaval?

We've lost touch in Britain with the march of cable news, which still attracts only fragments of audience here. It isn't like that in the third world of ferment. When I was in Pakistan this year I found a satellite dish in every flyblown village. It cost two or three pounds a month, shared among the villagers, and it was their window on the world, reaching more than 50% of the entire population. Through that window, now, they will be seeing Jews kill Arab children round the clock, white-faced western reporters, rivers of blood flowing far into the future.

There is, if we are honest, a terrible - and new - dilemma here for journalists, and for those who buy their wares. We're hot on our dignity about spin doctoring. We quiver with rage whenever Mr Campbell peddles his tales. But what is this, on a more awful stage, than the work of the spinners of despair?

The parents of the West Bank could guard their children. The schools could stay open. The police could control the demonstrations and the age of the demonstrators. Yasser Arafat and Marwan Barghouti, the leader on the streets, could unite to keep the kids away. No more 12 or 13-year-old "martyrs". But none of that happens. The spectacle - the spectacle we watch and, in the watching, in the viewing figures, perpetuate - continues.

As miserably usual with moral dilemmas, there is no pat solution. Shutting out the cameras and the reporters (as the Israelis would like) isn't an answer: darkness didn't stop the bloodshed in the first intifada, darkness cloaks a multitude of other sins. The sense of a watching world - from Belgrade to Maputo - is a powerful force for good. It may even, here, drive Jerusalem to see what havoc it is making for itself.

But if we're going to choose truth above silence, then let it be the truth. And the truth here is not merely that the young men of Israel are shooting the young boys of Palestine, but that we, the reporters on the spot, the cameras, the editors at home and you in your living rooms, are a vital factors in this vile equation.

If we understand that, we begin to understand what's going on, and to be able to make judgments of our own as instinctively as we would make them for our own children, the special kids who come first. Without that, there is only one damnable thing after another.

webTitle: Roma embark on the long trek

fields.headline: Roma embark on the long trek
fields.trailText: They give you a gold star if you win 10 Italian championships but Roma have light years to go. They won their first title during the war, their second in 1983 and nothing since. This star trek will take generations.
fields.body:
They give you a gold star if you win 10 Italian championships but Roma have light years to go. They won their first title during the war, their second in 1983 and nothing since. This star trek will take generations.

But the Giallorossi may make up for some lost time this season. They beat Vicenza 3-1 on Sunday, their third win in three games. And as Juventus drew 2-2 at Milan on Saturday, Roma are the only team in Serie A with a 100% record.

It took them 39 minutes to open the scoring against last-placed Vicenza at the Olympic Stadium on Sunday when Francesco Totti converted a Marco Delvecchio cross.

The second goal took even longer to arrive, but it finally came when Giorgio Sterchele failed to hold on to Gabriel Batistuta's powerful drive in the 79th minute and Vicenzo Montella scored from the rebound.

But Batigol could not be denied a goal himself. Although Mohammed Kallon reduced the deficit six minutes later, the Argentinian replied within a minute.

And the day got even better for Roma fans: Lazio lost 2-0 at Verona.

Argentinian striker Hernan Crespo spurned two inviting first-half chances for the champions, while Yugoslav primatologist Sinisa Mihajlovic missed a late penalty after Verona's Alessandro Mazzola was sent off. Verona's Romanian forward Adrian Mutu punished them with two second-half goals.

At least, he would have had two goals if the Italians were not quite so tediously literal-minded about giving credit where it is due. His first goal came from a deflected shot, so it will be recorded as a Giuseppe Favalli own goal.

Meanwhile, Juventus recovered from 2-0 down to save a point at San Siro. Massimo Ambrosini and Andriy Shevchenko scored goals two minutes apart around the hour mark, but David Trezeguet began the Juventus fightback six minutes later and substitute Antonio Conte scored in injury time to earn the draw.

Udinese, who beat Internazionale 3-0 with the help of two penalties, and Atalanta, who won 2-0 at Bari with the help of two missed penalties, are level with Juve on seven points.

Atalanta's two wins have both come away from home. Fausto Rossini and Nicola Ventola scored their goals before Davide Pinato saved two Daniel Andersson penalties in the space of five minutes.

Inter's problems were made clear to their new coach Marco Tardelli, if they were not already. It was their second defeat in three games.

Reggina, who beat them on the opening day of the season, have lost twice since. On Sunday they went down 1-0 at home to Lecce. Cristiano Lucarelli earned and converted the 35th-minute penalty kick that gave the visitors their first win of the season.

And Napoli are even worse off. They lost for the third time - 5-1 at home to Bolgna. Beppe Signori scored two second-half goals.

webTitle: Fire and fury in Middle Eastern front pages

fields.headline: Fire and fury in Middle Eastern front pages
fields.trailText: As Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak calls for a 'time-out' from the peace process, Derek Brown looks at the reaction to the continuing violence in the Middle Eastern media.
fields.body:
With the front pages still full of fire and fury, there is a rising swell of commentary and analysis in the regional media. Unfortunately, the analysts are almost as bitterly divided as the young men risking their lives on the battered streets.

Hanan Ashrawi, the redoubtable former chief Palestinian negotiator, has a hard hitting piece on the Arab Media Internet Network website, in which she bitterly accuses Israel of institutionalised racism: "The most basic form of deception is in fabricating a false symmetry between occupier and occupied, between oppressor and victim. The 'violence' of the powerful Israeli occupation army using live ammunition, tanks and helicopter gun ships is (at best) equated with the 'violence' of Palestinian civilians protesting their victimization and continued loss of rights, lands, and lives."

Another website, Arabia.com, carries a long and thoughtful piece by US commentator Danny Schechter on media perceptions - and distortions - of the conflict: "If you read or watch American media, you'd think that the conflict between the Israelis and the Palestinians is a battle between opposing armies, ordered by Yasser Arafat to scuttle the peace process. And once again the issue has been framed as Arab versus Jew, with the substantial and vocal peace movement in Israel overlooked and Palestinians referred to as rock throwers and fanatics."

The Khaleej Times in the United Arab Emirates welcomes the final statement from the weekend Arab summit in Cairo: "The final communique of the Arab League summit in Cairo is proof, if any further was needed, that the Palestinian people are not alone at this critical moment in their struggle for self-determination. The statement is at once a tribute to the sacrifices of the Palestinian Arab martyrs and a warning to Israel that the cost of its heavy-handed policy will not be inconsiderable. Already Arab states that had established nominal links with Israel in the wake of the Oslo accord have moved to downgrade their diplomatic and commercial relations."

Going back to the other end of the regional telescope, the Jerusalem Post ridicules the Arab summit: "It must be great to be an Arab leader. With straight faces, Arab heads of state gathered in Cairo to label Israeli actions as 'barbaric,' when Israel acted with more restraint than most democracies would have, let alone how most of them have acted against lesser threats to their security. At the same time, being against launching an all-out war against Israel is enough to qualify an Arab leader with full membership in the 'moderate' camp."

The less strident Ha'aretz is calling for a thorough independent inquiry into the killing by security forces of 10 Israeli Arabs (they call themselves Palestinians who live in Israel) during the first waves of disturbances. It notes that the government may prefer a low-key inquiry, but says that only a high-level, legally-empowered commission of inquiry would have the full investigative powers necessary, as well as prestige for, and public confidence in, its work and its conclusions. However, the paper does not suggest any investigation of the 100-plus Palestinian deaths so far.

webTitle: Martin on course to win Speakership

fields.headline: Martin on course to win Speakership
fields.standfirst:
• Martin set to win crucial vote
• Sir George Young, Gwyneth Dunwoody, Alan Beith among defeated
• Heath rules out reform of system.
fields.trailText: Labour MP Michael Martin looks set to succeed Betty Boothroyd as Speaker of the House of Commons after his main rival, Sir George Young, was rejected by 317 to 241 votes.
fields.body:
Labour MP Michael Martin looks set to succeed Betty Boothroyd as Speaker of the House of Commons after his main rival, Sir George Young, was rejected by 317 to 241 votes.

Confirmation of Mr Martin's victory will come later this evening when the House completes debating the remaining candidates. None are thought likely to overtake Mr Martin.

Earlier, Gywneth Dunwoody joined the list of candidates ruled out of the contest. She was defeated by 341 votes to 170. Liberal Democrat MP Alan Beith was rejected by 409 votes to 83 and one of the current deputy speakers, Sir Alan Haselhurst, by 345 votes to 140.

Opening the debate, the father of the House, Sir Edward Heath, presiding over the election, angered MPs by insisting that the chamber uses the existing electoral system, which has come in for widespread criticism.

He explained that he believed his powers did not extend to changing the system. But he expressed "sympathy" for the views of the many MPs who have asked for reform.

Conservative MP Andrew Tyrie claimed there was a majority for a change in the rules. "We make our own rules in this House," he argued.

Former education minister Gillian Shephard said the "unprecedented number of contenders for the Speakership" justified a change.

Many MPs backed a two-stage system, proposed by Tony Benn before the contest got under way. They pressed for Sir Edward to allow a vote on whether or not to use it, but he refused.

However, Sir Edward did announce the order in which possible Speakers would be nominated, as follows: Michael Martin, Sir Alan Haselhurst, Alan Beith, Gwyneth Dunwoody, Sir George Young, Menzies Campbell, David Clark, Nicholas Winterton, John McWilliam, Michael Lord, Sir Patrick Cormack, Richard Shepherd.

fields.headline: 'Pump and dump' boy is unrepentant
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Net news
fields.trailText: A 16-year-old American who made hundreds of thousands of dollars by using internet bulletin boards to manipulate the price of shares he owned has said he does not think there is anything wrong with the practice.
fields.body:
A 16-year-old American who made hundreds of thousands of dollars by using internet bulletin boards to manipulate the price of shares he owned has said he does not think there is anything wrong with the practice.

Jonathan Lebed, who lives in New Jersey, bought his parents a $40,000 Mercedes car after surrendering $285,000 in profits from the scam and promising the securities and exchange commission that he would not do it again.

Jonathan, who is not old enough to smoke or drive legally, earlier this year became the youngest person to be charged with illegal stock dealing. Last month he agreed to hand over $285,000 to the SEC to settle civil charges that he fraudulently committed stock deals that netted him about $800,000 over a two-year period.

"Yes [I manipulated stocks], but I wasn't doing anything wrong ... I wasn't posting any false information," Jonathan told CBS's 60 Minutes in his first interview last night.

Jonathan told the programme how he made a fortune from "pumping and dumping" shares. That involves buying a stock, tipping it in internet chat rooms and selling when the price rises.

However, he said he was merely highlighting a number of undervalued companies "that would be worth a lot more if everybody knew about it".

SEC chairman Arthur Levitt saw it differently. Jonathan, he said, "used fictitious names. The purpose... was not to help investors... but rather to line his own pockets as soon as he hyped the price of the stock."

Jonathan's father Greg was proud of his son's gains. "He earned it. He did a lot of work. He didn't sit behind a garage smoking pot, or stealing wheels off a car."

fields.headline: Figo of hate
fields.standfirst: Barcelona gained some restitution for the loss of Luis Figo by beating Real Madrid 2-0 in the needle match with extra needle.
fields.trailText: So the whistle hand-out wasn't just a rumour. Nor were the websites, the placards, or the 10,000-peseta notes emblazoned with the Judas face and pesetero (money-grabber). And if you looked hard enough some of these notes were genuine - 150 of them in fact, courtesy of a Catalan businessman. Legal tender or not, they're not likely to be accepted down the Ramblas.
fields.body:
So the whistle hand-out wasn't just a rumour. Nor were the websites, the placards, or the 10,000-peseta notes emblazoned with the Judas face and pesetero (money-grabber). And if you looked hard enough some of these notes were genuine - 150 of them in fact, courtesy of a Catalan businessman. Legal tender or not, they're not likely to be accepted down the Ramblas.

The culés certainly know how to welcome back their loved ones. The two worst hours in the life of Michael Laudrup - a man who also made the trip from Camp Nou to Bernabéu - were a doddle compared to what Luis Figo went through on Saturday night. The Portuguese international was greeted with a deafening cacophony of whistles and boos every time he touched the ball.

It could have been worse, too. The World's Most Expensive Player normally takes Real Madrid's corners. Not this time, though. Not once. The reason, said Vicente Del Bosque, was to prevent the flow of the game from "being interrupted". He was probably right: when Figo chased a ball into the corner midway through the second half, the "lying mercenary" was met with a hail of oranges, bottles, cigarette lighters and even a couple of mobile phones. No one has questioned this. No one ever does. It's normal for Spanish fans to hurl more than just abuse.

In the midst of all the noise and the Figo-baiting - not exactly discouraged by Barca president Joan Gaspart - there was a football match going on. Despite a decent start, Real Madrid always looked like coming off second best. And so it proved with goals from Luis Enrique and Simão. The two goalscorers, plus Rivaldo and Philip Cocu, were far too good for Madrid's brand new midfield, which sorely lacked the fluidity of the Redondo-McManaman-Ral trio that so decisively saw off Man Utd and Valencia in last year's Champions League.

Once the dust settled Luis Figo, engaging in classic footballer-speak, claimed that the only thing that "upset and hurt" him was the result. Real president Florentino Pérez was singing from a different hymn sheet though, announcing that the "atmosphere got to us all". Del Bosque was just a wee bit stroppy, claiming that Gaspart had tried to "destabilise" Real Madrid. "If we were to do the same," promised The Man in the Moustache in threatening mode, the Barcelona players "wouldn't even be able to leave the house".

With all this going on, who cares about all the weekend's other games? Well, Real Oviedo and Valencia fans will for a start. Mighty Oviedo managed to see off potential league leaders Celta Vigo on Sunday with a sensational 3-1 victory. And there were two goals for returning hero Oli - who signed Betis for £5m a few seasons ago and promptly disappeared off the face of the earth. A bit like Denilson. Celta boss Victor Fernández bemoaned the limitations on substitutes, announcing that he would have made "11 changes in the first half if I could have".

With Celta's surprise defeat, Valencia went top for the first time in seven years after a 1-0 win over Zaragoza. It seems Didier Deschamps is not just a water-carrier but a tactical genius to boot. Zaragoza succeeded in frustrating Valencia before Deschamps had a brainwave. "I told the players to give it to Mendieta," the Frenchman explained. And so they did. Carboni's cross was finished off by the captain just when it looked dangerously like finishing 0-0. Inspired. It could have been more, too, had top scorer Juan Sánchez not seen his 88th-minute penalty saved.

The defeat saw Zaragoza slip to the bottom of the table. They do seem to be missing Savo Milosevic. No, really.

Meanwhile, Rayo Vallecano officially became Madrid's best side (again), moving into second after a 4-2 win over Real Sociedad. Athletic Bilbao capitulated 3-0 to Las Palmas in a pretty empty San Mames and Osasuna drew at Valladolid, while there were home victories for Alavés (1-0), Málaga (2-1) and Racing (4-2) against Espanyol, Villarreal and Numancia respectively.

webTitle: £11.5m for life and physical sciences research

fields.headline: £11.5m for life and physical sciences research
fields.trailText: Academics working in areas where the life sciences link with the engineering and physical sciences are being urged to apply for up to £11.5m of research grants being allocated for the coming year.
fields.body:
Academics working in areas where the life sciences link with the engineering and physical sciences are being urged to apply for up to £11.5m of research grants being allocated for the coming year.

Reflecting the government's increasing focus on the biological sciences - particularly the development of medical applications from the latest genome research - the engineering and physical sciences research council has taken the unusual step of publicly soliciting more grant proposals.

Research combining the expertise from traditional disciplines like physics, chemistry, mathematics and computing along with the emerging fields of genetics and biomolecular sciences is seen as one of the most dynamic areas of science over the next decade. Bioinformaticians - who apply computing techniques to organise and understand vast databases of genetic information - are already in high demand, for example.

But the government's research councils have found it difficult to get academics to work outside their traditional disciplines, and be aware of developments elsewhere.

Under its life sciences interface programme, the ESPRC is calling for research proposals that cover the engineering and physical sciences as well as the life sciences. The programme's budget in 1999-2000 was £11.5m, and is expected to rise in future years.

The council says that researchers can apply for all types of grants under the scheme. These range from project grants worth about £180,000 over three years, to awards for entire interdisciplinary units, sometimes costing more than £1m.

Proposals are welcome throughout the year.

For more information see epsrc.ac.uk

webTitle: Barak's talks with Israeli hawks flounder

fields.headline: Barak's talks with Israeli hawks flounder
fields.trailText: Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak's plans for a unity coalition faltered today, as talks with the leader of the hawkish opposition, Ariel Sharon, on the terms for joining his tottering government broke down.
fields.body:
Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak's plans for a unity coalition faltered today, as talks with the leader of the hawkish opposition, Ariel Sharon, on the terms for joining his tottering government broke down.

Further talks are expected, according to an official of the opposition Likud party.

"The paper (Barak presented) was unacceptable, but we are going to hold another meeting in 30 hours," Silvan Shalom announced, as clashes continued in the crisis-riven area.

Mr Shalom said that Likud wanted Mr Barak's agreement to give it "real influence" in the "diplomatic process" - which is understood to mean having substantial involvement in any future peace dealings with the Palestinians.

If talks are successful and a coalition is formed, it could freeze Middle East peace negotiations for many months.

The start of the formal coalition contacts came a day after the prime minister announced that Israel was taking "time out" from peace talks, to the chagrin of US President Bill Clinton and dovish members of Mr Barak's centre-left government.

Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat riposted by saying Barak could "go to hell".

In the West Bank town of Nablus, two Palestinian teenagers, aged 15 and 17, died today after being shot in the head during earlier clashes with Israeli troops. The deaths brought to 123 the number of people killed in 26 days of fighting. All but eight of those killed have been Arabs.

Israeli troops and Palestinian militants traded gunfire in the main street of Hebron, an almost daily event. Palestinian stone throwers also clashed with Israeli soldiers at two trouble spots in the Gaza strip, with 36 Palestinians wounded overall, according to hospital doctors.

In the West Bank town of Bethlehem, protesters spray-painted a donkey to resemble the Israeli flag, and tied up the animal in the street where rock throwers and soldiers clashed. The protesters also painted the names of Mr Barak and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak on the donkey.

With no letup in the confrontations, the Israelis clamped down on several Palestinian areas.

The Israelis again closed the Palestinian airport in Gaza City, further restricting Palestinian travel. "We consider this as another step in the hard siege on the Palestinian people," said Salman Abu Halib, general director of Palestinian Airlines.

Separately, the Israeli army imposed a blockade on Beit Jalla, a Palestinian town from which Palestinian gunmen have been shooting at the Jewish district of Gilo on the southern outskirts of Jerusalem.

Last night, Israel responded to the shooting with missiles and tank-mounted machine-gun fire. Beit Jalla and nearby Bethlehem were plunged in darkness, a Beit Jalla factory was destroyed and several homes damaged.

One rocket hit a children's bedroom in the home of the Nazal family in Beit Jalla. Sohana Nazal said moments earlier she had moved her children, George, 3, and Ghada, 2, from the room because it faces Israeli tanks on a nearby hill.

"We heard a loud crash. We thought it [the rocket] had landed on the street. Only when we opened the door to their room and saw all the smoke did we realise what had happened," Mrs Nazal said.

Hundreds of civilians have fled Beit Jalla and the nearby Aida refugee camp.

The Israeli army chief of staff, Lt Gen Shaul Mofaz, said life for the residents of Beit Jalla could only return to normal if the shooting from the Palestinian side stopped. "If they make it impossible to conduct a normal life on the Israeli side, I do not think we can tolerate such a situation," Mr Mofaz told Israel radio.

Mr Barak today launched formal talks to broaden his coalition, which at present controls only 30 seats in the 120-member legislature. Parliament returns from summer recess on Sunday. If Mr Barak fails to bring opposition leader Ariel Sharon and his Likud party into the government, early elections appear inevitable.

Mr Barak and his negotiators were to meet separately today with Mr Sharon as well as representatives from the ultra-Orthodox Shas party and the dovish Meretz factions, both former coalition members.

Mr Sharon has said he would not join the government unless Mr Barak distanced himself from concessions he offered the Palestinians during the Middle East summit at Camp David in the US in July.

At the time, Mr Barak was ready to give the Palestinians more than 90% of the West Bank, as well as control over parts of traditionally Arab east Jerusalem.

Critics said Mr Sharon's presence in the government would dim hopes for peace.

"I think a national unity government...would make the prospect of peace more distant and undermine the belief in the world that we really do want to make peace," said Justice Minister Yossi Beilin of Mr Barak's One Israel alignment.

"If Sharon has the right to veto peace negotiations, I will not be able to sit in it [the government]," said Mr Beilin, a key player in previous interim accords.

fields.headline: Manager, Chairman, and Uberchairman
fields.trailText: THE QUIET MAN
fields.body:
THE QUIET MAN

When Kelvin Koogan was given the England manager's job and immediately began to babble incoherently like a four-year-old full of cheap undiluted orange squash, the Fiver knew nothing good would come of the appointment. So you can imagine our relief when Peter Taylor opened his mouth after being put in charge of England for the upcoming friendly with Italy. There was no wide-eyed over-excitement, not a word of heart-on-sleeve jingoism, and as for cheesy self-deprecation spewing through a gormless grin ... well, you can forget it.

"The FA have given me the task of picking the team and I am happy with that responsibility," a level-headed and businesslike Taylor quietly announced. "Leicester are very happy for me to take charge of England for this one match and it will not affect my work at Filbert Street," he continued, before serenely floating back up the M1 to the midlands.

Not that Taylor is any less ambitious than his idiotic predecessor, mind you. "I will be looking to do my best and give the FA food for thought," he admitted to the London Evening Standard. "It is for one match only at this stage and after that, we will see what happens. My philosophy has to be to make the most of my opportunity. It has come very quickly but I am relishing the chance to work with the country's best players." So if things go well, the FA could decide to make their caretaker permanent - after all, there's a precedent. But if that's going to happen, please God don't let Paul Scholes put three past Francesco Toldo.

AXE MARKS THE SPOT

Bradford chairman Geoffrey "Zippy" Richmond may sound like a character from kids TV show Rainbow, but there was nothing remotely cuddly about his warning to manager Chris Hutchings today. "Clearly if results don't improve then appropriate action will be taken," said Richmond, sharpening a Dean Windass-sized axe. And just in case there was anyone out there wondering whether "appropriate action" might mean sending Benito Carbone and Dan Petrescu to a motivational seminar, they were soon set straight.

"We are having a bad time at the moment on the pitch," explained Richmond. "We find ourselves 19th in the table and have only scored four league goals this season. Yesterday I had a two-hour meeting with Chris Hutchings to discuss the situation. I made it clear that we need an improvement with immediate effect. I also made it clear that time was not on his side." Oo-er. Yet Richmond is clearly a benevolent man, asking the fans who booed Hutchings on Saturday to "trust my judgment whilst Chris is given the opportunity to put things right".

In fact, Richmond's harshest words were reserved for the supporters themselves. "It is perhaps worth reminding our new supporters that in 1994 we were mid-table in the Second Division, with an average attendance of 5,000," he thundered. "Indeed, I can remember my first home game, which was against Hartlepool." And if the memory of playing the monkey-hangers wasn't enough to shame Bradford fans to their senses, Richmond then offered anyone who has a ticket for next Sunday's game against Leeds their money back if they feel that they cannot support the team. "I believe that many of you should take a reality check," he ranted at the doubters, with - let's be honest - some justification.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If you stand still eventually you will end up going backwards" - Homespun philosophy from WBA manager Gary Megson, who is trying to persuade his chairman to give him some of the £3m windfall he received from Ugo Ehiogu's move to Middlesbrough.

RUTH(LESS) ELLIS

Say what you like about Aston Villa chairman Doug Ellis - actually, this country has libel laws, so forget that - but he knows his football. Only 24 hours after John Gregory's entertainers scraped and hoofed their way to a coma-inducing 0-0 draw at home to Sunderland, knowledgeable Doug has come to the conclusion that his club need to sign a new player. A striker, in fact.

"People don't have to tell me that we need someone that can knock a ball in the net consistently," said the man who brought the glory days to Villa Park in the early Eighties (by leaving). "No one needs to point that out to me. I don't want to complain about the existing players, and I won't. But John Gregory and his scouts are scouring many countries to find a new striker."

fields.bodyText: THE QUIET MAN When Kelvin Koogan was given the England manager's job and immediately began to babble incoherently like a four-year-old full of cheap undiluted orange squash, the Fiver knew nothing good would come of the appointment. So you can imagine our relief when Peter Taylor opened his mouth after being put in charge of England for the upcoming friendly with Italy. There was no wide-eyed over-excitement, not a word of heart-on-sleeve jingoism, and as for cheesy self-deprecation spewing through a gormless grin ... well, you can forget it. "Leicester are very happy for me to take charge of England for this one match and it will not affect my work at Filbert Street," he continued, before serenely floating back up the M1 to the midlands. fields.headline: Media Monkey's Diary
fields.body:
* Monkey is glad to report that after a meeting last week between Peter Bazalgette and Tim Gardam, Channel 4's director of programmes, a second series of Big Brother is definitely coming next year - and the format is staying the same, as Bazalgette wanted. (As he says, you don't change Changing Rooms from one series to the next.) The big challenge, says Gardam, is to get the casting right. I think we can trust Baz with that one.

* Who is going to take over from Matthew Bannister as Greg Dyke's director of marketing? Hot money is on Jim Hytner, marketing director of Channel 5 and before that a key Sky executive. The brother of film director Nicholas is a good friend of Dyke's - they worked together at Channel 5. Rumours that Sue Farr, who lost out to Bannister, might return to the Beeb are wide of the mark. Dyke offended her when he offered to "write her a good reference any time she wanted one", explains a friend. And she's holding out for a chief executive role, or something with international scope.

* Yet another humiliation for poor Jeremy Bowen, the normally flak-jacketed hack improbably parked on Sophie Raworth's sofa in BBC1's relaunched breakfast show. "Sophie gets back pain because she's younger," the show's doctor informed him last week, "but the reason you're OK is that the risk is reduced for over-45s." Rising slightly from his customary horizontal position, the greying reporter told her curtly, "I am 40."

* Is business a little slow for ex-TV presenter Noel Edmonds since the ending of his generous BBC contract? Monkey only asks because word has gone out that the bearded one is actively out in the market approaching anyone who might be interested in buying his 50% shareholding in the flabbily passé Mr Blobby. Perhaps it's all down to the increasing price of the fuel needed to propel Noel's private helicopter.

* Upheaval in the world of music PR, where Barbara Sharone - spin doctor at Warner Europe for a decade - is quitting to set up her own outfit. Luckily for Warner, she's not taking anyone major with her: just Madonna, REM, Mick Hucknall, William Orbit, Eliza Carthy...

 Email the Monkey at monkey@mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: Beatle crushed by Antiques Roadshow
fields.trailText: Overnights: It should have been another number one for former Beatles Sir Paul McCartney on ITV, but Michael Aspel's Antiques Roadshow on BBC! beat ITV's much hyped Stars and their Lives in the ratings.
fields.body:
It was a choice between two antiques - a couple of 18th century miniatures on BBC1 and a close-up of a music icon in a lingering kiss with his girlfriend on ITV.

And by all expectations it should have been another number one for Beatles legend Sir Paul McCartney.

But on the night Michael Aspel proved the more popular of the two, with Sunday night's Antiques Roadshow on BBC1 beating ITV's much hyped Stars and their Lives in the ratings.

Sir Paul's much-hyped appearance on the Carol Vorderman show was watched by an average of 6.6m viewers compared with 7.8m for Aspel

The former Beatle surprised Ms Mills, who was appearing on the Carol Vorderman-presented show to talk about her work for landmine charities, by turning up in the studio on the day of recording.

His admission that he he loved Ms Mills created a massive hype for the show, which mustered a mere 29% share.

The disappointing share prove the might of Antiques Roadshow. ITV struggles to beat the show and famously had to move Coronation Street in the schedule when it first launched on Sunday nights.

Stars and their Lives averaged 6.6m and a 29% share from 6.50-7.30pm - less than the previous week, when it took 7.5m.

Antiques Roadshow, which has just added Mr Aspel to its presenting team, started five minutes earlier and averaged 7.8m and a 34% share.

Panorama continued its ratings slide in the second week since the BBC1 current affairs flagship moved from its regular Monday night berth, shedding a further million viewers last night.

Last night's edition of Panorama, Digging the Dirt, which tackled the admittedly unsexy subject of the US presidential election, averaged just 2.2m and a 13% share. The previous week Panorama had averaged 3.2m on its 10.15pm Sunday night debut; while the final Monday night edition, on the Omagh bombing, had 4.2m and a 23% share.

The current affairs show lost out to ITV's Tarrant on TV repeat, which had 6.2m from 10pm, and its main news bulletin, which averaged 4.6m from 10.30pm.

Earlier in the evening, Heartbeat returned to ITV for a new series and comfortably beat a Casualty Sunday night special. The rural police drama averaged 11.5m and a 45% share from 8pm. Casualty could raise only 6.4m and a 25% share from 8.10pm, despite boasting guest appearances from Jenny Seagrove and Beverley Callard (Coronation Street's Liz McDonald).

fields.headline: M&S gets new concept right
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer will today announce that it has stepped up its store refurbishment programme and is opening five more new-look outlets including one at the huge Bluewater shopping centre in Kent.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer will today announce that it has stepped up its store refurbishment programme and is opening five more new-look outlets including one at the huge Bluewater shopping centre in Kent.

The ailing retailer, which is fighting to win back customers, will reveal plans to have 25 "concept" outlets in operation by the middle of next month, with five selling its new designer menswear collection.

The Autograph range for men, put together by leading fashion designers such as Katharine Hamnett and Timothy Everest, will be available in specially designed areas of the five stores including Bluewater and M&S's flagship Marble Arch store. M&S chairman Luc Vandevelde is also expected to announce plans for three new lingerie-only outlets in continental Europe and say that the first of its three factory outlets will open in Ashford, Kent, on November 2.

News of the initiatives comes as M&S reviews the future of its £3bn property portfolio, in particular the viability of its smaller stores format. Senior M&S managers are already said to have concluded that around 40 of its smaller outlets should be closed in what would be the group's first wholesale closure programme in more than 10 years. An announcement is not expected until interim results are reported in November.

M&S launched the first of its concept stores in May, after a lengthy market research programme. So far the five concept stores have been the stand-out performers. M&S say the five have produced sales increases averaging 16%.

Investors will be hoping news of the accelerated refurbishment plan will improve sentiment toward the retailer. On Friday, M&S shares closed at 170p - an 11-year closing low.

webTitle: Spice statistics spell the end for the Girls

fields.headline: Spice statistics spell the end for the Girls
fields.standfirst: The new Spice Girls single, Holler, is released today, tipped for the top of the charts. But where do you go, asks Caroline Sullivan, when you've broken all the records already?
fields.trailText: Analysis:The new Spice Girls single, Holler, is released today, tipped for the top of the charts. But where do you go, asks Caroline Sullivan, when you've broken all the records already?
fields.body:
The Spice Girls' first new single in two years, Holler, is out today and, you'll be unsurprised to learn, is tipped to be their ninth number one. That should earn them another platinum disc to cram on to the mantelpiece along with all the awards for their 55m (that's not a misprint) previous sales.

But Spice statistics have become meaningless - they've broken so many records, become so much a part of the fixtures and fittings of popular culture that another number one single doesn't mean much anymore. And when a band gets to that stage, it's time to go.

Despite being tarted up with a coat of R&B emulsion (complete with a black male backing vocalist muttering what sounds like "that's another Gucci handbag for you, Posh smart thinking with that new feminine haircut, Sporty"), Holler already feels like an anticlimax.

The natural progression of husbands and solo careers has eroded the original gang mentality that made them so appealing, and it's obvious that their hearts are no longer in the girl-power thing. Mel C hit the nail on the head last year when she remarked, "The Spice Girls are more like a hobby now."

That's borne out by Holler's sleeve photo of the four Girls - who are clearly not girls these days but grown-up post-partum women - dressed in Dynasty glitzwear and smiling gamely. They look not like a group but four strangers who happened to find themselves in front of the same photographer.

And what's with the evening gowns? There's nothing like brocade to add 15 years and 15 pounds. The difference between their current grande dame look and that of 1996, when they could only afford kit from Top Shop, speaks volumes about where they're at.

The pop revolution instigated by the Spices - which, according to George Michael, writing in yesterday's Times, has precipitated a cultural decline - has left the Girls themselves behind. There are younger wannabes unencumbered by personal and professional baggage snapping at their heels right now, and Emma, Victoria and the Mels now find themselves in the peculiar position of being old-timers in a scene that doesn't respect longevity.

In the natural way of pop culture, their moment - glorious though it was - has passed.

webTitle: John O'Farrell: from TV to books

fields.headline: Why I'm now a book man
fields.standfirst:
From Spitting Image to Have I Got News For You, for years he wrote jokes for other people. Now he's doing it for himself. New-found novelist John O'Farrell reflects on the transition from TV to the page
Read the first chapter of The Best A Man Can Get
fields.trailText: I had been earning my living from writing for about ten years before I wrote my first book, and up until then it had always been very easy to blame someone else when a piece of writing didn't work. "That was a really funny sketch when we wrote it, but the actors got it all wrong..."
fields.body:
I had been earning my living from writing for about ten years before I wrote my first book, and up until then it had always been very easy to blame someone else when a piece of writing didn't work. "That was a really funny sketch when we wrote it, but the actors got it all wrong" or "We couldn't use the best take of that scene as there was a boom microphone in shot."

On Spitting Image we could blame the foam puppets, on Chicken Run we could blame a lump of plasticine, but with a book what you write is what the reader gets. And so when Things Can Only Get Better was published I suddenly felt very exposed. If people hated it, what was I to say? "Yeah well, it's not my fault - the font was all wrong."

If novels were produced in the same haphazard way that television programmes are made, then paperbacks would come out with pages in the wrong order, words changing size in mid-sentence and paragraphs rewritten by everyone down to the bloke who does the typesetting.

Often the TV process can make a mediocre script better - although sometimes they will make a great script terrible - but only in a book will the final product be exactly as the writer intended. So I don't know what Jeffrey Archer's excuse is.

The book is such a perfect medium - it is the most direct means of communication that a writer can have. You engage with the reader in a far more intimate way than you can on screen or stage. You write a TV show that is apparently watched by millions of people, but a month later, no one can remember a thing about it.

But the few thousand that read your book have spent hours in your company (and in the case of my first book, they know all about the minor criminal activities of my youth). I was really flattered when one of the reps from the publishing company said my book made him cry - until I wondered if this was because he'd thought "I've got to try and sell this bloody thing into the bookshops."

What was also a revelation was how much more respected the author is than the TV writer. When I wrote gags for Have I Got News For You, everyone thought how funny Angus Deayton was. But when the jokes were in a book with my name on the cover, suddenly I found myself getting all the praise. It was a revelation.

The first time I went to my publishers people kept coming up to me and offering me cigarettes. Eventually I asked why this might be and my editor whispered: "We're not allowed to smoke unless the author does." So I accepted my first cigarette in years and everyone in the room lit up at exactly the same time.

I had been seduced by the flattering world of books and when I was asked if I would be interested in attempting a novel I readily said yes. Then I was approached about doing a TV adaptation of Things Can Only Get Better. So was I to spend the next six months in the world of books or stay in the world of TV? The path was clear - I rang up the TV company and said: "Yes - I think a TV adaptation is a great idea. But there's one condition. Get someone else to write it."
