I had been seduced by the flattering world of books and when I was asked if I would be interested in attempting a novel I readily said yes. Then I was approached about doing a TV adaptation of Things Can Only Get Better. So was I to spend the next six months in the world of books or stay in the world of TV? The path was clear - I rang up the TV company and said: "Yes - I think a TV adaptation is a great idea. But there's one condition. Get someone else to write it."

fields.headline: Herbie drives a bargain
fields.standfirst: The latest Beetle is packed with charm and character. And you save £2,000.  Pascal Wyse  loves it
fields.trailText: The latest Beetle is packed with charm and character. And you save £2,000. Pascal Wyse loves it.
fields.body:
In a world in which more and more cars look like they have been designed by someone taking a hairdryer to a block of soft cheese, the Beetle is a breath of fresh air. Among the bizarre mobile closets, family spaceships and executive aircraft on the road, it will invariably raise a smile of recognition. It's a smile that seems to be beamed back at you by the design, a simple collection of arcs and circles, bug eyes and a snub nose.

No wonder Hitler called it his "Strength-Through-Joy Car". His dream was that every member of his "workforce" should have a car - a Volksauto. The idea was quietly written off as absurd when he insisted they must be sold for under 1,000 Reichmarks (£85) but one engineer - a certain Dr Ferdinand Porsche - took up the challenge, partly because it coincided with his own ideas for an economy car. Workers paid for the car with a stamp system, accruing tokens that could eventually be swapped for a vehicle.

Production was temporarily halted by the second world war but by 1955 no fewer than a million Beetles had scuttled off the assembly line. German production of the original Beetle ended in 1978, but it is still manufactured in Mexico. So when VW radically updated the design a couple of years ago, giving those charming Herbie looks a no less charming turn-of-the-millennium makeover, it was religiously referred to as the New Beetle. The new addition to the range has a 1.6 engine instead of the 2-litre GTi, and does away with the alloy wheels and the air conditioning. More importantly, it costs £2,000 less.

The New Beetle has remained faithful to the vehicle's shape. It looks a little like an Audi TT that has been driven through a hall of mirrors, giving it a more dome-like roof without sacrificing that chunky, wide stance on the road, with arches that create the effect of oversized wheels. The two arcs meet to form the back, which is elegant, simple and looks like it belongs. (Why is it that so many cars look like they've left the garage with the wrong backside?)

But all of this is really a cosmetic memory of the original. Mechanically it is very different. The VW after-dinner joke about the woman who stops to help a fellow motorist, claiming she has a spare engine in the boot, is now gratifyingly extinct. Flip up the tailgate on the new one and you will discover that they kept everything so neat back there by assuming that you travel rather light.

It's quite difficult to comprehend that as you go nipping along the road because the expanse between the steering wheel and the windscreen stretching out towards the horizon could quite happily accommodate a small wedding reception. It's one of the pay-offs of being design-led, like the limited back seats. But for the driver it gives a feeling of being right in the middle of an oval shell, which in turn makes the handling feel immediate. Beetling along with enough room above your head for a fairly extensive afro, you almost expect the vehicle to be ungainly around corners, and to lean forward during braking. But there is very little hangover - it handles like a buggy. And all that room between you and the engine, plus the safety-conscious heavy doors, means good soundproofing. The time lag before acceleration when you hit the floor in second or third is understandably longer with the smaller engine, but it still feels unexpectedly responsive for its unaggressive, soft shaping.

Add the airbags, Conran-style handbrake, pretty displays, Electronic Stability Programme (which senses slipping and automatically corrects it by individually braking each wheel), sporty suspension, beverage whatnots and electrically heated this-that-and-the-other and you can see how far it has come from being a basic people's wagon.

One other distinguishing feature of the original Beetle has also gone: the ludicrous farmyard farting that used to herald its arrival. That indestructible plodder of an engine, which didn't so much rev as snore, has been replaced by VW's hugely successful 2-litre from the Golf GTi, or, in the latest model, the new 1.6.

And what's this? Just between the steering wheel and the dash there is a small plastic funnel. It won't hold a pen, a coffee, a map or a 20p. Maybe it's a valve to stick your lips round and blow up the airbags. The manual is having no jokes about this little homage to the car's hippy status in the Herbie films: "No articles should be kept in the vase when the vehicle is in motion. This could be a potential danger during a sudden braking manoeuvre as the contents of the vase could fly out and distract the driver from what is happening on the road." Just imagine getting a face full of daffodils when you switch on the air conditioning. Tricky.

But it's a little emblematic reminder that this is a car with character, and has managed to hang on to it while getting bang up to date. For some drivers, character is a bad word. Character equals frivolous. They want something that looks like a "serious bit of kit". But they can keep their motorised willies - this is much more fun.

The lowdown

Volkswagen Beetle 1.6

Price: £12,995

Acceleration: 0-62mph in 11.6 secs

Top speed: 111mph

Consumption: 36.7mpg (combined)

At the wheel: Bod

On the way to: Interflora

On the stereo: Herbie Hancock

webTitle: The Lib-Lab coalition that never was

fields.headline: The Lib-Lab coalition that never was
fields.standfirst: In the week that Paddy Ashdown's diaries are published, revealing how close Britain came to a Labour-Lib Dem coalition government, Julian Glover ponders, 'What if?'
fields.trailText: Analysis: In the week that Paddy Ashdown's diaries are published, revealing how close Britain came to a Labour-Lib Dem coalition government, Julian Glover ponders, 'What if?'
fields.body:
Only Tony Blair really knows how close Britain came to coalition government in May 1997. But Paddy Ashdown's diaries, published next week and currently being serialised in the Times, suggest it was very close indeed.

Ashdown claims that as Britain went to the polls on May 1 to evict the Conservatives, a public announcement that two Liberal Democrat MPs were to take their seats in Tony Blair's cabinet was being prepared. Had it happened, the effect of the announcement would have been akin to a detonation: it would have ripped apart both the old political order and all bets as to how the new one would shape up.

Of course it never happened. Daunted by the unexpected size of his parliamentary majority, Tony Blair extinguished the smouldering fuse of coalition as soon as the results came in. Paddy Ashdown watched as the leading place reserved for his party in government, the foreign secretary's job, went to Robin Cook and Lib Dem MPs took their places on the opposition side of the Commons. Politics as usual went on.

But what if it had not gone on? As things turned out, the private pre-election hyperbole of Blair and Ashdown crashed into electoral reality - but it is easy to imagine an election result which could have proved more congenial to their plans. A Labour majority of only, say, 40, would have given a powerful shove to the prime minister, aware that he had many more than 40 potential rebels on his backbenches. A less triumphant government would have seemed less daunting to Liberal Democrats, worried that their party's identity would be lost.

So imagine a coalition had been established. An obvious difference with today's politics would be the people dominating it. Menzies Campbell would almost certainly be a Liberal Democrat foreign secretary, rather than an outside bet to become Speaker. Alan Beith, another would-be Speaker, would also be a senior minister. Paddy Ashdown would still be the Liberal Democrat leader, though probably not in the government, while Charles Kennedy would have been free to spend more time at his Scottish croft. And John Prescott (if his threats are to be believed) would have resigned, to become a rebel on the backbenches, taunting his leader just as some purist Liberal Democrats would no doubt have taunted theirs.

In policy terms, the differences would be trickier to see. Welfare reform, the health service, education - all of them would have been run on much the same lines as today. Liberal Democrats like to think that the billions of pounds unleashed this year by Gordon Brown in his spending review would have been poured into essential services earlier. Perhaps, but Brown does not do the prime minister's bidding on such things, and certainly would not have done Paddy Ashdown's.

The big differences would have come on constitutional issues and the euro. Liberal Democrats in government would have been unwilling - even unable, given pressure from their party - to compromise on either the euro or a referendum on proportional representation.

PR first. Tony Blair would almost certainly have conceded a referendum on the issue. Had it been passed, the likely option, coalition government, would have become the norm in Westminster just as it has in Scotland and Wales. And coalition politics really would have changed Britain.

But had the electorate rejected PR, the coalition would have collapsed, the prime minister would have been threatened and William Hague would have been a very happy man.

Policy on the euro in a coalition might have made Hague happy, too. It is possible that in the bright days of mid-1997, Tony Blair might have announced a referendum on joining euroland and won it. If so, the country would now be preparing to adopt euro notes and coins in January 2002.

But had he shied from going to the people on the issue (as, in reality, he has) the euro would, surely, have split any coalition asunder. The Liberal Democrats would not have sat in office, content with Gordon Brown's decision to wait and see.

So a coalition would only have been the start. Two great hurdles - referendums on PR and the euro - would have put the Blair project to the test. Defeated on either, the prime minister might have lost everything. Victorious, he could claim his place in history. High stakes and a dangerous game, then; and of course with another election approaching, behind the scenes, round two might just be about to begin.

fields.headline: Norton promises to be nice
fields.trailText: 4pm: The new series of Channel 4's late night chat show, So Graham Norton, is cleaning up its act, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The new series of Channel 4's late night chat show, So Graham Norton, is cleaning up its act with the promise of a drastic cutback on sexual content.

Mr Norton admitted this week that the show couldn't impress viewers any more with crude innuendo. "We got bored with it. There's nowhere else to go unless you have couples actually making love on the carpet in front of you," he told the Radio Times.

Mr Norton's on-air antics have included visiting internet porn sites, telephoning people with sexually ambiguous names, chatting to a woman on a German sex line and a New Yorker who does housework in the nude. "It's not clever and we're not proud and it shouldn't be funny. We should have outgrown laughing at that sort of thing, but it's compulsive," he confessed.

He said that the show had been under pressure to be sexy because Eurotrash had previously occupied its time slot and it felt it needed to attract the same post-pub audience.

fields.headline: Sky targets women with Open Extra service
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Sky Digital's interactive TV service, Open, has launched its own department store called Open Extra. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Sky Digital's interactive TV service, Open, has launched its own department store called Open Extra to plug gaps in its retailer-branded offering.

The launch aims to add a layer of flexibility to the Open platform, enabling smaller and more specialist retailers to have a presence on the service for the first time.

Open Extra has already signed up around 35 goods providers, including Dorling Kindersley, Alton Towers, ThinkNatural.com, Ann Summers, the Jewellery Store and Ministry of Sound. In keeping with a department store philosophy, the store will be structured by sector, the first being 300 products aimed at women and their families.

Open Extra has signed up Prism Data Management to handle all deliveries, returns and customer services, with a price tag of £2.95 for post and packing. Details about how much it costs to sell products through Open Extra were not disclosed.

Ricardo Tejada, head of corporate communications at Open, said: "It's a major move for us and adds a new dimension to the service. Having complete editorial control over the service allows us to change things very quickly." He added that Open Extra allowed Open to be more flexible and tie in more promotions to Sky.

Open, which claims more than 1.1m homes use the service per week, is now 80.1% owned by BSkyB and the rest by BT.

fields.headline: Agency slams government NHS drive
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: A £2m drive to ease pressure on the NHS this winter will not solve the problem, says a Department of Health ad agency. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Labour's latest £2m advertising campaign aimed at easing the pressure on the NHS over the winter will not come close to solving the problem, according to one of the government's ad agencies.

The £1.75m "Get the right treatment" national press, poster and radio campaign launched today encourages people to use pharmacists and nurse helpline NHS Direct if they have colds or minor ailments, rather than go to their GP or local casualty department.

The campaign is part of a multimillion pound government initiative to avoid another NHS crisis this winter, but could waste £2m of tax-payers' money.

A senior source at one government ad agency said: "The winter problem is not something that can be solved by advertising. It's a matter of how many people get sick in relation to how many doctors and nurses are available to provide treatment."

"I can't believe this campaign will revolutionise the pressure on the NHS over the winter. If it is purely a reminder of the various options available to the public, it's misleading to say it will take the pressure off the NHS."

The government recently launched a national TV campaign, starring Sir Henry Cooper, to try to encourage more over-65s to take advantage of the free 'flu jab. The media spend on this campaign is £6m.

fields.headline: Tait steps up at Scotsman in readiness for Express success
fields.trailText: 8am: The Scotsman has promoted Stephen Tait to deputy managing director in readiness for a successful bid for the Express titles, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Scotsman has promoted its commercial manager, Stephen Tait, to deputy managing director in what insiders claim is a move by the paper's owners, the Barclay brothers, in readiness for developing the Express titles if their bid is successful.

Mr Tait will report to managing director Stephen Walker. Officially the Scotsman says his duties will cover a a range of marketing and circulation initiatives for the Scotsman, Scotland on Sunday and Sunday Business.

But insiders claim that the Barclays have earmarked Mr Tait for a managerial position if the bid by their company, Press Holdings, for the Express newspaper titles is successful.

So far Press Holdings is the only company to have put in an official bid - believed to be £75-100m - for the Express titles, comprising the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star. Last week the Express said in a statement that it had received a number of informal offers.

A £100m bid had been expected from the Hinduja Group, a UK firm owned by four billionaire Indian brothers with a range of media and utilities interests.

webTitle: Give the Crusader a fighting chance

fields.headline: Give the Crusader a fighting chance
fields.standfirst: On the press: Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: Through the smoke and behind the mirrors, can we really determine what's going to happen to Express Newspapers? The short answer, of course, is no. By Roy Greenslade.
fields.body:
Through the smoke and behind the mirrors, can we really determine what's going to happen to Express Newspapers? The short answer, of course, is no. With new bidders emerging almost every day and a seller remaining so economical with the truth it's impossible to divine intention or strategy, the outcome is anything but clear.

The only serious bid so far has been made by the Barclay brothers' Press Holdings company. But the decision of the Telegraph group to "have a look" at the Express is the first sign of genuine competition.

The Telegraph's involvement is entirely logical given that it and the Express's owner, United News & Media, jointly own West Ferry Printers, the only properly profitable bit of Express Newspapers. It is said to contribute at least £5m to the Express's annual profits. This 50-50 ownership is a massive headache for every other bidder because, under the terms of their agreement, United cannot sell its interest without offering it first to the Telegraph.

In confirming this arrangement, the Telegraph's deputy chairman, Dan Colson, indicated that it would definitely buy United's half. The price is fixed on a pre-set formula which makes it a sensible purchase.

West Ferry is probably Europe's, if not the world's, largest printing site and is immensely profitable. It prints both the Telegraphs, the three Express titles, the Financial Times, the Guardian and the Observer.

One of the most lucrative of these contracts, which run until 2009, is that for the Guardian. Last Wednesday the paper was equal in size to a 100-page broadsheet, prompting a Guardian executive to point out that West Ferry "must be making a fortune from us alone".

I understand that the Telegraph have found their United partners anything but helpful in the past few months as they seek decisions necessary to upgrade presses required urgently by the Daily Telegraph to improve its pagination. The problems have convinced Colson and chairman Conrad Black of the benefits of single ownership.

With the Telegraph and the Express also sharing distribution and newsprint-buying arrangements, it's natural that the Telegraph should be concerned about any change of Express ownership.

It's difficult to know what to make of claims that Gopi and Srichand Hinduja, two of four brothers from India who are always described as "being worth £1bn", have made a bid of £100m.

In the event of their winning a bidding war, there must be a question mark over their suitability for the office of fair trading to consider. All newspaper bids are referred and one major criterion is whether the bid is in the public interest.

Though the Hindujas have not been charged with any offence, India's central bureau of investigations has been looking into whether they played a part in the Bofors arms commission scandal. They may be right in dismissing the allegations as "all Indian politics", but they will need to swim clear of these muddy waters.

A referral to the OFT might also prove embarrassing to the government. Soon after the brothers donated £1m to save the faith zone in the Millennium Dome, they received British passports. These events may not be linked, of course, but we all need to know more about the Hindujas. Their public relations spokesman promised last week to provide me with their biographies, but none arrived.

It also emerged that the Hindujas know very little about British newspapers or, indeed, any newspapers. They have evidently been seeking someone with expertise in the industry and there was an unconfirmed report in yesterday's Sunday Times that they have been approached by another bid hopeful, David Montgomery, in order to make a joint approach.

Montgomery, the former chief executive of Mirror group who was ousted just before Trinity's takeover, certainly has a deep knowledge of newspapers. But his post-Maxwell stewardship of the Mirror titles was all about cutting costs in order to return the papers to profitability. There can't be much fat at the Express after its years under Clive Hollick and David Stevens before him. Both men tightened budgets, pruning to the bone.

What the papers require is massive investment, anything between £40m and £50m a year for at least four years, if they are to stand any chance in future. Without the £5m or so from West Ferry and a transfer payment from the papers' hived-off dot.com enterprise, Xilerate, of something like £3m, there is no profit stream from Express Newspapers.

They have stuck to their lasts, despite working under the worst conditions of any national newspaper in Britain. A Daily Star sub-editor claims that the very fact his paper comes out every day is "some kind of miracle".

For the once-proud Daily Express, the pain is greatest of all. There are still one or two journalists working there who can recall its glorious past. They don't necessarily approve of editor Rosie Boycott's transformation of the paper from right to left, but there is wide admiration for her spirit and determination, and a residue of sympathy for the way she is forced to operate in a kind of limbo with Hollick rarely speaking to her.

Journalists were disgusted by a memo sent last week in which Hollick sought to calm their fears about a takeover. They were quick to note that the same message was sent to his television staff not long before his TV companies were sold off. "He had merely substituted the word newspapers for TV," says one angry reporter. "Anyway, we need a new owner."

The apparent loss of enthusiasm for the papers by Hollick, United's chief executive, is difficult to understand. Similarly, City analysts are puzzled by his recent behaviour over offers for the papers.

Two weeks ago United's head of investor relations, Michael Waring, told the trade magazine, Press Gazette: "We are not in negotiations with the Barclays." That categorical denial was, to say the least, strange. Andrew Neil, the Barclays' publisher, had been provided with figures, had been in talks with Bernard Gray, United's director of group strategy, and had made a formal bid. No negotiations, Mr Waring? You must be joking.

webTitle: Struggling Barak reviews new barriers to peace

fields.headline: Struggling Barak reviews new barriers to peace
fields.standfirst: Israeli prime minsiter Ehud Barak is struggling for domestic political survival, and his latest suggestions for dealing with the Mid East peace crisis are a symptom of that, as Derek Brown explains
fields.trailText: Israeli prime minsiter Ehud Barak is struggling for domestic political survival, and his latest suggestions for dealing with the Mid East peace crisis are a symptom of that, as Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak has apparently softened his line on the crumbling Middle East peace process.

At the weekend, he talked of taking a "time out", suggesting that, for the time being at least, Israel's only dealings with its immediate neighbours would be through the smoking barrels of its soldiers' guns.

Now Barak is talking of "a review" of the stalled peace negotiation, which suggests that he might be preparing for a new round of diplomatic contacts with Yasser Arafat to defuse the crisis.

In reality, while fighting still rages along Israel's ill-defined border with Arafat's nascent statelet, Barak has little scope for manoeuvre.

His opinion poll ratings have plummeted, and there are rumbles of dissent from within his own political faction. When the Knesset (parliament) reconvenes next week, he could quickly be in terminal trouble.

In the short term, Barak desperately needs to shore up his coalition by including the hawkish Likud bloc in a government of national unity.

Likud leader Ariel Sharon would love to be back in the cabinet, but knows that his hardliners could desert him if he does a deal with the prime minister.

The Israeli public, thoroughly rattled by the prolonged savagery on its doorstep, is sick of the political argy-bargy. It wants action.

That is why Barak is now playing with the old, tired chestnut of 'unilateral separation': creating a fortified de-facto boundary round the Palestinian enclaves of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

It is a tactic not only flawed, but doomed. It has been tried many times before, and has always disintegrated when it came up against political and economic reality.

Firstly, after more than 30 years of occupation, the Palestinian territories are effectively an integral part - though a distinctly poor relation - of the Israeli economy.

To have any hope of survival, let alone development, they depend on Israeli infrastructure. And Israel, in its turn, has come to depend on cheap Palestinian labour.

Secondly, in the West Bank the Palestinian enclaves are cut off from each other. Sealing off each one would be a Herculean task, even for the formidable Israeli army, especially as it has simultaneously to defend the clutter of Jewish settlements in the territory.

And then there is the small matter of the chunk of Israel that separates the West Bank from the Gaza Strip. It is a measure of their desperation that - not for the first time - Israelis are talking of building a 28-mile elevated highway between the two territories, to literally get over the problem.

Thirdly, simply sealing off the Palestinians might make the problem disappear from sight, but it won't make that problem go away.

For a start, one-third of the three million Palestinians under Israeli rule, live in Israel itself. There they are known as Israeli Arabs, but the vast majority identify themselves as Palestinians - though they don't necessarily want to live in Arafat's dingy little statelet.

The greatest objection to unilateral separation - apart from it being inherently racist - is that it will not address, let alone solve, the issue at the core of the crisis.

That is, the definition of the status and the boundaries of the full-fledged Palestinian state that everyone knows is coming.

webTitle: CPS drops mistreatment case against headteacher

fields.headline: CPS drops mistreatment case against headteacher
fields.trailText: No further action will be taken against Welsh headteacher Marjorie Evans, who was recently cleared of slapping one of her pupils, police announced today.
fields.body:
No further action will be taken against Welsh headteacher Marjorie Evans, who was recently cleared of slapping one of her pupils, police announced today.

The crown prosecution service has decided not to pursue further allegations by staff that she mistreated pupils, although it is up to Monmouthshire county council to decide whether she can take up her job again.

"We have received advice from the CPS on further inquiries relating to St Mary's Junior School in Caldicot and, having discussed the evidence in full, the police and the CPS are in agreement that no further action should be taken," said chief inspector Nigel Russell. In July this year, a magistrate found Mrs Evans guilty of slapping a 10-year-old boy across the face, but the verdict was overturned on appeal at Cardiff crown court. She had hoped to return to her post at the school after the appeal, but the fresh allegations meant she continued to be suspended from her post.

Mr Evans, who repeatedly protested her innocence, told a press conference in Cardiff: "I feel relief and delight that the CPS has decided to take no further action against me. However I'm also angry that this whole episode has dragged on for a whole year. I thought this whole ordeal was over when I was cleared at Cardiff crown court." She added: "The last six weeks have been the most stressful weeks of my whole life. I was shocked and dumbfounded when I heard of the new allegations. It distresses me to think that anyone in the teaching profession could suffer the same ordeal as I have had to suffer." National Union of Teachers general secretary Doug McAvoy said in a statement: "The union is delighted that Marjorie Evans is not to face further prosecution. I hope this brings an end to the torment she has suffered for more than a year. There are lessons to be learned from the way this matter has been conducted. We hope they have been learned." New guidelines on how to deal with disruptive children were being distributed to union members this week, Mr McAvoy added.

webTitle: The ratings war: the prime movers

fields.headline: The ratings war: the prime movers
fields.trailText: In case there was any doubt, Lorraine Heggessey has confirmed that the new regime at the BBC will not tolerate poorly performing shows. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
In case there was any doubt, Lorraine Heggessey has confirmed that the new regime at BBC1 will not tolerate poorly performing shows. After just a week of the new schedule, the listings are being torn up as the new controller attempts to fulfil her pledge to make BBC1 as popular as ITV.

Hope and Glory

Lucy Gannon's sure touch has faltered with this cheesy Lenny Henry drama. After registering figures of 4.6m, 1m down on the first series, it is being moved to Sunday evenings.

Holby City

The cheap Casualty spin-off has slumped from 9m last series to 6.5m. Against Millionaire, it managed just 5.3m. It is being moved back an hour to go head to head with Fat Friends at 9pm.

Brotherly Love

The twee Scottish sitcom, struggling to scrape 5m viewers, is being shunted from its Friday 8.30pm slot to Sundays at 6.15pm.

Question Time

Moved from its traditional Thursday night home to 10.30pm Wednesdays - but at least has a regular slot now.

ITV has not been slow to join in the Beeb's game of musical schedules:

Cold Feet

The fourth series of this comedy-drama was postponed to make way for the vulnerable Ross Kemp series Without Motive, which moved to Sundays from Mondays to avoid a drubbing from BBC1's comedy double-bill.

Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?

ITV chief David Liddiment has again been using Millionaire as his principal sniper. It has been appearing more regularly on Mondays, Thursdays and Sundays, but at varying times. The weekend edition now switches to Saturdays in a bid to wear down Casualty.

News at When?

ITV inserted a news special at 9pm on the night of the Hatfield rail crash. It drew 8.5m viewers, but the network insists it was not a scheduling stunt.

webTitle: David Young in charge of BBC's light entertainment

fields.headline: He ain't heavy
fields.standfirst:
Plucked from independent production at the tender age of 32 and offered the run of the BBC's light entertainment output, David Young didn't disappoint. Maggie Brown meets him

Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Plucked from independent production at the tender age of 32 and offered the run of the BBC's light entertainment output, David Young didn't disappoint. Maggie Brown meets him.
fields.body:
While the launch of News at Ten marks Greg Dyke's biggest impact on the BBC so far, changes are under way in that trickiest of areas, light entertainment. Next Tuesday, The Weakest Link, the quiz show hosted by Anne Robinson, moves from BBC2 daytime to a prime mid-evening BBC1 slot.

Hailed by Peter Bazalgette as a "breakthrough" quiz version of his show Big Brother (contestants vote to throw a panellist off after each round), though it also owes something to Channel 4's Fifteen to One, its significance is that this is the first mainstream hit to come out of BBC light entertainment for some years.

Under John Birt, light entertainment was seen as a disaster area, and the in-house team was nicknamed Noel's House Party Productions. To some extent it is still iffy, the home of tacky stars - Jim Davidson - flashy sets, end of the pier variety ... and the Lottery. Eighteen months ago, in desperation and with the cupboard bare, the BBC hired a young turk working for Bazalgette, doubled his salary, installed him in Television Centre, and gave him the freedom to operate and be rewarded like a top independent producer.

David Young, at 32, is rebuilding the BBC's output. His clarion calls include: "Forget about the 11 O'Clock Show, think mainstream" and "don't be snooty about daytime". And instead of giving holidays as prizes, he's won the battle to offer big cash prizes on BBC1.

A fluent talker clad in a black Joseph suit, Young happily agrees he lacked experience when he came on board. He was hired because he had so many ideas in development and had this unstoppable entrepreneurial energy. Now he's got hits.

The BBC is, naturally, milking every drop from the novel experience of owning the rights to a show so hot it is moving to BBC1 (the champions from the BBC2 series will compete against each other). Kevin Lygo, Channel 4's head of entertainment, says: "It is strange and encouraging that the BBC can move so fast." The show is also being sold abroad (Germany and the US) along with another Young department hit format, Friends Like These (Holland, Belgium) in which teams of teenagers compete.

When the Weakest Link hits BBC1, the prize money is going up to £20,000, the highest ever offered by the channel - doubling the show's BBC2 limit. This reverses the policy contained in the BBC producers' guidelines, reissued by Dyke only last year, which encapsulate "BBC values and standards". Page 197 says: "Cash prizes should be avoided ... It is inappropriate to spend licence fee money on prizes of excessive value."

Young is endearingly frank: "We're always being told 'you can't do big money'. The Gen [Generation] Game gives away holidays, how much do they think they cost?" He shrugs: "Most producers' guidelines are so ambiguous - it's the controllers who say what you can do."

He's right, the guidelines also say: "Any proposal to offer a cash prize must be referred to the head of output and the controller must be informed."

Bazalgette, a former BBC producer, comments: "That's radical. A big story. This is prize money not funded by phone calls [as in Millionaire]. In my view, it's wholly admirable. Greg has thrown open the curtains at the BBC. Light entertainment was so bad, stale, turgid, it had to get better."

Lygo is doubtful though: "Is it right that the equivalent of all the licence fees from a small Oxford village should go to fund that? It's a bit off for the BBC. They have managed for years without big prizes."

Young has brought to the BBC a razor-sharp commercial edge, honed by nine years at Hat Trick, then Bazal. Poacher turned gamekeeper, he now aims to push back the independents who supply everything from Have I Got News For You to Star For a Night and Robot Wars.

He hails from Woking in Surrey, went to a comprehensive school and is the son of a gas engineer and social worker. At Bristol University ("the nice thing about it, it was very non-public school") he studied drama. He always wanted to work in television, and wangled his way into Hat Trick as runner while still a student. He almost didn't finish his degree, returning late with a month's sick note (faked asthma attack), only to have his tutor see his name on the credits of Clive Anderson Talks Back.

Denise O'Donoghue, the joint managing director of Hat Trick who hired him, says: "Age doesn't matter. We knew very early on that David was very creative, he had talent, flair, energy, imagination and determination. At the BBC he's built something from nothing, got them hit shows." Young had a big falling out with Hat Trick in 1997 over Whatever You Want, a show he devised. But because he had a share of the format potential, it gave him some breathing space.

Young eventually rang Peter Bazalgette ("I regard him as the guv'nor of ideas"), and went to see him: "He was the rudest person I'd ever been interviewed by, so cutting, he didn't really want me. He thought, 'He's only done one thing'." Young asked for a sizeable salary and shares in his productions because "I've always believed format creators should be rewarded. If you'd given away Millionaire it's like not signing the Beatles". When Paul Jackson (who said of him: "He has more ideas than my entire department"), outgoing BBC controller of entertainment, came calling to poach him from Bazal, Young was surprised but couldn't resist.

At the BBC, Young has introduced a permanent development team of six: "I've created a mini-Bazal. Imported his system. We pay them to sit and think up ideas. They're a fantastic team." He describes organised brainstorming session where nothing is unacceptable ("You don't criticise someone's ideas unless it's constructive").

"I believe there are lots of people who can execute programmes, but very few who can create them," he says. "When you find creative people, you need to pluck them out of production, pay them decently, and persuade them to sit in a development office and work on ideas." His head of development, Andy Culpin, who suggested Anne Robinson for The Weakest Link, came from Bazal ("Baz was furious") where he'd been a £300-a-week trainee.

"The agreement was I could come in, bring in a team. I didn't have to work with anyone here unless I wanted to. I found a complete and utter lack of ideas. Shocking. The wrong people were doing development, being paid thousands of pounds." One of his ideas team was leasing photocopiers when Young hired him; within six months he'd won a commission from BBC Choice for Simply Complicated - a competition to invent daft machines (for example, to spread jam on bread). It's coming to BBC1.

"As a viewer of the BBC I'd get quite angry, I like to see good ideas. It was all star vehicles. It was Jim [Davidson] does this, so-and-so does that." He applied exactly what he'd learned: "The idea is the star. Out of great formats like Have I Got News For You, Hat Trick have created huge TV stars, but the format comes first."

Young launches into a tragi-comic account of one star vehicle he gleefully junked. Called Thank You, it used the stars to go around ... thanking people! "But if you get the idea right the talent will come and more importantly they will stay. Agents are saying to me 'Show me the idea'. Look at Lulu and [the Saturday-night flop] Red Alert. You realise how damaging that can be for an artist's career if they front the wrong show."

In an analogy that's pure Bazalgette, he compares his team to "an ad agency - the channel controllers are the clients, we have to solve their problems". This was how The Weakest Link was devised. One of the team's trainees brought him the title after looking at hundreds of letters. Two outsiders, Dr Finton Coyle and Cathy Dunning, wrote in (and now gain fees for the concept).

His team "just batted it around" for months and months, arguing, testing it. "When we pitched it to [BBC daytime head] Jane Lush, it was flawed, we planned originally to run it over five days, with only a resolution at the end of that time - bad. The rounds were too long, 20 minutes at one point; now they're two and-a-half minutes and get 10 seconds less with each round," as nine contestants are whittled down to two. "Every show I do always has some reference to the penalty shoot out, the greatest ever endgame. You're gripped." Young flourishes a list of 23 pilots for new shows: "Trial and error, that's what I like at the BBC: just have a go."

He's hatched a deal with BBC Worldwide and they pay £50,000 towards the £200,000 cost of each new pilot. But the BBC will now co-produce new formats abroad, with an executive producer in control - so "we make more money" says Colin Jarvis, director of programming at BBC Worldwide. Young also pitches new pilots to channel controllers this way: "Buy four, get one free!" Key production creatives gain bonuses from sales.

Eighteen months ago, in desperation and with the cupboard bare, the BBC hired a young turk working for Bazalgette, doubled his salary, installed him in Television Centre, and gave him the freedom to operate and be rewarded like a top independent producer. David Young, at 32, is rebuilding the BBC's output. His clarion calls include: "Forget about the 11 O'Clock Show, think mainstream" and "don't be snooty about daytime". And instead of giving holidays as prizes, he's won the battle to offer big cash prizes on BBC1. A fluent talker clad in a black Joseph suit, Young happily agrees he lacked experience when he came on board. He was hired because he had so many ideas in development and had this unstoppable entrepreneurial energy. Now he's got hits. The BBC is, naturally, milking every drop from the novel experience of owning the rights to a show so hot it is moving to BBC1 (the champions from the BBC2 series will compete against each other). The show is also being sold abroad (Germany and the US) along with another Young department hit format, Friends Like These (Holland, Belgium) in which teams of teenagers compete. The Gen [Generation] Game gives away holidays, how much do they think they cost?" He shrugs: "Most producers' guidelines are so ambiguous - it's the controllers who say what you can do." He describes organised brainstorming session where nothing is unacceptable ("You don't criticise someone's ideas unless it's constructive"). "I believe there are lots of people who can execute programmes, but very few who can create them," he says. "When you find creative people, you need to pluck them out of production, pay them decently, and persuade them to sit in a development office and work on ideas." His head of development, Andy Culpin, who suggested Anne Robinson for The Weakest Link, came from Bazal ("Baz was furious") where he'd been a £300-a-week trainee. "The agreement was I could come in, bring in a team. I didn't have to work with anyone here unless I wanted to. I found a complete and utter lack of ideas. Shocking. The wrong people were doing development, being paid thousands of pounds." One of his ideas team was leasing photocopiers when Young hired him; within six months he'd won a commission from BBC Choice for Simply Complicated - a competition to invent daft machines (for example, to spread jam on bread). It's coming to BBC1. "As a viewer of the BBC I'd get quite angry, I like to see good ideas. It was all star vehicles. It was Jim [Davidson] does this, so-and-so does that." He applied exactly what he'd learned: "The idea is the star. Out of great formats like Have I Got News For You, Hat Trick have created huge TV stars, but the format comes first." webTitle: Media: Asset stripping at the Beeb

fields.headline: Asset stripping at the Beeb
fields.standfirst:
Greg Dyke's efforts to beef up BBC1 have had an unexpected casualty, says Maggie Brown - BBC2

Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke's efforts to beef up BBC1 have had an unexpected casualty, says Maggie Brown - BBC2.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke's ruthless crusade to revitalise BBC1 raises the question: what is BBC2 for? To experts and viewers alike it seems it is being sacrificed, stripped of distinctive features, to shore up the main channel in its battle with ITV. "I'm not quite sure what it's about - a heritage channel for the over-45s, middle England, which sees history as something comfortable?" suggests Tim Gardam, director of programmes at Channel 4.

A crucial signal of BBC2's newly demoted status came last week, when Attachments, the Tony Garnett-produced dotcom drama, a rare treat for BBC2, was pitted against Men in Black, the blockbuster Hollywood movie. It slumped to a 4% share, and audience of 1m. Experts gasped because both products appealed to younger audiences. A former BBC scheduler commented: "Before all of this, Attachments would have been sheltered." But then perhaps it looks out of place on what BBC2 seems set to become.

The most high-profile example of plunder is the sudden loss of its biggest hit, Have I Got News for You, which switched to BBC1 to run at the same time, 9pm on Fridays. It was expected to move next autumn, not this. This dealt a sudden death blow to BBC2's established Friday night comedy zone. Now BBC1 has cornered the Friday comedy slot and another on Mondays for good measure (One Foot in the Grave and The Royle Family). Friday night on BBC2 is to settle down as a soft history/documentary zone, the place where gardening and lifestyle gives way to programmes liked by middle-aged viewers. True, it also has a History Zone on Saturday nights, but that's for tougher history series, following on from the foreign affairs gem Correspondent. BBC1 doesn't want the Arts Zone either - that stays on BBC2 on Sundays.

Where BBC2's new comedy zone will go is still not clear: Mondays and Thursdays are being researched, says scheduler Liam Keelan, but as there is nothing urgent to go in them, this probably won't be resolved until January when series like Never Mind the Buzzcocks return. It will not lose its role as a nursery bed for comedy talent - it still has the pilot of a predicted new Johnny Vaughan hit, 'Orrible - but whether the priority is to make new BBC2-style hits or programmes that might be suitable for transplanting to BBC1 remains unclear.

As Lorraine Heggessey, controller of BBC1, made clear last week, there will be more collaboration between the two. Greg Dyke rather let the cat out of the bag at Edinburgh when he said he wasn't quite sure what BBC2 was about. One producer saw the BBC's rethink this way: "It's a huge problem for [BBC2 controller] Jane Root." "I feel really sorry for her," agrees Gardam.

Root, meanwhile, claims to be relaxed. The upside, she says, is that there is more capacity to commission other things, and the blows have been softened with an extra £25m this year to boost her budget.

"She thought she was running one sort of channel, and has made a good try at giving it some identity. Now it has got to be an adult channel, with leisure, cooking - home counties television," said an insider. Masterchef has been moved across to BBC2 to compensate, as have repeats of The X Files, and a series about life in PoW camps in the second world war.

Further, a new concept of sharing hit programmes has been conjured up. Though BBC2 will continue to strip The Weakest Link, a hasty weekly champions' version of the show will go on prime-time BBC1. As for Robot Wars, BBC2's cult boys' show, there's a BBC1 Christmas special in the works. Panorama has not moved to BBC2, though Dyke would clearly love it to, because the governors defended its place on BBC1; as with Question Time, though, it is probably only a matter of time.

The real problem for Root is ratings. So far this year BBC2 has averaged a share of 10.8%, close to the figure it has held steadily for a decade. She has the chance to fight back by, for example, pitching comedy against Panorama and the 10pm news. In prime time last week BBC2 was down around 2.3%, and may well slip below 10% as the new schedules bite. In fairness, all the minority channels were hit last week. But television is a tough business. It's hard not to see a controller being blamed for falling ratings, even though it is not their fault.

webTitle: BBC feels fall out from NTL football deal

fields.headline: BBC feels fall-out from NTL football deal
fields.trailText: 9am: The collapse of the Premier League's plans for pay-per-view football has dealt a multi-million pound blow to the BBC, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The collapse of the Premier League's plans for pay-per-view football has dealt a multi-million pound blow to the BBC, it emerged today.

The corporation's sports department had been lined up to produce the coverage in a deal that could have been worth more than £10m a year.

Under the proposed deal, the BBC would have provided production staff and resources for NTL's Premier League service - a package of 40 PPV games per year.

However the planned partnership collapsed after NTL walked away from its £327m PPV deal with the Premier League.

An insider at BBC Sport said: "After the loss of so many sporting rights contracts it was felt that the NTL deal would, at the very least, have kept our production staff busy and employed. Although we do still have the FA deal it's not the end of the world, but this isn't a week-in, week out contract."

"It's a shifting market, but there is some concern that the best staff will start defecting to Sky or ONdigital," the source added.

The collapse of NTL's plans to work with the BBC is the latest in a string of blows to BBC football. Earlier this year it lost the rights to cover Premier League highlights covered by Match of the Day for decades.

It is also a blow for the BBC's new controller of sport, Peter Salmon, who has been charged with overhauling the corporation's sport department and winning back some high-profile sport rights.

Over the past few years the corporation has lost much of its sports rights, including test match cricket coverage, Formula One and Premier League football.

A BBC spokesman said: "This doesn't impact on us at all. The deal was never signed."

Meanwhile an NTL spokesman said it would be interested in reopening talks with the Premier League. He said: "If we're invited to bid, we'd be delighted to, but it's now with the Premier League."

fields.headline: MacIntyre to sue Kent police
fields.trailText: 12.30pm update: BBC investigative journalist Donal MacIntyre has launched a libel action against the Kent police force relating to allegedly defamatory comments it made about an edition of MacIntyre Undercover that led to the closure of a care home in the county.
fields.body:
BBC investigative journalist Donal MacIntyre has today launched a libel action against the Kent police force relating to allegedly defamatory comments it made about an edition of MacIntyre Undercover that led to the closure of a care home in the county.

Solicitors acting for Mr MacIntyre served a libel writ on the chief constable of Kent, Sir David Phillips, Kent police spokesman Mark Pugash and acting detective inspector Michael Costello.

Mr Costello was quoted in a Sunday Telegraph article in June in which Kent police's allegations against MacIntyre Undercover were first revealed.

His comments related to a MacIntyre Undercover investigation of alleged abuse and neglect at the privately run Brompton care home in Kent. Following the programme, which went out in November 1999, Medway Council carried out its own investigation and closed the home.

Mr MacIntyre said: "It is a fundamental purpose of journalism to give voice to those, who because of their circumstances, are unable to speak for themselves. It would not serve the public interest if our findings were diminished by the totally unfounded and defamatory comments made by Kent Police."

The undercover reporter who shot to fame on the back of his hit investigative series is taking out the action personally, but the BBC said it was backing his decision fully.

Mr MacIntyre, who will face huge legal bills, said today that issuing a libel writ was a last resort.

He added: "It is a matter of personal regret that it has been necessary to issue legal proceedings against Kent police. It is not a course of action that has been undertaken lightly.

"However, Kent police have declined to retract their allegations despite being given every opportunity to do so. In making these allegations, they have both damaged my personal reputation as a journalist, and brought the reputation of the BBC's journalism into question."

BBC director of television Mark Thompson said the BBC "fully supported" Mr Macintyre's legal action. Mr Thompson added: "The remarks made by Kent police called into question a programme which revealed the abuse, humiliation and neglect of vulnerable residents, who did not have the ability to speak for themselves."

A spokesman for the BBC said Mr MacIntyre did not rule out further action in his fight to protect his reputation.

Kent police confirmed it had received a writ naming chief constable Sir David Phillips, detective sergeant Mr Costello and the force's media adviser, Mr Pugash.

Mr Pugash said Kent police would be "contesting the action vigorously".

webTitle: BBC bends rules on quiz prizes in battle for ratings

fields.headline: BBC bends rules on quiz prizes in battle for ratings
fields.trailText: 8am: The BBC is to raise the stakes in the ratings war by offering the biggest game show cash prize it has ever put up, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The BBC is to raise the stakes in the ratings war with ITV by offering the biggest game show cash prize it has ever put up, in apparent contravention of its own guidelines.

When the hit daytime quiz show The Weakest Link is launched in prime time on BBC1 next week, its top prize will be doubled to £20,000. While the sum is minimal compared with the potential £1m offered by ITV's Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, BBC guidelines counsel against prizes of "excessive value".

The BBC is determined that The Weakest Link's prime time run should be a success. The show, presented by Anne Robinson, has been a surprise hit in its teatime slot on BBC2 and is being deployed in the ratings war that flared up after the BBC1's Nine O'Clock News was shifted to 10pm.

While there is no limit on what prizes television shows can offer, the BBC guidelines for programme makers say "cash prizes should be avoided... It is inappropriate to spend licence fee money on prizes of excessive value".

The boost to The Weakest Link's prize fund was approved by the BBC1 controller, Lorraine Heggessey.

The BBC stressed that it was unlikely anyone would win the £20,000, while its head of light entertainment, David Young, said it had always offered big-value prizes. "We're always being told, 'You can't do big money'," he said. "The Generation Game gives away holidays; how much do they think they cost? Most producers' guidelines are so ambiguous, it's the controllers who say what you can do."

BBC's rivals criticised The Weakest Link's prize. Kevin Lygo, Channel 4's head of entertainment, said: "Is it right that the licence fee from a small Oxford village should go to fund that? It's a bit off for the BBC. They have managed for years without big prizes."

But it won support from Peter Bazalgette, a former BBC producer whose firm Bazal Productions was behind Big Brother, Channel 4's reality TV game show that paid £70,000 to the winner. It was a sign that the BBC director general, Greg Dyke, was determined to inject life into entertainment shows, he said. "It's wholly admirable...Light entertainment was so bad, stale, turgid, it had to get better."

The Weakest Link is one of a number of hit shows developed by Mr Young's department. Its success is derived from a combination of Robinson's schoolma'am manner and a format that has contestants voting out their worst-performing team-mates. Robinson dismisses each departing contestant with her catchphrase: "You're the weakest link, goodbye."

Participants in the daytime version pocket between £1,500 and £2,000.

A BBC spokesman said: "You have to put it in context. We are not giving away £1m and we don't believe £20,000 is an unreasonable amount, especially when you take into account the fact that the odds against anyone winning it are high."

Cheap at the price

The BBC's track record in game shows:

Generation Game
Now spiced up with exotic holidays, strict rules used to mean that contestants rarely went away with more than the deep fat fryer and cuddly toy. Oh for the return of the glory days of Larry Grayson and Isla St Clair.

Crackerjack
For the privilege of being covered in slime and humiliation on national television, schoolchildren aspired to that great giveaway, a Crackerjack pencil and pen.

Blankety Blank
Terry Wogan, Les Dawson and Lily Savage never let their guests go away empty-handed. As well as toasters and towel sets, contestants got the show's chequebook and pen.

Mastermind
The privilege was to take part in this general knowledge quiz. The only prize on offer was a fetching piece of crystal.

It is inappropriate to spend licence fee money on prizes of excessive value". The boost to The Weakest Link's prize fund was approved by the BBC1 controller, Lorraine Heggessey. The BBC stressed that it was unlikely anyone would win the £20,000, while its head of light entertainment, David Young, said it had always offered big-value prizes. "We're always being told, 'You can't do big money'," he said. "The Generation Game gives away holidays; how much do they think they cost? Most producers' guidelines are so ambiguous, it's the controllers who say what you can do." BBC's rivals criticised The Weakest Link's prize. Kevin Lygo, Channel 4's head of entertainment, said: "Is it right that the licence fee from a small Oxford village should go to fund that? It's a bit off for the BBC. They have managed for years without big prizes." But it won support from Peter Bazalgette, a former BBC producer whose firm Bazal Productions was behind Big Brother, Channel 4's reality TV game show that paid £70,000 to the winner. It was a sign that the BBC director general, Greg Dyke, was determined to inject life into entertainment shows, he said. "It's wholly admirable...Light entertainment was so bad, stale, turgid, it had to get better." The Weakest Link is one of a number of hit shows developed by Mr Young's department. Its success is derived from a combination of Robinson's schoolma'am manner and a format that has contestants voting out their worst-performing team-mates. Robinson dismisses each departing contestant with her catchphrase: "You're the weakest link, goodbye." Participants in the daytime version pocket between £1,500 and £2,000. A BBC spokesman said: "You have to put it in context. We are not giving away £1m and we don't believe £20,000 is an unreasonable amount, especially when you take into account the fact that the odds against anyone winning it are high." Crackerjack For the privilege of being covered in slime and humiliation on national television, schoolchildren aspired to that great giveaway, a Crackerjack pencil and pen. Blankety Blank Terry Wogan, Les Dawson and Lily Savage never let their guests go away empty-handed. As well as toasters and towel sets, contestants got the show's chequebook and pen. Mastermind The privilege was to take part in this general knowledge quiz. The only prize on offer was a fetching piece of crystal.

webTitle: ITV drama in turmoil over new ad breaks

fields.headline: ITV drama in turmoil over new ad breaks
fields.trailText: Prime time television on ITV will see a sharp rise in advertising breaks next month, writes Nick Paton Walsh.
fields.body:
Prime time television on ITV will see a sharp rise in advertising breaks next month, sparking an angry reaction from producers anxious not to see their shows suffer from interruptions.

David Liddiment, director of programmes at ITV, has asked that all prime-time television shows should re-structure themselves to fit another ad break. Hour-long programmes scripted to work up to a climax before two breaks, now have to keep audiences gripped during three.

Favourites like Peak Practice and Cold Feet, the last episode of Inspector Morse, and a new Robson Green drama, Close and True, which all begin on ITV next month are among the shows affected by the change. Many have been prepared months before they are transmitted, and now have to be re-edited to fit the new ad break.

"Everyone in the indie sector is furious about this," said a senior television producer. "From 30 October the character of ITV television will subtly change - it'll be perceptibly different for viewers. The network have brought this iron curtain down. It's been done without warning,"' the producer said.

"Everyone designs their hour-long epsiodes to a three-act structure, and we now have to re-cut to fit this new structure. Inevitably, pace will have to pick up and there will be less of an opportunity to develop ideas between ads. How can you do Jane Austen when you have adverts for luxury soaps stuck in the middle? We're going to have to charge ITV for changing the episodes. They're going to squeal when they find out how much it will cost them. And this comes at a time when the BBC are rallying around their prime-time slots, with Men In Black and One Foot in the Grave."

Another senior television executive said: "The three-act structure is the staple of television. It's another step down the road to turning British TV into American TV. It's a process that started 10 years ago. It doesn't help make good programmes."

The extra ad breaks are the result of an increase in prime-time advertising space granted to ITV in return for its decision to take the evening news broadcast back to 10pm. The Independent Television Commission has granted ITV the right to move two and a half minutes' worth of advertising from the daytime to more lucrative evening slots. Some 90-minute programmes will now have four breaks, and a two-hour programme five.

The uproar comes up at a time when Liddiment has been criticised following the rescheduling fiasco of ITV's evening news bulletins. The ITV network is also struggling to find the fair share of the prime-time audience. Last month the auditors Merrill Lynch reported that poor viewing figures and lacklustre advertising revenue could trigger ITV's decline. In the same month the network reported its lowest ever share of the audience, 25.7 per cent.

The changes to peak schedules will be seen by many as a last-ditch attempt to raise advertising revenues, at the expense of quality programming and consequently viewing figures.

Paul Tyrrell, the Head of Press for ITV, said: "I would categorically refute that it will damage the quality of the programmes.

"There will have to be some realignment. We believe that this will safeguard the future of commercial television and the adjustments are a price worth paying."

webTitle: Totally buys SoJewish and London Jewish News

fields.headline: Totally buys SoJewish and London Jewish News
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Two of the most prominent Jewish media outlets have today been taken over, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Two of the most prominent Jewish media outlets have today been taken over, sparking consolidation in the Jewish sector.

Totally Jewish has bought SoJewish.co.uk and London Jewish News in an all-share deal.

The acquisition, which is going through for 12.5m new ordinary shares, will allow Aim-listed parent company Totally Plc to consolidate its position as a Jewish multimedia and leisure firm and expand into new markets, particularly the US, Israel, continental Europe and the former Soviet Union.

The acquisition will also enable Totally to move into the offline world by taking on leading UK Jewish newspaper London Jewish News.

Totallyjewish.com was launched at the start of March and, according to its proforma, pulled in revenue of £184,000 in its first four months.

The website claims to have around 40,000 unique visitors a month and over 450,000 page impressions.

Steve Burns, chief executive of Totally, said: "The proposed deal represents a great opportunity to position and develop the number one Jewish multimedia and leisure group in the world. We have assembled a board with proven business acumen which will be able to make this a reality."

fields.headline: Media Monkey's Diary
fields.trailText: * Monkey is glad to report that after a meeting last week between Peter Bazalgette and Tim Gardam, Channel 4's director of programmes, a second series of Big Brother is definitely coming next year - and the format is staying the same, as Bazalgette wanted. (As he says, you don't change Changing Rooms from one series to the next.) The big challenge, says Gardam, is to get the casting right. I think we can trust Baz with that one.
fields.body:
* Monkey is glad to report that after a meeting last week between Peter Bazalgette and Tim Gardam, Channel 4's director of programmes, a second series of Big Brother is definitely coming next year - and the format is staying the same, as Bazalgette wanted. (As he says, you don't change Changing Rooms from one series to the next.) The big challenge, says Gardam, is to get the casting right. I think we can trust Baz with that one.

* Who is going to take over from Matthew Bannister as Greg Dyke's director of marketing? Hot money is on Jim Hytner, marketing director of Channel 5 and before that a key Sky executive. The brother of film director Nicholas is a good friend of Dyke's - they worked together at Channel 5. Rumours that Sue Farr, who lost out to Bannister, might return to the Beeb are wide of the mark. Dyke offended her when he offered to "write her a good reference any time she wanted one", explains a friend. And she's holding out for a chief executive role, or something with international scope.

* Yet another humiliation for poor Jeremy Bowen, the normally flak-jacketed hack improbably parked on Sophie Raworth's sofa in BBC1's relaunched breakfast show. "Sophie gets back pain because she's younger," the show's doctor informed him last week, "but the reason you're OK is that the risk is reduced for over-45s." Rising slightly from his customary horizontal position, the greying reporter told her curtly, "I am 40."

* Is business a little slow for ex-TV presenter Noel Edmonds since the ending of his generous BBC contract? Monkey only asks because word has gone out that the bearded one is actively out in the market approaching anyone who might be interested in buying his 50% shareholding in the flabbily passé Mr Blobby. Perhaps it's all down to the increasing price of the fuel needed to propel Noel's private helicopter.

* The brouhaha over John Prescott's alleged remarks about Henry Moore rumbled on last week after they were "reported" in Tuesday's Telegraph - culminating in a joky "Prescott's A-Z of Art" in Thursday's Mail. But is the Telegraph coming to regret the supposed story's durability? A Moore expert at the deputy PM's side throughout the visit says he never made the remarks; the Telegraph's Beijing man - one of two reporters credited - has told the British Council they were "not in my copy". Which only leaves co-byliner Sean O'Neill, a London-based reporter, whose powers of hearing are clearly awe-inspiring.

* Upheaval in the world of music PR, where Barbara Sharone - spin doctor at Warner Europe for a decade - is quitting to set up her own outfit. Luckily for Warner, she's not taking anyone major with her: just Madonna, REM, Mick Hucknall, William Orbit, Eliza Carthy...

 Email the Monkey at monkey@mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: Jonathan Steele on Radio Television Serbia

fields.headline: The ultimate sacrifice
fields.standfirst:
When Nato bombed Radio Television Serbia in Belgrade, 16 people died. A new documentary suggests the bosses knew the attack was coming - but failed to evacuate the building. Jonathan Steele reports

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: When Nato bombed Radio Television Serbia in Belgrade, 16 people died. A new documentary suggests the bosses knew the attack was coming - but failed to evacuate the building. Jonathan Steele reports.
fields.body:
No incident caused as much outcry among opponents of Nato's air campaign against Yugoslavia last year, or as much anguish among those who supported it, as the missile strike on Radio Television Serbia. Sixteen people died, two of them so completely destroyed that nothing remained from which to identify them. Two gravestones had to be put up in the yard of RTS itself since there was nothing left to bury in a proper cemetery, not even a ring or an ID card.

Yet it was this same building in central Belgrade that Serbia's anti-Milosevic protesters had as number two on their list of targets in this month's uprising. Like Nato, they too saw it as a hated symbol of the regime, and as soon as the Federal parliament building had been stormed they turned their anger on RTS. The front part of the TV headquarters which had escaped attack by Nato was set alight and looted. Dragoljub Milanovic, RTS's general manager, narrowly avoided being lynched when the crowd spotted him escaping from the building. He was severely beaten and stamped on.

The crowd's fury was a useful reminder that even at the time of Nato's attack Serbian attitudes to the bombing were more complex than the Milosevic regime's officials tried to pretend. Not everyone saw Nato as the primary villain, and certainly not as the exclusive one. Now under new editorship, RTS has just marked its liberation from the one-sided propaganda of the Milosevic years by screening a remarkable documentary about the Nato bombing of its own building. Anatomy of Pain had previously been aired only on the small network of private TV stations available in some provincial towns. In Belgrade it had a single showing before an invited audience in a local cinema this summer.

The millions of Serbs who saw it on RTS last week were treated to a harrowing set of interviews with the parents and wives of the 16 people who died. Obliquely, and without heavy explanation since the film was made under the conditions of dictatorship, one of the grieving relatives every so often throws in a soft accusation or a leading question. Why was every other government building that was hit by Nato evacuated long before it was struck? Why didn't the RTS management empty the building, especially after foreign TV journalists, who had been using it for their transmissions, stopped coming about a week before the attack? Did the government want a large number of casualties as a propaganda weapon against Nato?

As though in answer to the last question, the film shows a clip of Tatjana Lenard, one of RTS's best-known announcers and a member of JUL, the party founded by Slobodan Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic. Two weeks before the strike, she is shown on air taunting Nato: "We're waiting for you. Shoot us if you like. We won't stop working." The night Nato struck, she was not in the building.

Janko Balyak, the film's 35-year-old director, is planning to make a second part to the film, this time focusing on its storming during this month's protests. In the early 1990s he worked in RTS's cultural department and knew some of those who died. The new film will be a much sharper and clearer attack on the RTS management. "I hope it will lead to a trial of the RTS directors for negligence in leaving their staff in the building. For most of the relatives, Nato was an invisible enemy, almost like something from outer space. They blame the management in the first place for the 16 deaths", he says.

The back of the sprawling building where the Nato missile hit was deliberately left by the Milosevic regime as it was on the night of the attack. A dozen burnt-out cars remain in the yard, whitened by the colossal heat as though they have been coated with sand from a tropical beach. Curtains flap in the draught that comes through the building's shattered window-frames. A potted plant on the third floor still flourishes, the only remaining sign of life.

There is a new message now. On the wall in the yard someone has scrawled the main slogan of the Belgrade autumn: "He is finished." A few yards away stands the memorial erected by the families, with the names of the dead and the single word "Why?". A few days ago an unknown vandal removed the flowers and replaced them with cabbages and a bottle of cooking oil.

Sitting in the kitchen of their suburban house in Beli Potok on the southern outskirts of Belgrade, Kurman and Mirjana Stojmenovski never stop asking themselves the question, now compounded by uncertainty as to why anyone would want to tamper with the memorial. Their son, Darko, was 25 when he died, the youngest of the 16 victims. "When you lose a son or daughter in a car accident, you also suffer. But there are not the same questions. We are still waiting for answers. For a long time it was taboo to discuss it. When the bombing started, we were afraid for Darko. All his friends were called up into the army. He wasn't, and we thought he would be safer working at RTS." The couple are still wearing black clothes.

"He was sure Nato warned people before they hit targets. When they bombed RTS in the city of Novi Sad, the building was empty. We still can't get into the minds of people who would leave people there. No one in the senior management was in the building at 2am when the missile struck. One girl on the night shift was the daughter of Dusan Vojvodic, a senior editor. He rang her and urged her to leave before the missile struck," they add.

The Stojmenovskis say they opposed Milosevic's policies for at least 10 years. During the bombing they were shocked to see tanks and armoured personnel carriers from a nearby base camouflaged in suburban streets in their neighbourhood. Soldiers were sleeping in local schools and kindergartens. They found this a reckless and irresponsible playing with civilian lives, though typical of Milosevic. "The government would have been happier if it had been 50 or 100 people killed at RTS, not 16," Mr Stojmenovski says bitterly.

They and three other families have started a case against Nato at the European Court for Human Rights. But the main purpose, they say, is to get Nato to open its files. "This could show whether Nato warned RTS that an attack was coming. This would prove that the management deliberately sacrificed our children," he explains. "But even if the management didn't know, they're still responsible for failing to take sufficient precautions to protect their staff." Shortly before last month's elections which brought Milosevic's downfall, the regime held a war crimes trial for Bill Clinton, Tony Blair, and other Nato leaders in absentia. "They invited us to go as witnesses, but we refused," says Mirjana Stojmenovski. "But we decided to turn up as members of the public just to see. It was a political farce."

Amazingly calm and clear-eyed in their political views, the Stojmenovskis regret that it has taken so long for other Serbs to see things the way they do. "It will take time for people to come round to our point of view. They share our grief but still think Milosevic was right. I said to them, 'If you are such patriots, why don't you go down to Kosovo and defend it yourselves?' Nato killed our son, but I can't have any influence on Nato. I expect my government to do the best for its people. Unfortunately, Milosevic needed this war to stay in power," says Kurman Stojmenovski. Now that Anatomy of Pain has been aired on RTS itself, they hope more Serbs will accept that truth.
