No one in the senior management was in the building at 2am when the missile struck. One girl on the night shift was the daughter of Dusan Vojvodic, a senior editor. He rang her and urged her to leave before the missile struck," they add. The Stojmenovskis say they opposed Milosevic's policies for at least 10 years. During the bombing they were shocked to see tanks and armoured personnel carriers from a nearby base camouflaged in suburban streets in their neighbourhood. Soldiers were sleeping in local schools and kindergartens. They found this a reckless and irresponsible playing with civilian lives, though typical of Milosevic. "The government would have been happier if it had been 50 or 100 people killed at RTS, not 16," Mr Stojmenovski says bitterly. They and three other families have started a case against Nato at the European Court for Human Rights. But the main purpose, they say, is to get Nato to open its files. "This could show whether Nato warned RTS that an attack was coming. This would prove that the management deliberately sacrificed our children," he explains. "But even if the management didn't know, they're still responsible for failing to take sufficient precautions to protect their staff." Shortly before last month's elections which brought Milosevic's downfall, the regime held a war crimes trial for Bill Clinton, Tony Blair, and other Nato leaders in absentia. "They invited us to go as witnesses, but we refused," says Mirjana Stojmenovski. "But we decided to turn up as members of the public just to see. It was a political farce." Amazingly calm and clear-eyed in their political views, the Stojmenovskis regret that it has taken so long for other Serbs to see things the way they do. "It will take time for people to come round to our point of view. They share our grief but still think Milosevic was right. I said to them, 'If you are such patriots, why don't you go down to Kosovo and defend it yourselves?' Nato killed our son, but I can't have any influence on Nato. I expect my government to do the best for its people. Unfortunately, Milosevic needed this war to stay in power," says Kurman Stojmenovski. Now that Anatomy of Pain has been aired on RTS itself, they hope more Serbs will accept that truth.

webTitle: The men who made politics boring again

fields.headline: The men who made politics boring again
fields.standfirst: From the look of this year's US presidential campaigns, the Americans have a lot to learn about selling political product. But as  Chris Powell points out, things could be better on this side of the pond, too
fields.trailText: From the look of this year's US presidential campaigns, the Americans have a lot to learn about selling political product. But as Chris Powell points out, things could be better on this side of the pond, too.
fields.body:
It is estimated that, for the first time this year, more than $1bn will be spent on the elections in the US (state as well as presidential). Of this figure, $400m will go on advertising. Surely, at these levels of spend, there must be much to learn from America? It is well known that both Conservatives and Labour visit the US to learn what's new in electioneering. Should the advertising advisers go there too?

The simple answer is that they needn't bother. There is now a convenient website (www.adcritic.com) that keeps you up to date with advertising in the US, even featuring the latest TV commercials for the candidates. Which is lucky, because it wouldn't be worth the price of a ticket to see the drab succession of tit-for-tat commercials that both camps are churning out.

This is a missed opportunity. As Roy Spence, president of ad agency GSD&M of Austin, Texas points out: "Unlike in the past, advertising could play a pivotal role in this election. In the past there were fundamental differences, and the ads played a supportive role to the messages. The issues and personalities were so stark, publicity played a supporting, not a primary, role. This time the economy is strong, there's not a world at war, Bush has moved to the middle, and there's a lot of blurring of lines in terms of the average person out there. All of that leads to advertising playing a major role."

In the event, however, this has not been the outcome. Kathy Delaney, creative director of the Deutsch ad agency in New York, says: "Both candidates do themselves a disservice by producing commercials that look and sound like bad informercials. They're invisible. It's 'Blah, blah, blah' cut against sappy music. Compelling, single-minded, believable commercials are completely missing here. The best advertising starts with a single honest truth about the brand. This stuff is served up in such a mundane, cliched way that even if there is a truth in there, it blew right by me."

What the hapless US viewers are getting is what we used to get in UK party political broadcasts in the 70s - the illustrated talking head. The candidate talks to camera and when he makes a point you cut away to an illustration, as though you were a backward child who needed it all spelt out in picture-book style.

So Bush addresses you on medical matters and when he says something about old people you get a picture of someone being pushed along in a wheelchair. In really exciting versions you get a bit of tabletop illustration, too - maybe a pile of dollar bills to make the point that it will cost money.

There are two sorts of these commercials. First there's the one where the talking head says what his policy is before slagging off the other guy's stance on that area. The subject changes almost daily (the environment on Wednesday, Medicare on Thursday) and takes different forms for each state and for each ethnic and linguistic group (no wonder they have to be cheap and quickly made). Second, there's the "morning in America" life story of the candidate. It's not really advertising at all.

The only change of pace comes from Ralph Nader (the ex-consumerist leader and now an independent presidential candidate). He makes TV ads attacking both the other candidates for spending fortunes making TV ads!

What has happened? No especially golden period of US political advertising springs to mind, but there have been some memorable ads - LBJ's anti-Goldwater "Daisy" ad, with the child counting down to an atomic explosion; the unfair but memorable Republican attack on Dukakis's furlough policy that supposedly let killers out of jail to kill again.

It seems that now the politicians have decided that they know it all and give no room to the advertising advisers (there was a telling shot in the programme about Clinton's Little Rock campaign headquarters, featuring a staff member on the telephone "ordering up" a tightly specified ad for the following day). That's not advertising. That's just spin, baldly stated in TV slots. There is no "defining" advertising theme, no strategy. Its use is solely tactical and day to day.

The past 20 years have seen political campaigners on both sides of the Atlantic come on in leaps and bounds in their understanding of how to get through to the public. Much of this is learned from the world of advertising: the focus-group feedback, the concise message, speaking in unison, the need for repetition. Politicians have got very good at communicating - so good, it seems, that they have decided there's no room left for the input of advertising agencies. In the US, tedious ads make it obvious that the creative imagination has not been allowed to brighten things up.

Things are rather different in the UK. Peter Mandelson learned the tricks of the trade early on and his Millbank army no longer feels the need for much more than spiky executions of its briefs. The Conservatives have always contracted it out anyway. Saatchis did it all, whether Tim Bell or, successfully in 92 and disastrously in 97, Maurice Saatchi was in charge. After the spectacular failure of their advertising strategy in 97, the Conservatives have clearly decided to internalise strategy too, with the appointment of Yellow M to do the executions.

Both Labour and the Conservatives seem to feel that while there's not much room for ad-agency thinking, there's still a role for the memorable ad. With Trevor Beattie and Yellow M - two "shock jocks" if ever there were any - we should see some sparks.

Despite the fact that the UK is unlikely to be as boring as the US, advertising could be doing more for political parties here as well as across the Atlantic. Brand advertising that creates such enormously valuable properties for companies comes from the understanding that thinking can't sensibly be separated from execution. The great campaigns come from the interaction of strategic planning and creative skills. Big brand owners, like VW or Orange, don't instruct their agencies in detailed content, but allow them latitude to spot the public's nerve end, both in the route to choose and the way that it is expressed.

There is a role for advertising in politics beyond the recitation of policy and abuse of the other side. Parties benefit from clarity of positioning in the electorate's mind, and this needs constant adaptation as the context changes. Much of this is done, of course, by the character and message of the leader. But advertising can also delineate the territory. Mitterrand stood for president with a poster that just said "La force tranquille", which neatly summed up what he offered in the chaotic environment of French politics. Wilson's Labour grabbed the moment of a dying Conservative government with "Let's Go with Labour".

Current political advertising is not using any of the skills that advertising agencies have in abundance: the ability to get under the skin of the public, to have insights that coincide with the way the voters, and not the politicians, see it. Advertising can do more than it is being asked to, almost as much in the UK as in the US.

 Chris Powell is chairman of BMP DDB and led Labour's 1997 election campaign advertising

fields.headline: Reports of our demise have been greatly exaggerated
fields.standfirst: Four weeks ago in Media Guardian, Andrew Neil attacked Scotland's first financial tabloid, Business a.m. Now  John Penman  responds
fields.trailText: Four weeks ago in Media Guardian, Andrew Neil attacked Scotland's first financial tabloid, Business a.m. Now John Penman responds.
fields.body:
On the night we launched Business a.m., a Scotsman journalist tried to woo her way into our printing plant by pretending to be an advertiser anxious to check her ad. At least she didn't rake through our dustbins.

I used to work for the Scotsman. Many of my colleagues at Business a.m. did. We were, and are, proud of having worked for a paper with a fantastic tradition. However, the tactics employed on our launch night, and the recent rantings of Andrew Neil, smack more of the tabloid end of the market towards which the Scotsman seems to be plunging.

That's their problem. We have ignored most of their criticism, but when downright falsehoods are employed in an effort to damage us, we have to respond.

Neil has now resorted to dressing up comment as fact, claiming that "industry sources" predict that we will face a crisis by Christmas, a phrase he himself used in the Guardian recently, and as "evidence", he revealed just part of our circulation figures.

Let's explain something. As has been widely reported, we are a subscription newspaper. Business a.m. was never conceived as being a mass-circulation title dependent on heavy retail sales.

Right from the beginning Business a.m. had a clear objective; to reach Scotland's business decision-makers. Subscription allows us to better serve and understand our target audience. Our independent research showed there was a clear and unsatisfied demand for news and opinion of high importance to this particular group of people, with more than seven out of 10 people believing there was room for a business title.

That perhaps explains why 55% of working ABs in Scotland do not currently read a broadsheet newspaper. Two-thirds of the Herald and Scotsman readers have no interest in business news. That's why there is a demand for Business a.m.

To underpin all of this, the formula for Business a.m. is one which our parent company, the Bonnier Group of Sweden, has repeated successfully in nine other countries across northern Europe.

So how have we done in our first month? Editorially, we have focused on the business, financial and political news of importance to our audience. In our launch issue, we revealed that Govan had lost a major shipyard contract, a story the rest of the Scottish press caught up with this week, and since then we have exposed the Scottish Executive's U-turn to build the vital M74 motorway linking Glasgow to the south, reported on a £170m drop in Scottish venture-capital deals, a major extension of public/private deals by the Scottish Executive and we launched ScottTECH, our own unique index designed to track Scotland's fast-growing technology, media and telecoms companies.

Scotland's journalist of the year, Ian Bell, has shown why he remains one of our country's most gifted writers. We have a 16-page Investor section which has won enormous praise, and an absolute gem in our p.m. features pages, which no one expected from a business paper but which everyone has praised. While Neil prefers to hide behind "industry sources", I prefer to quote someone real - former Scotsman editor and current Times columnist Magnus Linklater, who described Business a.m. as a "serious and professional paper". The FT, while acknowledging that Business a.m. was a rival publication in the Scottish market, printed a favourable analysis of "the UK's first dedicated tabloid business newspaper". Advertising sales are considerably ahead of schedule, with business from Scottish agencies standing at 75% of our target for the remainder of the year. There has also been a strong response from London agencies.

The truth is that with just one month under our belts, our circulation is well ahead of where our management expected us to be. In two or three weeks, we anticipate that we will be able to publish audited figures which show that Business a.m.'s circulation is in excess of 10,000 copies a day.

And today, Business a.m. goes on sale in London for the first time. Judge us on our content, not on the misconceptions of others.

 John Penman is editor of Business a.m.

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: Paradox of the week is the aptly titled LibertySurf.co.uk that has joined in the farce sweeping through unmetered ISPs by kicking heavy users off its service.
fields.body:
 Paradox of the week is the aptly titled LibertySurf.co.uk that has joined in the farce sweeping through unmetered ISPs by kicking heavy users off its service. Disgruntled punters who initially paid £55 to get onto the service are being accused of having "abnormal" usage patterns, even if, according to users, they are barely using the service. Was it really only a few months back that LibertySurf pulled in users by saying there would be no restrictions about online time? Well, it had to happen sooner or later . . .

 A well-known brand don't mean nothing these days, well not according to those discerning and well-educated readers of the Torygraph. Poor old Lastminute.com came in for a bit of a bashing by being voted the worst travel site on the web. Oh dear. The strange thing is that Lastminute.com has long since stopped referring to itself as a travel website, because let's face it, what decent, flexible and cheap last-minute travel inventory does it actually offer these days? Not much. It's heartening that for once almost 6,000 Torygraph readers are talking sense.

 Attendees of the Guardian Unlimited event last Tuesday were treated to the most flagrant bit of PR from a member of the audience so far this year. Who was this odious reprobate? None other than Mike Butcher, formerly of New Media Age, now news editor of the Industry Standard Europe. After launching what seemed like a sales pitch for ISE, Butcher wasn't even given a chance to finish his diatribe as the crowd hissed and booed before he reached the punchline. What was this witty punchline? Over to Butcher: "I certainly hope there's something new about the new economy - as I'm on a new economy magazine which launches in 48 hours." Boom boom.

 Sanskrit scholar and co-founder of TheRegister.co.uk, Mystic Mike Magee, is about to depart on a three-month sabbatical to India. Nothing new there really. Peers and compatriots however, are now spinning his break into something much bigger than it is, gossiping that Magee is seen as a Sanskrit god and is going to India to "be with his people". A far cry from Magee's spinmeister ways at The Reg.

 Forget yuppies, the new social group sweeping the nation is bobos, or bourgeois bohemians - people who combine the values of the cultural 60s with the achievements of the 80s. The Express was so impressed with this new cultural phenomenon that it devoted an entire page to it last Monday, and picked none other than Richard Daws, chairman of Victoria Real, as the atypical bobo. "He may be rich, 34 and unmarried, but bobo Richard Daws lives a simple life." How exactly does Richard fit into this new phenomenon? He works in the internet industry. Nuff said really.

Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Karen Hanton
fields.trailText: My New Media by Karen Hanton.
fields.body:
Favourite sites?
My real, real favourite right now is breathe.com. What they're trying to do is be a true lifestyle product. You can do SMS, you can do Wap, you can do Voice . . . it's brilliant. My second favourite is shellgeostar.com. It's like a route planner and it has very clear and concise information.

Last online purchase?
I bought a pair of tickets to Zurich on our old friend easyJet.

Most recent technological faux pas?
This is embarrassing. I got a very glamorous, exciting Wap phone which I turned off when I was travelling on an aircraft. Trouble was, I couldn't work out how to switch it on again.

Main news sources on the web?
ft.com. I don't have an enormous amount of time for general news but I'm most interested in financial news and that's where I find it.

Most persistent spam emailer?
Mildly irritating is moneysupermarket. It hunts down prices for really good financial products but they're a bit too proactive so you do end up with lots of mortgage offers.

Time spent on web?
I could while away whole days on it, but frequently it's four or five hours at a time.

Next boo.com/clickmango?
I think there will be lots of them. On the one hand, new media has been extremely exciting. On the other, it has bred lots of people that perhaps shouldn't be running companies. I couldn't point out one specifically.

Least useful site/s on web?
It's a bit of a personal thing but as a trustee of a Westminster Tree Trust I do think the environment is terribly important, so when I see sites like brazilexporters.com it really makes me really angry.

Least user-friendly sites?
Where you have to register and give your whole life history to get anywhere.

What screensaver do you use?
I have a great number of alpacas repeated on my screen. They're just a pleasing thing for me to look at.

Most irritating thing about the web?
The fact that the vast majority of sites don't actually do anything. The web has always been good for the transfer of information but there's an awful lot of useless sites.

Do you bother with old media?
Definitely. There's no substitute for hanging around Waterstone's or popping in and buying a Guardian and reading it over a coffee. My personal view is that the internet is here to stay, but it'll work in conjunction with everything else. There'll always be something very human about picking up a book or looking at a newspaper.

Karen Hanton is managing director of toptable.co.uk

It hunts down prices for really good financial products but they're a bit too proactive so you do end up with lots of mortgage offers. Time spent on web? I could while away whole days on it, but frequently it's four or five hours at a time. Next boo.com/clickmango? I think there will be lots of them. On the one hand, new media has been extremely exciting. On the other, it has bred lots of people that perhaps shouldn't be running companies. I couldn't point out one specifically. Least useful site/s on web? It's a bit of a personal thing but as a trustee of a Westminster Tree Trust I do think the environment is terribly important, so when I see sites like brazilexporters.com it really makes me really angry. Least user-friendly sites? Where you have to register and give your whole life history to get anywhere. What screensaver do you use? I have a great number of alpacas repeated on my screen. They're just a pleasing thing for me to look at. Most irritating thing about the web? The fact that the vast majority of sites don't actually do anything. The web has always been good for the transfer of information but there's an awful lot of useless sites. Do you bother with old media? Definitely. There's no substitute for hanging around Waterstone's or popping in and buying a Guardian and reading it over a coffee. My personal view is that the internet is here to stay, but it'll work in conjunction with everything else. There'll always be something very human about picking up a book or looking at a newspaper. Karen Hanton is managing director of toptable.co.uk

fields.headline: My media: Trezza Azzopardi
fields.trailText: My media by Trezza Azzopardi.
fields.body:
Newspapers: I read the Guardian. I'll buy the Times most days but especially on Saturdays and Sundays, and the Observer. I don't like the Daily Mail.

Magazines: I'll read anything with an exclamation mark: Hello!, OK!, Now!, I love it when they have 15 pictures all the same just enlarged slightly. If I'm going on a train I might buy Marie Claire, but I'd rather have a Private Eye.

Books: I'm reading the Blind Assassin by Margaret Atwood. I've also just finished a proof copy of a book by Lavinia Greenlaw called Mary George of Allnorthover. It's coming out next year and it's very interesting. I'm also going back to Martin Amis's Experience. I finished that about two months ago but there are bits that really make me laugh.

Film: The last film I saw was High Fidelity which was quite good, except it was more like Low Fidelity in our cinema because it was difficult to hear. I have two favourite films: Now, Voyager, a fantastic black and white film where Bette Davis wears wonderful dresses. And a film called Random Harvest which is the same sort of genre - a black and white weepie.

Television: I'm very keen on Black Books [C4]. I caught the first one and thought it was fantastic. And I love The Royle Family [BBC1]. University Challenge [BBC2] is always good for a laugh. I'll watch anything except for darts, really.

Radio: I listen to Radio 2 in the mornings. Sarah Kennedy is a scream. Then it's Radio 4 for the rest of the day. I like having the people talking in the background when I'm having a break from writing.

Ads: I can't think of any I like particularly. That Budweiser one annoys me. It's just gone on too long.

Multimedia: I'm a big fan of the internet. I like all the news sites and there's a site called eyestorm which is great. It's like walking into a cool art gallery where people sneer at you but it's a beautiful site.

 Trezza Azzopardi's novel, The Hiding Place (Picador), has been shortlisted for the Booker Prize and longlisted for the Guardian First Book Prize.

fields.headline: Mayor vs media baron
fields.standfirst: Big boats, a US spin doctor and a nude daughter-in-law. Italy's premiership candidates really know how to throw an election campaign.  Rory Carroll  reports
fields.trailText: Big boats, a US spin doctor and a nude daughter-in-law. Italy's premiership candidates really know how to throw an election campaign. Rory Carroll reports.
fields.body:
Giuliano Amato's biggest mistake was to resemble a rodent. Possessing a toothy grin, protuberant ears and slender frame, he is called Topolino, Italy's version of Mickey Mouse. Rivals cannot touch him for intellectual or strategic finesse but he is soon to lose his job. A prime minister is no longer allowed to look like a mouse, no matter how mighty.

Welcome to Italy's election campaign, where the path to power is via permanent tans, Hollywood smiles and glossy hair. Keep your eyes peeled for policies, they don't show up so brightly on television. Victory belongs to whichever side masters image, for this is a campaign fought almost exclusively through the media. Never have soundbites, photo opportunities and spin mattered so much.

Silvio Berlusconi, the conservative opposition leader and media magnate, is firing up his newspapers and television stations for a US presidential-style campaign. Opinion polls put him on course for a spectacular come-back, seven years after he tumbled from the premiership in disgrace.

The centre-left government, shaky after four troubled years in power, reckoned its best chance was to chew up its third leader and come up with one even silkier than Berlusconi. The signal for Amato, 61, to walk the plank. He will step down before the election, a decision he announced on a chat show, Porta a Porta.

Enter Francesco Rutelli, 46, the mayor of Rome and arguably Italy's best-looking politician. A clean cut, relaxed style has invited comparisons to Tony Blair. Others call him Cicciobello, after a plastic doll. He is not well known and his policies, if he has any, remain a mystery. But that will change from today when he launches his campaign in Milan. Few are better at kissing babies, shaking hands or working crowds.

The veteran commentator Indro Montanelli despaired that Italy was choosing leaders based on looks. The newspaper La Repubblica was kinder. "Rutelli is the novelty, the generational turn, the spirit of competition, the challenge on Berlusconi's grounds of modernisation, newness and image." Either way, the scene is set for a campaign which is likely to turn dirty.

Too much is at stake, and too many voters floating, to be otherwise. The election is not due until April 2001 but the battle is already turning hot. Rutelli has enlisted Stan Greenberg, the American campaign guru who advised Bill Clinton, Tony Blair and Gerhard Schröder and was the alleged mastermind of Al Gore's uxorious kiss at the Democratic convention. "We will have a few surprises for Mr Berlusconi," smiled the mayor.

The Queen became a pawn last week. After being greeted by Rutelli in Rome it was vital to the opposition for their man to get a chance to bask in regal glory, which he did in Milan. The jostling for front row seats in St Peter's square will be intense next month when Pope John Paul II proclaims Sir Thomas More the patron saint of politicians. Recent photo opportunities have shown both candidates replicating famous Benito Mussolini images of harvesting crops and embracing children. Commentators are divided over whether the echoes were intentional.

Berlusconi, 64, who has a tight rein on his coalition, has successfully presented the myriad corruption allegations against him as judicial witch-hunts. He launched his campaign this month with a billboard blitz which has papered Italy blue. "More pensions for everybody," says the caption, beneath a tanned, beaming visage which appears to be from 15 years ago. "More hair for everybody," sniggers the government.

Estimated to be worth $13bn, the owner of AC Milan football club returned from his Bermuda holiday home with 25 "recipes" for a better future involving jobs, tax breaks and crackdowns on illegal immigration. Cheered on by his three TV stations and publishing empire, he has brushed aside criticisms that such power will present conflict of interest issues if he is elected. The man who brought soap operas and show girls to Italian TV always appears sunny. He stops smiling only when denouncing his opponents as "child-eating communists".

Family and yacht complete the image. His 34-year-old daughter Marina, vice-president of his holding company Fininvest, posed in a black bikini for the lifestyle magazine Oggi while the accompanying text praised her physique and brains. Kristen Pazik, the girlfriend of Berlusconi's son Pier Silvio, 31, posed nude for an eight-page spread in Italy's GQ magazine. Her potential father-in-law was the most fascinating man in the world, she revealed. Flaunting wealth is a calculated gamble to appeal to Italian aspirations.

The man the media call the Cavalier intends to replicate the tactics which won him last April's regional election. A 37,000-tonne cruiser ship, renamed the Ship of Freedom, was backed up with a fleet of planes and vehicles. Berlusconi instructed canvassers to carry sweets to ward off bad breath, a handkerchief to dry their hands and to always clean public lavatories after use in case voters thought they had dirtied them. "Make sincere compliments to people. Tell the ladies, 'what a lovely smile, what elegance'."

He is competing with Rutelli for floating centrist Catholics. "Anti-communism is a moral duty," he has repeatedly said. "We have two candidates fighting a presidential-style campaign, just like Blair and Hague, but without a cohesive two-party system behind them. They do not have fully developed manifestos on which people can judge them, so image becomes more important," says James Walston, of the American University of Rome.

Flashes of dirty tricks are a taste of what is likely to come, says Prof Walston. Branded an abortionist and derided by Berlusconi allies for adopting an Ecuadorean child, Rutelli has reminded voters that the Cavalier has been married twice. Oblique references to sexuality have been made.

Today's press conference in Milan, his opponent's heartland, is a typically bold move but Rutelli has a mountain to climb. Fractious and unwieldy, the ruling coalition surprised itself by managing to agree on a new name: "The Olive Tree Together for Italy". Not quite as snazzy as Berlusconi's House of Liberty. But it's Rutelli's job to make up for that. He will spend the next few months traversing Italy in a bus trying to build momentum. Sitting in his office in Rome, he looks sad for a moment. "We don't have a boat."

fields.headline: Crossing the tracks
fields.standfirst:
Justin Rowlatt is a journalist who was involved in the Hatfield train crash. But does that make him a reporter or a victim?

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Justin Rowlatt is a journalist who was involved in the Hatfield train crash. But does that make him a reporter or a victim?
fields.body:
I got a message from my office on Wednesday morning saying that Gloria Hunniford's chat show had rung to invite me to be a guest. I knew perfectly well what Gloria wanted. They wanted me on the show as a "victim".

I was unfortunate enough to be one of the 200 or so people who caught the 12.10 London to Leeds train on Tuesday last week. That morning I'd been in the ITN building on Gray's Inn Road collecting a computer. I was on my way back to my office in Leeds. A routine journey.

Or at least it was until just before 12.30 when the crash took place.

My first instincts were journalistic. I dug out my mobile and told the Channel 4 News newsdesk that I'd been in a serious train crash. It was only later that the bizarre transition from reporter to victim took place.

As I walked towards the back of the train the severity of the accident became clear. Half the roof of the buffet car had been ripped off and it was with trepidation that I looked in at the twisted metal of the seats and the litter of newspapers and bags. I expected to see mangled corpses.

Later I'd hear myself describing that moment again and again on radio and TV. I did a live interview with the ITN's new 24-hour news channel and then the ITV lunchtime bulletin. I said the roof had been peeled back "like a sardine can".

As the other passengers were led away to be taken on to the reception centre I asked to stay behind. I still thought of myself as a reporter and that helped me deal with the horror of it. But as soon as I stepped over the police cordon at the end of the road I stopped being a reporter and became one of the reported. By the time I crossed that makeshift line I was the only eye-witness still on the scene and everyone needed a first-hand account of what had happened.

I've been part of the press pack many times but I've never had to face it and I wasn't really prepared for how it would feel.

I agreed to do an interview with ITN's ITV team. The camera was set up just beyond the police cordon. As soon as the interview began all the other journalists huddled around. There seemed to be dozens of them: five or more TV crews, a clutch of press photographers and who knows how many radio and print journalists.

It's a very strange thing to have that much attention focused on you. The lights, the people fighting to ask the next question. Even more strange is when your interviewers have got the quotes they want. Then - almost as quickly as the press pack gathers - it evaporates. Everyone is off to ferret out the next element of their story.

Normally I'd be with them. Today I was the one left on my own.

There's no doubt that in a crisis like this it can be cathartic to talk about what has happened - it certainly was for me. But as I discovered, it's a dangerous game. I wanted the attention but what I wasn't ready for was how it would feel when the pack turned its back. You're left feeling very lonely. And for people who don't understand the workings of the press that feeling must be even more pronounced.

One of the ITN cameramen - Bruce Shayler - must have sensed that I was starting to get a little shaky. He led me away for a hot, sweet cup of tea.

That's when I began to feel the impact of what had happened. I did some other interviews later that day but at that moment, cradling my tea in my hands, I was no longer a journalist. At that moment I was just another shocked and frightened passenger. Just another victim.

I turned Gloria down though.

fields.headline: Deayton and co blasted away by Schwarzenegger
fields.trailText: Have I Got News For You made a disappointing move from BBC2 to BBC1 on Friday night, losing out to ITV's Arnie Schwarzenegger film repeat Eraser despite a heavy promotional push.
fields.body:
Have I Got News For You made a disappointing move from BBC2 to BBC1 on Friday night, losing out to ITV's Arnie Schwarzenegger film repeat Eraser despite a heavy promotional push.

The topical news quiz, shifted after 19 series on BBC2 to bolster BBC1's ratings campaign, did not add significantly to its BBC2 audience, averaging 6.5m and a 28% share from 9pm. Eraser on ITV drew an average audience of 7.7m and a 37% share from 9pm-11pm.

In fact, Eraser, which features Arnie as a US government witness protection agent, got the better of BBC1's entire new post 9pm line-up, also seeing off a Vicar of Dibley repeat, the Ten O'Clock News and new sitcom Too Much Sun.

The 10pm news bulletin attracted 4.9m, slightly down on last Friday's final Nine O'Clock News, which averaged 5m. But it had a bigger audience share, with 24%, compared with the last Friday's 22%.

At 9.30pm the Vicar of Dibley repeat averaged 5.7m and a 25% share. After the news at 10.30pm new BBC1 comedy Too Much Sun - which features Full Monty star Mark Addy as a Brit writer trying to make it in Hollywood - opened with a paltry 3m and 18% share.

Elsewhere on Friday night, BBC2 debuted Clarissa and the Countryman, Clarissa Dickson Wright's first new televisual outing since the death of her Two Fat Ladies co-presenter Jennifer Paterson. The show, in which Ms Dickson Wright teams up with friend and farmer Johnny Scott to explore country matters, opened with 2.3m and a 10% share at 8pm.

On Saturday night, Parkinson benefited from its move from Friday and the inheritance bequeathed by Casualty. The long-running chat show, whose guests included Ian Botham, Richard Attenborough and Richard Wilson, averaged 6.8m and a 30% share from 9.05pm. The previous week Parkinson had bowed out on Friday night with 5.5m and 25% in the 9.30pm slot.

Over on ITV from 9.05pm, customs and excise drama The Knock returned with the first of four 90-minute stories. The drama, which featured a guest appearance by Rik Mayall, averaged 6.6m and a 30% share.

Earlier in the evening, BBC1's Star for a Night Final was neck and neck with longer established ITV makeover show Stars in their Eyes, before pulling ahead of You've Been Framed in its final half-hour. The BBC1 show, fronted by former docu-soap star Jane McDonald, averaged 7.5m and a 36% share from 6.45-8.05pm.

Later on the Star for a Night Result show had 6.8m - a 32% share - following on from Parkinson at 9.55-10.15pm.

webTitle: 'I can't wait for the time when the BBC is asking us for the next Simpsons'

fields.headline: 'I can't wait for the time when the BBC is asking us for the next Simpsons'
fields.standfirst: Billie Piper shoots JFK and David Beckham explores feminism. Ex-Loaded man Tim Southwell is behind it all, and  Stephen Armstrong  asks, is it TV or is it a website?
fields.trailText: Billie Piper shoots JFK and David Beckham explores feminism. Ex-Loaded man Tim Southwell is behind it all, and Stephen Armstrong asks, is it TV or is it a website?
fields.body:
There's a sort of mood that follows Tim Southwell around. It's an aura of intense chaos that clings to him like Pigpen's cloud of dust. You can't quite put your finger on it, but it's definitely there. When I arrive in his new office at Switch2, for instance, he's been held up by Railtrack's post-GNER train go-slow policy. His room is quiet and calm. One scruffy bloke in a T-shirt taps away at a computer. People wander about outside peacefully. It's a normal place of work on a normal Thursday morning. And then Southwell arrives.

Without anything actually happening, the whole tempo rises perceptibly. Men appear from nowhere, talking incredibly fast and throwing gags around like they're in a pub. Videos start playing mad cookery shows hosted by New York gangsters. Someone starts up Spinal Tap on a laptop DVD. And in the middle of it all Southwell's changing into his suit and parrying the gags with the best of them.

Later, we'll be having coffee in a nearby greasy spoon and he'll say to me that the most important way to get people's creativity and enthusiasm flowing is to convince them that they've got the best job in the world, and that they're working for the greatest company in the world. Right now the blokes bounding round his desk look just like they're having the time of their lives and, well, Jesus, they're getting paid for it.

Around the office there are two mottoes printed out on A4 and Sellotaped onto window blinds and cupboard doors: "If you always tell the truth, you won't need a good memory" and "Don't accept the old order. Get rid of it."

" 'Don't accept the old order,' that's Johnny Rotten from The Filth and the Fury," Southwell explains. "I've been watching that a lot recently. That was the attitude we had at Loaded and that's what I want us to have here. It's punk rock really. It gives everyone the idea that they can go out and do something."

"Here" is Switch2. It's a website, in a way, but it's a website with big ambitions. It's got four channels of streamed video - comedy, music, sports and film - and its programming aims make it clear that it basically wants to be a television company. Southwell joined it as editorial director from his job editing Loaded in April this year. Typically, his departure was steeped in chaos. IPC issued a statement saying he was leaving the magazine because he was no longer the Loaded man he used to be. Southwell reacted furiously, pointing out that IPC had tried to tempt him to stay by matching his salary and giving him share options.

"It annoyed me because it made everyone on the magazine look like old men," he grouches. "I thought that was ungenerous considering what we'd done for them. I went to Switch2 because it wasn't the easy option. The men's magazine market had reached this situation where when we put Martin Kemp on the cover our circulation dropped by 100,000. Inside, Loaded was still about celebrating that mad British eccentricity, but on the cover you could have taken it for Maxim."

He says he was attracted by the possibility of making the animated cartoons and mad, televised road trips that he always felt the Loaded lifestyle should have produced.

As a result, the site has cartoon shorts like Pop School, where brainless celebrities fumble around trying to explain serious issues from history. Thus, Billie Piper talks us through the Kennedy assassination and an animated David Beckham covers feminism. It's got a music show called Cock Soup, presented by ex-MTV frontman Eddie Temple Morris from his living room. Indie superstars Coldplay had to perform their latest single on toy instruments and were asked to bring in biscuits that expressed their personality. Naturally, they look somewhat bemused.

There's Market Boy, a 14-year-old lad who works on a market stall on Saturdays and who Switch2 got to visit the summer's festivals and taunt the famous and the lowly. At one point, he approaches Donna Air, who's clearly baffled but knows she's on camera so grins vacantly and mugs at the lens for all she's worth while Market Boy rips her to shreds. There are sick notes to print out and hand to your boss. There's Celebrity Freakshow, where Daniella Westbrook vacuums a room with her nose. But there are also one or two teething problems.

The site launched its revamped output last week, but to really zing it needs to be viewed using a broadband connection. On a home PC, the video moves too slowly and the sound races ahead leaving you baffled as to what's going on. The site also struggles with Macs, which only rules out 5% of the world's computer users - but that includes most of the media. "People tend to watch us in the office at lunchtime," Southwell says. "Once ADSL becomes national, that'll help, and Oftel are leaning on BT to open up their copper wires to other users, but it is going to take time."

The company maintains it is in for the long haul, and it's going to need to be. It was established in 1998 and is backed by Open, the digital television platform, and Sir Harry Solomon, founder and former chairman of Hillsdown Holdings plc. It plans to make money from banner ads, acting as a production company, selling merchandise and subscriptions from affiliate sites.

"I can't wait for the time when the BBC is asking us for the next Simpsons," Southwell says. "Think about it. This is video made by a bunch of berks which can be seen anywhere in the world. A bloke in China can watch Billie Piper shoot JFK. Loaded was like a gang, but this is bigger. We're like the Double Deckers on a Learjet."

He still talks fondly of the first year and a half when he and James Brown launched Loaded, but he doesn't really see Brown any more. Rumour has it there's some bad blood between them, but Southwell isn't keen to rake it over. "It used to bother me and I spent quite a bit of time thinking about it, but we're both pretty ego-driven people and I guess our paths don't cross any more," he says.

And then he's on to Three Men in a Boat which he's just read for the first time. He can't believe how brilliant it is. "It's like Loaded or Switch2 but a hundred years ago," he enthuses. After some banter about Jerome K Jerome, he's got to head back to the office to watch this psychotic cookery show they've just made called Marco Black. "So keep yourself nice," he says, and he's gone. And it's suddenly very calm.

webTitle: End in sight to US actors' unions strike

fields.headline: End in sight to US actors' unions strike
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: The striking actors who have caused Elizabeth Hurley so much embarrassment have reached a tentative agreement to end their six-month strike. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The striking actors who have caused Elizabeth Hurley so much embarrassment over the past week have reached a tentative agreement to end their six-month strike.

According to press reports, the US entertainment industry's two biggest unions last night reached an agreement with the advertising industry to end the ban on shooting commercials in the US. An announcement is expected later today.

Ms Hurley became a high-profile target for the actors' unions after they discovered she had performed in a non-union shoot for an Estee Lauder perfume ad.

Striking actors last week achieved a PR coup when they picketed the Los Angeles premiere of Ms Hurley's new film, Bedazzled, carrying banners branding her a "scab". The images appeared in newspapers around the world.

The agreement represents a victory for the actors' unions, who are understood to have secured improved cable television fees for their members. However, the unions failed to win one of their main demands, for a pay-per-play formula that would force advertisers to pay actors every time a commercial aired on TV. Instead actors will be paid a single upfront fee.

A number of celebrity actors added their support for the strike, boosting its profile and putting additional pressure on the ad industry. George Clooney, Tom Hanks, Paul Newman and Susan Sarandon all gave their support, either financially or by giving speeches.

webTitle: Arts: Jonathan Romney on Wong Kar-Wai

fields.headline: Mood music
fields.standfirst: With films such as Chungking Express, he became Hong Kong's coolest cinematic export. Now Wong Kar-Wai has drawn on personal experience for a 60s-set love story. He talks to  Jonathan Romney
fields.trailText: With films such as Chungking Express, he became Hong Kong's coolest cinematic export. Now Wong Kar-Wai has drawn on personal experience for a 60s-set love story. He talks to Jonathan Romney.
fields.body:
What is it that gets a film-maker accepted as an international exemplar of hipness? It may be something as simple as the habit of wearing sunglasses morning, noon and night (at least, when the press is present), though I suspect the quietly-spoken Wong Kar-Wai just likes something to hide behind. The Hong Kong director's hipster reputation really derives from his mid-90s films Chungking Express and Fallen Angels - fast-moving, fragmented stories about moody hitmen, zany gamines and mystery vamps, shot on the hoof in neon-steeped urban locations and imbued with a flavour of lovelorn melancholy.

But if the exuberance of those films could be misread as surface stylishness, his latest film moves into what you might call deep style. In the Mood for Love is indeed moody and amorous, and takes the art of mise en scène to rich new levels: you could swoon just at the heat of the wallpaper colours. Wong has previously claimed that his life is too boring for any of his films to be autobiographical. But this 1960s-set love story has more of himself than usual. Its setting is the Hong Kong of Wong's childhood; his family moved there from Shanghai in 1963, when he was five, and lived in the cosmopolitan district of Tsimshatsui, where his father ran a nightclub. "This film is more personal to me," he says. "It's about a certain period in our life, a certain lifestyle or manner that is lost already."

In the Mood for Love is also about history: starting in 1962, it ends with a newsreel of General de Gaulle in Cambodia four years later. What seems to be a sultry romantic vignette gestures at a wider picture. "We ended in 1966. That was a critical moment in Hong Kong history. There was the Cultural Revolution in China, and in Hong Kong we had the anti-colonial riots. Those people who had moved from China to Hong Kong since 1949 had to realise that the place is easily influenced by the changes in China."

Much of the work was a matter of historical reconstruction: shooting partly in Hong Kong, partly in Bangkok, Wong and his regular designer William Chang used real buildings, but made the interiors look like highly stylised sets. "The hotel is actually a British army hospital - you know, in the good old days," says Wong, and you can't quite gauge how much nostalgia or irony there is in that phrase. "I liked that hotel: architecturally it was wonderful. But it's gone now."

Wong's new film may come as a shock to fans of his jazzier style, but then his work has always switched from mood to mood. A former genre screenwriter, Wong got into directing in 1988 with As Tears Go By, a straight cop story with MTV flourishes. But his follow-up, Days of Being Wild, established him as a master of mood: it was an almost dream-like study, with a dense atmosphere of rain, mildew and melancholy.

Wong Kar-Wai is renowned for filming as circumstances allow - Chungking Express, his next film, was famously shot in 1994 around Hong Kong with hand-held cameras. His methods, especially his aversion to fixed scripts, bring their own problems: "It's not easy. We can only work with people who know us very well and understand us."

"Us" includes his collaborators, regular designer William Chang and mercurial cameraman Chris Doyle. Wong has described their collaboration as being like a jazz band jamming, and he makes it sound remarkably easy: "I tell William, 'She's working in a shipping office,' and he'll do it. We don't have to discuss it; he doesn't have to show me a draft or anything. Then Chris will walk in, I'll say it's a day scene, and he'll light the set. Then I'll come in and see how it looks, we make some adjustments, and that's it."

People, he believes, misunderstand his methods: "Sometimes they think the way we work is very stylish and romantic, but actually it's the way we can survive and make the films. We can work with the things that we get, but not the things we wish we had. A lot of young film-makers say, 'OK, we'll make a film the Wong Kar-Wai way.' They think this is the way to make films, but I tell them that we work very hard - it's not a party."

Despite offers from Hollywood, Wong is sticking with his Asian stories. He is currently working on a film called 2046, the title referring to the 50th year after the handover of Hong Kong. "We want to explore how many things will be unchanged in our life. It is not so much science fiction - don't expect something like The Matrix. I think it will be more like an opera. We started with three stories, and I'm very curious about how many stories will be left in there at the end of the film."Elsewhere, Wong has intimated that 2046 and In the Mood for Love are, in some sense, both parts of the same film. And the latter, he admits, might not have been quite the same film had he not already been working on 2046.

Wong's projects have a habit of losing branches: a whole segment of his last film, Happy Together, about a nightclub singer, was lost in cutting, while a projected continuation of Days of Being Wild exists only in palimpsest, in the otherwise inexplicable appearance of a new character at the end of the film. Equally, new projects sprout fully-formed out of old ones. In the Mood for Love started as a 30-minute episode of an intended portmanteau film, which itself was a rethink of something else. Wong had planned a feature called Summer in Beijing, to be shot in mainland China, but the Chinese government refused a permit. "I still wanted to make a film called Summer in Beijing, but in Macao, in a restaurant called Beijing. We called the project Three Stories About Food. And one of the stories became In the Mood for Love."

There is often a sense that Wong's films refer to each other, subliminally or otherwise: the heroine of In the Mood for Love, Wong says, both is and isn't an older version of the ingenue soda-pop vendor played by the same actress, Maggie Cheung, in Days of Being Wild. "I wanted to give Maggie some references about Hong Kong in the old days. The only reference she had in her mind was her mother. One day I told her, 'OK, don't let the dresses or the look or the behaviour make you uneasy. You didn't have any problems in Days of Being Wild [set in 1960].' She said, 'No, because I think that girl is me.' I said, 'OK, why don't we consider this character as the same girl? Ten years later you marry somebody and you find your husband is cheating on you. Can you consider this as Days of Being Wild Part 2? It's a sequel.' Somehow it worked."

"The way we make films is very organic - it's not a product. It's not like saying, 'OK, we've finished a film and a film should be like this for ever.' I think some day we can go back and we can grow something out of it." Projects cross-pollinate and, like collapsed trees in a forest feeding new growth, one film seems to fall through just so that others can sprout off it. Judging from In the Mood for Love, Wong Kar-Wai's garden of forking paths may become even richer and denser.

 In the Mood for Love is released on October 27.

fields.headline: Scully plans QXL TV tie-up
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Hugh Scully is to take QXL into the TV arena with a series of initiatives that tap into his broadcast experience, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Hugh Scully is to take QXL into the TV arena with a series of initiatives that tap into his broadcast experience.

The first, a tie-up with Sky Sports to sell Wembley stadium memorabilia, is being simultaneously broadcast live on the internet and Sky Sports One on October 30.

In an exclusive interview with Media Guardian, Mr Scully said the next broadcast-related step would be with another big media company in his area of expertise, suggesting a QXL-branded Antiques Roadshow.

Mr Scully, who sold his World of Antiques website to QXL in October for £3m on condition that he would be the front man for the service, relaunched the website in April. The site, which taps into 26 experts scattered throughout the UK, has recently cut down its original valuation price tag, down from £12m to £5m.

While Mr Scully says the World of Antiques website is doing "phenomenally well", there are no traffic or sales figures to support this. QXL refuses to give any figures other than general ones - 1.1m members across all European websites - and Mr Scully said he wasn't in a position to know how many valuations came through the site each week given that they were automatically farmed out to the relevant experts.

"It's still very early days for us, we've only had the site up and running since April," said Mr Scully. "What we're finding though is people are saying what a wonderful thing it is to have something valued while sitting at their desks."

He added that feedback indicated that users were not put off by having to take photos of their items, then scan them into a digital format and upload them to the website. Insiders have voiced concerns about whether the business has long-term sustainability given the target demographic would not be at ease scanning photographs or likely to be early adopters of web services.

Internally, while the World of Antiques site is seen as a quality addition to the QXL portfolio, many think it won't work because the old-fashioned antiques trade likes to see and touch an item, not view digital photographs of it, which explains the thinking behind the move towards a TV broadcast-type model.

Insiders have voiced concerns about whether the business has long-term sustainability given the target demographic would not be at ease scanning photographs or likely to be early adopters of web services. Internally, while the World of Antiques site is seen as a quality addition to the QXL portfolio, many think it won't work because the old-fashioned antiques trade likes to see and touch an item, not view digital photographs of it, which explains the thinking behind the move towards a TV broadcast-type model.

fields.headline: WH Smith admits newspaper distribution 'below par'
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: WH Smith has admitted that its wholesale operation is underperforming, following criticism from the NPA. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
WH Smith has admitted that its wholesale operation is underperforming, following a statement from the Newspaper Publishers Association which attacked its service levels as "below par".

Late last week the NPA issued a press release providing distribution figures from different newspaper publishers, comparing WH Smith with rival distributors. A statement from the NPA quotes spokespeople for the Telegraph Group, News International, Mirror Group Newspapers (MGN), Associated Newspapers and the Guardian, who have all provided figures.

In each case, the spokesmen criticise WH Smith's distribution. The Telegraph Group's spokesman says "despite their depots being in the more affluent parts of the country, Smiths feature strongly in the bottom half. The Telegraph Group has put a disproportionate amount of effort into attempting to improve WH Smith News' performance - but it has been an uphill battle."

MGN claims that WH Smith wholesalers have been "consistently over-represented" in the bottom half of its performance league tables for wholesale agents, adding: "It is disappointing to report that WH Smith, as our biggest wholesaler, consistently underperforms in all these areas compared to the other wholesale groups."

WH Smith's admission is a U-turn on its stance last week - when it accused the NPA of "propaganda". The newsagent and wholesaler now concedes it has suffered distribution service problems. A spokeswoman said: "We do take comments like these very seriously...we do accept that our service levels do not always reach the standards we aim for."

The NPA is responding to moves on the part of WH Smith to force newspaper publishers and distributors to move onto its wholesale national distribution network. Newspaper and magazine publishers have slammed the plans, which they say will reduce choice and put many small retailers out of business.

The dispute between the NPA and WH Smith follows similar wrangles between WH Smith and the magazines industry. Last month the Periodical Publishers Association published a compromise plan which would allow WH Smith to move towards more centralised distribution, but would guarantee versatility for local retailers. WH Smith has yet to respond to the plans.

fields.headline: The lowdown on Geoffrey Chaucer
fields.trailText: Pass notes on Chaucer? Didn't Letts Study Guides already cover him? Undoubtedly, and with the kind of in-depth analytical skill one would expect for the princely sum of £2.99.
fields.body:
Pass notes on Chaucer? Didn't Letts Study Guides already cover him? Undoubtedly, and with the kind of in-depth analytical skill one would expect for the princely sum of £2.99.

So why are we providing a shoddy 45p version? In honour of Mr Chaucer, who passed away some 600 years ago this Wednesday.

But today's Monday. Yes, which gives you time to send flowers and a card of condolence to the Chaucer family.

Thank you. Now tell me all about The Canterbury Tales. Geoff didn't just write The Canterbury Tales. He started off with translations, such as The Romaunt of the Rose. But his first major work was The Book of the Duchess.

Oh, I thought that was one of Andrew Morton's best-selling biographies. No, The Book of the Duchess was a 1,300-line poem, which employed the popular "dream-vision" form.

Something akin to the Bouncer's Dream episode of Neighbours? Exactly. Just like that. However, Chaucer's better known works are Troilus and Criseyde, which has been regarded as the first English novel, and ...

... The Canterbury Tales! Yes, The Canterbury Tales, a collection of 24 stories delivered by a group of pilgrims, including a knight, a pardoner, a monk, a miller and a wife of Bath, as they progress from the Tabard Inn in Southwark to the shrine of Thomas a Becket at Canterbury. This is Chaucer's most read work.

Hmm, well, I haven't actually read it. I just skipped to the racy bits and watched the TV version. Yes, it is a little difficult to read if one is not accustomed to Middle English. However, it is important to note that Chaucer's use of his mother tongue rather than French or Latin, was revolutionary.

I have noted it well. Well done.

Don't say: "By God," quod he, "for pleynly, at a word, Thy drasty rymng is nat worth a toord!" (The Canterbury Tales, Sir Thopas)

Do say: "By golly! In truth, your horrible poetry is not worth toffee!"

webTitle: 'Parents' fights off new box office challenges

fields.headline: 'Parents' fights off new box office challenges
fields.trailText: Meet the Parents, starring Robert De Niro and Ben Stiller, remained top of the US box office for the third consecutive weekend
fields.body:
Meet the Parents, starring Robert De Niro and Ben Stiller, remained top of the US box office for the third consecutive weekend. The family comedy survived challenges from three new movies, most notably Bedazzled, which stars Elizabeth Hurley and Brendan Fraser.

Meet the Parents has now taken $81m in the three weeks of its release, and looks set to perform well internationally.

Bedazzled, which opened to mixed reviews, was second, and Pay it Forward took third place at the domestic box office, despite a critical panning. The tear-jerker stars Oscar winners Helen Hunt and Kevin Spacey, and the Oscar-nominated Haley Joel Osment. Osment plays a schoolboy whose classroom assignment to think of a way to change the world mushrooms into a widespread altruistic movement.

USA Today warned that "the urge to gag will be overwhelming", "No wonder Arlene keeps a bottle of vodka in the chandelier. You would too with this demonic, passive-aggressive, New Age munchkin trying to run your life," says online magazine Salon.

Back in Britain, the Harrison Ford-Michelle Pfeiffer thriller What Lies Beneath went straight to the top of the box office on its opening weekend, toppling Disney's special effects spectacular Dinosaur.

webTitle: Charlie's Angel makes up with 'wonderful' Murray

fields.headline: Charlie's Angel makes up with 'wonderful' Murray
fields.trailText: Lucy Liu has spoken out to put an end to rumours that she got physical with co-star Bill Murray during the recent filming of Charlie's Angels
fields.body:
Lucy Liu has spoken out to put an end to rumours that she got physical with co-star Bill Murray during the recent filming of Charlie's Angels.

Liu, 31, admitted that she and the actor had some creative differences about one scene, but their disagreement never became physical.

"The rumours started going crazy that I swung at him. This guy is like 6'2". I wasn't going to pull out kung fu on him," Liu told America's TV Guide.

She said she and Murray were on good terms after making the film. "When I saw the movie, I called him up and left him a message and told him how wonderful he was," Liu said.

The movie, which has been dogged by adverse rumours since preproduction, will open in Britain on November 24. All three stars will be in the UK for a royal premiere in aid of the Prince's Trust, where our very own Charles will be in attendance. A source close to the prince said: "He was a big fan of the original programme and was really keen to meet the new line-up."

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week ten, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week ten, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Patrick Murray examines how they're doing...
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £140.72, Sean Ingle = £77.84, Paul MacInnes = £66.37, Football Unlimited punters collective = £68.02
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £140.72, Sean Ingle = £77.84, Paul MacInnes = £66.37, Football Unlimited punters collective = £68.02

Scott Murray
Newcastle v Everton: Everton to win @ 5/1 - £5

Mr Murray strikes again. You don't need many of these 5/1 shots to come in to make a profit but the more you get the better it is. And Mr M seems to get more than his fair share.

This isn't a bet I would have made myself. Everton were ravaged by injuries and totally failing to gel as a team; Newcastle were third in table coming off an impressive win at Middlesbrough. But Mr Murray looked beneath this and thought he saw a bit of value. As he rightly pointed out Newcastle's home form isn't what one might expect this season. As he a little more dodgily pointed out, Everton have already won in the north-east this season.

Just how significant things like this are is a matter of conjecture. The fact that Everton's last win was in the north-east is irrelevant in itself but if the footballers themselves take some heart from it then it could make a difference to the game. The same is true of 'bogey teams', lucky grounds and so forth. These are not things that should have a major bearing on your betting habits but they might be the final clincher that convinces you a bet is value.

So Mr Murray marches on, avoiding the easy favourites, seeking out the value, surging ahead of his less inspired colleagues. There might be something to this approach you know.

Sean Ingle
1x 50p accumulator and 4 x £3 trebles: Cambridge United to beat Colchester at @ 5/4; Norwich to draw with Sheffield United @ 9/4 Millwall to beat Stoke @ 7/4 and Porto to beat Sporting Lisbon @ 9/4

I'm very pleased to see our punters are starting to expand their horizons. By expanding into Europe Mr Ingle is venturing into far more verdant fields of value than he is likely to find in mundane old English football. And indeed of his four selections only Porto won.

European football is the home of value for one very simple reason, the bookies don't know much about it. I have said before that the secret to finding value is to look for the obscure and avoid the obvious - not to follow the crowd but to move in the opposite direction.

So if everyone is backing Man Utd (or Barcelona or Juventus) we should tend to back against them knowing that the bookies have set their prices believing that everyone will want to back Man Utd. If everyone is betting on win/draw/win markets we should look for more esoteric markets such as number of goals knowing that the bookies devote less effort to pricing them up correctly because they take comparatively few bets on them. And if everyone is betting on English football then we should bet on Portuguese football because the bookmaker will devote far less of his precious time getting his prices right on this extremely marginal part of his business than he will on the Premiership.

So if we are prepared to take some time to familiarise ourselves with a European League or two, to identify the best information sources on the web and to watch for breaking news on injuries, suspensions, club politics and so forth, we can know a lot more about them than the odds compilers we are up against.

If we know more than the bookies about something they are laying prices on, and we have the patience and the discipline to use that knowledge wisely, we can and will beat them. It's that simple. And obviously it's easier to know more than someone who knows little than it is to know more than someone who knows a lot.

Oh, and you can do unrestricted singles on European football too (FA edicts don't apply). Have I convinced you yet? I guess I'll find out next week.

Paul MacInnes
Liverpool v Leicester: Asian handicap, Leicester to win (+3/4) @ evens - £10

Ah, the wonder that is the Asian handicap. It really is worth getting to grips with this market because there is a fair bit of value to be had. And it really isn't that complicated, indeed once the penny drops it just becomes second nature (though even the inestimable Mr MacInnes seems slightly confused by it - contrary to what he wrote, had the game been a draw the whole of his bet would have won not just half).

The Liverpool v Leicester game is a good illustration of the bet's strengths. Basically by backing Leicester at evens with ¾ of a goal start Mr MacInnes was effectively laying Liverpool at evens but with the rather wonderful bonus that he only lost half the stake if Liverpool only won by one (as indeed they did). Given Leicester's good defensive record and their recent success at Anfield there seemed a fair chance Leicester could hang on for a draw, if not sneak a winner, and little chance they would lose by a landslide a la Derby.

By betting on the Asian handicap we avoid having to commit ourselves one way or another to the draw or to the Leicester win (or even the Liverpool win by one) just to the general idea that Leicester will do well. And it's a lot easier to identify a team that is underrated or overrated than it is to decide exactly how well or badly that team will perform.

In this case the decision to bet on the Asian handicap saved Paul money because he got half his stake returned as Liverpool won by one. Had Leicester won it would have cost him. The question is whether the increased chance of winning makes up for the shorter odds. Generally I would say it does but it's a judgement call. I dare say Scott is glad he played on the straight Everton win.

But enough, dear punter, I must go and formulate some ideas on staking plans for next week as requested by the incomparable Mr Ingle. Now there's something to look forward to.

webTitle: In brief: Costner's advertising bombardment called off

fields.headline: Costner's advertising bombardment called off
fields.trailText: In brief: Costner's advertising bombardment called offPlus: Brit film too racy for Ben & Jerry, new video awards announced and Demme opts for Intolerable Cruelty
fields.body:
 Early advertising for Kevin Costner's Cuban missile crisis film Thirteen Days has been abandoned; it was decided that the campaign - which shows missiles raining down on America accompanied by the line "You'll never know how close we came" would be in poor taste, following last week's explosion which killed 17 on the navy destroyer USS Cole. New Line spokesman Joe Nimziki said, "The ads were not exploitative or violent, but even the sight of a missile coming down on an American city wouldn't be right."

 American ice-cream manufacturers Ben & Jerry's are reported to have been angered about a new British film which shows their product being used as a sex aid. Chunky Monkey, named after the B&J ice-cream flavour, calls itself a dark comedy, and focuses on a serial killer's attempts to get ready for a big date. The offending scene sees the frozen desert feature prominently during a sex act between the main characters. Whereas big-name ice-cream rival Haagen Dazs's famously sexy advertising campaigns might lead some to believe this is precisely the purpose for which their product is intended, Ben & Jerry's products have made no attempt to associate themselves with the steamier side of life. Unilever, which bought Ben & Jerry's earlier this year, has threatened the film-makers with legal action and is seeking an injunction to prevent the film from being shown unless all references to their product are removed. Producer Phil Hunt is opposing the move however, insisting that deletions would remove "an integral part" of the film.

 The British Video Association and British Association of Record Dealers have announced new awards honouring the nation's favourite videos. Ananova reports that the video industry hopes the awards will become an annual event, with hundreds of thousands of viewers picking their favourites in categories such as best film, comedy or kid's movie. Voting forms are available at record and video shops and superstores, and a shortlist will be drawn up next month, with winners announced in January. There'll be no official ceremony, but organisers are hoping to establish one for the competition's second year.

 Silence of the Lambs director Jonathan Demme is in negotiations to direct Intolerable Cruelty, and is apparently courting Hugh Grant, Téa Leoni and Geoffrey Wright to star. The film concerns a revenge-seeking gold-digger, who marries a womanising Beverly Hills lawyer with the intention of making a killing in a divorce. The script has been rewritten by Joel and Ethan Coen.

fields.headline: Inaugural Ebook Awards honour veteran McBain and first-timer Smith
fields.trailText: British author Zadie Smith was one of the winners at Friday night's inaugural Frankfurt Book Fair Ebook Awards ceremony.
fields.body:
British author Zadie Smith was one of the winners at Friday night's inaugural Frankfurt Book Fair Ebook Awards ceremony.

Smith, who missed out on a place on the Booker shortlist this month, won best fiction work originally published in print and converted to ebook for her first novel, White Teeth. The awards, described as "the first designed to recognise achievements in the emerging ebook industry", also saw veteran crime writer Ed McBain win best fiction work originally published in ebook form for his Dectective Carella mystery, The Last Dance. The Grand Prize for the best original ebook was awarded jointly to EM Schorb for his murder mystery, Paradise Square, and David Maraniss for When Pride Still Mattered: A Life of Vince Lombardie, the biography of an American football coach. Both authors were awarded $50,000. The technology award was presented to Dr Peter N Yianilos for EbookMan, a handheld electronic multimedia device

The chairman of the judges, Peter Mollman, said he believed the major aims of the awards had been met. "The foundation was pleased to have accomplished several of the major goals of these first-time awards... to recognise and honour ebook authors, to promote the publishing of a wide variety of authors from around the world in the ebook format, and to bring ebooks to the wider attention of the reading public."

However, the awards have been criticised within the industry. Many ebook publishers were unhappy with the nomination of Ed McBain in the ebook originals section, claiming that the ebook version came out some four months after the print version (see earlier story, Controversy at Frankfurt ).

Also, just hours before the winners took the stage, another set of ebook prizes aimed purely at electronically published authors were announced. Pitched as "the ebook equivalent of the Sundance Film Festival", the Independent E-book Awards' only criterion is that entrants "must have been first published as an original electronic book". Categories include ebooks in fiction, non-fiction and short fiction (under 20,000 words), hypertext in fiction and non-fiction and digital storytelling in fiction and non-fiction.

FULL LIST OF WINNERS

Grand Prize - best original ebook:
EM Schorb, Paradise Square (Denlinger's Publishers Ltd) David Maraniss, When Pride Still Mattered: A Life of Vince Lombardi (Simon and Schuster)

Best fiction work originally published in ebook form:
Ed McBain, The Last Dance (Simon and Schuster)

Best non-fiction work originally published in ebook form:
Larry Colton, Counting Coup: A True Story of Bastketball and Honour on the Little Big Horn (iPublish.com/Time-Warner Books)

Best fiction work originally published in print and converted to ebook form:
Zadie Smith, White Teeth (Random House)

Best non-fiction work originally published in print and converted to ebook form:
Vilim Vasata, Uberleben in der Sintflu (Radical Brand) (Econ Verlag, Germany)

Ebook technology award:

fields.bodyText: British author Zadie Smith was one of the winners at Friday night's inaugural Frankfurt Book Fair Ebook Awards ceremony. Smith, who missed out on a place on the Booker shortlist this month, won best fiction work originally published in print and converted to ebook for her first novel, White Teeth. The awards, described as "the first designed to recognise achievements in the emerging ebook industry", also saw veteran crime writer Ed McBain win best fiction work originally published in ebook form for his Dectective Carella mystery, The Last Dance. The Grand Prize for the best original ebook was awarded jointly to EM Schorb for his murder mystery, Paradise Square, and David Maraniss for When Pride Still Mattered: A Life of Vince Lombardie, the biography of an American football coach. Both authors were awarded $50,000. The technology award was presented to Dr Peter N Yianilos for EbookMan, a handheld electronic multimedia device The chairman of the judges, Peter Mollman, said he believed the major aims of the awards had been met. "The foundation was pleased to have accomplished several of the major goals of these first-time awards... to recognise and honour ebook authors, to promote the publishing of a wide variety of authors from around the world in the ebook format, and to bring ebooks to the wider attention of the reading public." However, the awards have been criticised within the industry. Many ebook publishers were unhappy with the nomination of Ed McBain in the ebook originals section, claiming that the ebook version came out some four months after the print version (see earlier story, Controversy at Frankfurt ). Also, just hours before the winners took the stage, another set of ebook prizes aimed purely at electronically published authors were announced. Pitched as "the ebook equivalent of the Sundance Film Festival", the Independent E-book Awards' only criterion is that entrants "must have been first published as an original electronic book". Categories include ebooks in fiction, non-fiction and short fiction (under 20,000 words), hypertext in fiction and non-fiction and digital storytelling in fiction and non-fiction.
