webTitle: Fears for sculptor on life support

fields.headline: Fears for sculptor on life support
fields.standfirst: Sir Eduardo Paolozzi, Scottish artist renowned for bold geometric forms and big public works, has collapsed at his studio
fields.trailText: Sir Eduardo Paolozzi, Scottish artist renowned for bold geometric forms and big public works, has collapsed at his studio.
fields.body:
Sir Eduardo Paolozzi, one of the most prolific and distinctive British artists of the 20th century, is on a life-support machine after collapsing at his studio.

It is thought unlikely that the prolific Scottish-born artist will recover, leaving his family - he has three daughters by his former wife Freda Elliott - to decide whether to keep him alive or to allow him to pass away. Sir Eduardo, 76, collapsed at the end of August in Chelsea, west London.

Best known for his sculptures, Paolozzi was born to Italian parents in Edinburgh, where he attended the city's School of Art and then the Slade school in London before embarking on a career that has seen his bold, geometric interpretations of human forms and machinery installed in important sites across London and the UK.

In London large Paolozzis can be seen outside Euston station, on the forecourt of the British Library, inside the Queen Elizabeth II conference centre, and outside the British Museum and the Science Museum. He created the cast-aluminum doors at Glasgow's Hunterian gallery and the Dean gallery in Edinburgh is dedicated to his work.

Perhaps his most frequently viewed works are the glass mosaics at Tottenham Court Road tube station. His work also featured on a stamp in 1999 as part of a millennium collection.

His most recent major commission was London to Paris, an eight-metre-long, five-tonne flatbed locomotive, mounted on steel rails and carrying body parts including a giant head and pair of feet, which was installed in the courtyard of the Royal Academy on Piccadilly. This year he suggested it be moved to Paddington station as a memorial to the 31 people killed in the Ladbroke Grove train crash.

Paolozzi's star rose in the early 1950s when, after a spell studying in Paris he began producing work that according to Bryan Robertson, the former director of the Whitechapel gallery, "was hugely well informed about 20th century art".

Mr Robertson said: "His brilliance was evident at a very young age. He was immensely gifted and very un-English in his work, very knowledgeable about Giacometti [Alberto, the Swiss sculptor] and European art. He had enormous energy, and drew strength from his prolixity of interests. He was an energetic maker of graphics and layout as well as sculpture. He also had a great passion for collecting and was a serendipitous compiler of primitive works.

"There is nobody like him. He would pick up a piece of paper and a pencil and make you see something immediately. He could translate his point effortlessly."

Initially labelled a surrealist and then one of the first Britons to take on board Pop Art sensibilities forged in the United States, he latterly turned his attention to the major public works for which he is best known.

Paolozzi once said: "If it [sculpture] is out in a railway siding or it's stuck under your nose for the ordinary commuter who might not otherwise go to a sculpture park they can't miss it. It is a way of making sculpture more accessible."

Paolozzi's energy did not wane right up to his collapse. He was working on a number of commissions including bronze doors for St Giles cathedral and stained glass windows for St Mary's church, both in Edinburgh, another sculpture for the Royal Academy of which he is a senior academic, and set designs for the English Touring Opera's production of the Magic Flute.

Speaking this year he said: "Well I am still a poor old pro and I work as I always have. I just charge along, it's very instinctive and very difficult to explain."

webTitle: Ministers ready to compensate CJD families

fields.headline: Ministers ready to compensate CJD families
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Ministers will this week admit for the first time a government obligation to compensate families whose lives have been devastated by the human form of BSE.
fields.body:
Ministers will this week admit for the first time a government obligation to compensate families whose lives have been devastated by the human form of BSE.

A trust to administer "no fault" payments to relatives of the victims - 84 so far - is expected to be announced on Thursday, while a nationally-funded care package to help patients in the desperate last few months of their lives is also under consideration.

The cost could run into millions of pounds, but Tony Blair has accepted the government has a moral responsibility to the victims of variant CJD, linked for the past four years to BSE, the cattle disease that has already cost British and EU taxpayers £3.5bn in compensation and subsidies to farmers and the meat industry.

In addition, health secretary Alan Milburn will announce plans to "fast track" diagnosis following complaints at the length of time it takes for cases to be referred from GPs to consultants and the CJD surveillance unit at Edinburgh. This should allow medical and social services to swing into action more quickly.

Victims' families are preparing to launch court cases following this Thursday's publication of the long-awaited report of the inquiry into the BSE disaster, but ministers hope their gesture will limit political fall-out hitting the present administration. The Treasury had previously been reluctant to support compensation because of the precedent it might set for liability. The Major government refused to countenance any compensation when it learned of a probable link between vCJD and BSE in March 1996.

Estimates of the final death toll from the incurable condition that can take decades to develop range from the low hundreds to 136,000, but the number of cases has accelerated in recent months.

A health department source said: "There is a sense among families that not enough is being done for them. We want to make sure that families get the support.''

Another government source said: "The government believes that if we can compensate farmers for cattle, then we should compensate these people. There is a moral obligation because something went wrong in government."

David Body, the lawyer representing most vCJD families, said: "A care package is what our clients and ourselves have lobbied for during the past two years so the families of future victims receive better care than experienced by victims and families in the past. Previously families whose loved ones have contracted vCJD have received often poor and inconsistent standards of care. It has been something of a postcode lottery because of a lack of central funds."

Mr Body has estimated a central care package might cost nearly £50,000 per victim on average. The Department of Health believes that so far between £6,000 and £60,000 has been spent by local health authorities and social services on individual patients. The length of care needed between symptoms first becoming evident and death has varied from a few months to more than three years.

The health department recently issued new guidance, from spotting early signs of the disease, which has often at first been mistaken for depression, to funeral arrangements.

Early symptoms include mood swings and problems with balance. Patients fairly rapidly deteriorate, having problems with swallowing and continence before lapsing into coma before death.

Relatives, many of whom have given up work or cut back on hours to nurse relatives at home, have been divided over the extent of compensation but nearly all have been furious that they have never been offered personal apologies for the epidemic that is thought to have killed 78 people and left six others fatally ill.

David Churchill, whose son Stephen was the first known victim in May 1995, has suggested individuals who are criticised in the report covering the first 10 years of the crisis to 1996 should have their pensions stopped as punishment.

The inquiry team, headed by Lord Phillips of Worth Matravers, is expected to criticise both individual ministers and civil servants, and institutional failures within government, for failure to recognise the extent of the risk to humans from BSE and check that measures to combat such an eventuality were policed properly.

The prime suspect for causing the human epidemic is BSE-infected meat, but the use of vaccines made from infected cows is among other possibilities. An 11-year failure even to check those properly was revealed last week when the government had to recall stocks of a polio vaccine because it used bovine material from British herds against the spirit of guidelines dating from 1989.

fields.headline: Abducted baby reunited with parents
fields.trailText: A couple were reunited with their day-old son today, 13 hours after the infant was snatched from a maternity hospital, Irish police said.
fields.body:
A couple were reunited with their day-old son today, 13 hours after the infant was snatched from a maternity hospital, Irish police said.

A 19-year-old woman was arrested in connection with the abduction after an overnight search led detectives to a hotel where the infant was found safe and well, said a spokesman for the Garda Siochana, the Irish police force.

Meanwhile, managers at Cork's Erinville Hospital were today reviewing security arrangements, which had alerted staff to the baby's abduction but failed to stop a woman fleeing the hospital grounds with the child.

The parents, Brigid and John O'Brien, from Ballyporeen, Co Tipperary, were said to be "overjoyed" at the return of their son, who was just eight hours old when he was snatched from the second floor nursery of the hospital.

A security tag on the infant's foot triggered a security alarm as he was being carried down the stairs by a woman. But security staff at the hospital could only watch as the kidnapper ran to a waiting red Toyota Corolla, which was then driven off the wrong way along a one-way street.

Detectives, armed with the registration number of the vehicle and footage from closed circuit television cameras at the hospital, believed they knew the identity of the woman and continued searching throughout the night.

A vehicle was spotted in a hotel car park in Midleton, about 10 miles from Cork, and the baby, a woman and two girls, said to be aged 12 and 14, were found booked into a room.

After a medical examination, the infant was taken by ambulance back to the hospital, where police said he needed specialist treatment, and was reunited with his parents, who also have two daughters.

Gerry O'Dwyer, deputy general manager of the southern health board, said security measures at the hospital were now being reviewed. "Obviously there are lessons in it for everybody, and we will be working very closely with the Gardai to ensure that we have a more comprehensive system in place," he said.

webTitle: Government to launch £5m family tax credit drive

fields.headline: Government launches £5m family tax credit drive
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Gordon Brown is putting £5m into an ad campaign to promote the family tax credit, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, is pumping £5m into an advertising campaign to promote the family tax credit and convince the public that work pays more than benefits alone.

A national TV, press and radio campaign through St Luke's will run until the end of the year to promote the Working Families Tax Credit (WFTC), originally launched in September 1999.

The campaign, which will feature real beneficiaries of the tax credit, also intends to highlight how it provides help with childcare costs. Government estimates show that on average families which claim the credit are £30-a-week better off.

Sue McGrath, account director at St Luke's, said: "It was always our intention to have a second phase of the campaign so that we could show how families have been benefiting. There are lots of people out there who didn't feel this was for them because it was being viewed as a benefit. What we have tried to do is show how much more money people will have as a result."

Since the launch of WFTC, 1.1m families have started to claim the in-work benefit, which guarantees a family with a full-time working member a minimum income of £207 per week.

The government believes that between 1.5m and 1.75m families could be eligible.

Mr Brown has set a target for a second successive Labour government to lift a further 1m children out of poverty.

webTitle: Sceptical readers hunger for real debate on Europe

fields.headline: Sceptical readers hunger for real debate on Europe
fields.standfirst: British readers want a debate on Europe and it's up to the press to provide it, Peter Preston writes.
fields.trailText: British readers want a debate on Europe and it's up to the press to provide it, Peter Preston writes.
fields.body:
When Charles Moore, now editor of the Daily Telegraph , was editing its Sunday sister in the early 90s, he used to run a column by his distinguished predecessor, Peregrine Worsthorne. One day old Perry turned in a piece comparing some drivers who'd cut him up on the motorway to the bombers of Dresden, which young Charlie thought frankly "ludicrous".

But it was printed, of course, and in flooded the protest mail. Dear Sir, how dare Worsthorne trivialise the bravery of our servicemen who risked their lives over Dresden? From which, Moore says, he learned afresh how surprising (in a predictable way) readers can be.

That tale was retold the other day at an International Press Institute seminar where Moore and Neil Kinnock squared off over the British media's reporting of Europe; and it began to touch areas where more mundane charges of Euro-bias do not reach. Simply: is the sceptic tide all got up by the press, or does it reflect what ordinary people think for themselves?

Kinnock, of course, doesn't think so. He believes, with passion, that a powerfully hostile press doesn't give him or his fellow European commissioners a fair shake. What's more, it is shot through with "madness, wild exaggeration and venality - which amounts to an attack on the intelligence of the British people". And he comes armed with too many damning examples for comfort.

But let us stick to Charles Moore, because it's a rare treat to find a national editor out in public defending his line (you wouldn't find Paul Dacre of the Mail doing that) and because the Moore diagnosis breaks newer ground. For where, he inquires, is the alleged mis-match in firepower? The Europhiles have the Mirror, FT, Guardian, Independent and Express (roughly 40 per cent of national dailies, which echoes the breakdown of actual public opinion), plus the BBC, the Government and 90 per cent of continental newspapers? Nothing unfair about that.

No, he says, what infuriates the Brussels bureaucrats is that anybody should dare to criticise or interrogate them. They're not used to it: they are used, rather, to a compliant press lobby which takes down their statements and files them, largely unedited, to the capitals of Europe where belief in the Union isn't an issue.

That's not Moore's view of a newspaper's job. He wants to ask the "tricky question", to find out "what's going on here". And he does so, in part, because it's what his readers demand. When he was editing the Spectator in the 80s, a lonely critic of the Single European Act, he was inundated with letters of support from readers who'd made up their own minds, and not because of any national press campaigning (because there wasn't any). Thus he carries on. Of course, he says, turning to Kinnock, the press used to run a lot of tales about the loony left and some of them, to be sure, went over the top. But can you, Neil, tell me now that the loony left didn't exist - or that this wasn't a fight worth fighting?

Now some of this is, at best, contentious. The supposedly Europhile papers don't have anywhere near 40 per cent of sale, or much crusading zeal. The Guardian thinks there are more important things than joining the euro: the FT preaches to the converted of Frankfurt: the Express stable is up for sale. Yet there is force to Moore's basic thrust.

Kinnock himself dislikes a Brussels press lobby "which swallows the tablets as dished out and sends them on their way to Berlin or wherever... with a congenital laziness about the way Europe is reported". For 42 years, he says, "the European Commission saw no reason to be explanatory". Changing that is hard work in progress.

The entrancing thing about the Moore thesis is that, intrinsically, it downgrades the power of the press. Perhaps the Mail and the Sun aren't successful because they bang on about the euro; perhaps such obsession is irrelevant to their success.

Guardian readers, on a recent Mori research survey, are 66 per cent in favour of joining the euro: but the paper isn't. Seventy-three per cent of Daily Star readers are against yet the Express group to which it belongs is a joiner.

There are no symmetries here. The question that UK sceptics asked after the Danish referendum - how come the Danes said no when their entire press said yes? - can be put another way round. How come the Danish press didn't matter, and what makes anyone suppose that the British press matters more?

You may feel for Kinnock in his struggle for reform; but there is a narrow sense in which Charles Moore is right. Britain's newspaper readers want a debate, so they'd better have one, and if that means that Brussels has to start debating, so much the better. It's no sin to be sceptical. The journalistic sin, for both sides, is making up facts to fit your bill. And the human sin is to inflate your self-importance.

That's not Moore's view of a newspaper's job. He wants to ask the "tricky question", to find out "what's going on here". And he does so, in part, because it's what his readers demand. When he was editing the Spectator in the 80s, a lonely critic of the Single European Act, he was inundated with letters of support from readers who'd made up their own minds, and not because of any national press campaigning (because there wasn't any). Thus he carries on. Of course, he says, turning to Kinnock, the press used to run a lot of tales about the loony left and some of them, to be sure, went over the top. But can you, Neil, tell me now that the loony left didn't exist - or that this wasn't a fight worth fighting? Now some of this is, at best, contentious. The supposedly Europhile papers don't have anywhere near 40 per cent of sale, or much crusading zeal. The Guardian thinks there are more important things than joining the euro: the FT preaches to the converted of Frankfurt: the Express stable is up for sale. Yet there is force to Moore's basic thrust. Kinnock himself dislikes a Brussels press lobby "which swallows the tablets as dished out and sends them on their way to Berlin or wherever... with a congenital laziness about the way Europe is reported". For 42 years, he says, "the European Commission saw no reason to be explanatory". Changing that is hard work in progress. The entrancing thing about the Moore thesis is that, intrinsically, it downgrades the power of the press. Perhaps the Mail and the Sun aren't successful because they bang on about the euro; perhaps such obsession is irrelevant to their success. Guardian readers, on a recent Mori research survey, are 66 per cent in favour of joining the euro: but the paper isn't. Seventy-three per cent of Daily Star readers are against yet the Express group to which it belongs is a joiner. There are no symmetries here. The question that UK sceptics asked after the Danish referendum - how come the Danes said no when their entire press said yes? - can be put another way round. How come the Danish press didn't matter, and what makes anyone suppose that the British press matters more? You may feel for Kinnock in his struggle for reform; but there is a narrow sense in which Charles Moore is right. Britain's newspaper readers want a debate, so they'd better have one, and if that means that Brussels has to start debating, so much the better. It's no sin to be sceptical. The journalistic sin, for both sides, is making up facts to fit your bill. And the human sin is to inflate your self-importance.

webTitle: Striking actors reach agreement with industry reps

fields.headline: Striking actors reach agreement with industry reps
fields.trailText: A tentative agreement has been reached between the striking Screen Actors Guild and advertising industry representatives to end the longest strike in Hollywood history
fields.body:
A tentative agreement has been reached between the striking Screen Actors Guild (SAG) and advertising industry representatives to end the longest strike in Hollywood history, reports Yahoo! News.

A spokesman for AFTRA (American Federation of Television & Radio Artists) said that the two sides had reached agreement on the dispute over pay for television commercials, but provided no further details.

The strike by AFTRA and the Screen Actors Guild, which together represent 135,000 actors, began May 1. Both sides had said they were nearing a deal when the negotiations broke down on September 27.

fields.headline: WPP revenues rise 21%
fields.trailText: 10am: WPP, the world's biggest advertising group, has posted a 21% rise in revenues, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
WPP, the world's biggest advertising group, has posted a 21% rise in third quarter revenues, as new business poured in from existing and new clients including Ford, Nike, Goldman Sachs and Motorola.

WPP, which concluded its takeover of New York-based ad agency Young & Rubicam earlier this month, said it had reaped net new billings of £830m ($1.20bn) in the three months to the end of September, compared with £730m in the same period a year earlier.

Revenues grew 21.2% at constant currencies to £679.4m, after climbing 19.5 percent in its core North American market, which accounts for almost half the group's revenues.

In other areas, revenues rose 34.3% in continental Europe, 11.2% in Britain and 24.8% in Asia, Latin America, Africa and the Middle East.

In terms of business, WPP said in its trading update that its core advertising and media sector, which accounts for almost half the group's business, posted 19.7% growth in revenues at constant currencies. Public relations and public affairs, which accounts for 10%, rose 44.7%.

Gareth Thomas, media analyst at Commerzbank, said: "The results are definitely better than expected. The advertising industry has definitely benefited from the recent Olympics and the US presidential election but the one thing to bear in mind is that these figures don't account for recent acquisitions.

"There were also some concerns about slowdown, but that only became an issue around late September so won't show in these results. You would not expect this sort of performance to be sustained."

fields.headline: A fight against the floods
fields.standfirst: Every Monday wisden.com talks to a cricketing figure about his plans for the close season. This week we meet Roy McLaren, the Worcestershire groundsman who has to tend the wettest venue in the country
fields.trailText: Roy McLaren, 59, has been head groundsman at Worcestershire for 18 years
fields.body:
Roy McLaren, 59, has been head groundsman at Worcestershire for 18 years

"We have a lot of work to do at the end of the season. We have to scarify the pitch - which means get all the rubbish out of the top of the square before we put new grass seed in. Then we have to spike it. We use a hydrocorer - which drives spikes in about four inches - to aerate it and get water and air down to the roots. And then we top-dress it, that is put new soil on top. We have used Surrey loam since 1991.

"I wasn't particularly pleased with the square this year. We had real problems with the weather. New Road is on a flood plain and every time the river floods the water just percolates across the ground. The ground underneath the square is the wettest in the country by quite a long way. We managed to get the pitches quite firm but we never got them dry. We're looking at putting a ring drain round the square to try and control the water table.

"It's a little bit more relaxed in the winter than during the summer when we're hitting deadlines all the time: 11am, 1.15, tea, and so on. We try to keep the ground open all year as a tourist attraction. We leave all the gates open and the seats out until the first flood. We get people from all over the world coming over - especially Australia, New Zealand and South Africa. People used to buy memorial benches for relatives (though they don't so much now because of the cost), and they are always coming up and saying that their Uncle Fred died in 1973, could I show them where his bench is. About 95% of the benches are in the Ladies Pavilion so I can usually push people in roughly the right direction.

"Because there is more cricket played during the season we do more maintenance work during the winter. The team consists of myself, three assistant groundsmen and two juniors. We are working 8-4.30 at the moment though in the summer it can be half-six to half-ten - the floodlit games make for a very, very long day.

"At the moment I've got one young man taking branches off to be burnt, two lads trimming the big willow hedges that surround the ground, another putting the grass seed in, and I'm repairing the flagpole. But we are always within shouting distance of each other. In the summer you always get members chatting to you, asking you what you are doing and trying to ensure that you don't alter anything.

"You've got to be a cricket fan to do this job - if you weren't you'd go spare. My wife didn't like it much when I played, though as soon as our son started she became a very big fan. I've been a groundsman since I was 15. I left school to become a cricketer, but there were two other quick bowlers at Edgbaston. They shot up to six foot three, while I just shot out to 18 stone. Then I worked in Birmingham at the Lucas's car factory ground until the depression came in the car business. They used to employ 38,000 people there. Now it's probably about 2000. After they made me redundant I managed to get a job here.

"I like making videos with my camcorder if I have a bit of spare time. I've made a couple to help the ECB with their courses which they run in conjunction with the institute of groundsmanship. I teach a bit as well.

"I also enjoy reading, especially Alistair McLean, Clive Cussler and Dick Francis. Also the odd cricket book like Ian Botham's, Basil D'Oliveira's or Dickie Bird's. I'm not into a lot of analysis of the game though.

"My favourite current Worcester player is Graeme Hick. I saw him as a 16-year-old and to watch him get his 100th 100 here while Vikram Solanki got his first 100 at the other end was fantastic. Tom Graveney walked out with a glass of champagne when he did it, and it was a beautiful day. Worcester have won Championships and Sunday Leagues but that was my favourite moment. It was just so essentially Worcestershire. The word went around the town that Graeme was going to do it and people just kept coming in until, by four o'clock, it was practically full. It was just one of those things which will always stay with me.

"I'm having a week off this week - I'm going on a fly-cruise to Jersey with my wife Diane. We last went to the Channel Islands just after we got married in 1963, so it will be lovely."

Roy McLaren was talking to Tanya Aldred

webTitle: How technology has driven television's revolution in relaying the news

fields.headline: Now we go live to...
fields.standfirst: Jeremy Thompson  on how technology has driven television's revolution in relaying the news
fields.trailText: Jeremy Thompson on how technology has driven television's revolution in relaying the news.
fields.body:
"Here's a tenner for your expenses and a ticket to Belfast," growled Eddie the news editor. The year was 1970. I was a trainee reporter on the Cambridge Evening News and about to set off on my first "foreign".

"Any advice, boss?" I asked.

"Yes. Sharpen your pencil, take an extra notebook and make sure you've got some change for the 'phone. Now get out of here before I change my mind!" It was sophisticated stuff in those days.

Ten years on I was a television correspondent with BBC TV News, heading for South and Central America with Foreign Secretary Lord Carrington. Among my travelling companions was ITN correspondent Trevor Macdonald.

In those days Trevor and I shot our rival reports on film and recorded voice tracks on tape. The film cans were bundled into a well marked 'onion bag' and dispatched on the next flight to London: there was a fair chance they would arrive in time to appear on the following evening's news. Exhausted correspondents and camera crews then retired to a nearby beach or bar to consider the next story.

My crew and I were diverted to the Texas coast to cover Hurricane Allen. But before we could broadcast the amazing footage, we had to fly the length of the US to the BBC New York Bureau, the nearest place we could process and edit the film.

By 1990 I was with ITN reporting on the Gulf War. Mobile satellite dishes were now starting to transform the world of the television journalist. "Fly-away" dishes weren't quite the fairy-winged technological marvels they sounded, as many a TV engineer with back problems will testify, but at least they were portable (just). With up-links in Baghdad and the Saudi Arabian city of Dhahran, we found ourselves "going live" more than ever before. News picture-gathering was also more immediate with the advent of video cameras. Now tapes could be edited without delay - or put straight to air. The television correspondent was under increasing pressure to go live at a moment's notice.

As we moved over the border into Kuwait with the liberation forces, we had a sight of things to come. The first and only satellite link out of Kuwait City in those early hours was a cunning contrivance devised by a CBS camera crew. They had strapped and roped a dish on to an old flatbed truck and driven it across the desert from Saudi. Peter Sharp and I gratefully used it to broadcast the first live picture reports on ITN. What viewers didn't see was the CBS rag-and-bone-man's jalopy that was to fire the imagination of television engineers.

Nearly a decade later I was to see the benefits first-hand. Now a Sky News correspondent, I was waiting on the Macedonian border as the first Nato troops rolled into Kosovo - a province cut off from the world's view for many months. Within 15 minutes I was broadcasting live from inside Kosovo. The Yugoslav forces had left only moments before; KLA soldiers emerged from the hills to claim the villages; Gurkha infantrymen patrolled the streets searching out booby-traps; and British tanks trundled noisily by. I found bloodstains barely dry, hastily discarded family photographs, the wreckage of homes and lives - all live. By now we were armed with custom-made satellite trucks. Sky News boss Nick Pollard, had sent out four. So, I and my fellow correspondents - Keith Graves, David Chater and Andrew Wilson - were able to report the progress of the Nato peace-keeping force live all the way to Pristina while, from another satellite dish in the Kosovan capital, Tim Marshall charted the Yugoslav retreat as we headed towards him.

The speed, the flexibility and the immediacy of the coverage were at a level we had not been technically capable of producing before.

If you're wondering what's next, I'm worryingly reminded of a spoof I taped a few years back to mark Pollard's departure as executive editor of News at Ten. I was wandering round South Africa looking like a techno one-man-band with a digicam on one shoulder, a microphone strapped to my chest, an edit pack in hand and a dustbin lid - loosely representing a mini-dish - taped to my back. "The TV Correspondent of the Future" was the title. It's frighteningly close to coming true.

As the digital technology improves, so too does the TV news broadcaster's mobility and ability to reach the stories once deemed off the beaten track. On 24-hour rolling news channels live, breaking stories are the priority. Get there first, tell the story live, stay with the drama.

Mobile satellite trucks have enabled us to do that in Britain. But as the technology brings compression and condensing, it may soon be possible, thanks to mini satellite dishes, minicams and mini-edit packs, for a two-person team - a correspondent and camera operator/editor/engineer - to operate from the remotest corners of the globe.

The pros and cons of the broadcast news revolution? On the whole I think they are mainly pluses. On rolling news channels, a TV correspondent can tell his or her story as never before. The equipment allows them to go live from almost anywhere. They can move as and when the focus of the story shifts, updating it whenever there's something to add and turning round video pictures without delay.

But the immediacy also puts today's correspondent under a range of new pressures. There's precious little time to stop, think and prepare. At last week's Hatfield rail crash, some of my colleagues admitted they were often wired up at a live position doing two-way reports with the studio hour after hour. This left them little time to go news and picture gathering.

It's a familiar story across the industry. Field producers with each mobile team now play an important role as fact finders for on-air correspondents. Without good back-up there's always the danger of speaking out of necessity rather than from authority.

What this means is that there's a greater premium than ever on good journalism - the simple, basic tools of the trade. The TV news craftsmen and women who shine today are those who can not only deliver crisp and lucid live reports, but also put breaking stories into context, painting in the background. The TV hack who gives it to you fast and fair will never go out of fashion.

 Emmy Award winner Jeremy Thompson has been BBC television's North of England Correspondent; ITN's Chief Sports Correspondent, Asia Correspondent; Africa Correspondent and Sky's senior US Correspondent. He is now presenter of Sky's Live at Five and Sky's 9 O'clock News

fields.headline: Netvest posts promising results
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Netvest has reported financially sound results but has yet to prove it has a long-term business model, says Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet seed capital firm Netvest has reported financially sound results but has yet to prove it has a long-term business model for investing in early stage business-to-consumer start-ups.

Aim-listed Netvest pulled in pre-tax profits of £233,800 for the full year to May 31.

The company, which was part of a consortium that invested in the now-defunct Powernet Telecom, is profitable.

At the end of its financial year, Netvest's investments totalled £4.5m, while the market value of its quoted and listed investments was £4.9m, against a cost of £1.7m. The cost of unquoted investments was £2.8m.

Its portfolio remains varied. In the media sector, Netvest has stakes in Medi@invest, Pure Communication and Synergy Communications; in the dot.com world it has interests in Kelkoo, Intersaver.co.uk, E-garden and Gaming Internet; then there is MeanFiddler and investment fund Oxygen.

Andrew Balcombe, chairman of Netvest, said: "Our policy of investing primarily at an early stage in quality companies and helping these companies to obtain more value is beginning to bear fruit."

webTitle: Huston Jr to film dad's lost script

fields.headline: Huston Jr to film dad's lost script
fields.trailText: A lost screenplay by the late John Huston has been unearthed by the director's son, and is set finally to make it onto the big screen
fields.body:
A lost screenplay by the late John Huston has been unearthed by the director's son, and is set finally to make it onto the big screen.

Amparo, about a burned-out screenwriter, will be directed by the legendary film-maker's son, Danny Huston, who also has "polished up" the script. The project is about a screenwriter with writer's block, who heads for Mexico to get his creative juices flowing again. While there, he falls in love with a latina prostitute - Amparo.

"It was literally a discovery I made in one of his trunks," Huston told The Hollywood Reporter. "I'm terribly excited to make it. It's got a lot of potential. If there was ever a man who could weave a good yarn, it was my father."

One of the 20th century's greatest directors, John Huston's best known films include The Treasure of Sierra Madre (for which he received Best Director and Best Screenplay Oscars), The Asphalt Jungle, The African Queen and Prizzi's Honour.

Huston said he is looking to cast an unknown actress in the title role, while seeking a more established star for the role of the writer.

Amparo will be filmed in Manzanillo, a small town in central Mexico near the Pacific coast location of Puerto Vallarta, where John Huston had a home and filmed 1964's The Night of the Iguana.

Huston, whose directing experience comes primarily from TV movies, admitted that his father's unfinished screenplay project will bring with it difficulties, but hopes that the old man will be there with him, somehow.

"There are some scenes he has written that will be very difficult to achieve, but hopefully I can look up to the stars and have [my father] give me an occasional helping hand," he said.

webTitle: Ali biopic lives to fight another day

fields.headline: Ali biopic lives to fight another day
fields.trailText: After a week of fraught budget negotiations, Michael Mann's Muhammad Ali biopic, starring Will Smith, has been given the go-ahead
fields.body:
After a week of fraught budget negotiations, Michael Mann's Muhammad Ali biopic, starring Will Smith, has been given the go-ahead.

Studio executives at Columbia are said to have accepted new proposals satisfying them that the movie can be made within its estimated $105m (£70m) budget. Filming is set to begin in January.

The movie was almost abandoned after director Michael Mann told studio executives he couldn't guarantee the project would be delivered at the previously agreed cost.

It's understood that both star and director have taken reduced fees to get the movie made within its budget. In addition, Mann has elected to cut several days of New York location shooting.

A studio spokeswoman confirmed that the picture was back on track, saying: "We are pleased that we could work with all involved... to reach an understanding that will allow a great actor and a talented director to team up and tell the story of one of the best known men in the world."

webTitle: Albright makes historic visit to North Korea

fields.headline: Albright makes historic visit to North Korea
fields.trailText:
US secretary of state Madeleine Albright held unprecedented talks today with North Korea's
leader, Kim Jong Il, as she began laying the groundwork for a visit by President Bill Clinton to one of the last bastions of the
cold war.
fields.body:
US secretary of state Madeleine Albright held unprecedented talks today with North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, as she began laying the groundwork for a visit by President Bill Clinton to one of the last bastions of the cold war.

The two shook hands, and Mr Kim noted that Mrs Albright was the first secretary of state ever to visit North Korea. "This is a new one from a historical point of view," he said. "I am really very happy."

Mrs Albright responded, "I'm very glad to be here in your beautiful city."

The US secretary of state arrived to a low-key ceremony that belied the significance of her visit. Asked if the US was moving too quickly in its relationship with North Korea, she said: "We're not moving faster than it makes sense."

Despite the overtures, US officials warned in advance that serious differences remained between the two countries. Of primary concern is North Korea's missile development programme and its export of missiles to Iran and Syria. Mrs Albright planned to raise those issues with Mr Kim but officials said no agreements were expected.

South Korean officials welcomed the visit. "We must consider as desirable the North Korean moves to set up new relations with the outside world," presidential spokesman Park Joon-young said.

However, some critics feared the visit might make Pyongyang less willing to talk to the South, its rival since the country was partitioned after the second world war. Mrs Albright said the US had contributed nearly 1.5m tons of food to the UN aid programme for North Korea, which is suffering severe food shortages.

Mr Kim has shown surprising willingness to reciprocate Mr Clinton's moves to seek an accommodation between two countries that seemed close to war six years ago. The leader of the formerly closed country has reached out to other countries too, most notably South Korea.

The threat of war has hung over the Korean peninsula since the end of the Korean war in 1953. About 37,000 American troops are stationed in South Korea.

fields.headline: Telewest launches interactive TV outfit
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Telewest has formed an interactive TV joint venture with the US technology consultancy, AtomicTangerine, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Telewest, the UK cable network operator and content provider, has formed a new interactive TV joint venture with the US technology consultancy, AtomicTangerine.

The company, which is 60% owned by Telewest, is to be called SmashedAtom. It will offer services to TV channels, advertisers, retailers and government departments looking to develop interactive applications for digital satellite, cable or terrestrial TV.

Jonathan Peachey, vice-president of the Telewest subsidiary, Flextech Interactive, has been appointed chief executive of SmashedAtom. The joint venture will be staffed by a mix of Telewest and AtomicTangerine employees.

AtomicTangerine is a San Francisco-based techology venture consulting firm founded by SRI International (formerly Stanford Research International). The outfit has more than 250 employees in 11 offices worldwide.

Telewest's chief executive, Adam Singer, said: "Through SmashedAtom we can further benefit from the accelerated take-up of digital television in the UK and the rest of the world. It also ensures we continue to create value for our shareholders in a rapidly growing market."

fields.headline: How is the Speaker elected?
fields.standfirst: Today, MPs will choose the candidate they think is best-suited to be the new Speaker of the House of Commons. Julian Glover explains how
fields.trailText: Today, MPs will choose the candidate they think is best-suited to be the new Speaker of the House of Commons. We explain how.
fields.body:
Why is there an election?
Because the current Speaker, Betty Boothroyd, has decided to step down from the job. She told MPs of her decision when the Commons last met, in July, and now, as the House returns after its long summer break, it is time to choose her successor, who will be the 152nd Speaker. This has to happen before the Commons can move on to its proper business.

Who are the candidates?
Officially, there are no candidates. There is a tradition that MPs only accept the post with great reluctance - in fact, whoever is chosen will have to be symbolically dragged to the Speaker's chair by other MPs. In reality, of course, the post is much sought-after. Twelve MPs have made it clear that they would like to be chosen (a 13th dropped out recently). Among them, four or five are thought to have some chance of coming out on top.

Is this the usual number of candidates?
No. In fact there is rarely a contest for the job at all. Last time, in 1992, two MPs put their names forward, but one, Sir Peter Brooke, was convincingly beaten by the other, Betty Boothroyd. Before that, there has not been a contested election in living memory: a consensus candidate has always emerged. So this election will see the Commons venture onto virgin territory, albeit with a very traditional electoral system.

What is this system?
It is a version of the formal process used in parliamentary debates. By general consent, the longest-serving member of the House takes the chair - in this case (as in the last election for Speaker) it will be Sir Edward Heath, the former prime minister. He has been in the House since 1950 and the new Speaker will be the eighth he has served under.

And what happens?
Sir Edward will propose a motion, naming a candidate for the job - likely to be Sir Alan Haselhurst, a current deputy speaker. MPs will debate this motion for a few minutes and Sir Edward will then call for amendments to it, replacing the first candidate's name with another. This is where the most likely victor, Michael Martin, is likely to come in. MPs will then vote on the amendment, and, assuming it is passed, the initial candidate will drop out of the contest and the second candidate's name will be written into the motion. MPs are then free to propose another amendment, pitting the second candidate against a third. If this is passed, the second candidate, too, drops out and a fourth steps forward. The process continues until an amendment is defeated, the motion passed and the winner dragged to the Speaker's chair protesting their "reluctance" to take the job.

So the election could take hours?
Except that in reality the second candidate is likely to be Michael Martin, who will probably win when an amendment is proposed against his name. As a result, nine of the MPs who have said they are candidates will probably never get the chance to have their names put to a vote.

This sounds unfair. Is it really the best system?
Many MPs agree that a much fairer system should be used. As things stand, Sir Edward Heath has great power, since he determines the order in which candidates are voted upon. Many MPs, led by Tony Benn, have asked Sir Edward to bring in a two-stage election. The first stage would see MPs vote on all the candidates. The two names that come top in this election would then be put to a second vote, and the winner given the job. Sir Edward, though, has shown no sign of agreeing to this, so the traditional system will almost certainly be used.

How do MPs decide whom to support?
All sorts of competing pressures determine how members vote. One pressure is party. There is no formal whip in the election, so MPs are free to support candidates from other parties (as many Tories did in 1992 when they backed Betty Boothroyd, a Labour MP), but Labour's huge majority means that a Labour candidate must have an advantage. Another pressure comes from the informal networks of support that the candidates have built up: this is Michael Martin's big advantage. Yet another influence may be the short statements that some candidates have issued, describing their intentions if elected. And a fourth source of pressure is the government. Tony Blair is thought to favour either Menzies Campbell or Sir George Young. But perversely, this may deter MPs from backing them. They see the election of a Speaker as an assertion of the Common's independence from the government.

Will there be hustings?
Three hours before the vote begins, some MPs have organised an informal hustings for the candidates to put their case for election. Each will be allowed to speak for 10 minutes. But not all the candidates plan to attend. Three of the front-runners, including the likely victor Michael Martin, may stay away.

fields.headline: Text 100 unveils new name and flotation plans
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Text 100, the UK's biggest high-tech PR group, is to change its name to OneMonday Group, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Text 100, the UK's biggest high-tech PR group, is to change its name to OneMonday Group.

Unveiling results for the 12 months to July 31, the company also revealed plans to float a minority stake in its Bite Communications subsidiary on Ofex at the end of 2001.

Pre-tax profits rose 59% before exceptionals to £2.7m on a 60% rise in turnover to £36.4m. Earnings per share were up 74% to 7.89p. The board is proposing a dividend of 2p per share.

Tom Lewis, Text 100's chairman, said the strong growth had been entirely organic and had come in spite of substantial early-stage investment in new subsidiaries and the expansion of existing Text 100 offices.

He said: "The group has made a good start to the new year, winning some significant business. We expect that the market for technology-related PR services will continue to grow."

The somewhat inscrutable new name was devised internally, although the company declined to name who was responsible. The One echoes the number 100 in the old name, while the Monday is intended to convey new beginnings.

Mr Lewis added: "The new name highlights our emphasis on organic growth and reflects that our new operations are almost invariably start-ups, which open their doors for business on a Monday."

Assuming that the new name is approved by the group's shareholders at an EGM on November 15, it is expected to become effective on the following day.

The company is also changing the structure of its main board. Next year it will reduce the size of the board from 10 to five. It will also create an executive council comprising the chief executives of Text 100's subsidiaries, chaired by the group chief executive, Tim Dyson.

The council will take responsibility for many brand-level operational matters handled previously by the board.

Three hours before the vote begins, some MPs have organised an informal hustings for the candidates to put their case for election. Each will be allowed to speak for 10 minutes. But not all the candidates plan to attend. Three of the front-runners, including the likely victor Michael Martin, may stay away.

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

The chairman of the Broadcasting Standards Commission, Lord Holme of Cheltenham, has resigned after admitting a three-year extra-marital affair. (p2)
The BBC could risk contravening its own guidelines by doubling the top prize in hit BBC2 quiz show The Weakest Link to £20,000 when it moves to BBC1 peak time next week. (p5)
Guardian political editor Michael White comments on Lord Holme's resignation. He says the hypocrites in the story of Lord Holme's adultery are the News of the World and its proprietor. (p20)
Conrad Black's Telegraph group has confirmed it is considering joining the auction for the Express Newspapers. (p24)

MEDIA GUARDIAN
Maggie Brown interviews BBC head of light entertainment David Young, the man behind hit quiz show The Weakest Link. (p2)
Chris Powell, chairman of BMP DDB and mastermind of Labour's 1997 election campaign advertising, bemoans the lack of good politcial advertising on both sides of the Atlantic. (p4)
Roy Greenslade on the Express Newspapers auction. (p4)
Business a.m. editor Jonn Penman responds to Andrew Neil's earlier attack on his paper. (p6)
Maggie Brown looks at the plight of BBC2, which is losing several top-rating shows to BBC1 as part of the main channel's ratings drive. (p7)
Channel 4 News journalist Justin Rowlatt on how surviving the Hatfield rail crash turned him from a reporter to a victim. (p8)
Rory Carroll reports on Italian media baron Silvio Berlusconi's campaign to return to government in the country's forthcoming general election. (p8)
Jonathan Steele on a new documentary that claims Serb TV bosses knew their station was about to be attacked by Nato in last year's bombing campaign, but failed to evacuate the building. (p9)
NEW MEDIA
Jane Martinson reports from the US on the dwindling of dot.com advertising.(p54)
Stephen Armstrong on Switch2, the entertainment website run by former Loaded editor Tim Southwell. (p54)
Matt Haig offers some golden rules for internet PR. (p56)

FINANCIAL TIMES

The BBC is to open some of its buildings to the public as part of the £500m revamp of its property portfolio. (p5)
Internet companies that pull together information from other sites without authorisation "may find themselves being sued" according to law firm SJ Berwin, following the settlement of the first test case over the issue. (p18)
Richard Tomkins analyses the accelerating shake-out among internet companies. (p24)
Telewest has formed a joint venture called Smashed Atom with Atomic Tangerine, a subsidiary of the Stanford Research Institute, to develop interactive TV services. (p28)
The Einstein Channel will today announce a satellite distribution deal via S4C2. (p28)
Conrad Black is looking at a bid for Express Newspapers. (p30)
Last week's attempt to rekindle interest in internet investment funds got a resounding thumbs down. (p31)
Deutsche Telekom is considering splitting the German and international operations of its internet subsidiary, T-Online. (p34)

THE TIMES

The Times has BSC chairman Lord Holme's resignation on its front page, and then devotes a whole inside page and an editorial to his departure, which was prompted by revelations of extra-marital affairs in Murdoch-owned sister paper News of the World. (p1, p4, p18)
A new BSC report has found that growing numbers of viewers are expressing concern about explicit violence and sex on TV. (p4)
The paper previews today's third quarter results from advertising giant WPP on its business pages. (p24)
A merger between Telewest and ONdigital has been mooted. (p24)
Britain is lagging behind the rest of Europe in embracing e-commerce, according to a new survey. (p25)
The Times also reports Conrad Black's interest in the Express titles. (p26)

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

The Telegraph reports on Lord Holme's resignation. (p3)
A pilot lost £250,000 on Saturday night after wrongly answering a question about Amy Johnson's solo flight to Australia on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?. (p3)
The Television Corporation has sold £30,000 worth of toys based on hit BBC2 show Robot Wars in a fortnight. (p26)

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE

America Online and the Universal Music Group are developing online music subscription services. (p4)
Realnetworks plans to announce new audio technology today as a part of a deal with Sony. (p9)
In a comment piece, George Gilder argues that US Democrat presidential candidate Al Gore could impose an energy, tax and regulatory garrotte on the internet if his proposed policies are implemented. (p10)
The BBC has shortlisted two groups, 2020 Insight and the Foresite Consortium, to help it revamp its £500m property portfolio. (p28)
The WSJ Europe also carries an e-commerce report, produced jointly with WSJ.com.

THE SUN

BBC newsmen are reported to be "fuming" after rival broadcaster Sir Trevor McDonald was described as "Britain's best-loved newscaster" by BBC1 chat show host Michael Parkinson. (p3)

THE MIRROR

The Mirror carries an exclusive interview with TV gardener Charlie Dimmock's ex, in which he reveals the couple didn't even own a television until Ground Force began. (p8)
Viewers' concerns about sex and violence on television have rocketed in the past two years, according to a report by the Broadcasting Standards Commission. (p15)
The Mirror also reveals that the makers of Coronation Street are planning a special Christmas edition that will show Vera Duckworth fighting for her life. (p17)

AND FINALLY...

THE STAR
Stars of the comedy hit Goodness Gracious Me are jetting off to India to film a special "back to where they came from" edition. The fictional Indian family will arrive in their homeland after a series of holiday mishaps. (p3)

fields.headline: Nervous Nellies feel the fear
fields.trailText: October 23: Media industry executives who once viewed the internet as a serious threat to their business soon grew to love it once dot.coms started spending billions of dollars on ads. But now the fear may be coming back. By Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Media industry executives who once viewed the internet as a serious threat to their business, soon grew to love it once dot.coms started spending billions of dollars on advertising. But now the fear may be coming back.

Dot.com advertising - which reached its apogee when Pets.com appeared during the Super Bowl, the most expensive television event in America - is drying up, and traditional media companies are suffering.

The impact of a declining internet sector, combined with an expected economic slowdown, has dawned on media industry analysts as the days have drawn longer. Last week's wobbles on Wall Street were partly prompted by once cheerleading analysts warning of the coming slowdown in advertising spending.

Among the hardest hit by this autumnal crisis in confidence to date have been online companies themselves. Shares in Yahoo! and Doubleclick, which depend on their internet peers for a large percentage of their revenues, have been crushed in the past month. Yahoo lost more than 200 online advertisers during the past quarter as dot.coms either cut their spending or went bust.

Even the mighty America Online, which takes money from more than 24m subscribers before it even starts charging advertisers, has been hurt by the dot.com fallout. The stock market value of the world's largest internet service provider has fallen so sharply - halving since the beginning of the year - that shareholders in Time Warner, the media group being taken over by AOL, have now started to question the value of the deal.

But the downturn is also being felt by traditional media companies. The question is, how much will it hurt?

In a report issued last week, Merrill Lynch, once the most bullish of US investment banks, revised its 2001 estimate for growth in domestic advertising expenditure from 7% to between 5.5 and 6%.

The dot.com fallout was the main reason for the downgrade, although rising inflation and lower corporate profits across the board also played a large part.

Last year, when fledgling companies thought nothing of paying top dollar for the most expensive advertising slots in the world, traditional media companies such as television networks and newspapers earned an estimated $3.5bn-$4bn from dot.coms, according to Merrill Lynch. Anecdotal evidence of this spending came when webzines such as Wired grew fatter than telephone directories.

Until last week, Merrill Lynch expected this spending to increase to between $7bn-$8bn this year. Lauren Fine, the bank's media and publishing analyst, admits that these figures were based on the assumption that "dot.coms could do no wrong". Last week, some time after they started to go wrong in a big way, she chopped $2bn from her 2000 estimates and remains pessimistic about 2001.

Most industry analysts expect the pain to be felt most keenly by national radio stations and newspaper groups in the US as opposed to broadcast networks. Figures from the Radio Advertising Bureau of America suggest that month-by-month sales growth more than halved from 25% in May to 10% in August. In the fourth quarter, revenues are expected to increase by a less than staggering 0-5% before falling again next year.

Advertising revenues at national newspaper groups such as Gannett, which publishes USA Today, and the New York Times are also expected to slow significantly next year.

Some media executives were at pains to suggest that the glass was half full rather than half empty last week. Gerald Levin, the head of Time Warner, was contemptuous of the panic stalking the industry. He described talk of a dot.com shakeout as "a kind of nervous Nellie".

Rupert Murdoch took a different approach when speaking to shareholders of News Corporation. This latecomer to the dot.com party admitted that advertising sales for the Fox television network looked "a little uncertain" and explicitly blamed the downturn in dot.com spending.

In some ways, both men are right. Dot.com's share of television and radio advertising in America's biggest markets during 1999 - its peak - reached 13-15%. The 20 largest hi-tech companies in America - giants such as Microsoft and Dell - contribute about 5% of total national advertising expenditure.

Huge media companies like the proposed AOL Time Warner, with assets that stretch from the internet to print, cable and film, will still attract advertising from traditional sources such as food and drug companies.

The worry is that, without the competition from little-known brands trying to make a name for themselves and with the added pressures of higher prices, advertisers will no longer be willing to pay a fortune to advertise. Media industry executives could then become nervous Nellies indeed.

fields.headline: QXL marketing boss latest to depart ailing auctioneer
fields.trailText: 8am: Beleaguered online auctioneer QXL has suffered a fresh setback with the surprise departure of its marketing director, Alex Czajkowski. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Beleaguered online auctioneer QXL has suffered a fresh setback with the surprise departure of its marketing director, Alex Czajkowski.

Mr Czajkowski, who is believed to be joining a venture capital company, is the latest in a string of departures from the struggling dot.com.

QXL's managing director, Herbert Kim, left in May after just nine months in the job, closely followed by group merchandising director Richard Hogarth and business development director Rick Jones.

The news comes as QXL is struggling to shore up its share price in the light of recent market instability.

Analysts have questioned the company's future in a rapidly consolidating European market, particularly given the rapid advance into Europe of US rival eBay.

Analysts believe QXL may run out of money within 12 months and that its low share price also makes it vulnerable to a takeover bid.

QXL was the UK's first online auction service. It is one of the UK's biggest dot.com advertisers, having spent about £4m on advertising in the past 12 months through its ad agency, Leo Burnett.

Analysts believe QXL will need to raise up to £40m in new financing to see the business through to break-even. Possible strategic partners include Lycos Europe, BSkyB and Vivendi, all of which could provide new platforms for QXL as well as the much-needed cash.

The one bright spot for QXL is that its US rival Priceline.com has said its forthcoming UK launch will be backed only by a "modest" marketing budget. A hard launch is scheduled for next year, but even then the marketing support will be capped at the relatively low level of £10m.

fields.headline: Online shopper numbers rise 72%
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The number of consumers visiting retail websites has risen 72% since the start of this year, according to figures from MMXI Europe, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The number of consumers visiting retail websites has risen 72% since the start of this year, according to the latest figures from MMXI Europe.

The total number of visitors to online shops reached 4.4m in September, an increase of almost 2m since January despite a number of high-profile collapses in the sector and what has generally been seen as a downturn in the online retail market.

It comes as no surprise to see that Amazon is the leading website in this section, recording both the top two positions with its .co.uk and .com websites respectively.

According to the research, Amazon now reaches more than 10%, or some 1.1m individuals of the UK web audience at home. The closest competitor is Shopsmart with a reach of 2.8% and 307,000 individuals.

Other retail websites in the top 10 included Jungle.com with 284,000 users, StreetsOnline.co.uk with 282,000, WHSmith with 251,000, BOL 240,000, Letsbuyit.com 231,000, beeb.com 219,000 and Argos with 208,000 users.

On average, consumers spent 23 minutes on retail websites in September, an increase of eight minutes since January.

Mari Kim Coleman, UK managing director of MMXI Europe, said: "It is encouraging to see people going to the sites of high street retailers like Argos and WH Smith, as well as those of the well-known internet brands."

Overall, for September, MSN retained pole position as the leading website among UK home internet users, with 4.9m, a reach of 45%. There were few changes in the top 10 for September, with Yahoo, Freeserve, Microsoft, Lycos, AOL and Passport, retaining the same positions as last month.

New entrants included Ask Jeeves and BBC, which managed to push Excite down a peg to number 10.

webTitle: Public demands answers as an age of inquiries grapples with past failings

fields.headline: Public demands answers as an age of inquiries grapples with past failings
fields.standfirst:
The exhaustive BSE report, out this week, could have been more democratic, say critics
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
Public inquiries currently under way
fields.trailText: When Lord Phillips of Worth Matravers makes public his 16 volume report on the BSE crisis this Thursday it will mark the end of a process that began three years ago when Tony Blair, fresh to office, ceded to demands for a full public inquiry into the disease and its link with vCJD.
fields.body:
When Lord Phillips of Worth Matravers makes public his 16 volume report on the BSE crisis this Thursday it will mark the end of a process that began three years ago when Tony Blair, fresh to office, ceded to demands for a full public inquiry into the disease and its link with vCJD.

At the inquiry offices in Hercules Road, London, Lord Phillips and his committee have studied more than 3,000 files, received 12,000 items of correspondence, looked at 1,200 witness statements and heard evidence from 333 witnesses at a total cost of £27m.

Time consuming, complex and expensive, it is the model of a public inquiry, eight of which are in session.

Hearings into the Marchioness river boat accident, the Ladbroke Grove and Southall rail crashes and the Bloody Sunday shootings are ongoing. The inquiries into the paediatric cardiac unit at the Bristol royal infirmary and a projected fifth terminal at Heathrow will report in the new year, while the investigation into how Harold Shipman was able to murder so many of his patients will begin once parliament has given approval.

Under the Blair government public inquiries have undergone a renaissance, being convened to investigate avoidable accidents and public health scandals, most of which took place under a Conservative administration reluctant to focus attention on its failings.

But are these investigations a product of political expediency, the last recourse of guilty ministers keen to see uncomfortable questions kicked into the long grass? An expensive and drawn-out way of shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted? Or is the public inquiry a vital democratic tool fulfilling an investigative role on behalf of the public, while providing catharsis and, crucially, answers for families of the bereaved?

Campaign

Maria Shortis has first hand experience of the process. Her daughter Jacinta died in 1986 at the Bristol royal infirmary after being born with five heart defects. She received conflicting advice before an operation, which might have allowed Jacinta to live for a number of years, was bodged. As an NHS manager she recognised a flawed management overseeing a low level of surgical skill. Appalled, she began a three year campaign for an inquiry. fields.headline: BSC seeks successor to Holme
fields.trailText: 9am: The search is on today for a successor to Lord Holme, who resigned as chairman of TV watchdog the BSC after revelations about his private life. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The search is on today for a successor to Lord Holme, who resigned as chairman of the Broadcasting Standards Commission after revelations about his private life.

It is likely that the new chairman will come from outside the organisation, whose profile increased under the leadership of the Liberal Democrat peer.

The BSC's deputy chairman, Suzanne Warner, is understood not to be in the running. Even in the broadcasting industry, she is not widely known outside the commission.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, is being urged to fill the post soon - a white paper on broadcasting that would change the face of TV and radio regulation is being finalised.

At the weekend, the News of the World printed embarrassing and lurid details about Lord Holme's private life. He was pictured with two women, aged 28 and 32. Lord Holme, 64, said he could not continue as chairman of a broadcasting watchdog in the light of the report.

Sources at the BSC said the organisation had been taken completely by surprise by the News of the World revelations. "We're shell-shocked," said one.

Lord Holme was well-liked - he is credited with modernising the commission's outlook and had taken an active role in the white paper consultation process. It is likely that broadcasting regulators will be consolidated, and Lord Holme had already engineered a close relationship between the BSC and other bodies in the same field. The BSC has signed a 'memorandum of understanding' with the radio authority.

Attempts to pursue a rapprochement with the Independent Television Commission had met with less success, although the situation showed signs of change when Patricia Hodgson was appointed chief executive there.

webTitle: Railtrack to get £4.7bn to improve safety

fields.headline: Railtrack to get £4.7bn to improve safety
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in the UK
Special report: Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText:
Railtrack is to receive a five-year grant of £4.7bn from the rail industry regulator to "deliver a modern safe railway with greater public accountability",
it was announced today.
fields.body:
Railtrack is to receive a five-year grant of £4.7bn from the rail industry regulator to "deliver a modern safe railway with greater public accountability", it was announced today.

The money, from Rail Regulator Tom Winsor, is £900m more than was originally planned.

But Mr Winsor stipulated that Railtrack would now have to produce an asset register showing the "condition, capability and capacity of all its assets".

Mr Winsor said he held Railtrack responsible for the Hatfield crash. "There is no conflict between safety and performance. A well-managed company will be able to organise these things well," he said.

"The rail at Hatfield broke. That shouldn't have happened. It is not a matter of hundreds of different companies with different contracts, as has been trotted around so much over the last few days.

"It was almost certainly a failure in the chain of command, a simple relationship between Railtrack and the organisation engaged to carry out maintenance on that piece of network," he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

"The indications so far are (that it was) Railtrack's fault and Railtrack has admitted it was its fault.

"Broken rails are a matter on which I have been putting pressure on Railtrack for some considerable time now. They have responded - their broken rail numbers have been going down sharply since I began the pressure last year."

He added: "Railtrack has to improve its performance. It has the right under its contracts with the train operators to shut the railway for safety reasons.

"It not only has that right, it has the obligation under its safety responsibilities to do this. "It is not a question of them being fined or penalised. They have the obligation to run a safe railway and that is what they must do."

Mr Winsor stressed that his report was completed before the Hatfield crash and was not amended as a result of the tragedy.

Mr Winsor's announcement, postponed from last week, comes as Railtrack faces mounting criticism over its track renewal system following last Tuesday's Hatfield rail crash, which claimed four lives.

An interim report into the accident from the Health and Safety Executive has said a broken rail was the likely cause.

Mr Winsor, who was publishing his periodic review of Railtrack's access charges, said: "Along with this considerable injection of money comes much greater accountability."

Mr Winsor said that, in all, Railtrack would be spending £14.9bn over the next five years "to ensure that Britain has a railway fit for the demands of increasing passenger numbers and freight users".

On the requirement that Railtrack should produce an asset register, Mr Winsor said: "It is remarkable that no centrally-held comprehensive and accurate register exists.

"I have been and will continue to regulate Railtrack in the public interest. By its own admission, the company must do better. There can be no excuses now."

Railtrack has already been fined £40m by Mr Winsor for failing to meet targets for reducing passenger train delays for the year 1999-2000.

It had decided to fight the financial penalty through the courts, but decided last Friday to drop the case. The company said that, after the Hatfield crash, it would be "inappropriate" to pursue the matter.

Railtrack is already struggling to meet the 2000-01 delay-reduction target, which has been made tougher by the company having to carry over until this financial year the shortfall from last year.

Today, Mr Winsor slightly changed the rules on these performance targets. He gave Railtrack another year to catch up with the 1999-2000 shortfall and said that every percentage point the company falls behind its target will result in a £3.6 million reduction in revenue in 2001-02.

The City gave the report the thumbs up and shares in Railtrack rose 6% in the first hour of trading - up 62p at £11.12p.

Office of the rail regulator
Railtrack

webTitle: Blair mooted Lib Dem coalition deal - Ashdown

fields.headline: Blair mooted Lib Dem coalition deal - Ashdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair told Paddy Ashdown that he would back reform of the electoral system - and put Liberal Democrats in his government, it was reported today.
fields.body:
Tony Blair told Paddy Ashdown that he would back reform of the electoral system - and put Liberal Democrats in his government, it was reported today.

Ahead of a serialisation of the former Liberal Democrat leader's diaries in the Times beginning tomorrow, the paper reported today that Mr Blair had extensive discussions with Mr Ashdown about the extent of possible cooperation between the two parties while Labour was still in opposition.

Mr Blair is said to have told Mr Ashdown on January 14 1997 that he had become convinced of the need for electoral reform in Britain.

The diaries suggest that Mr Blair wanted Liberal Democrats in his administration regardless of whether he won a working majority.

In addition to Mr Ashdown, Liberal Democrat MPs Menzies Campbell and Alan Beith were earmarked for places in the cabinet if the coalition was formed.

But Mr Blair was forced to back off because Gordon Brown opposed the proportional representation electoral system, and there was fierce opposition within the shadow cabinet to the concessions being made to Mr Ashdown's party.

Mr Blair even floated the idea of a merger of the two parties, though that was quickly stamped on by senior figures in both camps.

The extent of cooperation between the parties was often discussed at Mr Blair's and Mr Ashdown's homes, with their wives part of the discussions.

Though actual cooperation has been much more limited since Labour came to power in May 1997, Mr Ashdown said he still believed that, eventually, the two parties would engage in coalition government in England.

Mr Ashdown told the paper: "The project was to design an aircraft which we believed could fly.

"What we have left is a blueprint for it to be done in the future, and two scale models in Wales and Scotland (the coalition pacts for the Welsh assembly and Scottish parliament) are already in the air."

But Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott made clear that he would not have served in a coalition cabinet involving Mr Ashdown.

Asked whether he would have served in a coalition government, Mr Prescott said: "No. Paddy's dreams...

"Of course we agreed to have meetings. Tony Blair made it absolutely clear we would discuss issues of constitutional matters, and we continued to do that, and we thought that was profitable and right, on major constitutional issues.

"But Paddy wanted to go further, he wants to sit in this little chair in the cabinet and become part of the government. I wouldn't have sat with him, no."

Asked whether he would consider sitting in cabinet with current Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy in any future coalition, Mr Prescott told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost yesterday: "Liberals want to do what is in their interests, but it is not in ours.

"You shouldn't do anything like that, and I don't believe in it anyway."

Mr Ashdown said today that he believed that Mr Blair would have preferred the 1997 election to have produced a Lib-Lab coalition government, rather than the massive Labour majority which resulted.

"I am absolutely convinced he wanted it to happen. I believe that to be the case," he said.

"But it isn't a question of whether we would have preferred this coalition or that.

"We would have preferred, and I would still prefer and I believe it will happen, to have a system of government in which parties cooperate and work together in the interests of the nation and the parties of the left make sure we have a better government," he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

A coalition government would have been better than Labour alone had proved to be, said Mr Ashdown.

"What a much better government this would have been if it had happened," he said.

"It would have been much more pro-European, it would have invested early in health and education and it would have been much more liberal than it actually is."

Mr Ashdown said he believed that coalition government on the model seen in Edinburgh and Cardiff would "inevitably" happen at Westminster.

He was convinced that Mr Blair had not abandoned his long-term ambition to achieve a realignment of the left.

He said: "Mr Blair does think large and I think he understands the importance of a long-term vision for the left and the country, and I think that is in the front of his mind still. I don't think this is a vision...which we will easily let go away."
