webTitle: Railtrack to be policed on spending

fields.headline: Railtrack to be policed on spending
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Railtrack is to be policed by a special team of investigators to make sure it carries out its commitment to the government to invest in the industry, it will be announced today.
fields.body:
Railtrack is to be policed by a special team of investigators to make sure it carries out its commitment to the government to invest in the industry, it will be announced today.

The team of consultants, to be announced by the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, will act as reporters to the regulator, although they will be paid for from Railtrack funds. They will make sure that the £5bn of taxpayers' money which Railtrack is likely to get over the next five years goes directly towards enhancing the railway.

Railtrack will today welcome the new money from the government, although it forms part of the £30bn package of improvements for rail announced by the chancellor in July.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, yesterday signalled major investment in railway maintenance in the wake of the Hatfield tragedy. Pledging that safety was his "top priority" on the railways, Mr Prescott indicated that Railtrack is to be given extra leeway to finance increased investment in track maintenance and renewal.

Mr Prescott said Railtrack had an obligation under its operating licence to maintain a safe railway system - and that licence could be taken away if it failed to do so.

Mr Winsor is expected to set tough conditions on Railtrack, including a demand that by next April the company sets up a computer database of all its activities. At the moment Railtrack is unaware of the state of its assets, which are filed on pieces of paper in different offices. This means that in some parts of the country Railtrack is still uncertain what improvements are necessary to bring it up to date four years after privatisation.

Mr Winsor delayed his periodic review, the first since Railtrack was set up. It was due to have been published last week the day after the Hatfield rail crash, but the regulator did not think it was appropriate to proceed with it so soon after the tragic event.

Senior Railtrack executives were last night getting ready to welcome the review and the extra guaranteed cash from the government. With so much money committed from the public purse the Railtrack board is likely to feel emboldened to go out to the market and raise more capital with another share issue.

The burden of funding the improvements is likely to be split between the government and train operating companies.

Various agencies, such as the health and safety executive, advise Mr Prescott on whether Railtrack is meeting its safety obligations, he pointed out on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost.

"If they are not doing that, they [the agencies] make a recommendation to me, and I have the authority to take the licence away from Railtrack."

Mr Prescott said he had asked the HSE to report to him on Tuesday with an assessment of whether the best possible safety procedures were being operated.

On the structure of the industry, he said it was possible that the number of train operating companies could be reduced from the current 25.

He also discussed a likely strengthening of the law on corporate manslaughter.

The Tory transport spokesman Bernard Jenkin said the investment in maintenance was not new money. "The money Mr Prescott is promising in tomorrow's announcement by the regulator is reannouncing money allocated in the spending review and the 10-year transport plan," he said.

webTitle: Three injured in suspected gas explosion

fields.headline: Three injured in suspected gas explosion
fields.trailText: Two people were critically injured and a third badly burned after a suspected gas blast destroyed at a house in Dundee yesterday morning.
fields.body:
Two people were critically injured and a third badly burned after a suspected gas blast destroyed at a house in Dundee yesterday morning.

Buildings within 100 yards of the terrace home in the Mid Craigie area were evacuated and firefighters said adjacent properties would have to be demolished after the blast.

A spokeswoman for Ninewells hospital said last night: "A man and a woman have critical, life-threatening injuries. A second woman has been transferred to our burns unit, where she has severe, but not life-threatening, injuries."

The most seriously injured are understood to be the occupant of the house, a woman, and an elderly couple who lived next door.

A further three people were treated for minor injuries, smoke inhalation and shock and have been discharged from hospital.

The house, part of a block of four, was destroyed in the blast, and debris from the explosion was thrown over the immediate area.

A spokesman for Tayside fire brigade said the initial call came in at about 8.50am and fire crews found a scene of devastation with flames reaching up to 30ft in the air.

One neighbour said: "I heard the bang and I thought it was a car crash. I ran down the stairs. There were flames just round the bottom of the door and then the next thing there was a big bang and you just saw all the flames.

"A lady who was in the house kept saying, 'help me, help me, help me'. Her clothes were all tatters and her hair was all burned."

The gas supply firm Transco said engineers were continuing to work at the scene of the explosion to discover the cause.

webTitle: Comment: Michael White on Lord Holme's adultery

fields.headline: Humbug
fields.standfirst:
The hypocrites in the story of Lord Holme's adultery are the News of the World and its proprietor

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Chances are that you don't read the News of the World. I don't usually buy it myself, though I do still take its sister paper, the Sunday Times, despite everything. Even that causes my more fastidious friends to wrinkle their noses on the grounds that nowadays the once-mighty ST does much more harm to the tone of public life than the old-fashioned News of the Screws.
fields.body:
Chances are that you don't read the News of the World. I don't usually buy it myself, though I do still take its sister paper, the Sunday Times, despite everything. Even that causes my more fastidious friends to wrinkle their noses on the grounds that nowadays the once-mighty ST does much more harm to the tone of public life than the old-fashioned News of the Screws.

Fair point, but yesterday the Screws took a scalp. Paddy Ashdown's grey eminence, Richard Holme - or "the Rt Hon Lord Holme of Cheltenham CBE", as the paper grandly called him - resigned as chairman of the Broadcasting Standards Commission after being caught in adultery at a £270-a-night hotel in West Sussex.

The Gravetye Manor Hotel set in 30 acres of beautiful forest at Turner's Heath, since you ask. And yes the total bill for two nights and the trimmings was £798, paid by the dapper peer before dropping bit-part actress Nicola Paull off at the station and driving home in his blue Volvo.

You didn't want to know those details? Obviously not NoW readership material, let alone the sort of person who would enjoy tracking the 64-year-old father of four to assorted trysts, armed to the teeth with the tools of the interception trade, over what seems to have been weeks, if not months.

But does it matter to the rest of us? Who is Richard Holme? And what is the purpose of the News of the World? First Lord Holme. He is one of those people well known to political insiders, certainly in the old Liberal party and the Ashdown Lib Dems, but also to Lib-Lab-minded Labour types who would happily have seen a coalition in 1997 - the near-miss subject of Paddy Ashdown's memoirs out this week.

In tandem with building a successful career in the City (he was a director of Prima Europe, a lobbying firm with significant Mandelsonian connections), the former Gurkha officer supported worthy liberal causes and was a useful conduit in the Northern Ireland peace process too.

He also fought a series of parliamentary elections from 1964 to 1987, notably in Cheltenham, all of which he lost. No wonder he is a pillar of the Electoral Reform Society and a key player in Ashdown's joint consultative committee with Tony Blair.

None of which matters much to Rebekah Wade, the Screws' editor, fresh from her triumph in getting distraught and angry parents to attack neighbours who vaguely resemble paedophiles. To raven-haired Rebekah (as I feel we should describe her) he is a hypocrite who does one thing in public and another in private. "By day he decides what YOU watch on TV. By night he indulges his fantasies," the paper told its readers.

Actually the fantasy side sounded reassuringly thin. There were circumstantial suggestions of spanking and a definite allegation by one ex-mistress that the accused indulged in a Wind in the Willows caper in which he played Mr Toad. Sounds good to me, but what do I know? I had not even heard of Skin 2, the "fetish magazine" the busy lord is said to read "occasionally".

The only valid justification for printing all this prurient rubbish would be that Holme was a humbug whose resignation is justified in the public interest. Kevin Keegan resigned as England football coach because he failed. Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, offered to go because he failed. Lord Holme, too, may have failed to strike the right balance between quality and market forces in British TV, between standards and the rising tide of sex, violence and generally brain-damaged rubbish either side of the 9pm watershed.

But that is not why he has been forced out. He has resigned because a red-top tabloid has caught him being unfaithful to his wife, not a subject he pronounces on at the commission. She is standing by him, which should be enough for most people. Lord Holme is smart enough to know it will not be enough for the tabloids.

An old story perhaps, one on which Guardian readers may differ. But they should be reminded that when one of Rupert Murdoch's titles attacks a senior regulator in the television industry it is also promoting, consciously in my experience, the Digger's commercial media interests, here - notably the troubled BSkyB - and around the world.

When people like Lord Holme are stalked by Murdoch operatives, one is often led to think how much a bulging file always helps in the big-money battles over ownership and regulation where, contrary to leftwing conspiracy theory, the Blairites have been much less obliging to Mr Murdoch than Margaret Thatcher was in her prime.

Even at 69 the old brute remains a formidable manipulator of politicians of every hue, a point on which ex-Murdoch editors are usually more eloquent than incumbents. Mr Murdoch himself has recently married for the third time, evidently finding it as hard as his lordship to practice all that his papers preach.

A new wife of child-bearing age is an event of huge importance for the family dynasty, but went largely unreported in his papers. Mr Murdoch has not resigned so far.

fields.headline: Violence more of a turn-off, says BSC report
fields.trailText: 8.15am: BSC figures show that more people turned off a TV programme because they felt "personally disgusted" by it last year than in the previous year, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
More people turned off a television programme because they felt "personally disgusted" by it last year than in the previous year, according to research published today by the Broadcasting Standards Commission.

A study of 1,000 adults revealed that 37% of people had switched a programme off or over, either because they felt personally disgusted by it or because they were watching with children. The most common reason given was violence, with 38% of people giving it as a reason for the decision to switch over, a rise of 15% from the 1998 figures.

Concern about swearing and the portrayal of sexual activity on TV has also risen 21% between 1997 and 1999. But respondents indicated that they were progressively more likely to accept or tolerate it.

But when questioned about issues that had lead respondents to make an actual complaint, the largest factor was perceived unfairness to people or organisations.

But the study found that respondents found most offensive material justifiable within its editorial context. Fewer than 2.5% of pre-watershed programmes watched by the respondents were described as containing unjustifiable incidents.

webTitle: TV decency watchdog quits over affair

fields.headline: TV decency watchdog quits over affair
fields.trailText: 8am: The chairman of television's taste and decency watchdog resigned yesterday after admitting a three-year extra-marital affair, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The chairman of television's taste and decency watchdog resigned yesterday after admitting a three-year extra-marital affair.

Lord Holme of Cheltenham, a Liberal Democrat peer, stood down from the broadcasting standards commission after a newspaper revealed details about his private life, acknowledging that he could not continue in the light of the story.

He tendered his resignation in a letter to Chris Smith, the culture secretary, saying he did not want the affair to reflect on the work of the commission.

Lord Holme said: "I do not seek to excuse myself but, as I duly fall on my sword, I leave it to others to judge what effect this sort of journalism, based on spying, telephone interception and misappropriated private correspondence for commercial gain, has on the quality of our public life."

His departure creates a headache for ministers, who are finalising a white paper on the future of broadcasting. The number of regulatory bodies is likely to be slimmed down, and the peer had been playing a crucial role in formulating the new set-up.

The News of the World alleged that Lord Holme, who has been married for 42 years, had been having affairs with two women, aged 28 and 32. It printed details of the millionaire peer's sexual preferences and revealed that he liked to be called "Lord Toad", after the fictional character in the Wind in the Willows children's stories.

Lord Holme, who managed the Liberal Democrats' general election campaign in 1997, said his wife, Kay, was standing by him. "She wants it to be known that, although she felt very hurt when I told her of my infidelity, she is nevertheless determined, as am I, that we shall stay together at the heart of our family. I am glad of her love and grateful for her determination," he said.

According to the News of the World, Lord Holme's two affairs were with a young woman from the midlands and an Australian television actor. The news shocked colleagues at the BSC, who were told about the story by the newspaper on Saturday.

Stephen Whittle, the watchdog's director, said: "He had given the commission strong leadership and served it with skill and flair."

Mr Smith said he accepted Lord Holme's resignation "with regret", and expressed a hope that he would return to public life. Charles Kennedy, leader of the Liberal Democrats, said Lord Holme had made an outstanding contribution in a 36-year political career, and praised his "integrity" in resigning.

Lord Holme was appointed to the £49,000-a-year post last year, when he took over from Lady Howe, wife of the former foreign secretary Lord Howe. He was regarded as a breath of fresh air at the commission, which rules on taste and fairness on TV and radio, and conducts research into viewers' and listeners' attitudes.

As the news of his resignation was announced, the commission published its latest report, which shows that viewers say they are increasingly concerned by the amount of sex and violence on TV. Almost three-fifths said there was too much violence.

fields.headline: Black may bid for Express
fields.trailText: 8sm: Conrad Black's Telegraph group yesterday confirmed that it is considering joining the auction for Express newspapers, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
Conrad Black's Telegraph group yesterday confirmed that it is considering joining the auction for Express newspapers.

A successful bid from Mr Black would create a serious rival to Rupert Murdoch's dominant News International group but would need to clear an exhaustive monopolies and mergers commission inquiry.

The lengthy delay that would place over any deal with Mr Black could persuade Lord Hollick's United News & Media to sell to one of several other parties that see the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star titles as "trophy assets", industry observers said.

The Hinduja brothers, a venture capital-backed consortium led by former Mirror Group chief executive David Montgomery and the Barclay brothers, owners of the Scotsman and Sunday Business newspapers, have all expressed an interest in buying the papers, which are valued at around £120m.

"Clive [Hollick] has to ask himself whether he wants to hang on to the papers during a lengthy MMC inquiry and deal with the uncertainty that would bring to the business and staff or simply sell it to a bidder like the Barclays who would be unlikely to prick the interest of the MMC," said one senior industry executive.

The Telegraph group discussed a bid for Express newspapers at a board meeting last Friday. Reports quote Dan Colson, deputy chairman of Hollinger, the Telegraph's parent company, as saying: "We have always been opportunistic buyers of newspapers and we tend to look at most that come on the market. We will look at it."

The two groups already have a close relationship through their 50-50 joint ownership of West Ferry, a print works in London's east end. That venture accounts for about half Express Newspapers' profits. A change of ownership in either media group allows the other partner to buy the 50% of West Ferry it does not own at a pre-agreed valuation.

Observers say that the Telegraph, with its marketing and newspaper expertise, could revitalise the Express and turn it into a viable rival to Associated Newspapers' Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday titles. However, the Express is struggling to stem 30 years of circulation decline and operates in an increasingly competitive market whose boundaries have been blurred by price-cutting.

"Over the years the Express has moved left, right, young, old, north, south," said one source. "Does the Telegraph group want to spend millions finding a market position for the papers and revitalising them? It's more likely to go to a bidder like the Barclays, who see the paper as a trophy asset."

Media analysts say reports that venture capital firm Apax Partners is planning a bid are wide of the mark.

fields.headline: Bridging the green gap
fields.standfirst:
Mr Blair will need all his political nous

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Measured against the prospects for global survival as the planet warms and fossil fuels are depleted, Tony Blair will find it hard tomorrow to cut a dash when he makes what is being billed as his biggest speech on the environment since assuming office.
fields.body:
Measured against the prospects for global survival as the planet warms and fossil fuels are depleted, Tony Blair will find it hard tomorrow to cut a dash when he makes what is being billed as his biggest speech on the environment since assuming office. To choose this subject within days of the fuel protesters' declared "deadline" smacks either of foolhardiness or political nous. We hope the latter. Assessed against other countries, especially the United States, the UK deserves a small prize in the every-little-helps stakes. Building on Tory targets, Labour can claim the UK is now a world leader in cutting carbon emissions. Mixed as his fiscal motives were, Gordon Brown's foot-down approach to taxing petrol has at least mitigated the increased emissions of greenhouse gases caused by traffic growth - such emissions still rose over the 90s by about 10%.

webTitle: Meacher is rebuked for floating fuel tax escalator

fields.headline: Meacher is rebuked for floating fuel tax escalator
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Downing Street and the Treasury yesterday issued a joint rebuke to the environment minister, Michael Meacher, after he floated the idea of restoring the fuel duty escalator.
fields.body:
Downing Street and the Treasury yesterday issued a joint rebuke to the environment minister, Michael Meacher, after he floated the idea of restoring the fuel duty escalator.

Government spokesmen said that ministers had no intention of bringing back the escalator which was abolished by Gordon Brown in his budget this year.

Mr Meacher suggested that the escalator, which used to impose inflation-busting increases in fuel duties, could be restored if petrol prices fell.

In an interview on ITV's Jonathan Dimbleby programme, Mr Meacher said that the government was determined to encourage motorists to use their cars less. Asked whether the fuel duty escalator should be restored to discourage motorists, he said: "We may indeed have to return to the escalator if - not much hope of it at the moment - there were a sudden and dramatic fall in the oil prices."

His remarks drew a withering response from Downing Street and the Treasury. A Downing Street spokesman said: "Michael Meacher was talking about a hypothetical situation. The fact is that the government has got rid of the escalator and has no plans to bring it back again. It is as simple as that."

His remarks were echoed by a Treasury spokesman. "Mr Meacher was commenting on a hypothetical scenario and setting out the theoretical possibilities. But we abolished the fuel duty escalator at the last budget and have no intention of bringing it back."

Mr Meacher's remarks incensed Downing Street and the Treasury, which are working behind the scenes to prevent a repeat of the fuel protests in September.

The Treasury was particularly irritated because Mr Brown responded to unease among motorists in his last budget when he scrapped the fuel duty escalator which used to add 6% to fuel duties on top of the inflation rise.

Mr Meacher's remarks yesterday were the second time within a year that he has spoken out of turn. Downing Street was forced to slap him down at last year's Labour party conference when he said that wealthy people could be barred from owning second homes in the countryside to prevent local people being priced out of the housing market. Mr Meacher faced particular embarrassment because he owns a second home in the countryside.

The frequency with which Mr Meacher finds himself at odds with Downing Street shows the difficulties faced by the former star of the Labour left in adapting to his status as a relatively junior minister.

Mr Meacher, 60, was elected to the shadow cabinet in 1983, the year that the prime minister and the chancellor were elected to parliament. After the 1997 election, he was one of four shadow cabinet members to be excluded from the cabinet. He was appointed environment minister.

Many Labour MPs believe he has survived because the prime minister shows little interest in the environment. Mr Blair will attempt to show that he is committed to the environment when he addresses the Green Alliance tomorrow.

He will put a "third way" gloss on his commitment when he calls on environmentalists to form a partnership with business. Mr Blair will say that the days of environmental protests are over and that green campaigners should join forces with business to tap into the demand for "things that are green and clean".

webTitle: French communists launch Jesus art exhibition

fields.headline: French communists launch Jesus art exhibition
fields.standfirst: As the French Communist party follows a black-tie designer night with religious art, Jon Henley reports from Paris on attempts to revive the party's fortunes
fields.trailText: As the French Communist party follows a black-tie designer night with religious art, Jon Henley reports from Paris on attempts to revive the party's fortunes.
fields.body:
A striking exhibition of portraits and sculptures featuring Jesus Christ opens tomorrow at the headquarters of that well-known club for devout and evangelical church-goers, the French Communist party.

This comes just a week after the same building on Place Colonel Fabien - known to insiders as "the bunker" - was turned over to the not-very-proletarian fashion house Prada for a glamorous party whose guests included Malcolm McLaren and a clutch of scantily-clad supermodels.

It also follows a perfectly serious debate within the party's central committee about whether or not to accept the candidacy in next year's local Paris elections of a hitherto little-known revolutionary figure called Pierre Bergé, managing director of Yves Saint Laurent.

Something, in short, is up. In their traditional spirit of openness, the Communists are not prepared to tell you what it is, but it's not hard to work out. Having lost 100,000 members since the fall of the Berlin Wall, their image is not what it used to be, and they are also very short of cash.

"Those who think that communism rhymes with archaism are wrong," bellowed the party's leader, Robert Hue, over the blast of techno from the loudspeakers at the late-night champagne-and-caviar Prada bash. "Communism is about modernity, and there's nothing decadent about design."

Communist officials who insist that Miucca Prada's extreme leftist origins were behind the gesture are being equally ingenuous: after two years of running a deficit, the party treasurer, Roland Jacquet, presented a balanced budget in 1999 - but only by selling off various properties owned by the party for some £400,000.

And it is an open secret that the Italian fashion house was prepared to pour £30,000 into the party's shrinking coffers in exchange for the privilege of hosting what became known as "the Pravda show" at its modernistic HQ, designed by the Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer.

The art exhibition is rather harder to explain, since entrance to it is free. Thirty monumental works portraying Christ, mostly paintings but including some sculpture, will be on display in the vast hall where the party's national committee holds its strategy sessions.

But here too, the French Communists are polishing their tarnished image. "The message of the exhibition is clear and simple: the love of others," said José Fort, who writes for the party newspaper l'Humanit&2acute.

"Communism has a heavy debt to pay. We can't forget the gulags, the Eastern bloc countries. It could be seen as an invitation to understanding and tolerance."

In a further bid to broaden the party's appeal, Mr Hue warmly welcomed the popular Mr Bergé's surprise offer to head the communists' slate in the chic sixth arondissement of Paris, otherwise known as Saint-Germain-des-Prés.

Once the stamping ground of genuine leftist intellectuals like Sartre and de Beauvoir, it is now home to most of the capital's big-name designer stores.

But sadly, and despite the fact that the communists polled just five per cent of the Paris vote last time a round - and only two per cent in the sixth arondissement - the central committee rejected Mr Bergé's offer.

They decided that his track record in turning round one of the world's biggest fashion labels did not speak volumes for his socialist credentials.

Needless to say, all this has not gone down well with the diehards. Some rank and file members launched a dissident petition called "The Appeal of the 700" to protest against the Prada bash.

They slammed the party leadership for welcoming "the jet-set arriving in black limousines for an evening of sequins and glitter".

But others see the new approach as perhaps the only way of opening an ailing and fossilised organisation up to the modern world.

Asked what he thought of the art exhibition, René Chevailler, 80, a former resistance fighter, said that, to some, it may seem as if "a certain myth of the party" had been brutally shattered.

"But I don't think it's necessarily true," he said. "Perhaps they just want to show that Jesus was the first communist."

webTitle: US-style gun law comes to Britain

fields.headline: US-style gun law comes to Britain
fields.standfirst:
Nottingham police on armed foot patrol after rise in shootings

Special report: policing crime
British crime survey
Home Office crime reduction site
fields.trailText: Nottingham police on armed foot patrol after rise in shootings, report Steven Morris, Helen Carter and Keith Perry.
fields.byline: Steven Morris, Helen Carter and Keith Perry
fields.body:
At the start of their shifts the police officers insert their Walther P990 pistols into the holsters on their hips and, always operating in pairs with armed back-up vehicles close at hand, begin to patrol the two trouble-hit estates.

It is the sort of scene made familiar by films and television shows portraying the fictional lives of police on the mean streets of America. But yesterday it emerged that routine armed foot patrols are now being operated in Nottingham - the first time this has happened on the streets of mainland Britain.

The initiative, after a spate of shootings in the city, is seen by many as a worrying move which could spell the beginning of the end for the traditional notion of a bobby on patrol armed only with a truncheon and a pair of handcuffs, and as a further sign of a growing gun culture.

Some experts believe that within 10 years the police could be routinely armed, and warn that this in turn will encourage a greater proliferation of weapons among criminals. A senior officer said: "Arming officers could lead to a dangerous spiral of violence. If the police arm themselves, the criminals will stay a step ahead by obtaining bigger and better weapons. We could be heading for the sort of problems they have in America."

The Nottinghamshire force decided to set up its so-called "operation real estate" earlier this year after a boom in gun related crime on the St Ann's and Meadows estates in Nottingham.

In one of the most serious of the 14 shootings this year, a 23-year-old was shot at point-blank range when he answered his front door in St Ann's to five masked gunmen. The bullet smashed into his arm, breaking a bone and leaving him scarred for life. The motive for the attack remains unclear.

In other incidents a shotgun was fired into a house as a family, including an eight-year-old girl, slept upstairs and half a dozen rounds were shot through the window of a terraced house in the early hours.

Deterrent

In February the police force said that armed response vehicles would begin patrolling St Ann's, the Meadows and the city centre, so police marksmen would quickly be on the scene if there were further incidents. It then went a step further and introduced armed foot patrols.

Now at least six officers, operating in pairs, patrol the estates and the city centre from dusk to midnight. They are backed up by two armed response vehicles in which Heckler and Koch MP5 rifles are kept. The officers deliberately do not conceal their guns, a tactic intended to instill confidence in the public and act as a visible deterrent to criminals.

The estates have a history of drug-related crime; in a recent survey 63% of the 9,200 residents on the Meadows said they were worried about drugs. But police play down the idea that the shootings are part of a turf war between rival gangs of dealers. They believe the shootings are more haphazard - all the more worrying for those who believe that the gun culture is out of control.

Since the operation began there have been 150 arrests and 15 firearms recovered. Assistant chief constable Sean Price, who chairs meetings of the strategic command team which reviews the operation weekly, said: "This is the largest and most sustained police operation we have ever carried out. The shootings are not acceptable and we will not allow a gun culture to develop in Nottingham."

The Nottinghamshire force was yesterday swift to point out that the patrols have been set up as part of a "specific operation", but accepts that it is not wrong to call them routine.

Until now on mainland Britain, armed officers have been deployed only for diplomatic duties, to tackle specific incidents such as sieges and armed robberies, or in the light of a particular terrorist threat. Armed officers are routinely to be seen at airports.

It is up to chief constables to decide if, and how, they wish to deploy armed officers. They do not have to seek clearance from the government. Indeed, the home officer minister, Charles Clarke, was only told of the move in Nottingham last week, but has now asked for a full briefing.

The former deputy constable of Greater Manchester, John Stalker, said that thousands of police officers would be aghast at what was happening in Nottingham.

He said: "I see this as another step along the road to routinely arming police. We are moving towards what is happening in places like America and South Africa and away from our concept of an unarmed police force. For a new breed of senior officer, it's no big deal for police to be armed. It is very worrying indeed."

Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, said: "We have now reached a situation where police officers need to carry guns just to do their job. The decision to issue guns is, of course, a matter for the chief constable, but I am confident the decision was only taken in the face of extreme circumstances."

Crime rise

Other forces are watching developments in Nottingham with great interest. Some have dabbled with the idea of routine patrols in the past. After a spate of shootings in north-west London three years ago, the Metropolitan police launched 24-hour armed vehicle patrols.

There is no doubt that gun-related crime is on the increase. Last December it emerged that armed crime was up by 10%, with 13,671 armed offences in the year. Government research has found that one in three criminals under 25 has access to a firearm, and there are thought to be more than 3m firearms illegally in circulation, double the number 10 years ago.

Manchester has long had a notorious reputation for gun-related crime. There have been 40 shootings this year alone in the south of the city. Inter-gang violence is one of the main causes. Last month seven people were shot in a three-week period, among them a 16-year-old who was killed when he was gunned down at close range as he rode his mountain bike through a park.

Police suspect his murder was in retaliation for the death of a 21-year-old, believed to be a member of a rival gang, who was shot as he rode his bicycle through an alley 10 days before. The gangs allegedly involved, the Pit Bulls and the Longsight Crew, are involved in a turf war.

Detective superintendent Tony Porter, head of CID for south Manchester, said: "They are rivals who are young men who wear their firearms as fashion accessories. Some of them seem to think they are achieving kudos and credibility."

Drugs underpin all the gangland activity, but Mr Porter said that drugs were not the prime motive for the shootings.

Police and community leaders agree that guns are becoming all too common on the streets of Manchester. One youth worker, who asked not be named, said: "People are not shocked by the shootings any more. They just shrug their shoulders as if they are not bothered by it."

For now the sight of armed police on the beat in Nottingham is an exciting novelty for the estate's children. Soon, however, it too might be mundane.

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst: Two bosses
fields.trailText: To work for two managers is not unusual these days. In the IT sector the manager to secretary ratio can be as high as 15 to one. From time to time, people question whether the term "secretary" is obsolete, but given the way PAs are expected to divide their time between managers, perhaps it is the more esteemed job title "personal assistant" which needs a rethink.
fields.body:
To work for two managers is not unusual these days. In the IT sector the manager to secretary ratio can be as high as 15 to one. From time to time, people question whether the term "secretary" is obsolete, but given the way PAs are expected to divide their time between managers, perhaps it is the more esteemed job title "personal assistant" which needs a rethink.

Certainly the latter is a title that can create false expectations. The personal element of the job tends to become blurred, although not quite as blurred as it is in the public imagination. I can think of one chief executive, now retired, who was, in his day, a byword for rugged entrepreneurialism and flexible working practices. His own flexibility faltered over the question of lunch, however. Wherever he found himself in the world, and regardless of who was hosting, he expected a tuna sandwich. His PA took personal pride in seeing that he always got one. On the rare occasions she failed, he sulked dreadfully.

Few PAs would find time for such details for one manager these days, let alone two or three. Nevertheless, one personal consideration will creep into the most business-like relationship. A PA is a status symbol, a sign of a degree of seniority in business life, like the size of the company car or having an office with a door that shuts. Managers expect to set the priorities, and also expect for their immediate demands to rise to the top of the pile of work to be done. Even in a team, the head of department will expect the team secretary to perform his or her routine office chores, such as photocopying.

When secretaries and PAs ask for training in such skills as assertiveness, few managers realise that the skill is required not to keep hostile strangers at bay but to negotiate the politics of their own departments. With perhaps three managers simultaneously expecting to monopolise a PA's time, the word "no" has to become part of the office vocabulary. Indeed, some senior PAs have come to believe that the training course most useful for secretarial development would be one that trains novice managers how to work with a secretary.

webTitle: Officehours: At the heart of the auction

fields.headline: At the heart of the auction
fields.standfirst: Annabel Williams works at one of the largest auction houses in the world.  Tom Twentyman  finds out about life under the hammer
fields.trailText: Talk about a well-established family firm. Bonhams started in the business of selling in 1793, and is the only surviving Georgian auction house in London to remain under family ownership.
fields.body:
Talk about a well-established family firm. Bonhams started in the business of selling in 1793, and is the only surviving Georgian auction house in London to remain under family ownership.

Last month, a merger was announced: Bonhams is now Bonhams & Brooks, the former associated with paintings, furniture, jewellery, textiles and porcelain; the latter specialists in classic cars. With a combined annual turnover of £75m, this has created the fourth largest auctioneers in the world.

Annabel Williams, 31, is based in the Knightsbridge headquarters, where she is executive secretary to both Nicholas Bonham, deputy chairman, and Nicholas Thompson, finance director and company secretary. When she started work in March, talks on the deal were already underway.

"I didn't so much hit the ground running, as sprinting," she explains. Her first few months in the job involved taking part in a confidential due diligence exercise, in which management, lawyers and accountants went through Bonhams with the proverbial fine-toothed comb. "That was a great way of learning about the company, but a mammoth undertaking. Everything was examined. Not only the finances, but property issues, our terms of trade, insurance arrangements, and so on - the entire structure."

The process took its toll on those working at Bonhams. In Williams's case, she would wake up in the early hours of the morning, and write "must do" notes. "Looking back, however, it's been enjoyable. Something has been born, and I've been part of that." And while this corporate gestation has been taking place, routine matters have been continuing in tandem. Each lot offered for sale - there were in the region of 85,000 last year - generates a cycle of administration. "There can be days when Nicholas Bonham doesn't put upon me, and then he'll suddenly give me a massive pile of paper to work my way through," she says. Thompson provides a "pretty constant" flow of work.

So whose workload comes first when you have two bosses? "If I'm told, 'Whatever you're doing, stop, because this is more important', then I'll quickly reorganise. And when there's more than enough from one, then the other will understand. They know I try to find a fair path between them."

A major responsibility for Williams is preparing the monthly board meetings. "We currently have 14 people on the board, which does mean a huge stack of papers and reports from members of staff. Organising them all can be quite a task." Deadlines also loom large in her day. "I try to plan ahead, but I'm always under pressure to produce figures at speed," she says.

By way of a perk (and a handy break from her desk), Williams takes the opportunity of attending sales whenever possible. "They are the lifeblood of what we do, and watching the bidding is really exciting." The amounts of money involved - the fall of the gavel can be the signal for seven-figure sums to change hands - are not the primary appeal for her. Instead, it's the element of surprise when the reserve is exceeded way beyond expectations. An in-house course on taking telephone bids is available - she would love to do it, but regrets that, so far, shortage of time has got in her way.

A career in art was always Williams's preferred choice, but the route to her ideal job was far from simple. After studying sociology, and then completing a post-graduate degree in 16th-century Italian drawing, she wrote speculative letters to "anyone and everyone" who might be able to offer her work experience. Her efforts came to "absolutely nothing". Discovering for herself what a notoriously tough environment the art world is to break into, she signed up for intensive computer training to arm herself with more skills.

Six months after she landed a job as a telephonist at Theo Fennell, the luxury jewellers, she was PA to the joint managing director, eventually combining this with the position of facilities manager. "That's where I learned to juggle different people and demands. If someone wanted to be in charge of a building, it was a plum job, but I didn't want to immerse myself in that. Although it was a wrench to leave, I felt I had to move on, and I've found my niche at Bonhams & Brooks.

"It's taken me a decade since leaving university to land where I am today," adds Williams. "There is a strong sense of a reputation which has been built up over many, many years here, plus you belong to an identifiable team. I like that." Clearly, the long wait has been worthwhile for her.

fields.headline: Prescott dismisses coalition 'dreams'
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: John Prescott lifted the lid on his stormy relationship with Tony Blair yesterday when he confirmed that he would have resigned from the cabinet if the prime minister had formed a coalition with the Liberal Democrats.
fields.body:
John Prescott lifted the lid on his stormy relationship with Tony Blair yesterday when he confirmed that he would have resigned from the cabinet if the prime minister had formed a coalition with the Liberal Democrats.

Speaking on the eve of the publication of Sir Paddy Ashdown's diaries, Mr Prescott demonstrated his contempt for the prime minister's "big tent" politics when he dismissed the idea of a coalition as "Paddy's dreams".

The diaries of the former Lib Dem leader are expected to confirm that Sir Paddy was involved in lengthy negotiations with Mr Blair in the run-up to the general election over the possibility of forming a coalition government.

It is understood that two cabinet posts were to have been offered to the veteran Lib Dem MPs Menzies Campbell and Alan Beith, even if Labour won a majority. A coalition was temporarily ruled out in the immediate aftermath of Labour's landslide.

Mr Blair still harboured thoughts of a coalition until Mr Prescott threatened to resign from the cabinet in 1998, a point he confirmed publicly yesterday for the first time. Asked on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost whether he would have served in a Lab-Lib coalition cabinet, Mr Prescott said: "No. Paddy's dreams."

Mr Prescott said the prime minister had been right to set up a joint cabinet committee with the Liberal Democrats to discuss constitutional issues. "Of course we agreed to have meetings," he said.

"Tony Blair made it absolutely clear we would discuss issues of constitutional matters, and we continued to do that, and we thought that was profitable and right, on major constitutional issues."

However, Mr Prescott made clear his disdain for Sir Paddy when he said that the former Lib Dem leader was not happy with sitting on a mere cabinet committee.

"Paddy wanted to go further, he wants to sit in this little chair in the cabinet and become part of the government," Mr Prescott said. "I wouldn't have sat with him, no."

Asked whether he would sit in cabinet with the current Lib-Dem leader, Charles Kennedy, Mr Prescott said: "Liberals want to do what is in their interests, but it is not in ours. You shouldn't do anything like that, and I don't believe in it anyway."

Mr Prescott was careful to restrict his criticisms to Sir Paddy. However, his remarks were aimed indirectly at the prime minister. The Ashdown diaries, which cover the period up to 1997, are expected to make clear that Mr Blair wanted to form a coalition with the Lib Dems when he thought that Labour would win a majority of around 50.

Mr Blair was terrified that a Labour government with a small majority would suffer the same fate as John Major, whose premiership was destroyed - after he had secured a small majority in 1992 - by a combination of disloyal Tories and the combined forces of Labour and the Lib Dems.

When Labour achieved its landslide Mr Blair still thought of forming a coalition because he had grand hopes of re-aligning the centre left with the help of the Lib Dems. Egged on the former SDP leader Lord Jenkins of Hillhead, Mr Blair felt that the 21st century could be the "radical century" if the divisions on the left and centre left could be healed.

Both sides now agree that a coalition is only ever likely if Labour loses its overall parliamentary majority.

webTitle: Black and Asian people obtain more degrees than whites. So why do so few get senior jobs?

fields.headline: Black and Asian people obtain more degrees than whites. So why do so few get senior jobs?
fields.standfirst:
Mabel Msonthi on race and the workplace

Special report: Racism in the UK
fields.trailText: The recent, and much-discussed, report by the Runnymede Trust on the future of multi-ethnic Britain rightly asked why so few black or Asian workers make it into senior positions in the workplace.
fields.body:
The recent, and much-discussed, report by the Runnymede Trust on the future of multi-ethnic Britain rightly asked why so few black or Asian workers make it into senior positions in the workplace. So when it emerged last week that only one black person had worked on the report, and in a junior position - Helen Francis, an administrative assistant, who left the commission not long after the inquiry started - charges of hypocrisy were levelled. Robin Richardson, who edited the report, conceded: "I am embarrassed. I agree with you that it doesn't look good."

A response involving glass houses and stones is tantalisingly easy to trot out; investigating the central tenet of the report on equal opportunities in the workplace, however, is a modern day Gordian Knot. With Ireland's "anti-racist workplace week" coming up at the start of November, what is the real state of race equality in employment as we near the end of the first year of the new millennium?

"We have commissioned four reports over the last year which have revealed worryingly disproportionate levels of unemployment amongst black and Asian workers despite their degree level qualifications," says a spokesperson for the TUC. Set against statistics gleaned from the Labour Force Survey commissioned by the Department for Education and Employment, which show that 21% of black and Asian people obtain degrees, compared with 16% of their white counterparts, the question of why they are still far less likely to make it to a senior role in the workplace is a pertinent one.

"The TUC set up a Rooting Out Racism hotline in June of this year and within five days we had received 450 calls, all recounting harrowing tales of workplace harassment and consistent examples of people being overlooked for promotion," adds the spokesperson. "There are many recommendations in the Future of Multi-Ethnic Britain report that need to be focused on by employers, not simply the one aspect [that of the contentious meanings of the word 'British'] that was highlighted by most of the press."

The commission's 417-page report contained recommendations aimed at ensuring that more black and Asian people are employed in senior roles. But how easy is to enforce these policies? Alarmingly, it seems that the culture in many offices discriminates against people of ethnic minority origin often without companies and staff being aware of it.

According to the commission for racial equality, companies can discriminate indirectly by not advertising vacancies in certain areas of the press to attract applicants from a diverse background, thus ruling out a whole section of the population. Another example is word of mouth recruitment which often favours the well-connected and privileged in society - the very antithesis of equal opportunities for all. Similarly, enforcing rules which make all employees work on particular days of the year despite their religious beliefs can amount to indirect discrimination. So how should companies go about resolving anomalies in the recruitment process? Dianah Worman of the chartered institute of personnel & development emphasises the need for "education and awareness-raising exercises in the workplace.

"Promoting race equality is all about valuing differences. It's in the interests of all businesses to communicate and deliver customer and client needs. Where are companies advertising? If this isn't pulling a diverse pool of applicants, where else could an organisation advertise?"

The economic aspect of this conundrum makes for fascinating reading. The Business Benefits of Race Equality at Work report is just one of those commissioned by the Department of Education and Employment for its Race Research for the Future series. It shows that an ethnically diverse workforce certainly pays: bottom line savings of up to £250,000 were made by one of the companies interviewed. Companies selected for their efforts in increasing race equality demonstrated increased staff retention, reduced recruitment shortages, improved employee relations, better customer service, increased sales and improved marketing.

While research tends to focus on senior positions, there is also concern about the state of equality within the support staff industry, particularly in the light of the Helen Francis incident. A study by the institute for employment studies (IES), for example, looked into the effects of internal job advertising: in theory, it's fair, makes good use of available talent and shares opportunities around.

However, another report published in July reveals what really happens. As co-author Wendy Hirsh explains, "Managers are used to choosing people and putting them where they want, based on who they know and what they know about them. Putting jobs on noticeboards and intranets won't stop managers bucking the system, especially if the system seems bureaucratic and slow."

The IES has identified that what employees dislike most are managers who advertise a vacancy but have already really decided who they are going to appoint. This may mean strong candidates do not get looked at seriously. Particular members of the workforce may be more vulnerable to this discrimination as they possess fewer connections in the first place.

Listen to most support staff for any length of time and it soon becomes apparent that secretaries and administrators have a pretty hard time in terms of promotion prospects and increasing their areas of responsibility. The day-to-day experience of the average worker from an ethnic minority shows that these problems can be worse.

Elizabeth Johnson is black and has worked as a PA and team secretary for nearly nine years, in companies as diverse as a top public sector union and a merchant bank. "At the start of the recruitment process, I find that some consultancies want photographs to accompany your CV and it's at this point that my heart sinks. Too many times, I have nearly got the job but then a spurious reason for the vacancy no longer being available is given by the consultant, once the photos have been sent out."

Once in a role, progression through the ranks is not always purely on merit. "I seem to get along fine in team positions, but have found it harder to progress to senior roles such as a director's PA or an administrative manager," says Johnson. "I don't think I'm paranoid as nearly ten years of experience and a business administration degree from a red-brick university have still not enabled me to progress beyond team secretarial roles. Meanwhile, many of my contemporaries are now office managers and senior executive PAs earning well in the region of £30k."

Ultimately, there are no clear cut solutions. One way to level out the playing field is to make sure someone with no axe to grind - a manager from another area or someone from personnel, say - acts as a quality control in the recruitment process to ensure fair play.

It is clear that discrimination by employers is one reason for ethnic minorities failing to get access to jobs and promotions despite often having the necessary qualifications. However, serious attempts to redress imbalances are now in place and with the economic benefits of equality self-evident, more and more organisations will find exclusion a high price to pay.

 The Equality Authority in Ireland has nominated November 6-10 as Anti-Racist Workplace Week.

 Free, Fair and Efficient? Open internal job advertising, Hirsh W, Pollard E, Tamkin P. IES Report 371, July 2000. ISBN 1-85184-301-9. £19.95.

fields.headline: New twist in Speaker tussle
fields.standfirst: Special report: who will be the new Speaker?
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam is today planning to make a dramatic break with Westminster precedent by proposing the Labour MP Gwyneth Dunwoody as next Speaker of the House of Commons - despite being a cabinet minister who is not supposed to interfere with such historic backbench prerogatives.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam is today planning to make a dramatic break with Westminster precedent by proposing the Labour MP Gwyneth Dunwoody as next Speaker of the House of Commons - despite being a cabinet minister who is not supposed to interfere with such historic backbench prerogatives.

Not only is Tony Blair's most incorrigible rule-breaker hoping to influence wavering MPs into backing a friend and colleague who has been a thorn in the side of senior ministers, Ms Mowlam is also aware that many people in government are quietly promoting a different candidate - the Tory ex-minister Sir George Young.

Mrs Dunwoody, an MP on and off since 1966, is an Old Labour radical of the right who currently chairs the all-party Commons transport select committee with such independence that many Tories have come to see her virtues. Betty Boothroyd, who is close to Ms Mowlam, is said to be a fan.

Although Ms Mowlam has prepared her speech it is not clear if she will get the chance to deliver it. Sir Edward Heath, 84-year-old Father of the Commons, will preside over the election at 2.30pm after first telling MPs how he proposes to run it.

Michael "Mick" Martin, a Labour MP and trade union veteran from Glasgow, is generally thought to have most votes, more than 200 of the 659 available according to some rivals who claim that Mr Martin's support is all from the Labour side, rather than the cross-party backing that past speakers have enjoyed.

Some senior ministers, including Margaret Beckett, leader of the house, have been saying that Labour should respect the 35-year-old tradition that alternates the speakership between the parties.

That would point to a Tory speaker, and some Labour MPs say they have been urged by ministers to back Sir George, a moderate whose allies call him "the English Donald Dewar". But such rumours may be dirty tricks.

Faced with a crowded field of up to 12 would-be successors to Miss Boothroyd, Sir Edward has a number of options. But he wants to tell all contenders - and even the party whips - at the same time, later today. The current voting system is not designed for a big field and would be accident-prone, especially if candidates are called from alternate parties but in alphabetical party order.

Many MPs, both young and old, want a ballot with a run-off between the top two, as Tony Benn and others have proposed. But no system is neutral. That would guarantee victory to Mr Martin, one rival Labour camp protested yesterday. Sir George is said to have up to 160 votes so far.

Mr Martin has quietly courted Commons clerks and staff as well as MPs. He has ardent supporters who would love to see a "proper working-class MP" in what has become a high-profile post. His detractors doubt if he can do the job. Crucial may be younger MPs, who believe Miss Boothroyd, who came up the political hard way, was unsympathetic to their complaints about the tough Commons regime.

fields.headline: Barak dumps peace  hunt
fields.standfirst:
Defiant Palestinians boosted by $1bn Arab aid package
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday capped weeks of blood and rage by turning his back on the seven-year quest for peace, declaring a "time-out" in negotiations with the Palestinians.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem and Brian Whitaker in Cairo
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday capped weeks of blood and rage by turning his back on the seven-year quest for peace, declaring a "time-out" in negotiations with the Palestinians.

The announcement was delivered only minutes after an emergency Arab League summit in Cairo denounced the Jewish state as barbarian, and pledged financial support to a Palestinian intifada which has claimed at least 125 lives, almost all of them Palestinian.

Mr Barak met scorn from Yasser Arafat, who told him to "go to hell", setting the stage for further confrontation between the two masters of brinkmanship.

The emergency summit in Cairo agreed $1bn (£690m) backing for the Palestinians and called on all Arabs to donate one day's wages "as a popular Arab contribution to the intifada and support for the national Palestinian struggle".

With the peace process now clinically dead, Mr Barak is again toying with the idea of "unilateral separation", carving out a Palestinian state whose borders with Israel would be sealed by concrete walls and electrified fences.

Mr Arafat, in turn, is weighing the possibility of a unilateral declaration of independence, on or after November 15, an act that would be met with harsh Israeli reprisals.

Such high-wire machinations are the product of the basest of political instincts. Mr Barak's survival can be guaranteed for just 10 more days. If he does not woo the hawkish Likud party leader, Ariel Sharon, into a national emergency government, he faces dismissal when Israel's parliament returns at the end of the month.

Mr Sharon has made his price for joining the government abundantly clear: dump the peace process. Yesterday, Mr Barak acquiesced.

But Mr Barak and his aides tried to obscure such harsh realities, choosing to portray his decision as a suspension, and not the definitive end to negotiation efforts. They also refused to say how long the "time-out" would last, leaving the door slightly ajar for yet another diplomatic foray by the US, perhaps after the American elections.

Instead, they placed the blame for the suspension of negotiations squarely on the Palestinians and the Arabs.

"After the Arab summit, and in light of its results, we will have to call a time-out, the goal of which will be to reassess the diplomatic process in light of the events of recent weeks," said a statement from Mr Barak's office.

On his return to Gaza from the summit, Mr Arafat was predictably defiant. "I expected this from him. It is not the first time he said something like this," he said.

"My response is that our people are continuing the road to Jerusalem, the capital of our independent Palestinian state. To accept or not to accept it, let him go to hell," Mr Arafat said.

Mr Barak was adamant that his time-out was "dictated by common sense". With the violence unabated in the West Bank and Gaza, despite two US-mediated ceasefires, he said there was no point in an immediate resumption of negotiations with the Palestinians. In renewed unrest yesterday, four Palestinians were killed, including a 14-year-old boy in Gaza.

But while there is little end to the violence, Mr Barak's declaration is fiercely opposed even by members of his own cabinet. They see the time-out as a prelude to forming an emergency government with Mr Sharon within the next few days, an outcome that would destroy the last shreds of Palestinian trust in the Israeli prime minister.

The prime minister's aides yesterday insisted he did not need government's approval for his decision - and he might not have received it. At the weekend, at least four ministers voiced dismay, along with Peace Now, the leading coalition of Israeli doves.

"Calming the region is an immediate aim, but it should at the same time be linked to an immediate diplomatic alternative," the foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, said.

At their summit, the Arab leaders - reduced from 22 to 21 following a protest walkout by Libya - demanded that those "who committed the massacres against the Palestinians and Arabs in the occupied territories" be prosecuted as war criminals.

Saudi Arabia, a key American ally in the Arab world, accused the US of shirking its responsibilities as a sponsor of the peace process and failing to chastise Israel for "its unacceptable conduct".

War of words

'We will have to take a time-out to reassess the peace process in response to events of recent weeks' - Ehud Barak

'Let him go to hell' - Yasser Arafat

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: • Well, there was us thinking that the boss's little failings - the chronic untidiness, the incompetence when trying to construct a cup of coffee, the inability to remember without constant prompting the extension number of his or her own phone - were just a trying but necessary component of the PA's role.
fields.body:
 Well, there was us thinking that the boss's little failings - the chronic untidiness, the incompetence when trying to construct a cup of coffee, the inability to remember without constant prompting the extension number of his or her own phone - were just a trying but necessary component of the PA's role. When, in fact, all along these "eccentricities" have been deliberately cultivated as part of a management technique which aims to make them better leaders by appearing less perfect in the eyes of their staff. Of course.

A piece in the most recent Harvard Business Review by Robert Goffee and Gareth Jones puts forward the theory that managers ought to decide upon a character flaw to display when in the office. This, they say, has two advantages: it makes the boss seem more human and thus more approachable (true - WPM has always found jolly nice people ever so difficult to talk to); and it also serves the purpose of masking even more unsavoury character traits (a hint: it doesn't. We know them all). WPM can only wonder how bosses decide on the one fault they are prepared to reveal. "Shall I assemble all the paperclips in the office into a long chain? Hm, might not mask the fact that I'm a crashing bore. Set my computer to ping loudly when email arrives? No, need to be more human. Empty the photocopier of paper? A spot of vandalism in the staff toilets?"

 Dithering bosses would be advised not to follow the example of the City worker who admitted in a recent survey by onvocation.com that the most outrageous thing he had ever done in the office was "playing Status Quo at full volume on my computer".

 There's no advice on how to deal with a pub rock-loving colleague on www.secretary1.com, but there is plenty of stuff about improving your shorthand, finding companies to make conference badges and hiring a massage therapist to come to your office, and so it is website of the week. Although WPM, whose desk is currently carpeted in sticky memo notes of every hue, is disconcerted to learn from the site that this method of information gathering could give the impression that WPM is disorganised ...

*WPM can often be heard moaning about it, but workplace stress can have more serious effects on staff than the now-universal hunched shoulders and hollow eyes. Stressed Out, part of Channel 4's Stop, Go Home series, goes out on Sunday and concentrates on the chaotic working environment of a council One-Stop centre in Leeds. Professional stress consultants step in to help, but don't expect feng shui and back rubs: the experts here say that they expect to find 3% of any workforce exhibiting a degree of mental disturbance that would qualify them as psychiatric outpatients.

*From tomorrow, as Office Hours reported last month, employers have the right to monitor your emails and phone calls without your consent. Patricia Hewitt, the minister for e-commerce, has insisted that such "routine access" is necessary to ensure that employees are complying with company rules. Make sure you know why they can do this, and what your rights are today.
Check out www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/netprivacy.

 More effective rules against discrimination in the workplace should be put in place following a European Union directive passed last week that requires the government to introduce new penalties for companies that discriminate against workers because of their religion, sexual orientation, age or disability - which could go some way to resolving the problem of staff being forced to work on religious holidays. The regulations must be in place by 2003; those targeting age and disability discrimination by 2006.

 Just when WPM thought companies were becoming more people-friendly (they don't have to wait until 2006, do they?) comes news that only 50% of workers think that their managers take the idea of employee satisfaction seriously, according to recent research into workplace attitudes by Investors in People. It seems, however, that the other 50% may have been so content in their working lives that they allowed their bosses rather too much of the credit. In the same survey, just 8% of female managers and 4% of male managers agreed that employee satisfaction was "an important business objective". It seems those annoying little character flaws can hide more sinister failings after all ...

webTitle: Mark Lawson: BBC1's new drama The Sins

fields.headline: Don't tempt me
fields.standfirst: BBC1's new drama The Sins finds the great Pete Postlethwaite coming up against the seven deadly temptations. It sounds like a piece of high-concept nonsense.But  Mark Lawson finds it irresistible
fields.trailText: BBC1's new drama The Sins finds the great Pete Postlethwaite coming up against the seven deadly temptations. It sounds like a piece of high-concept nonsense. But Mark Lawson finds it irresistible.
fields.body:
Executives, critics and viewers whose formative years of television drama were in the 70s tend to be scathing about the ways in which small-screen plays are now commissioned. In those days, we're led to believe, a contract and advance could be issued merely for "new Dennis Potter" or "latest Trevor Griffiths". Now, possible projects are pitched to layers of executives and floated to focus groups before the dramatist's fingers can hit the keyboard.

A major drawback of this front-end scepticism about projects, it's usually said, is that it encourages concept pieces, dramas reducible to a grabby single-liner comprehensible to civilians: the thirtysomething cooking vet detective, set in Norwich. It's a fair fear, but there's proof this week that it shouldn't be a general prejudice.

The Sins was almost certainly outlined as "man faces each of the seven deadly sins in turn". The pitching process may even have contained helpful references to Seven, the movie in which Brad Pitt and Morgan Freeman as detectives are faced by a serial killer with tableaux illustrating pride, wrath, envy, lust, gluttony, avarice and sloth.

It's just the kind of idea that might be expected to appeal to drama-illiterate controllers and sample panels of viewers in Wolverhampton.

But it's also strange, dark, daring and brilliant.

One advantage of the concept drama for a viewer is the enjoyable relish, before it starts, in predicting how the writer will play the game.

When The Sins was first mentioned in the trade press, I'd guessed it'd be a conventional dramatisation of the trespasses: middle-aged man becomes snob (pride), purchases a mansion (avarice), shags his secretary (lust), gourmandises to a coronary (gluttony) and so on.

But the writer of The Sins - William Ivory, creator of Common As Muck - has dreamed up a very subtle scheme. Len (Pete Postlethwaite) is an ex-con who, on release from jail, is guilty of pride by declaring he'll prove himself to be better than the clan of crooks and no- hopers he comes from. The writing, though, is layered, so that the Kray-like pride of the villainous family in their community is also explored.

Generations of script editors have held that the greatest sin in drama writing is tonal inconsistency but - in that very 21st-century post-Tarantino way - The Sins treats these shifts as a virtue, alternating comedy and tragedy, slapstick dialogue and soaring rhetoric.

A sequence from the second pro gramme illustrates the risks the show takes with tone. Len's covetousness -the transgression under examination in this episode - involves desiring, while working as undertaker for his Uncle Irwin (Frank Finlay), the top-end hearse driven by rival funeral director Morrie (Trevor Peacock). Irwin's firm has such an old banger that one of their clients is carried to the church through the streets on foot. Len spends his evenings lasciviously inspecting brochures for state-of-depart death wagons.

In the best serial writing, facts established one week pay off the next. In the case of Len, we know from the opener that he dwells among thieves, and that his own part in their crimes was as get-away dri ver. So the ground is broken for the fact that the gang will nick Morrie's superior wheels to cheer Len up and that - with Morrie spotting the hot motor while leading a cortege in his back-up vehicle in the opposite direction - the scene is established for a startling variation on the car chase... A hearse chase, in which Len, at the wheel, must utilise his bank-dash know-how while observing the propriety that funeral processions go slowly.

Another unusual decision is hidden in this scene. The mourners for the loved one in the stolen hearse are a black family. When Len met the young Afro-Caribbean wife or mother in the funeral parlour, this viewer at least became wary. So strong are the Stephen Lawrence associations that I feared the family had been bereaved in some racial killing ignored by police, or that our hero would be incidentally tempted in this episode by the sin of racism. And yet to assume that non-white characters must be there to make a point is one of the deadly errors of the drama viewer. The family just happens to be black. That this should be the case - and in a scene which takes extravagant risks with taste - is a measure of the series' sophistication.

Another favourite complaint of the television drama golden-agers is that the system prizes ideas which can stretch to more than one series. But, again, The Sins definitively seems a single piece. The obvious sequel - man acts out each of the seven virtues in turn - would rightly be rejected by the executives and focus groups as lacking conflict and potential.

The Sins, though, ensures that the seven deadly sins of the television watcher (déjà-vu, confusion, cliché-spotting, boredom, switching over, licence-fee evasion and satellite purchase) are never a temptation.

 The Sins, tomorrow, 9.10pm, BBC1.

Pain barrier

A frequent subject for media pundits and watchdogs is "intrusion into grief": the knock on the door of the train-crash driver's widow; the scrum at the cemetery gates. A common editor's defence is that the bereaved or otherwise agonised find it useful to share their grief, to give publicity to their loved one.

It's easy to be cynical about this defence but there's increasing evidence that some of the distressed do find the media a friend. The parents of the murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne played out their grief through press conferences, newspaper interviews and campaigns.

And this week's Dispatches (Thursday, 9.30pm, Channel 4) seems to mark another threshold moment in the publicising of private nightmare.

Chris Oxley's documentary follows Tim Blackman from shortly after the disappearance of his daughter Lucie in Tokyo on July 1 this year. The conceit of the piece is that he operates as a kind of private detective trying to find his daughter or find out what happened to her.

Even in an age made ever more transparent by the media, most parents in Mr Blackman's circumstances would be more inclined to crawl into a corner and howl than invite a documentary crew to follow them. Presumably he made the judgement that publicity is often the best device in disappearance cases. (The father of the Kenya murder victim Julie Ward shared his grief with the media in the hope of finding her killer.) But he was taking the risk that the lens might be on him when he learned of his daughter's death.

The film was unavailable for preview, but it's reported that Lucie's father wasn't filmed when the news came through that Japanese police were digging up a garden. Even so, this distress-access documentary should be watched by all students of media behaviour with a view to answering two questions.

Does Mr Blackman's loss of privacy justify the gain in publicity for the case? Have we lost too many of the barriers which used to surround pain?
