A hearse chase, in which Len, at the wheel, must utilise his bank-dash know-how while observing the propriety that funeral processions go slowly. Another unusual decision is hidden in this scene. The mourners for the loved one in the stolen hearse are a black family. When Len met the young Afro-Caribbean wife or mother in the funeral parlour, this viewer at least became wary. So strong are the Stephen Lawrence associations that I feared the family had been bereaved in some racial killing ignored by police, or that our hero would be incidentally tempted in this episode by the sin of racism. And yet to assume that non-white characters must be there to make a point is one of the deadly errors of the drama viewer. The family just happens to be black. That this should be the case - and in a scene which takes extravagant risks with taste - is a measure of the series' sophistication. Another favourite complaint of the television drama golden-agers is that the system prizes ideas which can stretch to more than one series. But, again, The Sins definitively seems a single piece. The obvious sequel - man acts out each of the seven virtues in turn - would rightly be rejected by the executives and focus groups as lacking conflict and potential. The Sins, though, ensures that the seven deadly sins of the television watcher (déjà-vu, confusion, cliché-spotting, boredom, switching over, licence-fee evasion and satellite purchase) are never a temptation.  The Sins, tomorrow, 9.10pm, BBC1. Pain barrier A frequent subject for media pundits and watchdogs is "intrusion into grief": the knock on the door of the train-crash driver's widow; the scrum at the cemetery gates. A common editor's defence is that the bereaved or otherwise agonised find it useful to share their grief, to give publicity to their loved one. It's easy to be cynical about this defence but there's increasing evidence that some of the distressed do find the media a friend. The parents of the murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne played out their grief through press conferences, newspaper interviews and campaigns. And this week's Dispatches (Thursday, 9.30pm, Channel 4) seems to mark another threshold moment in the publicising of private nightmare. Chris Oxley's documentary follows Tim Blackman from shortly after the disappearance of his daughter Lucie in Tokyo on July 1 this year. The conceit of the piece is that he operates as a kind of private detective trying to find his daughter or find out what happened to her. Even in an age made ever more transparent by the media, most parents in Mr Blackman's circumstances would be more inclined to crawl into a corner and howl than invite a documentary crew to follow them. Presumably he made the judgement that publicity is often the best device in disappearance cases. (The father of the Kenya murder victim Julie Ward shared his grief with the media in the hope of finding her killer.) But he was taking the risk that the lens might be on him when he learned of his daughter's death. The film was unavailable for preview, but it's reported that Lucie's father wasn't filmed when the news came through that Japanese police were digging up a garden. Even so, this distress-access documentary should be watched by all students of media behaviour with a view to answering two questions. Does Mr Blackman's loss of privacy justify the gain in publicity for the case? Have we lost too many of the barriers which used to surround pain?

fields.headline: Regional theatre shows stubborn streak
fields.trailText: The stubborn vitality of regional theatre was demonstrated in last night's Barclays Theatre Awards - despite a devastating report for the Arts Council this year which pronounced it in terminal decline.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The stubborn vitality of regional theatre was demonstrated in last night's Barclays Theatre Awards - despite a devastating report for the Arts Council this year which pronounced it in terminal decline.

The Colour of Justice, the moving dramatisation by the Guardian's Richard Norton-Taylor of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, won the best touring production, beating a starry Royal Shakespeare Company tour of The Seagull.

The Almeida in north London, which has had another glittering year, including the world premiere of Harold Pinter's Celebration, and Ralph Fiennes starring as both Richard II and Coriolanus, was a predictable winner of the theatre of the year award.

However, a host of struggling small regional theatres also won awards. The Mercury in Colchester - beaten for theatre of the year - was consoled with the stage award for special achievement. The most welcoming theatre award went to the Theatre Royal in Plymouth, which has been to the brink of financial ruin on several occasions.

The prizes are unique in the panoply of theatre awards, which generally reflect the concentration of starry productions in London, because the nominations begin with a long list drawn from hundreds of reports from 150 judges all over the country.

"It is quite remarkable," Andrew Leigh, chairman of the awards, said. "The obituary of regional theatre has been written so many times, and yet theatres themselves are the ultimate optimists, somehow they pick themselves up and on.

"It is slightly ambivalent presenting these awards, because here we are celebrating the richness and variety of the work that is being done, but the crisis is real. Theatres are going to close, casts are getting smaller, there is less new writing, and it all comes down to underfunding."

Mr Leigh, who is now a theatre consultant, is the former director of the Theatre of Comedy in the West End and has worked with many of the major regional theatres. He added: "We are all looking forward to seeing the effects of the additional money which Chris Smith [the culture secretary] was so pleased to get. It is sorely needed."

The Arts Council report last spring warned that regional audiences, cast sizes, tours, performance numbers and new productions were declining to the point of collapse, while deficits soared.

Mr Leigh praised The Colour of Justice as an example of the enterprise and cooperation which was getting the smaller independent theatres through dire times. Many of the nominations were co-productions between regional theatres, and Justice originated in the tiny Tricycle Theatre in Kilburn, north London, was then mounted as a touring production by Virginia Buckley and the West Yorkshire Playhouse, and was finally televised on BBC2.

Richard Wilson, who has sworn never to repeat his One Foot in the Grave catchphrase "I don't believe it!" in public again, must have had to bite his tongue last night, when he took the best director award for Mr Kolpert, at the Royal Court Theatre Upstairs, south London.

The best new play prize went to Ben Brown's Larkin With Women, at the Stephen Joseph theatre in Scarborough, a play based on the poet's poems, letters, and biography.

The play had some last minute rewrites when Mr Brown's portrayal of Larkin, often seen as a great poet but a grumpy misogynist, was passionately attacked by Maev Brennan, a former lover and close friend.

She offered a startling alternative vision of Larkin as a major league romantic, who gave her a gift of a Harrods bag containing the perfume Memoire Cherie because he was so moved by the name.

The winners:

Best actress: Victoria Hamilton, As You Like It, Crucible Sheffield, and Lyric Hammersmith

Best actor: Jonathan Cake, Baby Doll, Birmingham Repertory theatre

Best supporting actress: Emma Cunniffe, The Master Builder, English Touring Theatre

Best supporting actor: Guy Henry, Volpone, RSC at Newcastle Playhouse and the Theatre Royal Plymouth

Best director: Richard Wilson, Mr Kolpert, Jerwood Theatre Upstairs, Royal Court

Best designer: Jeremy Herbert, 4.48 Psychosis, Jerwood Theatre Upstairs, Royal Court

Theatre of the year: Almeida, London

Best new play: Larkin with Women, Ben Brown, Stephen Joseph theatre, Scarborough

Best touring production: The Colour of Justice: The Stephen Lawrence Inquiry, edited by Richard Norton-Taylor, Tricycle London and Virginia Buckley and West Yorkshire Playhouse

Best musical: Anonymous Society, music by Jacques Brel, start at the Lyric Theatre Hammersmith

Equity best show for children and young people: Under the Apple Tree, devised by Paul Harman, Philip Harrison and David Tarkenter, touring production

Most welcoming theatre: Theatre Royal Plymouth

Outstanding achievement in dance: Tamara Jojo, with English National Ballet

Outstanding achievement in opera: Anja Silja, Amanda Roocroft and Jiri Behohlaveck, for Glyndebourne's Jenufa

Stage award for special achievement in regional theatre: Mercury theatre, Colchester

webTitle: Downing Street hit by donor revelation

fields.headline: Downing Street hit by donor revelation
fields.standfirst:
Blair aide asked Robinson to contribute to election fund

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Downing Street was dragged into the Geoffrey Robinson controversy yesterday when Labour confirmed that Tony Blair's chief-of-staff asked the multimillionaire to make a donation to the party before the last general election.
fields.body:
Downing Street was dragged into the Geoffrey Robinson controversy yesterday when Labour confirmed that Tony Blair's chief-of-staff asked the multimillionaire to make a donation to the party before the last general election.

As Labour frantically tried to match Tory spending in the run-up to the election, Jonathan Powell held discussions with the future paymaster general about making a contribution to the party's election campaign fund.

The disclosure came as an embarrassment to Downing Street, which had insisted that Mr Blair's closest circle were not involved directly in any fundraising.

As head of Mr Blair's office before the election, Mr Powell was the link with the "blind trust" which funded the Labour leader's office. Under strict rules designed to create "Chinese walls" between donors and the leadership, Mr Powell liaised with the trustees rather than donors to the trust.

Labour insisted that Mr Powell had done nothing wrong because he spoke to Mr Robinson about general party funding, rather than donations to the trust.

In a statement, Lance Price, the party's director of communications, said: "In the run-up to the general election, as part of his role in liaising with the Labour party over election planning, Jonathan Powell discussed, perfectly legitimately, with Geoffrey Robinson whether he could contribute to the Labour party's general election campaign fund, not the Labour leader's office fund. In the end, he did not do so."

Mr Price said it was "absurd" that Mr Robinson should not be free to discuss general party funding with the leader's chief-of-staff. "There is no way you could stop the then leader of the opposition knowing who was donating to the overall funds of the Labour party," he said. "No one ever said you should."

The Tories seized on the disclosures yesterday as another sign of the "web of deceit" surrounding Labour funding.

Michael Ancram, the Tory chairman, said: "They refuse to tell the truth until it is dragged out of them, just as they refused to tell the truth about the formula one saga until that was dragged out of them too. Their claim to be a government of integrity is now in tatters."

The disclosure about Mr Powell's discussions with Mr Robinson will irritate Downing Street, which had hoped to put behind it the furore over the multimillionaire's legendary generosity.

Blairites spent most of last week rounding on Mr Robinson after his memoirs revived embarrassing memories of his £373,000 loan to Peter Mandelson.

Mr Robinson, who resigned as paymaster general after details of his loan to Mr Mandelson were leaked to the Guardian, made clear yesterday that he had no intention of disappearing from the political scene and indicated that he would like to return to government.

Asked on Sky News whether he would like to make a comeback as a minister, Mr Robinson said: "That's for someone else."

webTitle: Israeli plan to build fences, not bridges

fields.headline: Israeli plan to build fences, not bridges
fields.standfirst:
New map: 'Berlin wall' would seal off Palestinians

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: An elevated highway racing 28 miles across Israel with no exit, and electrified fences slicing through the stony hills of the West Bank. As visions of peace drown in rivers of blood, the Israeli prime minister is drawing a new map of the Middle East, one that is both futuristic and a throwback to the concrete walls and checkpoints of cold war Europe.
fields.body:
An elevated highway racing 28 miles across Israel with no exit, and electrified fences slicing through the stony hills of the West Bank. As visions of peace drown in rivers of blood, the Israeli prime minister is drawing a new map of the Middle East, one that is both futuristic and a throwback to the concrete walls and checkpoints of cold war Europe.

After turning his back on negotiations by declaring an indefinite "time-out" to the peace process yesterday, Ehud Barak is reviving a plan to change the whole architecture of the Middle East. He wants to build fences, not bridges.

In effect, Israel would simply impose the boundaries on a separate Palestinian entity - with none of the haggling about percentages of territory in the West Bank. At its most extreme, the concept of "unilateral separation" being debated in Israeli circles would hermetically seal off the West Bank and Gaza with an elaborate system of roads, tunnels and road blocks, akin to international border crossings.

This is Israel's worst-case scenario - and the Palestinians'. It could become reality if the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, declares an independent state on or after November 15, and Israel takes retributive action.

Mr Barak's new sketch map of the Middle East would bar 110,000 Palestinians from their jobs in Israel, painfully sever telecommunications, electricity and water systems that are deeply intertwined, and kill off economists' hopes of a happy marriage between a hi-tech economy and a low-wage Arab workforce.

Last week the Palestinians' information minister, Yasser Abd Rabbo, denounced it as apartheid. "Separation means first and foremost the shattering of a dream that has already died," said a comment in the liberal Ha'aretz newspaper. But despite opposition from liberals and 200,000 Jewish settlers in the West Bank, who would be forced to abandon isolated enclaves and amalgamate settlement blocks, the idea of separation is gaining momentum.

Last week Mr Barak charged Israel's deputy defence minister, Efraim Sneh, with studying the plan, and the trade and industry ministries have been instructed to look into its economic implications.

"If it becomes obvious that an agreement between Israel and the Palestinians is not at hand, we have to think about a new direction," Mr Sneh said.

Despite devoting months to peace negotiations, Mr Barak is a longstanding believer in the idea of separating Israel from the Palestinians physically, economically and politically. "Good fences make good neighbours" is one of his favourite axioms.

This is an ideal with immense psychological appeal for many Israelis, who would gladly wash their hands of the Palestinians, and who see it as a solution to their bottomless sense of insecurity about losing their demographic edge in the Jewish state.

There is already some degree of separation. The Gaza Strip is cut off from Israel by an electrified fence, breached by two border crossings: Karni for commercial goods, and Erez for tens of thousands of Palestinian workers. But in its most absolute form, separation is an extremely complicated and expensive venture.

According to an idea under discussion since last year, Israel would build an exitless elevated highway from Gaza, decanting near Hebron so that Palestinians could travel to the West Bank without setting foot on Israeli soil. In concept, the highway would resemble the autobahn lined with watchtowers that allowed West Germans to travel through East Germany to West Berlin during the cold war. That alone would cost $250m.

But the border between the West Bank and Israel is extremely porous and would require radical solutions. Mr Barak is ready for that, with proposals to tunnel under the Mount of Olives, and to erect high fences along the seam that divides Jewish west Jerusalem from the Arab east, occupied by Israel since 1967. Estimates put the cost of that as high as $1bn.

Separation

Israel stakes its claims to its territory, and by default lays out the borders of a new Palestinian state

Turn existing army roadblocks into international border crossings

$1bn for a system of roads, tunnels and bridges to seal off the West Bank, while providing access to Jewish settlements

$250m for a sealed 28-mile elevated highway from Gaza to the West Bank

Reduce Israel's reliance on 110,000 Palestinian labourers

webTitle: Return ticket to state control easily bought

fields.headline: Return ticket to state control easily bought
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: It is the morning after the Hatfield rail crash. A poster on East Croydon station catches the eye of a Guardian reader. "Will it happen on the next train?" say the white letters on a black background. "Will it happen today?"
fields.body:
It is the morning after the Hatfield rail crash. A poster on East Croydon station catches the eye of a Guardian reader. "Will it happen on the next train?" say the white letters on a black background. "Will it happen today?"

Intrigued, he takes a closer look. Perhaps this is the industry trying to reassure passengers after another crash in which lives have been lost. Perhaps an explanation for why speed restrictions are being imposed on 81 stretches of line in a textbook case of stable door bolting. No. The pay-off line from Connex South Central is: "With more people checking than ever before, fare evaders will be caught."

Apart from its grotesque insensitivity, this warning tells us much about the modern railway industry. The name of the game is profit maximisation and for the train operating companies that means cramming more passengers on to the finite number of trains and making sure that fewer of them bilk the system. Increasing the network's capacity is the job of Railtrack, which has no economic incentive to spend money increasing the number of lines or the size of stations to accommodate longer trains.

It is obvious that the privatisation of the railways has been a failure. As Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, said candidly last week: "The railway was ripped apart at privatisation and the structure that was put in place was a structure designed, if we are honest, to maximise the proceeds to the Treasury. It was not a structure designed to optimise safety, optimise investment or, indeed, cope with the huge increase in the number of passengers the railway has seen."

Quite. Railtrack was told about the faults on the track at Hatfield last year but nothing was done because it became embroiled in an argument with Balfour Beatty, the company responsible for maintenance of the line, about who should pay for the repair work.

The idea behind privatisation - a crackpot idea from the management consultancy industry - was that the discipline of the market would make the railways more efficient and modern. Instead, the crashes, the skimping on safety, the belated recognition that something has to be done are testament to market failure on a quite staggering scale.

Under privatisation, the strong chain of command and responsibility which made safety the prime consideration was broken, with Railtrack paying the price for the job cuts and the haggling over contracts that helped boost its profitability. That is not to say that the railways were wonderful under state ownership. They were not. But the problem was not the structure of the industry but the lack of money.

However, there seems a strange reluctance now to state the blindingly obvious. Let us stop messing around and restore Railtrack to public ownership. The idea that Labour should do what it said it would do in opposition does not appear on the agenda.

Indeed, it is as though the very mention of the words "public ownership" is a faux pas. It would be the simplest thing in the world for Labour to blame privatisation for Southall, Paddington and Hatfield, but it shows not the slightest desire to do so for fear that it might then come under pressure to reassert state control over the railways.

There can really only be three explanations for the government's refusal to countenance renationalisation. The first is that it has an ideological objection, sharing the Conservative belief that the private sector is innately superior. The second is that it would like to renationalise the railways but has not got the money. The third is it fears renationalisation would be unpopular with the voters.

It only takes a moment to realise that none of these possible explanations holds water. If Labour really has a doctrinal problem with state ownership, then logically this must extend to those parts of the economy which are still in public hands, up to and including the national health service. Yet ministers see it as their duty - their destiny, even - to prevent Nye Bevan's creation falling into the hands of the privatisers. Labour had no qualms about rolling back Conservative reforms in health, but has been reluctant to do the same with the railways. This is intellectually incoherent.

It may be that, despite its massive majority, the government lacks the confidence to say that privatisation of the railways was a mistake and should be reversed.

One of Tony Blair's proudest boasts is that his government eschews dogma and instead makes decisions on the basis of what works best. That is certainly not the case with the railways, where we now have a system of Byzantine complexity, with shadow strategic rail authorities and rail regulators rather than a cleaner, simpler alternative. But to change this would mean that Labour would have to make the case for public ownership, something it seems incapable of doing.

Instead of explaining why state control of the railways makes sense, the government has continually fallen back on the argument that, while it might in theory like to consider renationalisation, sadly the state of the public finances makes it impossible. As Robert Barrie shows elsewhere on this page, this argument is now threadbare. The healthy state of the economy means that there will be a budget surplus of around £20bn this year, and that does not take into account the £22.5bn garnered from the sale of mobile phone licences.

Money has been a real problem for the railways in the past, for when times have been tough governments of both right and left have found it easier politically to shelve spending on the infrastructure than on front-line services. The result has been a network starved of investment. But money is no longer a problem. Gordon Brown has more money than he knows what to do with. If he chose, he could use the mobile phone licence cash to invest in a long-term plan for the railways rather than to pay down the national debt.

Buying up every share in Railtrack would cost the government around £5bn at the company's current market capitalisation, but the government would only need a 51% stake to have overall control. This would cost £2.5bn, less than the cost of reducing the basic rate of income tax by 1p in the pound or, to put it another way, the equivalent of three millennium domes. This would be £2.5bn well spent, ensuring that the government once again had strategic control of the railways. It could end the ridiculous division with the maintenance companies, expedite repairs and make the funds available for expansion of the network rather than expansion of fast food outlets on station forecourts.

fields.bodyText: It is the morning after the Hatfield rail crash. A poster on East Croydon station catches the eye of a Guardian reader. "Will it happen on the next train?" say the white letters on a black background. "Will it happen today?" Intrigued, he takes a closer look. Perhaps this is the industry trying to reassure passengers after another crash in which lives have been lost. Perhaps an explanation for why speed restrictions are being imposed on 81 stretches of line in a textbook case of stable door bolting. No. The pay-off line from Connex South Central is: "With more people checking than ever before, fare evaders will be caught." Apart from its grotesque insensitivity, this warning tells us much about the modern railway industry. The name of the game is profit maximisation and for the train operating companies that means cramming more passengers on to the finite number of trains and making sure that fewer of them bilk the system. Increasing the network's capacity is the job of Railtrack, which has no economic incentive to spend money increasing the number of lines or the size of stations to accommodate longer trains. It is obvious that the privatisation of the railways has been a failure. As Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, said candidly last week: "The railway was ripped apart at privatisation and the structure that was put in place was a structure designed, if we are honest, to maximise the proceeds to the Treasury. It was not a structure designed to optimise safety, optimise investment or, indeed, cope with the huge increase in the number of passengers the railway has seen." Quite. Railtrack was told about the faults on the track at Hatfield last year but nothing was done because it became embroiled in an argument with Balfour Beatty, the company responsible for maintenance of the line, about who should pay for the repair work. The idea behind privatisation - a crackpot idea from the management consultancy industry - was that the discipline of the market would make the railways more efficient and modern. Instead, the crashes, the skimping on safety, the belated recognition that something has to be done are testament to market failure on a quite staggering scale. Under privatisation, the strong chain of command and responsibility which made safety the prime consideration was broken, with Railtrack paying the price for the job cuts and the haggling over contracts that helped boost its profitability. That is not to say that the railways were wonderful under state ownership. They were not. But the problem was not the structure of the industry but the lack of money. However, there seems a strange reluctance now to state the blindingly obvious. Let us stop messing around and restore Railtrack to public ownership. The idea that Labour should do what it said it would do in opposition does not appear on the agenda. Indeed, it is as though the very mention of the words "public ownership" is a faux pas. It would be the simplest thing in the world for Labour to blame privatisation for Southall, Paddington and Hatfield, but it shows not the slightest desire to do so for fear that it might then come under pressure to reassert state control over the railways. There can really only be three explanations for the government's refusal to countenance renationalisation. The first is that it has an ideological objection, sharing the Conservative belief that the private sector is innately superior. The second is that it would like to renationalise the railways but has not got the money. The third is it fears renationalisation would be unpopular with the voters. It only takes a moment to realise that none of these possible explanations holds water. If Labour really has a doctrinal problem with state ownership, then logically this must extend to those parts of the economy which are still in public hands, up to and including the national health service. Yet ministers see it as their duty - their destiny, even - to prevent Nye Bevan's creation falling into the hands of the privatisers. Labour had no qualms about rolling back Conservative reforms in health, but has been reluctant to do the same with the railways. This is intellectually incoherent. It may be that, despite its massive majority, the government lacks the confidence to say that privatisation of the railways was a mistake and should be reversed. One of Tony Blair's proudest boasts is that his government eschews dogma and instead makes decisions on the basis of what works best. That is certainly not the case with the railways, where we now have a system of Byzantine complexity, with shadow strategic rail authorities and rail regulators rather than a cleaner, simpler alternative. But to change this would mean that Labour would have to make the case for public ownership, something it seems incapable of doing. Instead of explaining why state control of the railways makes sense, the government has continually fallen back on the argument that, while it might in theory like to consider renationalisation, sadly the state of the public finances makes it impossible. If he chose, he could use the mobile phone licence cash to invest in a long-term plan for the railways rather than to pay down the national debt. webTitle: Whitehall employees are the unhappiest in Britain

fields.headline: Whitehall employees are the unhappiest in Britain
fields.trailText: Research carried out for the government has revealed that its own employees are the most demoralised group of workers in the country.
fields.body:
Research carried out for the government has revealed that its own employees are the most demoralised group of workers in the country.

Twenty years of cost-cutting and constant change have left Britain's army of Whitehall civil servants the most demoralised group of workers in the UK, the survey shows.

Central government employees are the least likely to look forward to going to work when they wake up in the morning, the least likely to be proud to tell other people who they work for, and have the weakest sense of loyalty towards their employers.

Only one in seven say they trust senior management.

The embarrassing findings, which the Cabinet Office tried to water down, are revealed in research carried out by the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development for the government's in-house civil service training centre.

Its findings, to be published on Wednesday, suggest that the prime minister's pledge to modernise British government could be threatened by discontented civil servants.

The head of the civil service, Sir Richard Butler, said it provided a welcome insight into what staff in Whitehall think. "But we accept fully that there is a lot more work to be done."

Privately however, sources say the Cabinet Office was dismayed by the negative picture of Whitehall workers emerging from the research, for which it provided 15% of the funding. Senior officials at the Cabinet Office asked the institute to play down the morale problem in its presentation of the report, fearing ministers could use it as a stick with which to beat the civil service.

Continuous Whitehall restructuring is to blame for the low morale, according to the institute. "Over the last two decades central government has enjoyed a plethora of initiatives designed to extend the operation of business disciplines and practices within the public sector," said Mike Emmott of the CIPD. "Such change clearly does not come without a cost."

Low morale comes despite civil servants enjoying more job security than any other group of workers and the most flexible working arrangements. More than half believe they are not fairly paid for the work they do compared with a third of private sector workers.

Within central government, more employees now work for private sector-style agencies than for traditional departments of state. But there is no evidence from the study that the move away from rigid Whitehall hierarchies to the more decentralised style of working in agencies makes their staff any happier.

"Public servants feel that the public service ethos to which they are committed is undervalued when compared with the emphasis on commercial imperatives and imported management practices," said Geoff Armstrong, the CIPD's director. Whitehall workers feel let down by senior managers, who they say make promises they fail to keep. "It is clear from our report that employees in central government are not yet convinced that management is keeping its side of the bargain," Mr Armstrong said.

The findings pose a big challenge to senior management and the government, which launched a programme to modernise the civil service last year. This promised a better deal for staff and new, non-bureaucratic ways of working.

The Cabinet Office said yesterday: "Obviously some people aren't satisfied with their lot. If anything this research confirms the need for the [reform] programme. We are committed to making the civil service a better place to work."

The CIPD interviewed 2,000 workers from private firms, the health service, and central and local government. Health workers were the most contented group, followed by private sector workers.

webTitle: Sir Edward prepares to spring a surprise

fields.headline: Sir Edward prepares to spring a surprise
fields.standfirst: Special report: who will be the new Speaker?
fields.trailText: Sir Edward Heath, whose 1970 election victory was one of the great surprises of post-war history, is set to surprise fellow MPs again today when he waits until the last minute before telling them exactly how he will let them elect Betty Boothroyd's successor as Speaker of the Commons.
fields.body:
Sir Edward Heath, whose 1970 election victory was one of the great surprises of post-war history, is set to surprise fellow MPs again today when he waits until the last minute before telling them exactly how he will let them elect Betty Boothroyd's successor as Speaker of the Commons.

Whatever he says will cause trouble. Ever since July when Miss Boothroyd announced her intention to stand down in October and let parliament make an informed choice on the 152nd holder of her office the prospect of chaos has been compounded by the size of the field and pressure to democratise the process.

Sir Edward has not made it easier by his refusal to say if he will adapt the existing procedure for the election to the 12-candidate situation. Alternatively, he could take Tony Benn's advice and use his powers to invent a new tradition - a simple vote between every candidate who is nominated, followed by a run-off between the two with the highest votes.

Either way, Michael Martin, Labour MP for Glasgow Springburn, remains the odds-on favourite, though there are enough MPs around who want someone else to win to make it a horse race. Sir George Young, the former Tory cabinet minister and baronet, is the former shop steward's main rival.

But the prospect that Mo Mowlam will propose her old friend Gwyneth Dunwoody, if Sir Edward lets her, underlines the fact that anything may happen. Friends of David Clark, dismissed from the cabinet in 1998, say that he is more likely than Mrs Dunwoody to slip through the middle if Mr Martin falters.

But how will MPs vote at all? The former prime minister will be acting in his capacity of father of the House. He is the longest serving MP, first elected in the 1950 general election, the man who took Britain into Europe in 1973, still MP for Old Bexley and Sidcup and a regular Commons attender at 84.

Friends confirm that he sometimes tires easily and can get grumpy but remains in possession of his powers.

In 1992 when Miss Boothroyd beat the Tory former cabinet minister Peter Brooke by 372 to 238 votes, Sir Edward was in the chair. There were five potential candidates, including Labour's Harold Walker, then deputy Speaker to Bernard Weatherill.

Sir Harold, as he became, never got near testing his claim. The Speakership - Peter de Montfort was the first in 1268 - has usually been carved up by the party establishments so that an acceptable name emerged.

But the times are becoming more democratic. In 1992, Sir Edward followed a limited precedent in accepting a nomination from the Tory side, Mr Brooke.

With up to a dozen candidates it is all much harder. Rumour last night was that Sir Edward will decide that a Benn ballot will prove too complex and longwinded. Indeed, some MPs predicted he will tell them they must choose between the two perceived frontrunners, Mr Martin and Sir George.

That would cause ructions. Sir Edward is not telling even senior whips what he will do. But if speculation is right he will adapt the 1992 procedure in some way. If he goes by seniority, what form of seniority? Sir George is a cabinet grandee and privy counsellor, elected in 1974.

But should nomination go on long service? On government seniority or Commons seniority? As Betty Boothroyd's deputy, Sir Alan Haselhurst has that claim. Yet another school of thought says that the seniority of the MP nominating a candidate should influence Sir Edward.

If Sir Edward follows his own precedence he will simply go for alphabetical seniority. But even that presents problems. As such David Clark comes first on the Labour side while Mick Martin comes in the middle and Sir George right at the end. Even with proposers and seconders making very short speeches it might take hours longer than 84-year-old Sir Edward's bones could stand. It could be a long day.

The runners

 Alan Beith, 57, Liberal Democrat MP for Berwick-upon-Tweed since 1973. Lib Dem favourite.

 Menzies Campbell, 59, MP for North East Fife since June 1987. Hurt by alleged Blair support.

 David Clark, 61, Labour MP for Colne Valley between 1970 and 1974 and for South Shields since May 1979. Possible dark horse.

 Sir Patrick Cormack, 61, Conservative MP for South Staffordshire. Choice of the Commons cognoscenti only.

 Gwyneth Dunwoody, 69, Labour MP for Crewe and Nantwich. The cross-party troublemakers' candidate.

 Sir Alan Haselhurst, 63, Conservative MP for Saffron Walden. Nobody loves him.

 Michael Lord, 62, Conservative MP for Central Suffolk and North Ipswich. Also ran.

 John McWilliam, 59, Labour MP for Blaydon since 1979. Nice, but not a Speaker.

 Michael Martin, 55, Labour MP for Glasgow Springburn since 1979. The bookies' favourite.

 Richard Shepherd, 67, Conservative MP for Aldridge-Brownhills since 1979. A saint, too good for the job.

 Nicholas Winterton, 62, Conservative MP for Macclesfield since 1971. Dunwoody in trousers.

 Sir George Young, 59, Conservative MP for Ealing Acton between 1974 and 1997 and North West Hampshire since 1997. The People's Toff?

webTitle: Arabs declare jihad and agree $1bn aid deal for Palestinians

fields.headline: Arabs declare jihad and agree $1bn aid deal for Palestinians
fields.standfirst:
Summit: Tough rhetoric but leaders refuse to cut all ties with Israel

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Arab leaders set themselves on a collision course with the United States yesterday by declaring an economic and diplomatic jihad against Israel.
fields.body:
Arab leaders set themselves on a collision course with the United States yesterday by declaring an economic and diplomatic jihad against Israel.

The emergency summit in Cairo accepted a Saudi proposal to provide $1bn (£690m) in support for the Palestinians.

Under the scheme, $800m will be used to "preserve the Islamic identity of Jerusalem" and $200m - to be known as the Jerusalem intifada fund - will be allocated "to the families and education of the children of Palestinian martyrs".

Saudi Arabia, normally a close US ally, will provide 25% of the money. Individual Arabs will be asked to give a day's pay towards the rest.

Although it is not clear how the $800m protection fund for Jerusalem will be spent, it can be seen as a challenge to those who claim the city as Israel's eternal and undivided capital.

The attitude of the Saudis, who received a pre-summit visit from Madeline Albright, the secretary of state, is likely to worry the US. At the summit, Crown Prince Abdullah openly blamed it for the collapse of the peace process.

Accusing the US of neglecting its responsibilities as sponsor of the peace process, he said: "We anticipated, after the positive stand of the Arab side, that the Israeli side would be chastised or at least blamed for its unacceptable conduct."

Other measures agreed by the summit provide the basis for a continuing diplomatic offensive in the UN, which, if pursued, could put the US on the spot. These include:

A call for an international investigation into the causes of the recent conflict which, in effect, rejects the inquiry announced by President Bill Clinton at the Sharm al-Sheikh summit last week;

A call for the UN secretary general to provide international forces to protect the Palestinian people;

A call for an international tribunal to try alleged Israeli war criminals.

Besides pleasing Arab public opinion, the moves seem aimed at driving a wedge between Israel and Washington by pressurising the US to moderate its support for Israel.

At a press conference after the summit, the Egyptian foreign minister, Amr Mousa, warned: "We mean business. All Arabs, left, right and centre, are angry. We cannot accept the current policy followed by Israel."

But the summit rejected moves to sever all Arab-Israeli links built since the start of the peace process. Egypt had argued that maintaining communication was vital. Instead, the 21 leaders decided to halt further development of relations with Israel.

The compromise avoided a rift with Egypt, Jordan and Mauritania, which have full diplomatic relations with Israel. A handful of other Arab states, including Oman and Qatar, have low-level ties, but both froze steps towards normalisation three years ago.

Last week, Oman closed its office in Tel Aviv in protest at the violence. Morocco recently downgraded its relations and Tunisia said it had shut both its liaison office in Tel Aviv and Israel's liaison office in Tunis.

Libya had argued that cutting all ties was the least Arabs could do, and its representative walked out of the summit.

The summit also decided to boycott multilateral talks on regional economic cooperation. Although the level of economic cooperation is small, Israel attaches political importance to it.

Other countries were warned against transferring their embassies to Jerusalem or recognising it as the capital of Israel. Mr Clinton has hinted several times that the US may soon move its embassy to Jerusalem.

While the summit was unified in blaming Israel for the violence, moderates cautioned against doing anything that might make future negotiations difficult.

A prominent Palestinian spokeswoman, Hanan Ashrawi, said the declaration was "a whimper that fell well short of Palestinian expectations".

webTitle: Hawk's return symbolises end of hope

fields.headline: Hawk's return symbolises end of hope
fields.standfirst:
Barak: Beleaguered PM forced to bring Sharon back into fold

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: For days, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, complained that Yasser Arafat was no fit partner for peace. Yesterday, he made it clear who he wants by his side for that dance into the   great unknown: the hawkish Likud party leader, Ariel Sharon.
fields.body:
For days, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, complained that Yasser Arafat was no fit partner for peace. Yesterday, he made it clear who he wants by his side for that dance into the great unknown: the hawkish Likud party leader, Ariel Sharon.

Mr Barak's announcement yesterday that he was suspending the peace process had been anticipated in the Israeli press, which has charted the former army chief's journey from warrior to peacemaker to social reformer and now, perhaps, back to warrior.

After dithering for days, he is believed to have taken the fateful decision on the basis of reports from Israel's intelligence community and the CIA that Mr Arafat may be preparing to declare a Palestinian state without first gaining Israel's assent. The angry denunciation of the Arab summit's rather restrained declaration yesterday was a handy pretext.

"Barak's announcement has one central meaning. It opens the door for Sharon to join a national emergency government," said Simon Shiffer, a commentator in Israel's biggest-selling newspaper, Yediot Ahronot. For the Palestinians, and for Washington, there could hardly be a more depressing decision from the man who only short months ago went farther than any other Israeli leader in the search for peace.

Last May, a defiant Mr Barak ordered Israel to retreat from south Lebanon, despite fears that a unilateral withdrawal would leave northern villages dangerously vulnerable to Lebanese-based Hizbullah guerrillas.

At the Camp David summit last July, Mr Barak shattered powerful taboos by offering Mr Arafat control over far-flung suburbs of Arab East Jerusalem, occupied by Israel since 1967.

The offer fell far short of what Mr Arafat could accept, and the last weeks have written in blood the Palestinian attachment to the holy places of Jerusalem.

While the peace process faltered, Mr Barak plodded ahead, promising: "I will leave no stone unturned for peace." But the collapse of his coalition, and the failure of two US-mediated ceasefires to end the violence, finally led Mr Barak to the man seen by Palestinians as the most fearsome opponent of peace.

Reviled throughout the Arab world for his role in the massacre of Palestinian refugees in Lebanon nearly two decades ago, Mr Sharon is seen as a symbol of opposition to the principle Mr Barak pursued of trading land for peace.

It was Mr Sharon's provocative visit to the Haram al-Sharif on September 28 that ignited weeks of bloody mayhem that have left 120 dead.

Still, Mr Barak has been wooing Mr Sharon to join a national emergency government. The Likud leader admitted yesterday that he would enlist if Mr Barak abandoned seven years of peacemaking.

Instead of a settlement with the Palestinians that would lead to a state, Mr Sharon told Israel Radio he supported talks towards "a long-term interim agreement that will keep strategic points in our hands". That is a rejection of the concessions Mr Barak offered at Camp David.

Mr Barak's change of heart is the product of hard logic. With his popular support sinking to an all-time low, and rumbles of rebellion against his leadership within the Labour party, the prime minister has few remaining options.

fields.headline: Greedy and incompetent men
fields.standfirst:
I don't quite see Gerald Corbett as a saint and a martyr

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: The contempt in which I hold the greedy and incompetent men who run benighted Railtrack was not reduced by Gerald Corbett's offer to resign. No doubt it was meant sincerely. But who can doubt that it will be cynically exploited in the hope of improving the putrefying image of a company which ought not to exist.
fields.body:
The contempt in which I hold the greedy and incompetent men who run benighted Railtrack was not reduced by Gerald Corbett's offer to resign. No doubt it was meant sincerely. But who can doubt that it will be cynically exploited in the hope of improving the putrefying image of a company which ought not to exist. It is easy enough to predict what the apologists for the next disaster will say. Not concerned with safety? Was not the anguished chief executive prepared to sacrifice his astronomical salary as an act of contrition and proof of repentance for the Hatfield tragedy? And did he then not agree, despite his vicarious trauma, to accept the judgment of colleagues that only he could create a rail network which was fit for heroes to travel on? Railtrack, run by a saint and martyr, will become beyond reproach.

The piety will, however, be Augustinian. Oh Lord, make the railways safe - but not yet. Weaknesses on the section of the line on which the Hatfield crash happened were identified at the turn of the year. Work of a sort began eight months later. The track, inspected on October 10 and found "safe" was, according to Railtrack's immediate admission, "one of the factors" which led to another four railway deaths. Then the notion of admitting culpability was hit upon as the best way to ingratiate Railtrack with the public. If the top man had taken responsibility for that deplorable sequence of events, the notion that safety was the operator's first priority might have sounded almost plausible. But it would not have been true. Railtrack's first priority is profit.

I am reminded of Railtrack's reason for existence every Monday morning as I stand amongst the bricks and rubble waiting for the nine forty from Chesterfield to London. A year ago Chesterfield was a slightly dilapidated but entirely adequate station. It is now being transformed into what will look like a cross between a giant filling station and a television evangelist's chapel in one of the more vulgar suburbs of Dallas or Houston. The notices, which apologise for any inconvenience caused, ends with the announcement that the new development will include numerous "retail opportunities". Railtrack can, it seems, raise capital to invest in commercial property. What a pity that they cannot, or do not, raise it to accelerate the (admittedly less remunerative) safety programme.

It would be easy to suggest that there is an innate, but obvious, immorality in Railtrack's choice of priorities - easy but wrong. As Frederick Von Hayek - the real patron saint of rail privatisation - is the first to insist, private enterprise is amoral. It operates according to rules which have nothing to do with ethics or social justice. It is there to make a profit and, as a by-product of that process, guarantee the efficiency that competition and the free market bring to the economy. That was the theory on which the privatisation of British Rail was based.

There was a flaw in the Tory government's logic. The benefits of competition have not come to the railways because privatisation created a series of private monopolies. Competition requires consumers to be offered a choice. If I want to travel by rail to Chesterfield, my choice is limited to going by Midland main line or going somewhere else. I cannot believe that many customers (as passengers are now called) say to themselves, "I was going to York by Great North Eastern but Virgin give free drinks to first class ticket holders so I shall go to Manchester instead". Competition was only possible on the railways when rival companies offered alternative services to the same destination. Now all we have is a bonanza - profit without the pressure to improve what the market provides.

In the days of real rail competition my parents could travel to London from either Sheffield Victoria or Sheffield Midland station and the rails over which they were carried would have been particular to the railway company of their choice. Not even John Redwood - who wanted competition in water supply and in consequence a double or treble set of taps in every bathroom - suggests we duplicate track. So Railtrack remains a monopoly. There was no more justification for privatising BR than there would be for selling off the motorways.

The argument against correcting the crass economic mistake is the cost of renationalisation. So the government will have no choice but to increase Railtrack's value by providing extra funds to meet improved safety's bills. Either that or more customers will die. The moral blackmail is irresistible. But the absurdity of using public money to subsidise the private railway's profits was one of the reasons why the companies were nationalised in 1948. The government could impose such stringent safety regulations on the industry that the profits would fall, the value be reduced and the possibility of a cheap buy back increase. That would be a highly disreputable way to behave. But the directors of Railtrack would understand.

webTitle: Analysis: The Commons needs radical reform

fields.headline: Lost in the past
fields.standfirst:
The Commons will elect a new Speaker today. But there must be radical reform if the chamber is not to become an irrelevant curiosity
Special report: who will be the new Speaker?
fields.trailText: MPs return from their summer break today to elect a new Speaker for the Commons. But what exactly are they returning to? The Commons is closer to a museum than a serious, topical debating chamber in which the government comes under proper scrutiny. So much so that the most contentious division in the campaign for Speaker was whether he or she should wear a wig.
fields.body:
MPs return from their summer break today to elect a new Speaker for the Commons. But what exactly are they returning to? The Commons is closer to a museum than a serious, topical debating chamber in which the government comes under proper scrutiny. So much so that the most contentious division in the campaign for Speaker was whether he or she should wear a wig.

The selection of the Speaker is indicative of the wider problem facing parliament. Media interest has not focused on the relative merits of the candidates to succeed Betty Boothroyd or the importance of the job itself, but the absurdity of the election process. Parliament has a curiosity value, but little else. It is governed by arcane procedures which few understand and, for most people, it neither looks nor sounds relevant. The half-hearted attempts to recall parliament during the fuel crisis merely highlighted the fact that the chamber is no longer the principal forum for political debate, no longer the "cockpit of the nation".

If parliament is to restore its relevance, it must change. And it is the Commons' chamber - the public face of the house - that is in most need of overhaul.

The fundamental problem is that the chamber meets too often for too long. Whereas a hundred years ago all of parliament's work revolved around the chamber, there are now numerous other outlets for MP activity. MPs are expected be in the standing committees examining legislation, the select committees which do the detailed work of scrutinising government departments or pursuing constituents' concerns. Yet the chamber continues to meet in almost permanent plenary. The resulting low attendance means rows of empty green benches for most debates, which simply emphasises their unimportance.

The chamber should meet less frequently, perhaps one less day each week, which would be set aside for committee work. Opposition parties may object that reducing time in the chamber would limit their already meagre opportunities to scrutinise government activity. However, this assumes that effective scrutiny requires long hours. Patently it does not.

There is no other profession where one would discuss something for six hours and expect the issues to be clearer at the end of that debate than they were at the beginning. Yet this is the principal means the opposition has for holding government to account. Unsurprisingly, the results of such debates are often inconclusive, even for the few who bother to attend, and they very rarely succeed in reaching an audience beyond the walls of Westminster.

Far better surely to have a series of shorter, sharper sessions with ministers. The opposition could trade some debating time for the opportunity to call a minister before the house to answer questions on a topical issue of their choice. These short question and answer sessions would do far more to achieve accountability than the current procession of 20-minute speeches to an empty chamber.

It would mean that more MPs got the chance to quiz ministers and make a meaningful contribution to parliamentary scrutiny. And, at a basic level, the attraction for many MPs would be the promise of a wider audience - a fuller chamber in parliament and greater likelihood of media coverage outside.

It would also make the Commons look more responsive to public concerns. Too much time is spent debating issues of little importance, while the bigger issues are often missed. At the beginning of this year, the two hottest issues were the extradition of General Pinochet and the admission of Mike Tyson - both Home Office matters. Yet the existing notice period for questions meant that neither was tabled for Jack Straw's appearance before the House in January. Similarly, last year's problems at the Passport Agency were raised as early as February, but parliament did not properly debate them until the end of June, by which time the situation had reached crisis point.

With that sort of reaction time it is not surprising that parliament rarely sets the day's news agenda or leads the evening television bulletins. Even where there are important and topical matters being discussed, parliament's sitting hours actively work against media coverage. Evening debates not only miss broadcast deadlines, but often the next day's papers. This is a problem for parliament, not the media. Politicians now simply announce initiatives outside parliament, communicating more directly to a bigger audience.

The chamber needs new hours, starting in the morning and finishing early in the evening, with the most important statements at 10.30am. This would not stop ministers trailing their policies on the Today programme, but it would make parliament the focus for the debate. Reforms designed to improve the public perception of the house are pointless if no one outside is watching.

In her parting comments, Betty Boothroyd lamented the low public opinion of parliament, but described the chamber as "the chief forum of the nation - today, tomorrow and, I hope, for ever". If those wishes are to be met, her successor must preside over a period of radical reform.

 Greg Power is secretary to the Hansard Society Commission on Parliamentary Scrutiny. He is the author of Creating a Working Parliament, published today by the Hansard Society

G.Power@hansard.lse.ac.uk

fields.headline: Economics made easy
fields.standfirst: What is stagflation?
fields.trailText: It is an economic policymaker's worst nightmare: a combination of rampant inflation, falling output and high unemployment.
fields.body:
It is an economic policymaker's worst nightmare: a combination of rampant inflation, falling output and high unemployment.

Stagflation last stalked the headlines in the 1970s, when two successive oil price rises sent inflation spiralling while choking off growth in the west.

It destroyed the assumption of some economic policymakers at the time that there was a trade-off between unemployment and inflation and that higher inflation allowed lower unemployment. The trebling of oil prices over the last 18 months to levels not seen since the Gulf war has led some to wonder if we could be in for a re-run of the 1970s - not just on the catwalks but in the economy.

Any signs of its return?

There are no signs as yet in Britain where inflation is the lowest of any European Union country. Although headline inflation has been pushed up by higher petrol prices, the Bank of England has said that unless this spills over into price increases in the rest of the economy, it will not react.

However, the 11 members of the eurozone are in more trouble: inflation is at 2.8%, which is well above the 2% ceiling which the European Central Bank has set itself as its inflation target.

But policymakers are reluctant to raise interest rates because there are signs that the French and German economies, the motors of the eurozone, are slowing down.

In the US, inflation is above 3.5%, but the Federal Reserve is in a dilemma, partly because of the impending US election, but also because American companies are starting to issue profits warnings which are having an unsettling effect on the markets. A rise in interest rates could cause the US stock markets to tumble.

What should they do?

Stagflation poses a real dilemma for policymakers: do they cut rates to stimulate the economy or raise them to tackle the threat of inflation. Last time, the countries which survived the oil price rise the best were the ones which did least to accommodate it by lowering interest rates: Germany for example.

However, some people argue that things are different this time; there are fewer signs that rising energy prices are spilling over into other areas of the economy.

For example, wage inflation is subdued by historical standards, suggesting fewer dangers of an inflationary wage price spiral.

Central bankers may be able to negotiate their way through the minefield this time, better than they did the last, but it will take some careful navigating.

webTitle: Harold Evans: White House for sale

fields.headline: White House for sale
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Here is a political mystery worthy of Sherlock Holmes at his best. Why was Al Gore found in the library on Saturday with a dagger in his back?
fields.body:
Here is a political mystery worthy of Sherlock Holmes at his best. Why was Al Gore found in the library on Saturday with a dagger in his back?

An average of four polls taken after Tuesday's debate showed him a possibly mortal four points behind Bush. But pretty well everybody, including the Bushites, agrees that in the crucial debate in the "show-me" state of Missouri, Gore did a much better job on the issues than Bush. Gore showed that he had mastered the details of his budget - and also that he had a better grasp of the cost of Bush's proposals than Bush himself. Bush explained to Reuters his idea of what budgeting is all about: "It's clearly a budget," he said, "it's got a lot of numbers in it."

A debate question that should have been a home run for Bush, every bit as decisive as David Justice the same evening hitting a home run for the Yankees, was from a 30ish woman who wanted to know how the rival tax policies would affect her. Bush told her we needed a stronger military. Come again? Well, somewhere in an irrelevant rambling answer there was a vague reference to his plan to cut taxes across the board, but the bewilderment of the woman was shared by everyone. A little later he stumbled into the realisation that his partial privatisation of social security would take $1 trillion from future retirees, a key voting constituency.

The spear carriers in the press for Bush agree that he does not have the right answers, but now say that doesn't matter. The play is that Bush is really that older governor from California and people love him for his cozy woolliness just as they loved Reagan. It's a switch sale. It is true Bush still scores higher on likeability, but that is not enough to explain the contradiction between voting intentions and judgments on brainpower and policies. American voters may not be the most attentive in the world, but they also kick the tyres when offered a "great deal" at the used car lot.

So why did Gallup/CNN/USA Today, for instance, give Bush a 10-point lead in voting intention, but report that most of these same people scored Gore 6% ahead of Bush on policies and nine points ahead on clarity of expression? The clue to the mystery, as in the Hound of the Baskervilles, is the dog we don't hear barking. Nobody at the national level has an ear to something that is happening in millions of homes across this vast country. It's this: when families sit down in front of the television, they are assailed and wooed night after night, hour after hour, by the most momentous political advertising campaign in history. So far Bush has spent $120m and Gore only $60m. "Only!"

This advertising blitz, from the richer party, with more support from business, makes a farce of elective democracy, but it is only a Republican revenge for what the Democrats did to them in 1996 when Bill Clinton routed Bob Dole to win a second term. Nobody noticed in the early summer of 1996 that the Democrats were spending advertising millions unconventionally early. The Clinton campaign kept the scale of their spending secret. They concentrated the investment outside the media capitals of New York and Los Angeles. Neither the press or the Republican party caught on until it was too late.

The scale of the Bush advertising campaign is one thing. The other is the cleverness of its disinformation. Ordinary people watching may well believe that the Gore they saw is really "Gore-gantuan" who secretly has plans to raise federal spending more than any president since Johnson's Great Society. They are being misled. As a percentage of national income, the only meaningful standard, Gore promises to reduce federal spending. Another scare ad says he will spend three times as much as Clinton envisaged in 1992. Again, it is not true.

webTitle: A bit of networking goes a long way

fields.headline: A bit of networking goes a long way
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sometimes we become so engrossed in the day-to-day operation of our business that it's difficult to take a step back. We find that attending conferences helps us to do this and also helps us keep up with developments in the internet world.
fields.body:
Sometimes we become so engrossed in the day-to-day operation of our business that it's difficult to take a step back. We find that attending conferences helps us to do this and also helps us keep up with developments in the internet world.

We've found that the most valuable of these are the networking evenings organised by our investors.

One event we attended was in Paris on the day we completed our first funding round. Because signing on the dotted line took longer that day than expected we missed the business end of the event and arrived just as dinner was being served. That suited us; after the stress of fundraising we were in the mood to celebrate.

Last week we swapped Paris for a hotel in the City of London. More convenient and more like real work. The venture capital firm had invited along all the UK-based companies belonging to the group, made up of a diverse selection of businesses all linked by new technology. Following a short presentation we settled down to the real business of the evening, which was meeting other members of the group. It worked well. We came away with some great contacts.

Just as interesting was the opportunity to talk to entrepreneurs whose businesses are more advanced than ours. We are preparing to launch our service, but most of the companies in attendance have already done so. They've overcome the technology hurdles. "Everything takes longer than you think," said one. They've also gone through more tricky funding rounds. And they've also learnt sometimes painful lessons about marketing. "We don't spend anything on online marketing anymore - everything we've invested in this area before was wasted."

The nature of internet businesses is definitely evolving. Judging by the number of suits in attendance last week, dotcom businesses run by casually dressed twentysomethings are much rarer than they used to be.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the founders of rools, a new service that enables teenagers to buy online without a credit card

fields.headline: From no-go to go-go area
fields.standfirst: Investment sage aims to show the chancellor how to unleash entrepreneurial talents imprisoned within city walls
fields.trailText: Investment sage aims to show the chancellor how to unleash entrepreneurial talents imprisoned within city walls, writes Mark Atkinson.
fields.body:
Ronald Cohen has a track record of picking winners. Co-founder and executive chairman of Apax Partners, the European venture capital company which manages about £4bn on behalf of institutional investors, he has been responsible for financing some of the biggest hi-tech business success stories of recent years. These include the British company Autonomy, which developed the software that fuels many of the search engines on the net, and PPL Therapeutics, the firm behind Dolly the cloned sheep.

Now he is turning his talents to the tricky task of unlocking the entrepreneurial talent imprisoned in Britain's inner cities, for years regarded by many financiers as no-go areas.

After a nine-month investigation into the problems of starting and growing a business in some of the most deprived areas of the country, Mr Cohen tomorrow publishes his recommendations. They will form the basis of proposals on urban enterprise to be announced by Gordon Brown in his pre-Budget report, now expected on November 8.

Chief among Mr Cohen's recommendations is expected to be a new tax break to encourage investors to put money into places they have traditionally avoided because they are considered too risky or offer inadequate returns. It is likely to be modelled on the US president's new markets tax credit under which investors in eligible funds receive a tax credit worth more than 30% of the amount invested.

Eligible funds include community development banks and other community development financial institutions, venture capital funds and for-profit subsidiaries of community development corporations.

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Cohen said the report would come up with proposals about the sort of government incentives needed to replicate America's success in revitalising depressed urban communities. "America started earlier in tackling this problem because it had a bigger problem to start with and in a sense the US system is cobbled together through trial and error," Mr Cohen said. "But there's a lot the UK can learn."

Mr Cohen's recommendations have been developed by the Social Investment Taskforce, which he chairs. Set up in February, the taskforce is independently managed by the UK Social Investment Forum in partnership with the New Economics Foundation and the Development Trusts Association. The Treasury has an observer role.

Ed Mayo, head of the New Economics Foundation, said: "The inner cities are perceived as no-go areas for business and investment and that can often become a self-fulfilling prophecy."

Mr Cohen is in no doubt that there is a huge amount of untapped talent in Britain's inner cities. After visiting up to 50 enterprises around the country, he said: "The first thing you come away with is the sense that these individuals could have been successful in any other walk of life."

He cites Questions Publishing, a software company in Birmingham set up by Howard Sharon, a former Sunday Times journalist; David Robinson's Community Links in London, an organisation which is trying to develop commercial activities to fund community projects; and KMP Turnkey, a small manufacturer of sports car accessories in Birmingham. To highlight the opportunities, the NEF plans to publish a regional survey of the fastest growing firms in deprived areas.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Times
fields.body:
Sunday Times

Talks have begun between British Airways, Air France and Delta Airlines to form a new alliance, which could result in the break-up of BA's existing Oneworld partnership. BA may switch allegiance from American Airlines, with which it started Oneworld, to Air France and Delta's Skyteam collaboration.

Private equity groups Cinven and BC Partners are frontrunners to buy Burmah Castrol's chemicals businesses from BP Amoco for up to £800m. BP paid £3bn for Burmah earlier this year for its lubricants division, and put the rest up for sale.

South African group Logical Holdings has pulled its proposed £1.5bn London listing just weeks before it was due to float. It blames volatile market conditions.

Sunday Telegraph

Sir Christopher Lewinton, chairman of TI, has reportedly succumbed to shareholder pressure and agreed to halve his multi-million payoff following the group's merger with Smiths Industries. Lewinton has also ruled himself out of the running to become the next chairman of advertising group WPP, and advertising executives now say it is "highly unlikely" he will take up the post.

Lasmo is expected to sell North Sea assets and interests in Algeria and Venezuela, in an effort to bolster its flagging share price. The company has been under pressure from shareholders who are frustrated that the company's shares have failed to reflect the buoyant oil price.

Coral has abandoned plans for a £1bn stock market flotation for the foreseeable future. The company is said to believe its internet business needs more development, and it is concerned about the uncertain state of the stock market.

Mail on Sunday

Camelot will this week announce plans for a Europe-wide lottery to strengthen its campaign to continue running Britain's national draw.

Its plans for a European lottery were rejected by the lottery commission last month. But now Camelot has been told by lawyers there are no obstacles to the scheme under British and European law.

British Airways has held talks with Tony Blair, seeking government support to revive its plans for an alliance with American Airlines.

Sunday Express

Unilever faces a battle with a 68-year-old grandmother, who claims its Bestfood business stole the name Skippy for its products from a cartoon character created by her father.

Observer

Alchemy, the venture capital group which lost out in the battle to buy Rover cars, is considering a £1.5bn bid for Whitbread's 3,000 pubs. Alchemy is keen to emulate the success in the pubs sector enjoyed by City rival Nomura.

Last year Alchemy joined Nomura to make a last-ditch bid for Allied Domecq's pub estate, which eventually went to entrepreneur Hugh Osmond's Punch Taverns.

BT is looking at a multi-billion pound sale of its interests in Asia and the Far East as a way of raising cash to offset its debts.

Sunday Business

Train companies are to be given millions of pounds of taxpayers' money to compensate for the loss of revenue during safety work.

The payments are being discussed by deputy prime minister John Prescott, shadow strategic rail authority chairman Sir Alastair Morton and Tom Winsor, the rail regulator.

US aerospace group BF Goodrich is considering a £1.8bn bid for TI to counter the merger of TI with Smiths Industries. KKR, the American private equity house is also eyeing the situation, according to investment bankers.

BT may sell its 25% stake in Cegetel, the French telephone company, and its 49% holding in Spanish group Airtel for close to £9bn.

IoS

Stock Exchange chairman Don Cruickshank will next month face another grilling from MPs anxious for an explanation of the failed merger with Deutsche Börse, once the fate of the hostile bid from Sweden's OM Gruppen is determined.

Five months ago Cruickshank and then chief executive Gavin Casey faced a tirade from MPs.

UK Non-EU trade (Sep).

webTitle: CBI urges Brown to aid industry, not motorists

fields.headline: CBI urges Brown to aid industry, not motorists
fields.trailText: Industry leaders will today call on Gordon Brown to deliver a £3bn tax cut for business in his autumn Budget statement, to offset rising business costs.
fields.body:
Industry leaders will today call on Gordon Brown to deliver a £3bn tax cut for business in his autumn Budget statement, to offset rising business costs.

Mr Brown is already under pressure to offer concessions to pensioners and motorists in the pre-Budget report, which is now expected to be delivered on November 8, just ahead of the deadline set by fuel protesters.

The Confederation of British Industry says today that the tax burden on business has gone up by £5bn this year alone and that any tax breaks must be targeted at firms, not motorists. The CBI says the chancellor has little room to manoeuvre either on tax cuts or spending increases.

"The top priority must be rolling back the hike in business taxation since 1997," says Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economic adviser. "We are concerned about low levels of planned company investment."

Meanwhile, independent forecasters warn that interest rates could rise as high as 7% next year if Mr Brown announces a package of pre-election giveaways in the draft budget. Cuts in petrol duty, income tax and an above-inflation rise for pensioners could add about £5bn to household purchasing power, according to the Centre for Economics and Business Research.

"The result of the chancellor's largesse will be interest rates significantly higher than they would have been otherwise," said Douglas McWilliams of the CEBR.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: BA wants to stay supersonic
fields.body:
BA wants to stay supersonic

British Airways is reportedly encouraging aircraft manufacturers to develop a long-term replacement for Concorde even if the supersonic airliner does return to service next year. It is thought BA has talked informally to Concorde manufacturers BAE Systems and European Aeronautic Space and Defence about a new version of the aircraft. Boeing, Dassault and Gulfstream are also seen as possible contenders.

Telematics on float track

Vehicle tracking specialist Global Telematics today reveals plans to raise about £60m through a flotation on the Alternative Investment Market in December. The flotation is expected to value Global Telematics, a 50/50 joint venture between Thomson-CSF and European Telecom, at £200m.

Carphone share lock-up ends

The controversial three-month lock-up period imposed on retail subscribers to Carphone Warehouse's flotation ends today. Many of the 10,300 people who bought shares under those terms are expected to sell because of the stock's steady slide from 200p at issue to 155p last Friday.
