webTitle: Chart success of Schröder CD raps up fortune for charity

fields.headline: Chart success of Schröder CD raps up fortune for charity
fields.trailText: Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, stands to receive at least half a million pounds thanks to his taste for beer and a new style of music which has been dubbed 'chancellor rap'.
fields.body:
Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, stands to receive at least half a million pounds thanks to his taste for beer and a new style of music which has been dubbed 'chancellor rap'.

A song based around a remark he made last summer has sold more than 360,000 copies, putting the head of the government and leader of the Social Democratic party at number two in the German charts, ahead of Britney Spears.

Copyright experts canvassed by the newspaper Bild am Sonntag estimated that Mr Schröder's first, and wholly unwitting, foray into pop had already entitled him to around DM1.5m (£500,000).

More royalties are on the way. The CD for which he unintentionally provided the lyrics has just been released in Austria and Switzerland.

The chancellor has said that he wants the proceeds to go to a children's helpline of which his wife, Doris Köpf, is a patron.

The unlikely story began last summer when Mr Schröder was touring eastern Germany. While signing autographs on a hot day, he barked at aides: "Get me a bottle of beer or I'm going on strike here".

The remark was picked up by journalists covering the tour and caught the fancy of a television comedian, Stefan Raab. He knitted the soundbite into a CD with a techno backing track, which was released last month.

The song, called Get Me A Bottle Of Beer, was also down loaded from the internet more than 700,000 times in the first 10 days following its release.

A copyright lawyer quoted by Bild am Sonntag said the chancellor was entitled to royalties not only as the performer and lyricist but also as the composer, since the rhythm of his staccato command dictates the beat of the song.

In addition, he is likely to receive money from the playing of the song on radio programmes and its inclusion on an album.

Earlier this year, Raab won notoriety with a Eurovision song contest entry in German baby language. It was entitled Wadde, Hadde, Dudde, Da or What Have You Got There?
fields.bodyText: Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, stands to receive at least half a million pounds thanks to his taste for beer and a new style of music which has been dubbed 'chancellor rap'. A song based around a remark he made last summer has sold more than 360,000 copies, putting the head of the government and leader of the Social Democratic party at number two in the German charts, ahead of Britney Spears. Copyright experts canvassed by the newspaper Bild am Sonntag estimated that Mr Schröder's first, and wholly unwitting, foray into pop had already entitled him to around DM1.5m (£500,000). More royalties are on the way. The CD for which he unintentionally provided the lyrics has just been released in Austria and Switzerland. The chancellor has said that he wants the proceeds to go to a children's helpline of which his wife, Doris Köpf, is a patron. The unlikely story began last summer when Mr Schröder was touring eastern Germany. While signing autographs on a hot day, he barked at aides: "Get me a bottle of beer or I'm going on strike here". The remark was picked up by journalists covering the tour and caught the fancy of a television comedian, Stefan Raab. He knitted the soundbite into a CD with a techno backing track, which was released last month. The song, called Get Me A Bottle Of Beer, was also down loaded from the internet more than 700,000 times in the first 10 days following its release. webTitle: Teacher who faked racist attack flees

fields.headline: Teacher who faked racist attack flees
fields.trailText: Italy's anti-racism campaigners have been left reeling by a teacher who faked an assault by neo-Nazis, writes Rory Carroll in Rome.
fields.body:
Italy's anti-racism campaigners have been left reeling by a teacher who faked an assault by neo-Nazis.

Luis Marsiglia, a Jewish convert to Catholicism, fled to South America yesterday after admitting he fabricated an attack which shocked the country and fuelled fears of swelling anti-semitism.

The centre-right opposition demanded an apology from those who accused it of fostering racism with xenophobic rhetoric.

Mr Marsiglia, who taught theology at Verona's elite Maffei secondary school, dominated the headlines last month after reporting that he had been ambushed by three youths wielding iron bars.

Cut and bruised, the Uruguay-born teacher had suggested that his assailants were pupils unleashed by colleagues.

He said: "The gang were shouting things in support of Jörg Haider. They screamed: 'You're a dirty Jew, get out of Verona'."

He added that a swastika had been painted on his door and showed investigators anti-semitic icons allegedly sent to him as part of a hate campaign.

The ruling centre-left coalition blamed the opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi for rising racism by making an issue of race and immigration.

"The centre right should examine its conscience," said Pierluigi Castagnetti, leader of the Italian Popular party.

Investigators exposed the deception at the weekend. Mr Marsiglia, 43, admitted beating his legs with a piece of wood and scratching his arms with an iron bar.

His lawyer, Guariente Guarienti, said the teacher was distraught at the prospect of losing his job after failing to provide evidence of his qualifications.

webTitle: Theatre production: experts recreate Rome's hidden wonder

fields.headline: Theatre production: experts recreate Rome's hidden wonder
fields.trailText: Ancient Rome's first and greatest theatre, considered lost forever, has been rebuilt, albeit virtually, to reveal a wonder of the empire.
fields.body:
Ancient Rome's first and greatest theatre, considered lost forever, has been rebuilt, albeit virtually, to reveal a wonder of the empire.

A British-led team of archaeologists has recreated the vast auditorium of the Pompey theatre, which stood for centuries as the prototype for all arenas.

Special effects on a stage the size of a football pitch were paid for by emperors keen to court popularity and crowd control methods were invented to stop the 20,000 spectators turning into a mob.

Buried beneath some of Rome's most beautiful palaces and squares, the Pompey theatre could not be excavated without destroying swathes of the city centre and generations of archaeologists were forced to abandon the site despite its fame.

Descriptions by the ancient historian Pliny of a gigantic structure were dismissed as gross exaggerations. But a two-year study, involving aerial photography, cellar inspections, the sifting of archives, mathematical extrapolations and computers has partially vindicated Pliny.

A team led by Richard Beacham, of the University of Warwick, and James Packer, of Northwestern University, Illinois, has built a three-dimensional model using computers.

The British Arts and Humanities Research Board funded much of the work.

Inaugurated in 55BC by the triumphant general Pompey, more than a century before the Colosseum, the building was Rome's first permanent and largest theatre, with an auditorium almost 152 metres in diameter, and a three-storey facade.

The theatre, intended to revive the general's waning popularity, was an integrated leisure complex with enclosed colonnades, galleries and gardens.

It was the first major example of the imperial style of architecture in Rome, said Prof Beacham. He added: "It influenced many subsequent buildings, not just theatres.

"Throughout its history it was one of the great showplaces of the city as well as the venue for many of its most momentous events."

Emperors used it to bolster their rule by staging spectacles. Seating replicated class divisions: the emperor and senators at the front, aristocrats and generals in the next 14 rows, then officials, priests, vestal virgins and citizens.

Foreigners, slaves and women were allowed to watch from the back.

"It was a microcosm of Roman society. All the stratas were laid out before you," said Prof Beacham.

Riot fears led to an elaborate ticketing system, believed to be the first of its kind, which allocated each person a particular tier, row, seat and exit.

Among those who appeared on stage was Nero, playing the lead in Oedipus and the Madness of Hercules, his opera about Troy.

By the 6th century AD, the theatre had decayed, but Cassiodorus, the Roman chancellor to King Theodoric, was still in awe: "One would have thought it more likely for mountains to subside, than this strong building be shaken."

By the 20th century, the theatre had disappeared into or beneath Rome's Campo dei Fiori, Largo Argentina and Campo Marzio.

Prof Beacham's team now hopes to perform "keyhole archaeology" by digging to the foundations via a restaurant doorway.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 'Eta bomb' kills prison guard
fields.body:
'Eta bomb' kills prison guard

A prison officer died in a car bomb explosion in northern Spain yesterday, the latest of 16 killings this year blamed on the Basque separatist group Eta.

Maximo Casado Carrera, 44, was leaving home in the Basque capital Vitoria when the device exploded in his garage. He had been on his way to work at a jail where around 40 convicted members of Eta are housed, a prison official said.
Reuters, Madrid

Ugandan Ebola toll rises to 54

The death toll in the latest outbreak of Ebola fever in northern Uganda has risen to 54, and 10 new cases have been reported.

The ministry of health said three people had died in the past 24 hours. The new cases were identified around Gulu, 225 miles north of the capital, Kampala. A total of 149 people have fallen ill with the fever since the outbreak was confirmed on October 14.
AP, Kampala

Guerrillas held after Iran attack

Iranian intelligence ministry agents captured a group of armed opposition guerrillas in Tehran yesterday, a day after a rebel mortar attack in the capital.

The official Irna news agency quoted the ministry as saying the Mujahedin Khalq had planned to stage mortar attacks in poor and heavily populated areas of Tehran. The Iraq-based group, Iran's main armed opposition movement, said it had fired mortar rounds at the headquarters of the elite Republican Guards on Saturday night.
Reuters, Tehran

Tourists trapped in Rio cable car

About 40 people, most of them foreign tourists, spent more than an hour in a broken cable car suspended 500 metres above Rio de Janeiro's scenic bay.

The car stopped as it was taking the group to Sugar Loaf mountain, which gives panoramic views over the city. Firefighters managed to tow the car to a midway stopover point where the passengers escaped through a hatch.
Reuters, Rio de Janeiro

Persian queen found by police

A crowned mummy, possibly of a Persian queen, has been found by Pakistani police during a raid in the south-western town of Quetta. They said the mummy, estimated to be 2,500 years old, was found packed in a sealed box. It was heavily laden with jewellery, including a crown and a golden plate at her chest.
Reuters, Quetta

webTitle: Murder of a gentle priest baffles community

fields.headline: Murder of a gentle priest baffles community
fields.standfirst: As Leicester's Hindus prepare for Diwali, they mourn the killing of a respected religious leader and friend
fields.trailText: As Leicester's Hindus prepare for Diwali, they mourn the killing of a respected religious leader and friend, report Tania Branigan and Vikram Dodd.
fields.body:
This should have been the busiest week of Harish Purohit's hectic year. In the run-up to Diwali this Friday, the priest and president of Britain's Hindu Federation would usually be preparing for an onrush of worshippers seeking blessings.

But yesterday the scores of visitors calling in at the Shree Shakti Mandir temple in Leicester were there to mourn their friend and priest. Mr Purohit, a leading figure in the Hindu community and secretary of the National Association of Hindu Priests, had been murdered, in a brutal, mystifying attack.

The 42-year-old's body was discovered by his father and younger brother at an empty house on nearby Harrison Road. He had been stabbed 10 times in the neck, legs, back and lungs.

The house is owned by the Purohit family but is currently undergoing renovation. Mr Purohit is believed to have gone there on Thursday night, but the alarm was raised only on Friday morning when a neighbour spotted smoke seeping from the house.

The murderer or murderers appeared to have escaped through the first-floor bathroom window, after starting a fire to conceal the crime. A half burned sofa was jammed against the front door and the gas fire was turned on, but unlit.

The news has rocked the quiet neighbourhood of Belgrave in the north of Leicester. It's a model of multicultural Britain at its best. Hindus, Sikhs, Muslims and Christians live together happily in the neat, narrow brick terraces. The Carey Hall Baptist church and Shri Guru Ravidass Sikh temple lie within 500 metres of the Hindu temple.

No one can understand what prompted Mr Purohit's death. His family insist he had no enemies and the police refuse to speculate as to motives. His car was found yesterday on the other side of Leicester. His mobile phone is still missing.

Leicestershire police have not yet recovered the weapon used in the attack and have appealed to people in the area to check their gardens and bins.

"Diwali is just around the corner," said Mr Purohit's elder brother, Janardan, 46. "It's time to get everyone together and enjoy it. But this year it will leave us empty. The link in our family is broken and it can never be mended.

Mr Purohit's mother and father, Karunashanker, 83, and Madhukanta, 78, and his four sisters are closeted away with Mr Purohit's long-term girlfriend, a lawyer from Manchester, in the little house next to the temple. Janardan and his brother, Jai, 35, do their best to welcome mourners, but the dark shadows beneath their eyes and the endless cigarettes they light tell of their devastation.

"My parents feel like lightning has struck. We are all devastated. We have no idea at all what could have happened. He was such a warm, caring person. He honestly wouldn't hurt a fly. Even his tone of voice was soft. He had no aggression.

"That's what makes it so shocking. How could he have enemies? His popularity was so great among the community as a whole, not just the Hindus."

In the past few days the Purohits have received calls from friends of Harish in Australia, east Africa, the United States and across Europe. Like his parents, these mourners cannot understand who would harm a man who had devoted his life to others. As well as being a priest, Mr Purohit worked with people with learning disabilities.

His younger brother, Jai, said: "He fought for equal opportunities - for people with learning disabilities and for widows, who are often left behind in the Asian community. He brought them forward, saying they have the same rights to live life to the full."

Harish was born into a Brahmin family and was interested in the priesthood from childhood. His father, Karunashanker, is a priest who helped to found the Shree Shakti Mandir, one of the oldest temples in the city.

Mr Purohit adopted a more modern style than other priests. At weddings his style was more chatty, and he would take time to explain the meaning of different parts of the ceremony to non-Hindus and Hindus with a shaky grasp of the purpose of the ceremonies of their religion.

Keith Vaz, the MP for Leicester East, had known Mr Purohit for 15 years and had seen him last week at his constituency surgery where the priest had gone to talk about increasing the number of Hindus in the House of Lords.

Mr Vaz said: "He was very dynamic, not like your usual Hindu priest, with a big following, especially among young people.

"He was a different kind of priest, he was younger and less aloof.

"He had a particular following among the younger generation and his style was modern. I think he was a moderniser and tried to relate Hinduism to the needs of the community."

The family, which moved to Leicester from Kenya in 1968, always believed that religious devotion should be allied to a social conscience. The Purohit parents encouraged their children to help the weak and struggling; all of them would end up working for social services.

Even so, his brothers say that Harish took this sense of duty further than any of them.

"He fought for everyone who was weak and couldn't have their say," said Janardan. "He used his power to help them achieve their rights. He was there for anyone who had problems, not just Hindus. He was the community in himself."

Jai added: "All we can do now is have stone hearts and pray for justice. We know his time has finished here. Probably God needs him somewhere else, to look after humans in other parts of the world."

webTitle: The best overhearing scene: What Lies Beneath

fields.headline: The best overhearing scene: What Lies Beneath
fields.trailText: Night. Dr Norman Spencer (Harrison Ford) and his wife Claire (Michelle Pfeiffer) lie in bed the night after Claire's daughter Caitlin has left for college. Norman is ploughing through a series of textbooks. Claire picks up one of the books, and starts to leaf through it.
fields.body:
Night. Dr Norman Spencer (Harrison Ford) and his wife Claire (Michelle Pfeiffer) lie in bed the night after Claire's daughter Caitlin has left for college. Norman is ploughing through a series of textbooks. Claire picks up one of the books, and starts to leaf through it.

"Whatcha reading?" asks Norman.

Claire adopts a husky intonation.

"Genetic repair mechanisms in eukaryotic organisms."

"How is it?"

"Excellent. Couple of Swedish sailor cells just gang-divided a virginal cheerleader cell."

"Nice."

Claire snuggles up to him.

"If you have to work..."

"No, no. I'm just about..."

He puts his book down on the bedside table.

"There."

Norman turns to Claire.

"How are you?"

"Fine."

"It's okay if you're not."

"I am. Really..."

He kisses her.

"Tired?"

"Nope."

"Wanna fool around?"

"Yup."

They start to kiss. Suddenly, the sound of a woman wailing comes echoing through the window.

"Did you hear..."

"Shhh..."

It becomes obvious they are overhearing another couple in the throes of making love. The woman continues to moan. Norman strides over and closes the bedroom window.

"Jesus."

It doesn't do any good. The woman's moaning is almost impossibly loud. Claire's eyes widen.

"What is he doing to her?"

See also: Barton Fink, Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels

Don't see also: Jakob The Liar

Pointless trivia: Director Robert Zemeckis filmed What Lies Beneath during a hiatus on his Cast Away, caused by star Tom Hanks' need to lose weight.
